name: PAS: Bourton-on-the-Water Whiteshoots Hill, Cold Aston 593
comments: Two hoards of folles dated AD 307-318 found beneath a single layer of flat stones at site on Whiteshoots Hill on the Foss Way. One hoard consisted of 2749 coins, & retained shape of the cloth/leather bag in which it was deposited; the other disturbed but 600 scattered coins were recovered. A masonry wall W of, but not directly related to coin  hoard, extends E-W for at least 40m through an area containing other stone structures & a scatter of pottery, ironwork and bronzes.  Site of hoard discovered by Renfrew. Renfrew, C. 1980. Settlement area near Bourton Bridge, Bourton-on-the-Water. Glevensis 14: 23.

name: PAS: Chepstow area 598
comments: c.10,000 base silver nummi all of victoria dd avggq nn type (ad 341-8) (1,000 recorded)

name: PAS: Dereham 600
comments: 24 nummi to Magnentius. Addenda of 4 nummi to Magnentius. PATAR 2008, 545; NC 2010.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2008 T707Other PAS records associated with this hoard: NMS-D40697

name: PAS: Cirencester 601
comments: "This small hoard of Theodosian bronze coinsseems to be due to an old but hitherto undisclosed discovery in a gravel pit in Cirencester Park. The only details of discovery available are that 'they were in an earthenware pot, but the pot was smashed in little pieces and had been like it for a number of years. They were about 8 ft. down and about 6 ins. from the top of a gravel layer.'.The hoard consists of 214 pieces of bronze, all of 4 AE size or smaller, but this total includes quite a number of small pieces broken off 4 AE coins.Every coin is exceedingly worn.":AEValens 1Valentinian II 3House of Valentinian I 3Theodosius 2Maximus or Victor 1Arcadius 6"Theodosian" 44uncertain 154214(cl. to 4 AE size)(VICTORIA AVGGG)(cl. to 4 AE size)(SPES ROMANORVM)(VICTORIA AVGGG 3; uncertain 3)(SALVS REIPVBLICAE 12; VICTORIA AVGGG, one Victory, 3, two Victories, 29)The uncertain coins were almost certainly "Theodosian"."The absence of identifiable coins of Honorius in this case should be taken as fortuitous and due entirely to the number of illegible coins and the greater difficulty experienced in being certain of seeing in worn coins the letters of Honorius compared with those of Arcadius. The range of the hoard may, therefore, be taken as that normal for Theodosian hoards, but its condition shows it to be some of the last dregs of Roman currency in Britain. If any argument may be deduced from the wear of coins, in this case it may well be taken to indicate concealment up to as late as c. AD 450."B.H.St.J. O'Neil, in NC, 1952, 128f., types, mints214 coins in Gloucester City Museum and Art Gallery

name: PAS: Cirencester 602
comments: Robertson 2000, 374 no. 1529:""The 924 coins listed below are said to have been found as a hoard at Cirencester, but precise details of the find seem to be lacking."The coins were 3 ant., and 919 small AE:Ant. AEClaudius II (deified) 1Constantine I 1Constantine II, Caes. 2Constantius II, Caes. 3Constantinopolis 2Urbs Roma 2Helena 1Constantius II, or Constans, Aug. 1House of Constantine I 33Magnentius 1Julian II 1Valentinian I 1Valens 1Gratian 4Valentinian II 24House of Valentinian I 25Theodosius 19Magnus Maximus 2Flavius Victor 2Maximus or Victor 5Eugenius 1Arcadius 96Honorius 23"Theodosian" 340uncertain 2 3293 919(2 b. GLORIA EXERCITVS, 1 stand.)(4 b. FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman, 2 minims)(5 cut down)(SPES ROMANORVM)(b.)(12 minims, 1 semi-b.)Although the total no. of coins was given as 924, only 922 were listed."The unusually large proportion of illegible and only partly legible coins is due not only to their careless striking but mainly to their worn condition which suggests a somewhat prolonged continuance of the civic life of Corinium after the Roman evacuation."J.W.E. Pearce, in NC, 1929, 332-4, types, mints917 coins in Corinium Museum, CirencesterExamined, 1960 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Cirencester (Bathurst Coll.) 603
comments: Robertson 2000, 356-357 no. 1464:""Whilst rearranging the contents of the Corinium Museum for the Cirencester Urban District Council in October 1947, I [i.e. Lady Fox] found that one of the coarse pots contained a small packet of coins. The accession number B 1471 showed that the vessel was part of the late Lord Bathurst's collection, made up of Roman objects found in Cirencester in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. No special find-place was entered in the register, but the coins were there recorded as being in the pot. As both pot and coins were recognizable as late Roman types, it was presumed that the two constituted a hoard, and the coins were therefore sent to Mr. B.H. St.J. O'Neil for examination.The pot is a small squat vessel, with everted rim and a well-marked neck; it measures 4 in. high, 3 1/2 in. rim diameter, increasing to 4 in. on the body; about a third of the rim is missing. It is made of coarse dark grey clay, containing a good deal of pounded shell as 'backing'. The surface is black, except the neck which is grey in irregular patches, due probably to bad stacking in the kiln. The body of the pot has been lightly combed (with ?twigs) when still damp and on the wheel.The letter C has been incised and then pecked out on the shoulder..The Corinium pot is dated by its contents to the very end of the Roman period. I regard it as the sort of local product that is likely to have continued to be made in the ensuing Dark Ages."The coins were all small AE:AE.Constans, Aug. 1Constantius II, or Constans, Aug. 2Valentinian I (?) 1Theodosius I 1"Theodosian" 2uncertain 4th cent. (?) 31010(VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN)(FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman, "Galley")(SECVRITAS(?) REIPVBLICAE)(VICTORIA AVGGG, clipped)(SALVS REIPVBLICAE 1; VICTORIA AVGGG 1)One of the coins of Constantius II or Constans, Aug. is only a quarter of a coin, "having been cut off a whole coin in antiquity"."This collection of coins, having apparently been found in the pot, may be termed a hoard, although a very small one. Its composition resembles that of other Theodosian bronze hoards. The latest coins by their wear and clipping may have seen considerable use, but this should not be exaggerated, and the coins by themselves do not suggest that they were concealed after c. AD 450."Lady (Aileen) Fox and B.H. St.J. O'Neil, in Ant. J., XXIX (1949), 83f., types, mints, pl. IXa, photo. of potIt is possible that the hoard is incomplete.Examined, and pot drawn, 1960 (ASR)From the small size of the head on the coin of "Valentinian I", it seems likely that it was of Valentinian II."

name: PAS: Husthwaite 604
comments: Robertson 2000, 357 no. 1469:""Near Husthwaite a small hoard of coins was found in digging a trench for water-pipes to supply villages in the valley from Hood Hill. The coins were found underneath a thick slab of stone and resting on another stone, and had been buried in a bag, probably of leather; they were about 400 in number, 'small brass', and in very bad preservation. Mr. Nutley, of Dalton, was good enough to send me twenty-five to look at; these, as far as they were legible, dated from the reigns of Valens, Theodosius - that is, from the end of the fourth century."F. Haverfield, in Antiquary, XXXVIII (1902), 108"

name: PAS: Shefford 605
comments: "In the spring of this year, a farmer, ploughing in a field just beyond Shefford, in Bedfordshire, turned up several silver, potin and small brass coins, which were submitted to my inspection. They were nearly all of the same date, common and generally in bad condition; but three were in such good preservation that I considered a notice of them might not be unacceptable to your readers." The three coins were 1 quinarius, 1 ant. and 1 small AE:AR Ant. AEAllectus 1(Q.) 1Constans, Aug. 11 1 1J.Y. Akerman, in NJ, I (1837), 80, types

name: PAS: Appleford 608
comments: Robertson 2000, 303-305 no. 1261:""On 31 December 1954, during ploughing, a hoard of Roman coins was discovered between Sutton Courtenay and Appleford about 50 yards south of the road. Two pots of coarse grey ware had been buried side by side a short distance below the surface; their rims, broken away by the plough, were missing.Apart from a handful of earlier coins extending back to Gallienus, the great bulk of the hoard was made up of the issues of Constantine the Great and his sons from about AD 320-347. The latest coins were five examples of the FEL TEMP REPARATIO types of Constantius II and Constans, so that the hoard must have been buried within the few years before 350. Although the coins had been removed from their containers by the finder, it was evident from the metal stains that each pot had held different-sized coins. One had contained over 1,650 Constantinian issues minted from about 320-326. All except about 100 were from the mint of London and were in very fine condition with their silver coating often intact. Of the coins of London those of Constantine II Caesar far outnumber those of Constantine I or Crispus. Among the remaining coins nearly all the imperial mints (except Alexandria) were represented by occasional specimens.The second pot contained nearly 4,00 coins, of which the great majority were issued after 335; GLORIA EXERCITVS (one standard) and VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN far outnumber any other reverse type, and the great majority were struck at the mint of Trier. The very thin representation of types struck between 326 and 335 (GLORIA EXERCITVS (2 standards), VRBS ROMA, CONSTANTINOPOLIS) is remarkable.The owner, Mr. F.G. Napper of Didcot, has placed the hoard on loan at the Ashmolean Museum, where a full analysis is being prepared."(C.M. Kraay, in Oxon., XX (1955), 92f.)Later, Dr. Kraay's analysis of 5752 coins was made available to Dr. Cathy E. King. She combined this with a study of the imitations, and a large number of official coins from the hoard, which are now preserved in the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, and catalogued the coins according to mints.RBN, CXXIII (1977), 41-100, types, mints, some wts., tables, pls. I-III of coinsThe following is a list of the 5752 coins, rearranged according to emperors, etc.:Ant. AE IrregularGallienus (sole reign) 4Postumus 1Quintillus 1Tetricus I 1Aurelian 1Severina 1Carausius 3Allectus 4Galerius 3Constantius I (deified) 2Constantine I 339Constantine I (?) 9Constantine I (deified) 27 1Licinius I 10 1Licinius II 4Crispus 498Constantine II, Caes. 985 4Constantine II, Caes. (?) 41Constantius II, Caes. 111Constantius II, Caes. (?) 19Helena 4Fausta 7Constantinopolis 31 6Urbs Roma 39Constans, Caes. 45Constans, Caes. (?) 4Delmatius 16Delmatius (?) 1GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand. 13Helena (after AD 337) 145Theodora (after AD 337) 124Constantine II, Aug. 55Constantine II, Aug. (?) 17Constantius II, Aug. 731 9teConstantius II, Aug. (?) 57Constans, Aug. 2208 68Constans, Aug. (?) 49Constantine II,Constantius II, or 6 Constans, Aug. 6Constantius II, orConstans, Aug. 30 1816 5617 119(2 FEL TEMP REPARATIO, galley; phoenix)(55 GLORIA, 1 st.; 2 VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN)(2 FEL TEMP REPARATIO, phoenix)(39 GLORIA, 1 st.; 9 VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN; 1 SECVRITAS)(GLORIA, 1 st.)(1 VIRTVS AVGG NN; 29 VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN)(2 Victory; 2 GLORIA, 1 st.)(2 Const./U.R.; 4 U.R./Const.)(7 GLORIA, 1 st.; 1 FEL TEMP REPARATIO, galley; 1 brockage)(56 GLORIA, 1 st.; 11 VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN: 1 VICTORIA AVGG)(9 GLORIA, 1 st.; 9 VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN)D. Brown, in an Appendix to "A Roman Pewter Hoard from Appleford, Berks." (1968) in Oxon., XXXVIII (1973), 184-206, noted that the Appleford hoard of coins was found in 1954, "in Appleford Field at a point which must be about 200 yards north of the area of gravel working which produced the pewter", and described and illustrated the two pots (204-6, figs.):"The first pot (FIG. 10, A), is grey, quite pale in the break and hard, fired at a relatively high temperature. There is a cordon at the base of the neck; the mouth was probably curled over outwards till it was almost horizontal. The base and lower part of the body have been turned, the upper part of the body has been burnished and there is a rough band between them. There is also an unburnished decorative band flanked by grooves just above the belly of the pot.The second pot (FIG. 10, B) seems to be in much the same fabric though it is darker on the surface and darker in the break. Details of the neck are missing. The turned and burnished areas overlap - as they were presumably intended to do - leaving only the single unburnished band around the belly; this is embellished with a burnished wavy line.The general form of these vessels is best paralleled by a number of so-called handleless bottles from the Sandford kiln site (T. May, in Arch., LXXII (1921), 223-42), though the Sandford fabric is softer than these pieces. Hard, smooth-surfaced grey pottery like these two pieces is common in the region though not in dated contexts. Its use for containers for this coin hoard gives a firm date for its manufacture, in the second quarter of the 4th century."There followed a discussion whether pot A, containing the smaller, earlier part of the hoard was buried before the larger, later part, in pot B. If so, "this would be an example of banking by burying, the careful saver having taken careful note of the position of his first hoard so that he was able to relocate it and add to it twenty years later.And, from the way in which each hoard comes predominantly from a single mint, it looks as though he received his money en masse rather than by saving, perhaps as a gratuity, perhaps as pay.""

name: PAS: Aston Ingham (Addenda) 617
comments: 48 nummi to 335 (probably addenda to 1855 Aston Ingham hoard). PATAR 2007, 504; NC 2008, 29.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2007 T563Other PAS records associated with this hoard: PAS-70D823

name: PAS: Gloucester 622
comments: In 1966, during excavs at New Market Hall, Glouc. in masonry building, in colonia: "Hoard 1 scattered in trench AIX layer 22, horizon 13, (section AB, fig. 5)". 20 AE. M. Hassall & J. Rhodes 1974. Trans. Bristol & Glos. Arch. Soc. 93: 84f.

name: PAS: Gloucester 623
comments: In 1966, during excavations at New Market Hall, Gloucester, in masonry building, in colonia, "2 hypocaust pilae found in situ & others subsequently seen by Mr Garrod. In disturbed debris above destroyed remains of hypocaust, scattered hoard of 26 coins found ranging in date from Constantine II to Arcadius. Hoard 2 scattered in debris. Then a list of 101, not 26, AE. M. Hassall & J. Rhodes 1974. Trans. Bristol & Glos. Arch. Soc. 93: 17, 85.

name: PAS: Gloucester 624
comments: In 1966, during excavs at New Market Hall, Gloc: "A scattered hoard of 181 bronze coins ending with 29 of Arcadius and 12 of Honorius found among the roofing slates and charcoal and had probably been hidden in roof, falling when the building was burnt (hoard 3, pp. 85-6)." Scattered with late Roman group in trench BVIII layer 8, horizon 14. Hassall & J. Rhodes 1974. Trans. Bristol & Glos. Arch. Soc. 93: 30, 85f.

name: PAS: Springhead (Temple II) 628
comments: During excav. of Temple II. "The wings were filled with rubble, mainly red roofing tiles. Some from roof of main temple & had been scraped there by plough, but others from covering of wings themselves. A 'hoard' of coins & other small objects found lodged in one part of rubble in N wing, in one of crevices, protected by surrounding tiles. It may be that this remarkable collection was scoured off temple floor by plough & trapped among tiles, but also possible that many objects were deliberately buried, when the temple was partly ruined, in mid-4th C. There were many standard Springhead sherds of 4th C date & latest coin was dated AD 337-40. The hoard may well date to AD 350-60 when temple was possibly destroyed. W.S. Penn, W.S. Penn. 1962. Springhead: Temples II and V. Arch. Cant. 77: 110-32. Contents of hoard as were 23 coins, incl. rare coin of Carausius, a bronze stud; 3 small bronze rings; part of bronze bracelet; bronze plate with hole; small uninscribed bronze plaque with hole; bronze ligula; bronze lion's head; iron door hinge; three-legged candle holder (iron); T-shaped iron slide-key; bone pin; glass frag. with letter C; frag. of glass bowl; 6 tiny glass heads; broken flint blade; sherd of poppy-head beaker with graffito; many sherds of standard Springhead forms.

name: PAS: Ring Hill, Haresfield 629
comments: During 1828-1832 I had bought or found at Haresfield 40 Roman coins and had made an exact register of when, or where, they were found. In 1832, 14 coins were brought to me which had been found near the south gate. Thereupon I started with some friends and dug on the spot where the plough had turned up the coins. We found 6 more and also pieces of a broken pot with green rust sticking to them. Five years later, when I was abroad, the pot from which the three pieces had been broken was found on the same spot, containing between 2,000 and 3,000 3rd bronze coins. These coins with one exception are of the later Constantine type, and range from about 328 to 340."-J.D.T. Niblett, in Canon W. Bazeley, Proc. Cotteswold Nat. Field Club, 21 (1921-3), 141-50. Copy supplied by D. Sellwood. Mr Niblett, of Haresfield Court, was owner of the Iron Age hill fort on Haresfield Beacon.Burrow describes large camp enclosed by bank 18 feet high, on two sides, running from Beacon in west to the Bulwarks in east, enclosing area of c. 44 acres. In Aug 1837, vessel containing nearly 3000 Roman coins found near south gate. Bellows, J. 1893-1895. William Lucy and his friends of the Cotteswold Club, 5 & 30 years ago. Proc. of the Cotteswold Nat. Field Club 11: 188.

name: PAS: Bourton/Lower Slaughter, Great Chessells I 634
comments: Pastscape: Coins previously found at the Chessells site include hoard of about 1500 minimi discovered before 1881, possibly late 4th century in date. “The colour & richness of the soil, coins silver & bronze, & a crock containing the hoard of minimi found here…”. Royce, D. 1882-3. Trans Bristol & Glos. Arch. Soc. 7: 71-2.  O’Neill quotes from a notebook of Dr Moore: “Some 1500 minimi found in the Chestles at lower Slaughter in an earthen pot which contained also a silver coin of Valens & a 3rd brass of Decentius. John Meevin of this place…brought me 6 of these noumia found on Slaughter Farm enveloped in a substance resembling leather…. It is by no means impossible that they came from the Bourton Bridge villa site on Slaughter Farm.  O’Neill, B.H. St J. 1934. Trans Bristol & Glos. Arch. Soc. 56: 133-9.

name: PAS: Lydney Park 636
comments: During excav at Lydney, hoard found in 1929 in room XXXVIII of bath-building, deposited against broken edge of mosaic floor, which at time of deposition had reached advanced state of decay. The hoard found in a very restricted area; it occupied no more room than could be encompassed by two cupped hands. The soil round it noticeably dark & together with the small area, suggested that coins were dropped or deposited in a purse or covering, since perished. Subsequent to deposition of the hoard, the floor of the room repaired. Patches of poor, whitish cement inserted into cavities in the pavement to bring the floor to an even surface with broken edges of original mosaic. One such patch completely sealed the hoard, which was only discovered during careful removal of cement. The hoard consists of 1,646 coins, fragments of coins, & pieces of corroded bronze. Pastscape: Exacav. of context where corridor of bath building impinges on end wall of long building (Abaton) confirmed that the bath, which incorporates a hoard datable to c. 360, post-dated the long building. It was demonstrated that mosaics of long building, which sealed a coin of Gratian, are secondary, the original floors being flags or op sig. On present evidence the complex appears to date to the late 3rd or early 4th century.

name: PAS: Lydney Park 637
comments: During excav of temple site at Lydney "this hoard found in 1928 below flagged pavement in NE ambulatory. It consists, with three earlier exceptions, of 126 coins of Constantine I & successors. The lower limit of date for the deposit of the hoard cannot be determined with certainty from external evidence, since, at this point, the slab-paving beneath the level of which it was found was not in position. The slabs had subsided into soft earth containing the coins; but whether this should be taken to imply that the soft earth was already there when the slabs were laid (after AD 367) or whether it was due to subsequent burial of the coins beneath the slabs, it was impossible to determine. …the coins colouring was distinctive, & all found in a single square foot of earth whilst the adjacent soil was barren." Although total number of coins in hoard 126, only 116 listed.  "This hoard of greater interest. …it cannot be earlier than 364 (the earliest possible date for the Temple), and is unlikely to be earlier than 367 (the terminus post quem for the associated group of buildings). The internal evidence of the hoard itself might readily suggest a somewhat earlier date for its deposit." J.W.E. Pearce. 1932. Research Rep. Soc. Ant. 9: 112-15. Pastscape: The room of the temple in which coin hoard was discovered by Wheeler re-excav. in 1981 disclosing phase of flooring beneath that in which hoard was found. The excav. casts doubt on Wheeler's chronology for the site suggesting that majority of the buildings may date from the late 3rd or early 4th centuries, not late 4th.

name: PAS: Oldcroft 638
comments: Robertson 2000, 332-333 no. 1365:"The objects here described were found by Mr. P. Croal...in the parish of Lydney, Glos., close to the hamlet of Oldcroft. The site is immediately west of the Dean Road, a route between Lydney and Weston-under-Penyard for which a Roman origin has been claimed but not proved. The bronze coins were corroded together in groups within a deposit of loamy clay; they numbered about 3,333, of which 3, denariihave been examined and are listed below. The silver objects lay together within the mass of bronze coins and in association with two fragments of a textile wrapper or purse in which they may originally have been contained..Since three coins of Julian are present the deposit is later than AD 354, but since the type SPES REIPVBLICE is absent it is probably earlier than AD 359..The silver objects1. Proto-hand pin. The segment-shaped lower plate of the ring-head bears champlev[e] red enamel decoration of an eyed pelta linked with two eyed trumpet-scrolls.2. Small loop of strip.3-6. Four small bars weighing 9.68 gm., 7.86 gm., 3.04 gm., 2.25 gm.7. Siliqua of Constantius II, rev. PAX AV-GVSTORVM, m/m. TR (AD 342-3).8. Siliqua of Constans, rev. VICTORIA - AVGVSTORVM, m/m. SIS (AD 342-3)."The 3258 bronze coins examined and listed included 1614 regular coins, arranged according to mints, and 1644 irregular coins.J.F. Rhodes, in NC, 1974, 65-73, mints, types, LRBC refs., fig. 1 of silver objects other than the 2 sil., and note on the textile frags, by J.P. Wild, 73f.)The 1614 regular coins have been rearranged according to emperors, etc.:Ant. AEGallienus (sole reign) 1Victorinus 1uncertain 1Constantine I 17Licinius I 2Constantine II, Caes. 15Constantius II, Caes. 5Constantinopolis 42Urbs Roma 35Constans, Caes. 1Delmatius 2reign of Constantine I 11Helena (after AD 337) 6Theodora (after AD 337) 5Constantius II, Aug. 892Constans, Aug. 67Constantius II or Constans, Aug. 9Magnentius 100Decentius 13Magnentius or Decentius 5 Constantius Gallus 59Constantius II, Aug.or Constantius Gallus 322Julian II, Caes. 33 1611 TOTAL 1614(b.)(5 after AD 337)(5 after AD 337)The irregular AE coins were:reign of Constantine IGLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand. 1GLORIA EXERCITVS, 1 stand. 3Constantinopolis 2Constantius II, Aug.CONCORDIA MILITVM 1Constans, Aug.FEL TEMP REPARATIO phoenix 2Constantius II, or Constans, Aug.FEL TEMP REPARATIO galley 41MagnentiusGLORIA ROMANORVM 22Magnentius or DecentiusFELICITAS REIPVBLICE 54VICTORIA DD NN AVG ET CAE 155VICT DD NN AVG ET CAES 7SALVS DD NN AVG ET CAES 12overstrikes (GLORIA EXERCITVS, twostandards, 2; 1 stand., 2;Wolf and twins, 1) 5Constantius II, Aug. to GallusFEL TEMP REPARATIO falling horseman 1123overstrikes (radiate, 1; GLORIAEXERCITVS, 2 stand., 36; 1stand., 15; Wolf and twins, 12;Victory on prow, 15; VICTORIAE DDAVGGQ NN, 14; FEL TEMP REPARATIO,phoenix, 1; VICTORIAE DD NN AVGET CAE), 1 95illegible, probably irregular 90overstrikes (GLORIA EXERCITVS, twostandards, 11, illegible, 20) 311644Catherine Johns has given a fuller description and discussion of the silver proto-hand pin in Ant. J., 54 (1974), 295-7, fig. 6, and pl. LXVI a, for pin, and other silver objects.Cp. J.P.C. Kent and K.S. Painter, Wealth of the Roman World (1977), 58, no. 118 for silver pinThe silver objects, and the 2 sil. are in BM.The 3258 bronze coins and textile frags. were deposited by Mr. Croal in Gloucester City Museum."

name: PAS: Lydney Park (Bledisloe Coll.) 639
comments: Robertson 2000, 408 no. 1629:""Although I know of no other large 'Valentinianian' hoard recorded as found in Britain [i.e. than that from Shapwick, 1938, no. 1475], there can yet be little doubt that the 1,296 coins of that period which I noted in Lord Bledisloe's cabinet at Lydney Park also originally formed a hoard, though not so recorded. Their numbers contrast strongly with the mere handful of the 'Theodosian' coinage in his trays, and some devastating catastrophe seems to divide the two periods in the settlement at Lydney..What coins, if any, later than Valentinian I were found with the presumed Lydney hoard, we cannot, of course, now say, but among Lord Bledisloe's coins there is just that slight representation of the 375-388 coinage that we find in the present hoard."J.W.E. Pearce in NC, 1939, 139f., 142, 267-73 re. overstrikes, 275-8Theodosian?"

name: PAS: Lydney Park (Bledisloe Coll.) 640
comments: Robertson 2000, 353 no. 1451:""Although I know of no other large 'Valentinianian' hoard recorded as found in Britain [i.e. than that from Shapwick, 1938] there can yet be little doubt that the 1.296 coins of that period which I noted in Lord Bledisloe's cabinet at Lydney Park also originally formed a hoard, though not so recorded. Their numbers contrast strongly with the mere handful of the 'Theodosian' coinage in his trays and some devastating catastrophe seems to divide the two periods in the settlement at Lydney..What coins, if any, later than Valentinian I were found with the presumed Lydney hoard, we cannot, of course, now say, but among Lord Bledisloe's coins there is just that slight representation of the 375-388 coinage that we find in the present hoard."J.W.E. Pearce, in NC, 1939, 139f., 142, 269-73, 275-8)"

name: PAS: Nailsworth 643
comments: "From a farm on the Cotswoldsseveral miles S.W. of Nailsworth I have had brought to me some Neolithic Flint weapons and implements and a small lot of Roman Coins.The Roman coins 17 in number are all small brass of the Constantine family. Only one is in a fine state and this is of Constantine the Great."The rev. was PROVIDENTIAE AVGG, m/m. PCONST-J. E. Pritchard, in Trans. Bristol and Glos. Arch. Soc., XXXV (1912), 109

name: PAS: Nailsworth 644
comments: 9 siliquae to 383. NC 2006, 28.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2005 T186

name: PAS: Rodmarton Roman villa, Hocberry 648
comments: In 1800, during excav. of Roman villa, spaces between piers of hypocaust were filled with rubbish; between two of these piers more than 200 coins were found lying together; of the Lower Empire, from Constantine to Gratian, many in  perfect state of preservation." S. Lysons, Ms. Min. Soc. Ant. 31 (1806-8), 505f., & Arch. 18 (1815), 115. Pastscape: Roman corridor villa, reported in 1630, excav. in 1800. Tesselated pavements & hypocausts found in tripartite corridor plan building with 13 rooms. Pottery dated from 2nd to 4th century AD. Roman bronze coin hoard of over 200 bronze coins from Constantine to Gratian (AD 306-383), tile frags and pottery also recovered. Finds included hoard of over 200 bronze coins from Constantine to Gratian, a bronze fibula, an iron finger ring with blue intaglio, & stamped tiles. 2010 Cotswold Hills/South Cotswold NMP.

name: PAS: Stow On The Wold 653
comments: Robertson 2000, 320 no. 1325:""At Stow on the Wold, in the year 1717, were these following Coins found (amongst many more) and given me by Mr. Thomas Newsham, Counsellor at Law, and late Fellow of All souls College, Oxon, Amongst all which I could find none belonging to any other Emperors." Then came a description of 5 coins, all AE:AEConstantius II, Aug. 1Constans, Aug. 1 Magnentius 35(FEL TEMP REPARATIO, Emperor in galley)(As above 1; FELICITAS REIPVBLICE 1; GLORIA ROMANORVM 1)J. Pointer, Britannia Romana (1724), 38 f;, types"

name: PAS: Tewkesbury 655
comments: Robertson 2000, 336 no. 1372:""Mr. Gomonde forwarded some notes on ancient coins, recently discovered in Gloucestershire.Five gold coins of Valentinian, R. VICTORIA AVGG found at Tewkesbury."JBAA, I (1846), 157That these five gold coins came from a hoard seems probable, but whether they formed the whole hoard or not is uncertain."

name: PAS: Uley 656
comments: Robertson 2000, 278 no. 1168:""In 1872 a man digging on West Hill, near the footpath leading to Crawley, about 1½ furlongs from the camp [i.e. Uley Bury], found in a rubbish pit fifty Roman coins with Samian and commoner pottery. These coins were of the reigns of Victorinus, Claudius, Gothicus, 268; Tacitus, 275; Constantinus [I], 337; and Constans, 337. Some of these coins passed into the hands of Mr. W. P. Phillimore, and others belong to Canon Bazeley."-Trans. Bristol and Glos. Arch. Soc., XXXV (1912), 151-The coins of Victorinus, Claudius II and Tacitus must have been ant., the others were probably small AE."

name: PAS: Whittington 660
comments: During excav. of Roman villa at Whittington Court, in Room X, 8 coins (2 Gratian, 4 Valentinian, 1 Arcadius, 1 Theodosius) found in small area just above weathered bedding of the floor in NW corner of room. These may represent a dispersed hoard." O'Neil, H. 1952. Trans. Bristol and Glos. Arch. Soc. 71: 42, 49-53.

name: PAS: Willersey 661
comments: R-B burials & coin hoard, found during construction work on Hill Farm. Subsequent small-scale excavation. Near a stone-lined grave containing two skeletons, were 56 silver coins of 4C AD & silver ring. Ring & two coins in BM; other coins in Cheltenham Museum. O'Neil, H.E. 1971. A hoard of Roman silver coins from Willersey. Trans. Bristol and Gloc. Archaeol. Soc 90: 120-123. O’Neill stated that: “A small excavation was undertaken by me, with the help of Mr. K.W. Brown, to see if it were possible to locate any indication of a grave. A section 6 feet long from N to S did produce evidence of the narrow end of a stone-lined grave where fragments of bone including human toe bones were recovered in the dark loam filling of the grave. This type of grave is typical of one of the Romano-British period. A description of the find of the coins, given to me later by an onlooker at the time, stated that they were in a mass in a hole filled with dark earth dug into the clay and lying close to and on the west side of the human bones. The hoard thus appears not to have been in a container of any sort and that it was not part of the original interments.”

name: PAS: Foxcote 662
comments:
Robertson 2000, 350 no. 1434: "The account of the Foxcote Tumulus, as given by Mr. Norwood, is interesting and worthy of notation. The following are the facts as supplied by Mr. Norwood:-
A party of antiquaries, General Younghusband, Captain Bell, Mr. E. Harford, Dr. Bird, and the Rev. T.W. Norwood, visited the locality referred to on the 25th February, 1863, where they found the remains of what had been a large Tumulus, about 20 yards in diameter. There were no indications of those large stones which mark so characteristically so many Cotteswold barrows. A heap of greasy black earth occupied the centre of the area. A human skeleton was found, that of a young person, said to have been of the female sex. It is important to notice that there was but one body here buried, for in our usual chambered Tumuli of unknown age we generally find several bodies. The body is said to have been found lying at length, not doubled up. There were marks of fire on a few bones and stones, and some bits of pottery lying about within the area of the Tumulus were identical in kind with the Roman black pottery of the whole district. In the black earth were found 11 or 12 pieces of flint, of the sort known as 'flint flakes'. These have been found in graves of Roman age, according to Mr. Thomas Wright, as well as in 'primaeval' and Saxon graves, and must often have been brought over long distances.
A piece of rusty iron was found, apparently belonging to the interment. Many Roman coins were found in the Tumulus according to the workmen, not fewer than 200. Six were picked up by Mr. Norwood's party, bearing the names of Valens, Gratianus, Gallienus and Constantine 2nd. The others said to have been found there were mostly small brass of Valens, Valentinian, Tetricus, Gratianus, Victorinus, Gordian, Maximian, Postumus, Tacitus, Claudius Gothicus, Constantine 2nd, Constans and Constantius, with several of the 'Urbs Roma' and 'Constantinopolis' type. With these were five or six small coins, very small and rude, not Roman, but probably struck in imitation of Roman coins. The coins were not contained in any vessel, but were scattered broadcast throughout the mound. Mr. Norwood has come to the conclusion, from the foregoing facts, that this grave was Roman or Romano-British, of the date of about 400 AD; and he gives it as his opinion that in no other instance, in so far as he is aware, has it been found possible to fix an approximate date to an ancient Tumulus with so much probability as in the instance thus brought under our notice."
Proc. Cotteswold Nat. Field Club III (1865), 198f.
Dr. Bird, a member of Mr. Norwood's party, gave a briefer account in Proc. Cotteswold Nat. Field Club VI, 4 (1876), 335f.:
"The Foxcote Tumulus. In this Tumulus there were two Roman coins and a half found in the black earth, and a broken earthen vessel containing small coins. There was a dry wall across the heap of stones, and a kist near its centre, the ends and sides of it formed of flat stones placed on their edges and covered with flat stones two feet square. The kist contained the remains of only one female.
[Description of skull and bones].
The flint flakes were about fourteen altogether; the largest were in the red earth on the base of the Tumulus. The Tumulus measured twenty-six yards in one direction and twenty-three in the other, and the centre was raised from eight to ten feet."
G.B. Witts, Arch. Handbook of the Co. of Glos. (1883), 98, said of the Foxcote Tumulus: "This lies on the top of the hill, one mile south of Dowdeswell, and four miles south-east of Cheltenham", summarised the accounts given by Rev. T.W. Norwood and Dr. Bird, and added: "Between 300 and 400 Roman coins were found in the black earth near the surface."
Cp. Helen O'Neil and L.V. Grinsell, in Trans. Bristol and Glos. Arch. Soc., 79 (1960), 137.
L.V. Grinsell, in a letter, Jan. 1966, observed "that the barrow called St. Paul's Epistle (Dowdeswell parish) is about 1000 yards from that on Foxcote Hill (Withington parish). I suspect that these sites may have got confused in the literature."
See Dowdeswell, before 1922 (Glos.) find.
The coins from Gallienus to Tacitus, and possibly Maximian, must have been ant. The others were small AE."

name: PAS: Woolaston 663
comments: Robertson 2000, 278 no. 1169:""The discovery was made at High Woolaston, in Woolaston parish, 5 miles north of Chepstow, at the foot of Bowlash Hill [NB now known as Park Hill].The spot would be equally distant from a central point between the Roman works at 'the Chesters' and at 'Oldbury Field'and about half way between the recently discovered position on the Severn Cliffs in my own grounds at Sedbury, and the camp and temple at Lydney. On March 19 (1862) a labourer excavating a ditch at the point described came upon a mass of coins, several hundreds in number, cemented together by verdigris. The coins are now widely scattered but I have seen many of them, and about 30 are in my possession. All that I have seen are small brass coins of Constantine the Great, of the Empresses Helena and Fausta, of the sons of Constantine, namely, Crispus, Constantine, and Constantius, as Caesars, and his municipal coins. None are later or earlier."-G. Ormerod in AJ, XX (1863), 167f.-Ormerod gave two types, of Constantine I, rev. CONSTANTINVS AVG in wreath, and Constantine II, Caes., rev. BEATA TRANQVILLITASA note supplied by Dr. Ormerod to NC, 1862, 230, omitted Constantius II and added Constans."

name: PAS: Chitterne 664
comments: HER record of "26 coins from Antoninus Pius to Valentinian, a fibula and a small bronze plaque with eagles head" recorded as a probably hoard in the Devizes Museum Daybook 1969. As there is no listing of the coins, the date of the suggested hoard is uncertain.

name: PAS: Tavistock Square 667
comments: Robertson 2000, 274 no. 1145:""Workmen, excavating the site of a new hotel in Tavistock Square, Bloomsbury, in November, 1924, brought to light a hoard of some 700 Roman copper coins. No trace remains of the box (of tin?) in which they were said to have been found. The coins themselves, with the exception of quite a few which were given away in small lots, havebeen submitted to the British Museum for examination."The coins examined were folles or small AE:AEConstantine I 308 Licinius I 12Crispus 113Constantine II, Caes. 148Constantius II, Caes. 46Helena 26 (before AD 337)Fausta 12Constantinopolis 2667-H. Mattingly, in NC, 1925, 398f., types, mints-JRS, XIV (1924), 229f., said that the hoard was found at a depth of 7 feet, and was contained in a lead box, and added, on the authority of Mr. Mattingly, that the hoard included a base den. of Lucius Verus, and a billon ant. of Claudius II.113 coins in Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM, presented by H. Knott (BM Register of Coin Accessions, Jan. 1925)"

name: PAS: St. Pancras Window Box 668
comments: Robertson 2000, 403 no. 1618:""The siliqua of Honorius Pl. III.15) is one of only three specimens of this variety from the mint of Trier, all from British finds. The style of the piece is similar to that of Ravenna late in the reign of Honorius, about 420, when the mints in Gaul were once again under the emperor's control after the succession of usurpers from Constantine III onwards in the early part of the century."(Footnote: "This coin was found in the earth filling of a window-box of a flat in St. Pancras, together with six other siliquae of Valens, Maximus, and Arcadius. It was, unfortunately, not possible to trace from where the earth had come. A second example, also in B.M., came from the Coleraine hoard of 1847 [no. 1621] though it does not appear in the published account. The third was in the Terling treasure of 1824 [no. 1528], NC, 1933, 168.")R.A.G. Carson, in NC, 1959, 15, pl. III, 15Only the sil. of Honorius described above appears to have been registered, although the other 6 sil. are also in the Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM (BM Register of Coin Accessions, 1954-4-8-1, showing that the sil. were found before 1954).A.M. Burnett, in Britannia, XV (1984), 165, noted that the "St. Pancras" sil. came from the same obv. die as the Terling example, and suggested that "the Honorian Trier VRBS ROMA pieces" may have been "imitations (that is to say ancient counterfeits), combining an obverse of Honorius with the reverse of an earlier coin."All 3 examples illustrated, Britannia, XV (1984), pl. VI, 12-14."

name: PAS: London Wall 675
comments: Robertson 2000, 267 no. 1118:""Mr. T. Bliss exhibitedtwo silver coins of Constantius II lately found in an earthen vase under the foundations of Sion College, London Wall."-NC, 1855, Proc., 7-It seems possible that the pot once contained a hoard of fourth century silver, of which only two coins survived.Including Constantius II"

name: PAS: Yewden Villa 676
comments: In 1912, during excav. of R-B building at Hambledon Valley, hoard of 294 bronze coins found in small black pot, on inside of the N. wall of building built onto the W. end of the 2nd House, buried below the floor, and covered with two or three pieces of tile and brick, 15 ft. E. of the W. corner of the house. An ivory pin appeared to have fastened a cloth over mouth of the jar before it was laid on its side in the shallow space under floor, and this having eventually decayed, allowed some coins to slide out of the jar. The 294 coins were 8 ant. & 287 AE (folles). A.H. Cocks & J. Mill Stephenson. 1921 Archaeologia 71: 190. In recent study of the hoard, Dr Cathy King has assigned 1 ant. listed above under Tetricus II, to Tetricus I (b.?), and has identified 4 coins of Constantine I as fractions. The pot, a "fumed" [i.e. black burnished] cooking pot with overhanging rim, 5¾ in. high and 4 7/8 in. wide, was taken with coins to Hambledon Museum. 294 coins & pot now in Bucks. County Museum, Aylesbury.

name: PAS: Billingsgate 677
comments: During excav. of Billingsgate bath-house, earlier baths connected with poss. industrial use of site found. The site lay on the spring-line at base of steep hill, occupied by an L-shaped dwelling, in angle of which lay the bath-house – a simple building with entrance-vestibule giving access from corridor in N wing. Leading off vestibule were the cold, tepid & hot rooms. Each wing of house had corridor with rooms leading off; those in E wing were heated. Both buildings were constructed c. AD 200 & orig. had tessellated floors, mostly replaced by op. sig. in 4th C. Earlier baths connected with poss. industrial use of site have now been found. Finds incl. 200 late coins (some forming a scattered hoard) down to Arcadius & Honorius. Britannia (1976) 7: 350.

name: PAS: Principal Place 690
comments: 134 coins found in a poorly-defined cut through backfill of a boundary ditch, N edge of a late Roman cemetery. 19 gold solidi, 114 silver siliquae & 1 copper-alloy coin (a worn 3rd C. radiate), plus a lead object (a seal?), & a copper alloy strip, poss. a bracelet frag.

name: PAS: Redcross Street 694
comments: Robertson 2000, 411 no. 1649:""As some labourers were digging for a foundation in Redcross Street, where a meeting house is to be erected, they found some ancient pieces of silver coin, to a great value. At the same time was found by a poor man, a silver wedge weighing 121 ounces, which was claimed by the proprietor of the ground."Gent. Mag. 25 (1755), 375"The silver wedge" must have been a silver ingot of late fourth century date, like those found at the Tower of London, 1777 [no. 1563], and at Stanmore, 1781, (Middlesex) [no. 1619]. The silver coins were probably of late fourth century date also.Probably late 4th century AD"

name: PAS: Croydon 700
comments: Robertson 2000, 331 no. 1362:""The hoard which is described in the following pages was found at Croydon, Surrey, on March 10, 1903, by a workman in the employ of the Corporation, who was digging a drain-trench in Wandle Road, opposite No. 56. The coins were contained in two pots, buried only two feet below the surface. The pots were in fragments, and so much is missing that reconstruction appears to be impossible. One of the pots, of a red clay, was decorated with a single band of pattern (a row of circular pits between parallel lines): the other, of grey clay and harder ware, appears to have been quite plain. The pots were apparently without handles..When the coins were first counted they are said to have numbered 3600, the total number which I have been able to see amounts to 2796..It is also very difficult in many cases to distinguish between the better executed barbarous imitations and the worse executed official issues, and, as there can be no doubt that the imitations were accepted in commerce, I have not attempted to draw the line between the two kinds."The 2796 coins examined, all AE, were:Constantius II, Aug. 738Constans, Aug. 1311Constantius II, orConstans, Aug. 12Magnentius 724Constantius Gallus 112796(7 b. FEL TEMP REPARATIO, galley (4); falling horseman (3); 8 b.? FEL TEMP REPARATIO, galley (6), falling horseman (2))(1 b. FEL TEMP REPARATIO, galley; 4 b.? FEL TEMP REPARATIO, galley)(6 b.? GLORIA ROMANORVM (1), FELICITAS REIPVBLICE (5))(Sir) George Hill, in NC, 1905, 36-62, types, mints; and in Surrey Arch. Coll., XIX (1906), 1-26, types, mints, pl. I of 10 coinsCp. R.J. Brickstock, in BAR 176 (1987), 333f., no. 29, list of 2841 coins according to mints210 coins in Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM (BM Register of Coin Accessions, Oct. 1903)Examined, 1948 (ASR)22 coins in Guildford MuseumExamined, 1960 (ASR)"

name: PAS: South Croydon, 15-17 Brighton Road (former Dee's Garage) 701
comments: HER: An evaluation followed by excavation by MoLAS in July 1993 (site code BRR93). A number of Roman features, in particular two parallel ditches (c.AD 120-180) & a pit excavated. Pottery & building material also found. A dispersed hoard of 58 bronze coins (AD 341-352) & 3 other (2nd/3rd C) coins found with several Roman structures. MoLAS. 1993. Former Dee's Garage, Brighton Road, South Croydon: an archaeological report.

name: PAS: Croydon 708
comments: 2 solidi (Valentinian I). Gentleman's Magazine 1791, part 2, p. 596 and 727 (`Fig. 3 and 4 are two gold coins found lately in the neighbourhood of Croydon.') = Steinman, History of Croydon = VCH Surrey IV, 1912, p. 361 (`Croydon Numerous separate coins have been found at Mint Walk, High Street, the Cemetery, Sydenham Road, Park Street and Mitcham Road... Among them are several gold coins, including two of Valentinian (AD 364-75) [Gent. Mag. 1791, pt. ii, 596, 727].')

name: PAS: Cirencester 710
comments: Robertson 2000, 344 no. 1409:""At the completion of the sorting and listing of the coin collection of the Corinium Museum, Cirencester, there remained unlisted a small mass of fourth century coins, fused and corroded together, which were found in the town in the 19th. century, and were for a long time on display simply as 'a hoard.' Cleaning released 31 coins which are listed below. Die-links were looked for but were not found. They call for little comment save for their normality, that is, their close similarity to Valentinianic site finds. This appears in the proportions of the mints represented, and the small number of earlier coins."Then came a list of the 31 coins, with LRBC refs.A.M. Burnett and P.J. Casey, in CH VI (1981), 38, no. 189, types, mintsRearranged according to emperors, the coins were:Trier Lyons Arles Rome Aquileia Siscia Heraclea TOTALConstantius II 1 1 Constans 1 1Valentinian I 1 2 1 4 Valens 2 3 4 1 1 2 13Gratian 1 8 1 1 11uncertain 4th cent. 1RULE3 5 14 2 1 4 1+1 31The coins of Valentinian I, Valens, and Gratian all had rev. types GLORIA ROMANORVM or SECVRITAS REIPVBLICAE.The 31 coins are in the Corinium Museum, Cirencester."

name: PAS: Bentley 718
comments: Robertson 2000, 403 no. 1619:"8 Nov. 1781 "as some Labourers of Philip Duberley Esqr. of Bentley in Middlesex (about a mile from the ancient Sulloniaca) were employed in cleaning a Ditch, they discovered sevl. Roman Coins, both Gold & Silver, a Bracelet, & two Rings. They lay scatter'd loosely in the Soil, without any Vestige of an Urn or Vase; tho' from the Freshness & Brilliancy of the Gold there is every reason to suppose that they were contained in some Vessel, probably an earthen one, which moulder'd instantaneously at the first Stroke of the Spade."Then came a list of the gold coins, 40 in number:"Constantine" 1Constantius II 1Valentinian (I and II?) 11Valens 4Gratian 3Theodosius 7Magnus Maximus 5Arcadius 1Honorius 740"The Silver Coins are in general so much decayed, as to be pulveris'd with ease between the Fingers. A few are a more perfect State, but the Bust is discernible on one only, which he [i.e. J. Ibbetson] believes to be a Gratian; the Inscriptions are totally defaced.The Bracelet is composed of two Bars of Gold; each, in its greatest diameter, of the size of a very small Quill. They are closely interwoven, & taper gradually to the Extremities, one of which is beaten flat, & perforated, so as to admit a small Fibula or Button, which is annex'd to the other. The Bracelet is elastic, bright, & appears to be of pure Gold.One of the Rings is plain Gold, very broad, without any stone; but thicker & flatter on the upper part, on which are engraven two Heads, apparently of different Sexes. It has no Inscription.The other Ring is also Gold, ornamented with a Sort of Fret-work, & enclosing a dark blue unpolish'd Pebble, on which are engraven a large Eagle, supporting two smaller ones on her Back, whilst she herself is assaulting a Quadruped, wch, upon the most accurate Inspection, he conceives to be an Hare.Several other Coins, besides those here enumerated, were found, but purloin'd by the Labourer employed in the Work. There was also, it is said, a silver Plate with an Inscription, which would perhaps have thrown Light on the time & occasion of depositing the Treasure; but Mr. Ibbetson had unfortunately been disappointed in his Endeavours to get a Sight of it."Hon. D. Barrington: Letter from John Ibbetson, in Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., XVII (1780-1), 438-41Camden and Gough's Britannia (1789), II, 30f. and pl. showing ingot, gave the number of gold coins in the hoard as almost 50 ranging from "Constantine jun." to Honorius, with which were found, besides the two gold rings and gold bracelet, "some small silver and copper coins of Valentinian entirely corroded, and a plate or piece of silver inscribed HONOR, set in a triangular frame of metal."Gough's Camden also gave a list of the rev. types included, from which it is clear that the solidus attributed to Constantine jn. was in fact a coin of Constantine III.K.S. Painter recorded the silver ingot in JBAA, (3), 28 (1965), 12, no.6.M. Henig, Corpus of Roman Engraved Gemstones from British Sites, BAR 8, I (1974), gave Honorius as the latest coin in the hoard, and described the two gold rings, i, 92, no. 703; and 102, no. 791:"An Eagle disembowelling a hare - on its back are two eaglets. Nicolo (or Nicolo paste). 10 x 7 mm. Oval set in a gold ring.IntaglioTwo facing busts. Betrothal ringGold ring. Bezel, rectangular 12 x 10 mm.""

name: PAS: Brentford 720
comments: Robertson 2000, 266 no. 1115:""The coins listed and discussed below were brought to the author's attention when they were offered for sale in a London auction room. The provenance assigned to them has no authority beyond the tradition that they were found in Brentford, Middlesex, and no circumstantial account has survived of the date of the find or of the archaeological context from which it was recovered. The coins had been cleaned in acid so that similarity of patina or corrosion could not be used to supplement the evidence of their hoard status, though the internal evidence puts this beyond question."Then came a list of 67 Constantinian bronze coins-P.J. name: PAS: Islington, York Way 722
comments: Greater London SMR MLO1681 ('A reportedly iron urn with possibly gold and certainly silver coins of Constantine in it, found in Maiden Lane near Battle Bridge.'); W J Pinks, The History of Clerkenwell, London, 1865, p. 500: 'In a newspaper dated July 15th, 1845, we read:-"Discovery of Ancient Coins.-On Tuesday morning, a very singular discovery was made by some men employed in excavating for the purpose of forming a foundation for houses intended to be erected in Maiden-lane, Battle-bridge. It appears that one of the men having found a few coins which he conceived to be mere brass, carelessly mentioned it to a fellow workman, who, upon looking at them, declared his opinion that they were formed of metal more valuable than brass, and acquainted the surveyor of the fact, who immediately instituted a further search, and was at length rewarded by finding, at a depth of between ten and twelve feet, a small iron vessel shaped somewhat like an urn, which, upon being forced open, was found to contain a large quantity of gold and silver coins of the reign of Constantine, in the year 306, and several others bearing a date '53. These were, however, so much defaced, that no other inscription could be traced; besides which was found, some four or five feet deeper, large quantities of Roman tile, many parts of which were in a remarkable state of preservation."'; W Thornbury and E Walford, London, Old and New, vol. 2, London, 1878, p. 278: 'The last fact to be recorded about the Romans at Battle Bridge is the discovery, in 1845, under the foundation of a house in Maiden Lane, of an iron urn, full of gold and silver coins of the reign of Constantine'; I Schwab, The Archaeology of Islington, Inner London Archaeological Unit, 1978; B Robertson, 'Roman Camden', The London Archaeologist, vol. 2, 10, 1975, p. 253: 'The other find at Battle Bridge was made in 1845 when, during construction of houses in Maiden Lane, an urn, supposedly of iron, was discovered containing coins of Constantine.'

name: PAS: Letheringsett with Glandford 729
comments: IARCH record for a hoard of 17 silver siliquae (including fragments) and four copper alloy nummi. For further details and images see NMS-38CFB0.

name: PAS: Bermondsey 731
comments: Robertson 2000, 384-385 no. 1561:""In the course of preparing a housing site in Chilton Street, Bermondsey, in May 1946, a pot of Roman coins was found."(Footnote: "The pot is a small globular flagon of good hard-fired grey ware, retaining traces of what appears to be a thin purple-brown slip, with a band of white slip just above the bulge of the body. The single handle was weakly luted to the neck and body and is now missing.")The pot was 6 in. high, and 4 3/4 in. wide.The coins were 3 ant. and 358 small AE:Ant. AEConstantine I 3Constantinopolis 4Urbs Roma 2Constantius II, Aug. 3Constans, Aug. 1Constantius II, or Constans, Aug. 5House of Constantine I 6Constantius Gallus (?) 1Valens 1Valentinian I or Valens 8Valentinian II 14Theodosius 11Magnus Maximus 1Maximus or Victor 3Eugenius 2Arcadius 30Honorius 8"Theodosian" 192uncertain 3 633 358(1 b. GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand.)(b. FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman)(3 b. FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman)(2 b. GLORIA EXERCITVS, 1 stand.)(1 b.)(b.)(1 overstruck)Some of the coins were reduced from "third brass" to "fourth brass" size. "A considerable number of the late coins were imitations - many not far from original size, a few quite barbarous; the metal was notably impure and showed traces of heavy alloying with lead." The latest coins included 79 with rev. SALVS REIPVBLICAE, and 164 with rev. VICTORIA AVGGG.H. Mattingly, in NC, 1946, 167-9, types, mintsCp. G.C. Boon, in Coins and the Archaeologist (1988), 174, n. 232Dr. A.A. Moss, in NC, 1947, 91, gave an analysis of 4 coins from the hoard. Pot and 361 coins in London Museum (now in Museum of London)Examined, and pot drawn, 1948 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Surrey Commercial Docks/Lime Street I 732
comments: In May 1952 during excavs for Lloyd's building in Lime Street, EC3, a small but interesting hoard of barbarous radiates found by Noel Hume, Excav Assistant at Guildhall Museum, in course of routine 'rescue' excav. while builders' site clearance in progress. 32 coins found crammed tightly into hole 6 in. deep & with max. diameter of ¾ in., tapering downwards. It was made with pointed stick, thrust into clay deposit overlying foundations of earlier Roman building. There was another similar hole about 3 in. away, but this contained nothing. On the surface of clay lay portion of Roman tile, covering both holes. The hoard deposited after destruction of 2nd C building it overlay. This structure succeeded by a 2nd, larger Roman building on same site, & relationship of hoard to this later building more problematic. It was situated just within NE corner of one of rooms, about 6 in. from inner face of N foundation wall, about 3 ft. from inner corner. The stakehole with coins & tile cover sealed by thin layer of wood-ash, containing late 3rd or early 4th C pot.. This deposited after foundations of 2nd building, piled against their inner face. Above layer of ash was thicker layer of clay mixed with tile frags & wood-ash. All higher levels removed, including floors. Since hoard buried within 2nd building at foundation level, likely it was deposited before floors laid.  Of 32 coins, 2 disintegrated during cleaning, & one corroded & illegible. Another a plain disc of bronze, completely smooth, & poss. a moneyer's blank. hand, are crude. The presence of several die identities, with linked dies, coupled with fresh condition of most coins, suggests they deposited soon after manufacture. The suggestion that coins were foundation deposit is attractive; but petty theft, the concealment of an illegal currency, or even children's play might equally well account for their burial. R. Merrifield, in NC, 1955, 113-24.

name: PAS: Cotton's Wharf/Hay's Wharf 738
comments: Hoard of 44 bronze coins mainly Valentinianic, found in July 1984 during observation of redevelopment work on Hay's Wharf by DGLA (Southwark and Lambeth). Hoard in exposed section of machine-dug trench, & appeared to lie in shallow depression c 0.20m deep & 0.20m diameter, overlying dark grey sandy silt which may have been a Roman foreshore deposit. It was sealed by a layer of grey clay which represented post-Roman (possibly med.) flooding. Find-spot c. 250m E of London Bridge & c. 45m S of modern river wall. It is 150m E of higher ground which formed main Roman settlement, in area which was mainly creeks & marshes during much of Roman period, but depth at which coins were found, 1.20m AOD, suggests findspot was dry ground during at least part of Roman period. Found c. 20m W of a stone building excav. in 1983 which was prob. constructed during a later recession of Roman river, but the hoard could not be related strat. to the building. Unclear whether coins were concealed in a hole, dropped onto land surface, or even into mud or water. No trace of a container noted, & coins were loosely scattered within depression. Since hoard came from edge of a machine-dug trench, some coins may have been lost when trench dug, though size & shape of depression suggests at least half recovered. Latest coin in the hoard dated to 378-83, but of 36 Valentinianic coins identified, 21 (incl. most of latest coins) were in a state of wear suggesting they had been in circulation for some period, while a further 11 were more heavily worn. Only 3 showed slight wear. Coins may have been lost during early 380s. M. Hammerson. 1987. CHRB 7. BM Occas. Paper 59 (1987), 189-92.

name: PAS: Sale 749
comments: Robertson 2000, 337 no. 1380:""Mr. W. Charlton, J.P., exhibited forty-six Roman bronze coins found at Sale in October 1907. They were discovered when digging a drain for some new buildings near the highway, the old Roman road from Manchester to Chester. They consisted of examples of the coinage from the reign of Nerva, AD 96-98, to that of Valens, AD 364-378." Then came a list of 3 "middle brass", 15 ant., and 28 small AE:Ant. name: PAS: Caernarvon (Segontium Praetorium) 755
comments: Robertson 2000, 255 no. 1073:"In 1921, during the excavation of the Roman fort at Caernarvon, in the "Praetorium", i.e. the Headquarters Building:"the coins were found mostly stuck together amongst some loose stones which were lying on the penultimate surface on the north-west side of the courtyard, and had been incorporated in the latest floor.The fourth century coins were in very good or mint condition."Then came a list of 5 ant. and 11 Constantinian AE.-R.E.M. name: PAS: Tyddyn Isaf Penrhyndeudraeth 773
comments: Robertson 2000, 285 no. 1213:""A note in the National Museum from W.J. Hemp records from Breese MSS. a letter from Ellis Owen to Mrs. E.A. Roche, 5 January 1855, in which it is stated that 'a few years ago on a farm called Tyddyn Isaf Penrhyndeudraeth opposite ford of Felenrhyd, in moving some stones were found a great number (about two quarts my informant says) and of which I have three on the table before me of Roman coins of Constantinus with two warriors on the reverse'. If the estimate of the size is correct, the hoard must have been a large one of at least 5,000 pieces. The Gloria Exercitvs type mentioned puts it in a very common class."G.C. Boon, in BBCS, XXVI (1974-6), 240, no. 125"

name: PAS: Neatham, Cuckoos Corner 775
comments: During excavs for Farnham & District Museum Society, Hants. Arch. Unit & DOE, in area south of Roman defences, Roman roads, stone & wooden buildings, ditches & burials uncovered. Sill-beam structures built on gravel, & occ. continued (on coin-evidence) into 5th C. A hoard of 195 coins, mainly of AD 364-78, found in pit cut into silted up well. Millett, M & Graham, D. 1986. Excavations on the Romano-British Small Town at Neatham, Hampshire 1969-1979, 24-25, 95-99. Farnham & District Museum Society.

name: PAS: Amberwood 785
comments: Robertson 2000, 362 no. 1490:""Miss Pulteney forwarded, for the inspection of the Society, sixteen denarii found at Amberwood, on the borders of the New Forest, by a labourer, who was grubbing a bank. The coins are of Valentinian, Valens, Gratianus, Magnus Maximus, and Arcadius; reverses common; mintages, Lyons and Treves."NC, 1845, Proc., 5; coins identified by C. Roach Smith, cp. Coll. Ant., VI (1868), 192Rev. J.P. Bartlett, 9 Dec. 1852, in PSA, (1), II (1849-53), 278f., said that the coins were contained in a small "crock", and added Julian to the list of emperors included. He also gave rev. types of 2 coins: of Julian II, Aug. (VOT X MVLT XV), and of Valens (VRBS ROMA). The coins were sil., not den.J.Y. Akerman, in Arch., XXXV (1853), 94, said that the pot which held the coins was the exact shape "of a vessel of which we had found several nearly perfect specimens [i.e. in the examination of the New Forest pottery kilns].""

name: PAS: Polesworth 790
comments: 22 Nov. 1762"As some labourers were lately trenching near Polesworth in Warwickshire, they found a large earthen pot full of small copper coins, most part of which appear to bear a beautiful image of Constantine, with the name of Constantinus round it." Then came a description of several reverse types, which can be recognised as the GLORIA EXERCITVS, Urbs Roma, Constantinopolis, Constantine I (deified) and PAX PVBLICA or PIETAS ROMANA types."Annual Register, 1762, 111f., some types

name: PAS: Cadnam 792
comments: Robertson 2000,  290 no. 1229:""In June 1983, workmen digging the footings trenches for an extension to 'Oakley', Southampton Road, Cadnam, discovered the coin hoard described in this report. Initially they removed the coins from the site, an action which resulted in the loss of an unspecified number, but subsequently surrendered the great majority of them to the owner, Mrs. H. Marsh. Mrs. Marsh submitted them, together with the sherds of the pot which once contained them, to the Hampshire County Museum Service for identification.The sherds form part of a New Forest grey ware jar or jug, with decoration in the form of vertical and horizontal grooves, and with saltire crosses scored on its body. This is a known type, catalogued by Fulford (BAR 17 (1975), fig. 33, 20.1). This form had a terminal date of c. AD 350, which is in close agreement with the termination date of the hoard. The sherds recovered constitute only part of the vessel; the rim and base are missing. While the base and body sherds exhibit fresh breaks, the neck is abraded and worn, presumably as a result of plough or cultivation damage. As it was not possible to view the find 'in situ', nor recover details of its discovery, this is the only clue to the manner of deposition. Two other small Roman sherds collected from the area of the find were also submitted for identification. They are from different vessels but both are also of New Forest type. After they had been identified, the coins were retained by the owner, but the pottery sherds were donated to the Museum Service, where they are housed as A1984.29."The hoard comprised AE coins - 484 regular issues of AD 320-48 and 126 irregular copies of types of AD 330-48 - making a total of 610.The 484 regular coins were:Trier Lyons Arles Rome Aq. name: PAS: Cranborne Clump 794
comments: 6 silver siliquae and 69 bronze nummi to AD 402. "The silver coins were found close together and at a later date a Roman necklace clasp was found at the same spot." The bronze coins were dated to the period AD 253 to 393 and were thought not to consitute a hoard.Unpublished file report by R. Iles, Winchester Museum Service 1997, BM file

comments: 4 solidi (Honorius).
