name: PAS: Kingsclere 810
comments: Robertson 2000, 340 no. 1393:""Near Canon's Heath at Kingsclere, some Roman coins have recently been found, and they range in date from AD 275 to 375."Berks. Bucks. and Oxon. A.J., XVI (1912), 54The coins were probably ant. and small AE."

name: PAS: Tuddenham 814
comments: Robertson 2000, 395 no. 1593:""Sometime in the summer of 1938 or 1939 (either in June or July) a little hoard of late Roman silver was found, with a gold ring, blue-stone inset, in an earthenware pot in a sandpit at Tuddenham St. Martin, Suffolk."The coins were 114 sil.:Sil.Constantius II 2Julian II 5Jovian (?) 1 Valentinian I 3Valens 13Gratian 7Valentinian II 5Theodosius 2Magnus Maximus 10Flavius Victor 4Eugenius 4Arcadius 21Arcadius or Honorius 15Honorius 20"Theodosian" 2114(1 Caes.)(1 uncertain)About 1 in 10 sil. were said to have been clipped.H. Mattingly and J.W.E. Pearce, in NC, 1946, 169-73, types, mints M. Henig, Corpus of Roman Engraved Gemstones from British Sites, BAR 8 (1974), ii, 79, no. 581, and pl. XVIII, described and illustrated the inset of the gold ring; and pl. XLI Series B included a view of the hoard, with pot and gold ring, in Ipswich Museum. The description ran:"Figure standing towards the front, very probably Mars or some other deity was intended, but the body has been gouged away (? deliberate defacement by a Christian owner). Nicolo paste. 16 x 13 x 3.5 mm. Flat. OvalSet in a gold ring."The pot was of hard grey ware, 3 3/8 in. high and 3 1/2 in. in diam., with a globular body decorated with burnished vertical lines.12 sil. in Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM (BM Register of Coin Accessions, Oct. 1947)102 sil. in Ipswich MuseumExamined, 1978 (ASR)Of the 102 sil. in Ipswich Museum, 88 appeared to have been clipped. Of the 12 sil. in the BM, all but 1 were clippedInf. from Dr. J.P.C. Kent, 1985 The total no. clipped (99 out of 114) was a higher proportion than that suggested in NC, 1946."

name: PAS: Otterbourne 820
comments: Robertson 2000, 375 no. 1532:""On 17 January 1978 a hoard of 543 fourth century Roman silver coins together with the fragments of a pottery container was discovered near a footpath on the south side of Poles Lane, Otterbourne, Hants. and was declared a Treasure Trove by a Coroner's Inquest. Examination showed that the find was composed of 7 miliarenses and 536 siliquae..The latest coins in the hoard are the siliquae of Honorius from the Milan mint. These appear to be issues after the death of Theodosius I in 395, so that the closing of the hoard can be placed about 400."There followed a catalogue of the 543 coins, according to mints.R.A.G. Carson, in CHRB, I, BM Occas. Paper 5 (1979), 106-9, mints, types, wts.Rearranged according to emperors the coins were:Trier Lyons Arles Milan Rome Aquileia 0 1Sisc. 2Const. 3Nic. 4TOTALMil. Sil. Sil. Sil. Sil. Mil. Sil. Mil. 0Sil. 1Sil. 2Sil. 3Sil. 4Constantius II, Aug. 4 2 0 1 2 32 48Julian II, Caes. 2 0 1 2 3 42Julian II, Aug. 2 11 13 0 1 2 3 426Valentinian I 9 1 6 0 1 21 3 417Valens 3 127 8 05 11 2 3 4144Gratian 1 105 3 8 1 010 11 2 3 4129Valentinian II 1 42 1 010 1 2 3 454Theodosius 19 1 2 04 1 2 3 426Magnus Maximus 125 1 0 1 2 3 4126Flavius Victor 1 2 01 1 2 3 44Arcadius 3 1 0 1 2 3 44Honorius 3 0 1 2 3 43RULE 0RULE 1RULE 2RULE 3RULE 4RULE 5 + 430 20 17 9 1 + 25 1 + 030 12 21 32 45431 sil. of Gratian, minted at Trier, was irregular; 1 sil. of Magnus Maximus, minted at Trier, was clipped.In a note, 1978, R.A.G. Carson added to ASR:"Though over 30 fragments of the vessel are present, many are extremely small, and there are few joins. It is therefore not possible to reconstruct the form of the pot with any degree of certainty. Most of the footring is present; it is rounded in section, and has a diameter of about 6 cm. The wall of the vessel rises at a fairly steep angle to a surviving height of c. 8 cm. The point of greatest diameter would have been above this. The most likely form would have been a simple cooking-pot shape.The fabric is light pink, with sparse but quite large brick-red and cream inclusions. Traces remain of the slip, which is thin, matt, and a bright orange in colour. Over it is a layer of dark discoloration, which could be due to burning.The vessel is presumably a local fourth-century type; it does not have distinctive features which would assign it to any well-known group with a wide distribution."7 coins from this hoard acquired by Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM (BM Register of Coin Accessions, Sept. 1979 (6 sil. only?))3 coins in Winchester City Museum"

name: PAS: Otterbourne II 821
comments: Robertson 2000, 375-376 no. 1533:""The hoard of 155 late Roman siliquae was found by members of the Hampshire Detector Club, between August and October, 1980, near the Incinerator Plant at Poles Lane, Otterbourne, Hants. The coins were declared Treasure Trove at an Inquest held on 23 January 1981.108 coins were found in a nucleus, and 41 scattered in the same area. A further 6 were discovered on a subsequent occasion. Nearly all the coins from the scatter were clipped, showing that clipped coins had been added after the rest of the hoard.The coins came from the same place as the 1978 Otterbourne Treasure Trove of 7 miliarenses and 543 [sic] siliquae. Unfortunately the exact findspot of the first hoard cannot be reliably ascertained, and all that is certain is that the two finds came from the same field. They cannot, however, represent two parts of the same hoard as their compositions are rather different..Then followed lists of the 155 sil. from the 1980 hoard, and of 530 out of the 536 sil. from the 1978 hoard. (The total of coins of Honorius in the 1980 hoard was given as 16 instead of 17, although 17 were actually catalogued, making a total of 155).."This table shows that the 1978 hoard cut off sharply after 388 (except for six coins of the late 390s from the Milan mint) and consequently had no [sic] clipped coins. The 1980 hoard however is rather later, and is typical of some of the latest Roman silver hoards from Britain with a lot of Milan coins and a large percentage of clipped coins. Although the practice of clipping cannot be certainly dated, it suggests a date in the second decade of the fifth century for the deposition of the 1980 hoard.The presence of the six later coins in the 1978 hoard makes the precise relationship of the two hoards acute: the six were clearly added several years after the bulk of the hoard was deposited, and as they are the sort of coins so plentiful in the 1980 hoard it is tempting to think that they might have been added by the owner of that hoard. But it does not seem possible to be certain whether the two hoards represent two entirely distinct hoards, or are two parts of the same person's property, laid down at different times..A.M. Burnett, in CHRB V, BM Occas. Paper 54 (1984), 119-24."Five further late Roman silver siliquae have been found, additional to the 155 already published. They were all clipped, and confirm the pattern of the earlier stray finds, most of which (unlike the nucleus of the hoard) were also clipped..A. Burnett, in CHRB IX (1992), 364.The combined totals of the 155 sil. from the 1980 hoard and the additional 5 sil., were:Trier Lyons Arles Milan Rome Aquileia Siscia@ t9Antioch 0TOTALJulian II, Caes. 2 02Julian II, Aug. 3 7 1 011Valentinian I 3 2 05Valens 15 1 1 017Gratian 13 1 014Valentinian II 6 2 1 2 011Theodosius 8 1 2 2 013Magnus Maximus 24 024Eugenius 6 1 3 010Arcadius 24 9 033Honorius 19 019Arcadius or Honorius 1 01RULE 0 RULE99 8 9 34 3 5 1 1 0160(1 cl., 1 b.)(1 cl.)(cl.)(2 cl.)(4 cl.)(4 cl.)(2 cl.)(2 cl.)(1 cl.)(1 cl.)(4 cl.) (b.)(1 cl.)(5 cl.)(8 cl.)(8 cl.)(1 cl.)(1 cl.)(2 cl.)(9 cl.)(5 cl., 1 b.)(14 cl.)(7 cl.)(7 cl.)(29 cl.)(1 b.)(1 cl., 1 b.)(13 cl., 1 b.)(2 cl.)(1 cl.)(46 cl.)A.M. Burnett, in CHRB V, BM Occas. Paper 54 (1984), 119-24, types, mints. wts., ills. of 3 coins; A. Burnett, in CHRB IX (1992), 364 (additional 5 coins)17 sil. in Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM (BM Register of Coin Accessions, Sept. 1981 (16 sil.): 1982-4-2-1 (1 sil.))6 sil. in Winchester City Museum [NB 1990 addenda 6 silver siliquae to AD 395 NB CHRB has 5]"

name: PAS: Chilham 823
comments: Robertson 2000, 312 no. 1285:""The only other antiquity known to have come from the barrow [i.e. Jullieberrie's Grave] is a pot containing a hoard of Constantinian coins which was found in the posthole made for the fence mentioned above. The site still lies in the line of the ditch, which doubtless still afforded some shelter even in Roman times."R.F. Jessup, in Ant. J., XVII (1937), 126Mr. Jessup added, in a letter, Dec. 1952, that the hoard "was found whilst sinking a post-hole for a fence in the early years of the nineteenth century, and the information was given to me by an antiquarian member of the family who married a daughter of the estate. At one time, probably about 1890-1900, some of the coins were in the hands of the owners of Chilham Castle, and some were later given to my informant who was an earlier Curator of Sir John Soane's Museum in Lincoln's Inn Fields. None were available when I wrote the Excavation Report and I am sure none exist now."The coins were probably small AE.Constantinian"

name: PAS: Rockbourne 829
comments: Robertson 2000, 361 no. 1:""A hoard of 16 gold solidi of Gratian, Valentinian II, Arcadius and Eugenius, terminating AD 394 is recorded."-Britannia, XVIII (1987), 348; from A.M. Burnett"The hoard of 16 late Roman gold solidi was found on 10-11 October 1986 at Toyd Corner, Rockbourne, Hampshire, about two miles away from the well-known late Roman villa. There was no trace of any container, and no other artefacts have been recovered from the immediate vicinity..A. Burnett, in CHRB VIII (1988), 228"Four more late Roman gold solidi were found in 1988-9 at the same site as the 16 already published in CHRB VIII, 228..A. Burnett, in CHRB IX (1992), 358Trier Lyon Milan Aquileia ConstantinopleGratian 1Valentinian II 5 2 1Theodosius I 2Arcadius 1 1 1Eugenius 4 2Total 10 4 4 1 1A. Burnett, in CHRB VIII (1988), 228; A. Burnett, in CHRB IX (1992), 358, types, mints, wts.All 20 solidi in Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM."Addenda of 4 gold solidi to AD 395.

name: PAS: Rowlands Hill 831
comments: Robertson 2000, 320 no. 1326:"Dr. H. Mattingly, Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM, had a note that he examined, in Sept. 1927, about 17 brass coins, said to have been found as a hoard at Rowland's Castle, Rowland's Hill:AEConstantine I 2Constantinopolis 1Constantius II, Aug. c.2Constans, Aug. c.2Constantius II, orConstans, Aug. c.8Magnentius 2c.17It is uncertain whether these coins formed the whole hoard.Letter, Dec. 1953, from F. Cottrill, Winchester City Museums, stating that "Rowland's Hill is a farm, just to the south of Rowland's Castle Village, at  [...]"."

name: PAS: Silchester 840
comments: G.C. Boon, 1974. Silchester, The Roman Town of Calleva, 312, no. 27, following J.G. Joyce, J of Excavs at Silchester, 7 Feb and 16 July 1874 (in Reading Museum), noted a "scattered hoard (also omitted from my NC, 1960 list): 330-41 (88); 341-8 (6); Gratian (1)." Presumably coins were AE.

name: PAS: Silchester (South Of Forum) 841
comments: In Reading Museum "8 third brass found stuck together in a house south of the Forum – no container". Hoard IV. G.C. Boon, NC 1960, 247f.

name: PAS: Silchester (Insula III) 842
comments: Another hoard of coins found at SE corner of Insula III. …coins contained in a broken pot & … were all of the later emperors." G.E. Fox 1892. Archaeologia 53, 284.  2 ant. & 34 small AE, very badly preserved. Single coin of Valens may be stray. Hoard VII, G.C. Boon. 1960, NC 1960, 251.

name: PAS: Hale 843
comments: 881 nummi to 337.The nummi were discovered apparently in two distinct groups separated by approximately 30cm. Most of the coins were found in-situ, whilst some were discovered in the plough soil in the immediate area however the two groups and the plough soil finds were not kept separate during the removal of the coins. No pottery was discovered in-situ, however the finder described seeing what looked like 'leather' at the bottom of the pile of coins, which disintegrated on contact. This suggests the coins were deposited in a leather bag or perhaps a wooden box. NC 2007, 42.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2006 T410Other PAS records associated with this hoard: LIN-BAA846

name: PAS: Silchester (Church?) 844
comments: During excav by I.A. Richmond, of Christian church at Silchester, "a group of 7 coins found in the ‘squatters' hollow’ near E end of nave. …absence of coins from gravel make-up is evidence that these coins were not casual scatter below building. …possibilities remain that they represent a) a hoard concealed in gravel make-up & scattered by delving of squatters; (b) hoard concealed in superstructure of the building & later scattered by falling; (c) they were unconnected with building, & were dropped casually by squatters or collected by them for reworking; or (d) they are purely residual relics whose presence is entirely fortuitous. S.S. Frere. 1975. Archaeologia 105, 287-90, 297-9, types by G.C. Boon; note by R. Reece A. King, OJA 2 (1983) 225-37, suggested building may have been a centre of an eastern cult rather than a Christian church – has features in common with pagan temples.

name: PAS: Colchester 845
comments: Robertson 2000, 277-278 no. 1167: "The Cut (fig. 1) represents a vase of peculiar form, found at Colchester, filled with coins of Constans; it is five inches high, of white clay, and most probably of Anglo-Roman pottery."-Review of Museum Disneianum (1846 and 1848), in AJ, VI (1849), 85 and fig. 1-The fig. was of a small unguent pot with deep external grooving.The coins were probably small AE."

name: PAS: Silchester 846
comments: Robertson 2000, 376 no. 1534:""In the autumn of 1985, for the first time in many years, one of the fields adjacent to and outside the presumed late Iron Age earthworks in Rampler Copse (Silchester) was ploughed up. Working with the permission of the landowner the area was scanned by metal detector and the gold finger-ring described below was found by Mr. J. Young who duly passed it to the Hampshire coroner. Although the findspot was not measured in at the time, it is reported as centering on [...], that is about 160 m south west of the south west angle of the Roman town of Calleva.The ring (FIG. 4, P1. XXII) is an elaborate and flamboyant piece of jewellery with a large engraved gem and filigree hoop formed of beaded gold wire. It has been severely crushed before or during burial, but the detail of the goldwork remains undamaged."The oval bezel of dark blue onyx has been engraved with a satyr standing left, holding out right hand to small cupid standing right: the satyr holds crook in left hand, and has cloak over left arm. The area of the intaglio measures 18 by 17 mm. The gold ring weighs 10.1 grammes, and the composition of the gold is 93.9% gold, 3.8% silver and 2.3% copper.Four late Roman silver coins were found at the same time and in the general vicinity of the ring. Although neither coins nor ring were found close together the possibility remains that, given their general contemporaneity, they originally formed part of a hoard, subsequently dispersed by the plough. The coins are identified as follows:Mil. Sil.Gratian 1Arcadius 1Arcadius (?) 1Honorius 11 3(pitted)(cl.)(pitted)The miliarense was very slightly worn, but badly clipped."If coins and ring were once associated, this would point to an early fifth-century date for the concealment of the collection."The gold ring is in Reading Museum and Art Gallery (no. 41.86)M.G. Fulford, M. Henig and Catherine M. Johns, in Britannia, XVIII (1987), 279-81, types, mints, fig. and p1. of gold ring"A hoard containing 51 silver siliquae and fragments of siliquae down to Honorius (c. AD 402) together with three bronze fourth-century coins and seven whole or broken rings is reported." Britannia, XIX (1988), 477; from A.M. Burnett"

name: PAS: Silchester 847
comments: During excav of forum, the laterally-divided room in same range was, acc. to Joyce, a banker's: here were found not only unusually large number of coins ranging from Claudius II to Valens, but also 'recesses' in W wall, into which strong-boxes could have been built. …the coins mentioned are prob. only a scattered hoard, & recesses may merely be a trace of a different period of building." …coins listed as "radiates (7), Constantinian (28), Valentinianic (4), rest 'worthless'. A silver Licinius is a rare piece." G.C. Boon. 1974. Silchester, The Roman Town of Calleva, 321, no. 14, following J.G. Joyce, J of Excavs at Silchester.

name: PAS: Allington 855
comments: Robertson 2000, 376-377 no. 1536:""In the spring of this year [i.e. 1869], a labourer, in sinking a ditch on the farm of Robert Palmer, Esq., at Allington, a few miles from this place [i.e. Southampton], turned up a portion of a Roman vessel, which was found to contain coins. The portion remaining was merely the bottom, and two or three inches of the side, and has the appearance of having been deposited in its present condition - certainly not showing any recent fracture."The coins were one gold solidus, and 53 sil:Sol. Sil.Julian II, Aug. 7Valentinian I 1Valens 7Gratian 3Theodosius 2Magnus Maximus 2Arcadius *1 8Honorius 13uncertain 101 53(1 broken)* The solidus had rev. VICTORIA AVGGG, m/m. S/MCOMOBR. Jennings, in NC, 1869, 372, types, mints"

name: PAS: Whitchurch 856
comments: "A small hoard of 48 siliquae was discovered by members of the Andover metal detecting club and submitted to the British Museum in February 1989. It was declared Treasure Trove at an Inquest on 13 March 1989 and the coins were subsequently returned to the finders..Trier Lyon Arles Rome Aquileia Milan Uncertain TotalConstantius II 1 1Julian 6 3 9Valentinian I 1 1 2Valens 4 4Gratian 2 1 3Valentinian II 1 1Theodosius I 2 2Magnus Maximus 2 2Flavius Victor 1 1Eugenius 3 2 5Arcadius 2 1 3Honorius 14 14Contemporary forgery 1 1RULETotal 16 6 4 1 2 16 3 48R Bland, in CHRB IX (1992), 361-3, types, mints, wts.

name: PAS: Winchester 862
comments: Robertson 2000, 345 no. 1413:""In sinking the foundation for the purpose of enclosing a portion of a field, adjoining the residence of the Rev. Mr. Rashleigh, near Hyde Abbey, two skeletons were discovered, but at a considerable distance from each other. One, in a tolerably perfect condition, was lying quite straight, looking towards the east, and apparently that of a young person of rather short stature. A musket bullet was found near the back. The other body, may, with strong probability, be referred to a much earlier period. It appeared to have been hastily interred in the chalk, about three feet below the surface, and close to the hip bone were twelve small brass Roman coins, several of them adhering together, of the common types of the Emperors, Valentinian, Valens, and Gratian."W.B., in Gent. Mag., 1843, II, 131"

name: PAS: Winchester 863
comments: Robertson 2000, 267-268 no. 1120:""A small hoard of Constantinian 'silvered' bronze was found late in 1946 at Winchester. The coins were all in fine condition and showed the original silvering almost intact. The earliest coin was of about AD 313, the latest of about AD 333.":FollesGalerius (deified) 1Constantine I 11Licinius I 2Licinius II 1Crispus 2Constantine II, Caes. 5Constantius II, Caes. 1Helena 1Fausta 3Constantinopolis 1Urbs Roma 230(1 GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand.)(SECVRITAS REIPVBLICE)(SALVS REIPVBLICAE)-H. Mattingly, in NC, 1946, 152f., types, mints"

name: PAS: Winchester 864
comments: During excavs on Assize Courts South site in 1963 & 1964, 2 small hoards found scattered on surface of the street, one of 17 coins of house of Constantine, & not lost before 341 or after 346; the other of 20 coins, the latest possible date being AD 355-60. M. Biddle. 1965. Antiquaries J. 45: 240, 242.

name: PAS: Winchester 865
comments: During excavs on Assize Courts South site in 1963 & 1964, 2 small hoards found scattered on surface of the street, one of 17 coins of house of Constantine, & not lost before 341 or after 346; the other of 20 coins, the latest possible date being AD 355-60. M. Biddle. 1965. Antiquaries J. 45: 240, 242.

name: PAS: Winchester, The Brooks I 867
comments: In 1987 the main Roman discoveries have been two substantial town houses facing on a north-south street beneath Middle Brook Street...The space between the two town houses was presumably a garden. Only one later Roman pit found in this area, but this contained a hoard of more than 50 coins, & a necklace made from beads of white and blue glass, amber, coral & poss ivory". (CBA Arch. in Britain 1987, 87f. The hoard consisted of small frag. bronze objects (prob. scrap metal), a necklace of amber, glass & ivory beads, & 90 coins. Hoard cannot have been deposited before AD 395. In a small pit dug up against wall of Building VIII.9, poss. after it was abandoned. Scobie, G.D., Zant, J.M. & Whinney, R. 1991. The Brooks, Winchester. A Preliminary report on the Excavations, 1987-88, pp. 30-31.

name: PAS: Catcote II 869
comments: 11 nummi to 325. PATAR 2007, 502; NC 2008, 32.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2007 T314Other PAS records associated with this hoard: NCL-637911

name: PAS: Plympton 870
comments: 81 nummi to 324. A further find of 116 nummi was discovered in 2012 and 5 more in April 2013. BNJ 2012, 37.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2011 T579; 2012 T672Other PAS records associated with this hoard: DEV-8A5096; BM-11FBD8

name: PAS: Hereford 873
comments: Robertson 2000, 362-363 no. 1492:""Inventory 3-10 A small hoard dug up in the garden of 40 Merryhill Crescent, Hunderton, Hereford, in 1953 [...] 7420"Then came a list of 8 coins, 2 ant. and 6 AE:Ant. AEClaudius II (deified) 1Tetricus I 1Constantine I 1Constantius II, Caes. 1Constantinopolis 1Theodora (after AD 337) 1Constans, Aug. 1Arcadius 12 6(GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand.)(GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand.)(VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN)(rev. illegible)M. name: PAS: Llangarren 876
comments: Robertson 2000, 259 no. 1084:""This hoard was found in December, 1912, whilst ploughing in a field on the Hill Farm, Llangarren. According to the finder the coins were contained in a pot which stood within two parallel rows of stones, two feet long, ten inches wide, and about eighteen inches in depth. The pot was smashed to pieces and only two fragments were preserved at the time. Unfortunately these were subsequently thrown away or lost. At this time negotiations for the purchase of the hoard failed; but in 1926 it was secured, as far as can be judged, in the same condition as that in which it was found. Some few of the coins may have gone astray, but the hoard may be taken as practically complete. The coins received numbered 2,810.The coins are all in good condition, some in excellent preservation, and many still retain traces of the silver wash."Then came a list of the 2810 coins, all AE.-J. Mill Stephenson, in NC, 1929, 334f., types, mints-More recently, the surviving coins from the hoard, 2721 in number, were re-examined by R.A.G. Carson and J.P.C. Kent, in NC, 1956, 82-161, types, mints, die axes, pls., XIV-XVI of coinsThe two lists, in NC, 1929, and in NC, 1956, are:1929 1956AE AEDiocletian 117 114Maximian 162 120Constantius I, Caes. 98* 28Constantius I, Aug. 59Constantius I (deified) 5Galerius, Caes. 122* 85Galerius, Aug. 24Severus II, Caes. 9* 8Severus II, Aug. 1Maximinus Daza, Caes. 106* 19Maximinus Daza, Aug. 88Maxentius 3Constantine I, Caes. 1906* 56Constantine I, Aug. 1821Licinius I 269 268Crispus 3 4Constantine II, Caes. 18 182810 2721* These totals are for all the coins of Constantius I, Galerius, Severus II, Maximinus Daza and Constantine I.The 18 coins of Constantine II, Caes. have revs. BEAT(A) TRANQ(VI)LITAS 7; CAESARVM NOSTRORVM VOT V 1; CAESARVM NOSTRORVM VOT X 2; PROVIDENTIAE CAESS 2; SOLI INVICTO COMITI 6.616 coins in Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM (BM Register of Coin Accessions, June 1927)Examined, 1948 (ASR)Most of the remainder, 2105, in Hereford City Museum"

Burnett examined the hoard, which was said to consist of 2473 regular coins (1 ant. and 2472 "folles") and 21 irregular coins. However, only 2466 regular coins were apparently catalogued (according to mints).Dr. A.M. Burnett, in CHRB I, BM Occas. name: PAS: Eastington 878
comments: The Gloc & District Archaeol. Research Group, carrying out salvage excavs on Whitminster Roman site, discovered sandstone mortar, brooches, pottery, isolated coins & "4th century coin hoard from presumed villa site." 9 coins in hoard, found with pottery vessel, 3 other coins surface finds. P.J. Fowler & C.V. Walthew 1971. Archaeology and the M5 motorway. Trans. Bristol & Glos. Arch. Soc. 90 (1971), 57-59.

name: PAS: Scarborough (Signal Station) 881
comments: Robertson 2000, 400 no. 1607: "On 5 July 1924, hoard of 57 Roman AE coins found during excav. of Roman signal station on Castle Hill, Scarborough. These were listed briefly by H.H.E. Craster, together with 92 other coins discovered as site finds during excavs. of 1921-4.AJ, LXXXIX (1932), 251-3, types. In 1939 the coins were acquired by Scarborough Museums. They comprised the hoard of 57 coins (or possibly 58 coins, depending on whether 3 coin fragments came from 1 or 2 coins), and 98 coins recorded as site finds. They were accompanied by notes from Dr. H. Mattingly, as well as by H.H.E. Craster. Re-examined, 1979 (ASR); and again in 1980-1 when most of them were cleaned in the Dept. of Archaeology, University of Glasgow (ASR). The coins from hoard were identified as: AEConstantinopolis 1Urbs Roma 1Constantius II, Aug. 1Constantius II, orConstans, Aug. 1Valentinian I 1Valentinian I or Valens 1Gratian 1Valentinian II 2House of Valentinian I 1Theodosius 1Theodosius (?) 3Arcadius 14Arcadius (?) 12Eugenius (?) 1Honorius 2Arcadius or Honorius 2"Theodosian" 12 or 13TRULE57 or 58(b.?)(b. FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman)(GLORIA ROMANORVM?)(cut down, SECVRITAS REIPVBLICAE)(bust bearded?)(including frags: 1 b.?).

name: PAS: Ashwell 882
comments: Robertson 2000, 261 no. 1093: "At Arbury Banks has been discovered a hoard of coins entirely of Constantine II in mint condition."-W.P. Westell, in JBAA, n.s., XXXVIII (1932), 266-"[The hoard was] found just before the war [i.e., pre-1914]. That unfortunately is all we can find out about the time of the find. A ploughman turned up a pot and, hearing money inside, smashed the pot and carried home the coins, hoping they were of value. He kept it a secret for some time, and when eventually he showed them to a friend of mine, who told him they were worth only a few pence, he gave them to my friend, who in turn gave them to Ashwell Museum. The pot of course was never traced. The coins are in almost mint state."-Letter, 1937, from A.W. Sheldrick, Ashwell Village Museum.-The coins given to Ashwell Museum were 11 small AE:AEConstantine I 1Constantine II 1011 The coins have since been incorporated in the general coin collection in Ashwell Museum. It seems uncertain whether these 11 coins formed the whole hoard."

name: PAS: Chorleywood 889
comments: Robertson 2000, 292-3 no. 1234: ""The hoard was found on 21 April 1977 during the construction of a new reservoir at Stag Lane, Chorleywood, Hertfordshire. The hoard has now been dispersed, although the landowner kindly presented 446 pieces (including all the imitations) to the Verulamium Museum, St. Albans, and 244 to the British Museum.The hoard was found with a pot, and I am grateful to Adrian Havercroft of the Verulamium Museum for providing the accompanying drawing and comments. In all nine pieces of pottery were recovered with the hoard. There is no reason to suggest that they belong to more than one vessel, indeed seven of them join to form a base (Fig. 110: 1). The remaining two sherds are considerably thinner in section and are from the upper wall of the vessel.The ware is of medium hardness, with orange-surfaces and has an extremely coarse grey core. Throughout it is tempered with large, hard, light-dark grey grog, with occasional fine black inclusions and (?) flint. The surviving portion of the vessel is well made and indicates a flat base and marked internal rilling of the lower wall. In addition the internal surface is slightly vesiculated. In general terms however the base shows no signs of wear. The edges of several sherds indicate 'old breaks' and there is little doubt that the vessel was cracked 'in situ' prior to its discovery."A. Havercroft continued his comments by suggesting that the potsherds came from a large jar with a deep, out-turned undercut rim. He compared the form with similar potsherds from the Roman Theatre at Verulamium; Gadebridge; the kiln site at Radlett; and the Roman bath-house at Branch Road, St Albans (cp. Fig. 111: 2). "It can therefore be said that whilst a mid-fourth century usage is proven, the ware may have a long life beginning certainly no later than the mid-Antonine period."A.M. Burnett examined 4089 coins from the hoard (all AE "folles"), 248 irregular coins and 21 fragments, and catalogued them according to mints.A.M. Burnett, in CHRB I, BM Occas. Paper 5 (1979), 41-98, mints, types, officinae, discussion of Constantinian coinage, of c. AD 330-7, figs. of potsherdsRearranged according to emperors, etc, the 4089 regular coins were:Tr. Ly. Ar. name: PAS: Hemel Hempstead (Gadebridge Park) 890
comments: During excavs at Gadebridge Park Villa in 1968, NW of bathing pool "Besides the large number of nails there were 173 bronze coins, mostly House of Constantine; none later than AD 353, found mainly in lowest river gravels, but some of contemporary date also found in black earth over it. Even though this layer ran over primary fill of bathing pool, the coins were only found N of pool, & therefore became dispersed by water action from layer below. Also found in these two layers, but mainly in L8 were frags of 15 bronze bracelets, 11 bronze rings, frags of 4 bronze penannular brooches, 2 toilet tweezers, a frag of silvered bronze mirror, a bronze spoon, numerous frags of worked bronze & several broken iron knives. It is unlikely that coins represent a scattered hoard, because it is improbable that such a large group of trinkets would have been associated with them [!!]; finds poss. tribute to a water deity.  "A further 173 coins are suggested as being the dispersed contents of a votive deposit found in one-time waterlogged levels NW of bathing pool, although possibility of this group of coins being dispersed hoard should not be ignored." The 173 coins (10 ant. & 163 AE) listed by P.E. Curnow according to rev. types. The latest regular coin was 1 of Magnentius of AD 351-3. D.S. Neal. 1974. Research Rep. Soc. Ant. 31. Excavation of the Roman Villa in Gadebridge Park, Hemel Hempstead 1963-8, 73; P.E. Curnow, ibid., 101, 105-7, 115-17. Site now underneath a major arterial road.

name: PAS: Kings Langley I 894
comments: A Valentinianic hoard in Mainz said to be from Kings Langley. It is thought probable that this is the same hoard as hoard 45 but this cannot be verified and so separate records have been maintained.

name: PAS: Llangaffo 936
comments: `2 gold coins of Constantine I. Several copper and silver coins of [Constantine I] were found with them.' A Llwyd, A History of the Island of Mona or Anglesey, Ruthin, 1833, p. 270 ([Llangaffo] `Two gold coins of Constantine's, in good preservation, were found near the church in the year 1829, and several copper and silver coins of that emperor and others, have been found in the parish.') = Griffiths 1948, p. 110 citing Llwyd, History of Mona, 1833, p. 270 = Baynes, Trans. Anglesey Antiq. Soc., 1929, p. 25 = IARCW 1128 (`2 solidi found near Llangaffo Church in 1829. 'Several copper and silver coins of [Constantine I]., and others' were found with them.') = Gwynedd Archaeological Trust HER PRN 2620

name: PAS: Fenny Stratford 937
comments: On 9 July 1962 a hoard of 4th C. coins found during excavs in a 4th C. building site along & to S of Watling Street adjacent to Magiovinium. The coins were probably orig. contained in a bag as metal clasp with them. At time of discovery the excavator (R.W. Griffiths) stated there were c. 251 loose coins & conglomerate of c. 400 more. The hoard sent to Ashmolean Museum where an attempt was made to separate corroded mass into individual elements but without much success & a sig. no. of coins remained fused. A summary report of the hoard's contents was sent to excavators. In 1984 coins were again brought to the Ashmolean Museum for examination. At that time 306 pieces could be isolated & listed. The general condition of the coins was very poor - many were totally illegible or partially so. In initial report it was suggested that coins may have been orig. fused together as result of fire which also caused cup-shape form of some pieces, & that in some cases the side of the coins seems almost to have melted away. This hoard is composed almost entirely of ancient copies to which a few of the very common coins of 330 to 348 were added. This hoard consists of pieces of the lowest possible value & thus either the better quality pieces have been excluded or never came into the possession of the hoarder. It seems unlikely that the hoard would have been buried before AD 354-355. Cathy E. King, in CHRBVII, BM Occas. Paper 59 (1987), 181-6. Records of Bucks: Journal of Architect & Archaeol Society for County of Buckinghamshire 1961-5 17: 411 1971 19 (1): 93. Pastscape: A further 627 coins from hoard were found in 1987. HER: Watling Street/Galley Lane Junction. 251 loose & a conglom. of about 400, a corroded mass, perhaps caused by fire. May have been in bag: metal clasp found with them, in ‘temple’ area. Griffiths, R.W. 1967. Fenny Stratford hoard, found 9 July 1962. Wolverton & Dist Arch Soc Newsletter 11: 27-28.

name: PAS: Penrhos 938
comments: Robertson 2000 no. 1159: ""I must not omit in this place that a great quantity of Roman coins have been taken up lately (AD 1710) in this parish some of them as clear as if they had been stamped within these 10 years: their heads were Constantine, Constantius, Helena, Augustus [sic], H. Jul. Constantius, Constantinopolis, Crispus, Caius, Licinius, Licinianus, Fausta, Augusta, Julius Crispus and perhaps some others that are lost."-S. Lewis, in Cambrian Register, III (1818), 216f.-The coins were probably all AE."Guest and Wells (no. 1139 p.363) list 29 coins of a number from a brass container to AD 330-341.

name: PAS: Holyhead Mountain 939
comments: The completion of excavs. on the summit of the mountain confirmed that the structure there was a tower 5.45m square with 1.2m [thick] walls on 1.5m footings. There is no firm evidence for construction date, but this prob. in 4th C. Coins include a small hoard deposited c. 395 & a clipped siliqua. …structure best interpreted as a watch tower, which probably operated in conjunction with fortlet at Holyhead." Britannia 13 (1982), 328. …the recent discovery of a small hoard buried in the mid-390s close to a square masonry tower of uncertain (but most likely late Roman) date on the summit of Holyhead Mountain. This hoard comprises the latest coins from Anglesey and they are presumably military in origin." J.L. Davies. 1983. Arch. Camb. 132, 90, n. 73, referring to "Crew, P. Holyhead Mountain Roman Watch Tower. Interim Report on the 1980-1 Excavations (1981). Privately printed."); R.G. Livens, "Roman coastal defences in North Wales, Holyhead Mountain & Caergybi", in Studien zu den militärgrenzen Roms III, 13 Internationaler Limeskongress, Aalen 1983 (1986), 58f., added: "A hoard of 15 coins datable to 390s AD also found, either overlaid by, or incorporated in, the collapsed masonry of the superstructure".

name: PAS: Shorwell I 943
comments: Robertson 2000, 338 no. 1382:""The second find was in Limerstone Down, where, about a mile from the Shorwell end of the bridle-path along the ridge, a bank with a ditch to the west crosses it from north to south.Here, about Christmas 1932, gravel-digging on the south side of the down revealed Roman pottery and coins. It also showed the bank to have been a substantial one and the ditch 9 feet wide at the top and more than 4 feet deep. The bottom of the ditch was not reached and nothing was found in it or the bank, but in a depression near the top of the bank Mr. W. Flux, the gravel-digger who first noticed the sherds and coins found a large part of an undoubted Roman bowl, which goes to show that the bank is not later than the Roman period. Eastward of the bank a terrace of the original soil had been left by a previous gravel-digging, and it was from the thin layer of earth here that the bulk of the finds came. They include potsherds, a lump of lead, rings, a buckle and a socketed knife or sickle of iron, and 22 coins, mostly fourth century, with two worn survivals from the second. As Mr. Pritchett and I found 14 of them within a small area, they probably represent a hoard lost about the end of the fourth century, the latest legible specimens being four of the Valentinian dynasty (364-383 AD)"G.A. Sherwin, in Proc. I.O.W. Nat. Hist. and Ant. Soc., II (1930-7), 323f.The Rev. E. A. Sydenham described the find as "a small hoard of 22 bronze coins ranging from Constantine to Valens (AD 307-378), also two worn coins of Hadrian and M. Aurelius (?), probably not belonging to the hoard."Proc. I.O.W. Nat. Hist. and Ant. Soc., III (1938-45), 386"

name: PAS: Calbourne 945
comments: 2 solidi and 2 siliquae to 402. BNJ 2012, 48.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2011 T182Other PAS records associated with this hoard: IOW-099F52

name: PAS: Fishbourne Beach 946
comments: "A scatter of 71 fourth century billon and bronze coins was found in a shingle bank on the eastern side of the mouth of the creek at Fishbourne Beach, Wootton Creek, Isle of Wight, over a period of several months during the winter of 1987-1988, by metal detector user Mr Tom Winch. All of the coins found were taken to the Isle of Wight County Council Archaeological Unit for study. The coins were located in an area of about twenty square metres, in the intertidal zone, just below the high water mark. There was no trace of a container. Other finds from the same area include Roman glassware, pottery and a probable kiln of the Roman period, a Claudian copy (reverse Minerva), an as of Nero (RIC (2) 543 or 545), and three sestertii of Hadrian (BMC 1636) and Antoninus Pius (BMC 1656 and 1705). Investigations at the site by the Archaeological Unit are continuing with the aid of a grant from Sealink UK..House of Constantine 4Constans, Aug 1Constantius II, Aug or Constans, Aug 3Magnentius 1Gratian 3Valentinian II 1House of Valentinian 25Theodosius I 2Arcadius 1Magnus Maximus 22Uncertain 8Total 71K. Butcher, in CHRB IX (1992), 356f., types, mints

name: PAS: Ryde 952
comments: Robertson 2000, 377 no. 1537:""In cutting the railway line from Ryde to Newport, Isle of Wight, at Haven Street, the workmen dug up a hoard of small brass Roman coins, which by the energy of Mr. F. Roach, were secured by Dr. Barrow for the Museum of the Ryde Literary and Philosophical Society. It will suffice to say they are mostly of Theodosius, Arcadius, and Honorius, with the usual admixture of coins of preceding emperors back to the epoch of the Constantine family. The only coin of rarity which we noticed is a Magnus Maximus with the reverse SPES ROMANORVM; a castrum, in exergue PCON."C. Roach Smith, in NC, 1874, 352The Museum of the Ryde Literary and Philosophical Society was closed some years ago, and the contents dispersed.5 coins from this hoard were in Carisbrooke Castle Museum, Newport:AEValentinian II 1Eugenius 1Honorius (?) 1"Theodosian" 25(SALVS REIPVBLICAE 1; VICTORIA AVGGG 3; uncertain 1)Examined, 1960 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Shalfleet 960
comments: 2 solidi (Eugenius, 1; Arcadius, 1);7 siliquae (Honorius, 5; Arcadius or Honorius, 2, all of AD 394-402). Found by metal detectorist Mr Peter Peach, August 2003. Frank Basford writes: I have now visited the site with Mr Peach and have recorded the findspots very precisely using our GPS. All the coins were found together within an area defined by using a radius of 14 metres. Unfortunately I was not able to see other artefacts in the soil due to the presence of weeds and stubble. However, the nearest Roman artefact recorded on the SMR is about 600m from this site.' Report on the coins by Malcolm Lyne. AD 393-5 (1)1. Eugenius, rev.: VICTOR-iA AVGG, Two emperors std. facing; in field: L D; in exergue: COM, RIC IX Lyon 45, 4.47g AD 394-402 (1)2. Arcadius, rev.: VICTOR-IA AVGGG, Emperor stg. r., in field: M D; in exergue: COMOB, RIC IX Milan 35(b) = RIC X 1205, 4.43g. TAR 2003, 382.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2003 T185Other PAS records associated with this hoard: IOW-9FD543

E. Kell, in JBAA, VIII (1853), 329, gave the date of discovery as 1833.16 coins from this hoard, 1 ant. and 15 small AE, are in Carisbrooke Castle Museum, Newport:Ant. AEClaudius II (deified) 1House of Valentinian I 1Theodosius 1Arcadius 1Honorius 3 "Theodosian" 91 15(SALVS REIPVBLICAE 8 (1 b.?); VICTORIA AVGGG 5 )The 6 "den." were of course sil.Examined, 1960 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Vindolanda 962
comments: Robertson 2000, 321 no. 1330:""It is also worthy of remark that all these large, broad-bedded stones had a luis hole in their upper surface, by which they had been raised to the top of the wall, and that upon and about one of them belonging to this gateway 300 small brass coins, mostly of Constantius and Magnentius, but a few of Constantine II and Constans were found not in a heap, or a vessel but dispersed among the soil, evidently after the cordon stones of the tower had fallen from its top, and very probably some 70 or 80 years before the supposed date of the Notitia in 450, which authority garrisons the fourth cohort of the Gauls here at that time."J. Hodgson, Hist. of Northumberland, Part II (1840), Vol. III, 196J. Collingwood Bruce, Roman Wall, 2 ed. (1853), 415, gave 1833 as the date of discovery"

In Andover Museum."C. Lockhart, General Hist. of the I.O.W., Suppl. to B.B. Woodward and T.C. Wilks, Hist. of Hants. name: PAS: Wroxall 971
comments: Robertson 2000, 378 no. 1540:""I have much pleasure in sending the following notes respecting a jar of coins lately discovered in one of the cuttings of the Ryde and Ventnor Railway in this island.The coins were discovered on September the 25th, 1863, near the village of Wroxall, at the south of the island. They were all enclosed in a jar of coarse earthenware, which was buried about five feet below the surface of the ground. The jar was surrounded by a rubble wall of loose stones. The locality was the side of a steep rise near the fountain-head of a strong spring. The jar was broken by the stroke of a pick, and many of the coins were tipped into the railway embankment before it occurred to anybody to secure them. The number of coins in the jar was very great, probably amounting to 5,000. All of these that I have seen were of copper, and most of them exceedingly shabby. I should think that four-fifths of the whole number were quite blank, and hardly one in twenty presented any reliable face or inscription."Coins of the following emperors were identified:- Claudius II, Constantius (II?), Constans, Valens, Gratian, Valentinian II, Theodosius and Arcadius.W. Airy, in NC, 1863, 268J.A. Barton, of Southampton, stated that "although the number of coins turned up from the soil is said to have been very large, they have been so dispersed among the labourers and cottagers of the neighbourhood, that only a few hundreds remain in the possession of the overseer of the works." This "residue" was examined by Barton, and found to consist of 5 ant. and over 240 small AE:Ant. AEGallienus 1Claudius II 1Tetricus I 3Crispus 1Constantine II, Caes. 3Helena 1Constantius II, Aug. 9Valentinian I 6Valens 8Gratian 2Theodosius 3Arcadius and Honorius 200"Gate type" 3"broken and oxidised" "a great number"5 236 or moreor more (chiefly SALVS REIPVBLICAE) J.A. Barton, in Gent. Mag., 1864, I, 88In 1933, B.H.St.J. O'Neil examined 463 coins from this hoard, preserved in Carisbrooke Castle Museum, Newport, with the comment:-"It seems likely that the collection about to be described is this 'residue' [i.e. the 'residue' mentioned by Barton in Gent. Mag., 1864, 1, 88], as it was termed, bereft of nearly all its earlier coins, and many, also, of the larger fourth-century issues. Those which remain are almost all of 4 AE size, and in a very poor condition, representing the dregs of the largest recorded hoard of its kind.":Ant. AETetricus I 1Constantine I 1Urbs Roma 1Constantius II, or Constans, Aug. 1House of Constantine I 3House of Constantine I, or of Valentinian I 10Valentinian I 2Valentinian II 3House of Valentinian I 3Theodosius 7Maximus or Victor 1Arcadius 13Honorius 7Honorius (?) 1"Theodosian" 149uncertain 4th cent. 110frag.s c.1501 462(GLORIA EXERCITVS, 1 stand.)(1 overstruck)(1 overstruck)B.H.St.J. O'Neil, in NC, 1933, 220-2, types, mints; Proc. I.O.W. Nat. Hist. and Ant. Soc., II (1930-7), 299-310, types, mintsThe "Theodosian" coins included 22 with SALVS REIPVBLICAE, and 79 with VICTORIA AVGGG.20 other coins from this hoard were presented, 1963-4, to Leeds City Museum."

name: PAS: Great Witcombe Roman Villa 976
comments: In 1938, during excav. of Roman villa at Great Witcombe, 8 coins of Valentinian I & Valens found in fill of hypocaust after it had ceased functioning." JRS 1939. 29: 217. Letter, Sept. 1963, from E.M. Clifford, stated coins did not constitute a hoard.  Clifford, E.M. 1954. The Roman Villa, Witcombe Glos. Trans. Bristol & Glos Arch Soc 73: 5-69.

name: PAS: Watercrook Roman fort 977
comments: Roman fort at Watercrook S of Kendal was excav by Potter in 1975-5. In square stone guard chamber to NE gate of fort, one charcoal rich layer sandwiched in between 2 occupation layers/phases of use contained a ‘large quantitity of objects’ incl. pottery, bronze finger ring, arrowhead, calthrops, iron lock & building fittings, a surgical probe, & 4 coins close together. These dated to post-AD 268-273, & were of Claudius II, radiate copies of Victorinus, & Tetricus I. T.W. 1979. Romans in North-west England. Excavations at the Roman Forts of Ravenglass, Watercrook, and Bowness-on-Solway, pp. 158-160, figs. 60-61.

name: PAS: Richborough 978
comments: "hoard of 875 bronze coins, found on Sept 1st, 1931, at level within Roman fort of Richborough. The evidence of the finder is that the coins, found in a mass, were unaccompanied by any trace of purse, box or other container & showed no sign of having been secreted in a hole in a wall or in thatch. The corrosion of some of coins & traces of wood-fibre (?) on them suggest possible burial in a box with iron bands. The site on which coins found seems to have carried a hut, with foundation course of large rough pieces of Folkstone stone. The coins lay near an angle of this foundation, as they might if buried under a hearth. The general level of the site has yielded pottery of late 3rd to 4th C. date. H. Mattingly and W.P.D. Stebbing 1938. NNM 80. R. Reece. 1968. Research Rep. Soc. Ant. 26: 191. J.A. Davies, in BNJ 52 (1982), 17-26, re-investigated the 1931 Richborough hoard along with other more recent radiate hoards. Coins at a level within the Roman fort of "Richborough, which had been dated to the same age as the walls." Some of the coins said to show signs of burning. This is area XXII in Cunliffe 1968, 28 fig 11. The hoard was buried just to the south of a gully cutting through earlier ovens and with a silver ingot in its terminal, apparently in a layer of daub from an adjacent structure (although this could also be the context for hoard 1022).Cunliffe 1968, 28-29.

name: PAS: Caerleon (Fortress Baths 2) 979
comments: Six coins found partly fused on the site of the Fortress Baths during reconstruction work in 1982.

name: PAS: Richborough 981
comments: Robertson 2000, 381-382 no. 1551A:"In 1932, a hoard of c. 5000 late fourth century AE coins was presented to the Maidstone Museum. In 1957, Miss Elizabeth Pirie, Maidstone Museum, learned from W.P.D. Stebbing that he remembered hearing of the hoard turning up at Richborough (in 1932?), and that it was not directly connected with the site. Letter from Elizabeth Pirie, Aug. 1957In Dec. 1988, D.B. Kelly, Maidstone Museum, stated, in a letter, that the hoard had been presented to the Museum by Mrs. Routledge in 1932, and according to the Museum gazetteer had been found at Richborough by Canon Routledge. (There was a Canon Routledge at Canterbury, who died in 1904.)D.B. Kelly counted the coins, and made the total c. 4000. He also noted that out of a few hundreds sorted and identified some time ago, there were 8 antoniniani (3 irregular), and AE coins from the reign of Constantine I to Honorius (including about 80 coins of Arcadius and 20 of Honorius, all with the SALVS REIPVBLICAE or VICTORIA AVGGG rev.)."

name: PAS: Richborough (Area X) 982
comments: In 1928, a hoard "found in NE of Area X contained 364 coins, 92 per cent of those legible being Theodosian." The coins were 4 ant. and 360 small AE. J.P. Bushe-Fox & W.P.D. Stebbing. 1949. Research Rep. Soc. Ant. 16: 276, 278. In the north-east of area X (in the southern centre of the fort), no detail of context.

name: PAS: Richborough (Area XVII) 983
comments: 168 coins in rather poor condition." Letter, Jan. 1938, from B.W. Pearce. R. Reece. 1981. Bull. Inst. Arch. London 18: 69f. Reece labels as from area XVII/32 W Ext. XVII/32 seems to have covered the Chalk House and the area to the S of it.

name: PAS: Richborough (Pit 180) 984
comments: Hoard. Pit 180. Top". 91 coins, 4 ant. & 87 small AE. J.P. Bushe-Fox & W.P.D. Stebbing. 1949. Research Rep. Soc. Ant. 16: 99, where no. of coins is given as 83; & 276, 279. R. Reece. 1981. Bull. Inst. Arch., London 18: 70f, gives total as 95. Top of pit 180, in area XVI "cut through the road or path over the Claudian ditches, and was only cleared to the level of the bottom of the latter". This large pit is visible on the plan on Plate XCVI of Bushe-Fox 1949.Bushe-Fox 1949, 99.

name: PAS: Richborough (Pit 220) 985
comments: Pit 220 cut through fill of inner ditch on N side of 3rd C. earth fort.  A shallow pocket in mouth of pit contained hoard of 85 Theodosian coins, 1 ant. & 84 AE. J.P. Bushe-Fox & W.P.D. Stebbing. 1949. Research Rep. Soc. Ant. 16: 104, 276, 279. Pit 220 cut through the filling of the inner ditch on the north side of the third-century earth fort. It was 9 feet deep and 3 ft 2 inches in diameter, with third century coins at the bottom. A shallow pocket in the mouth of the pit contained a hoard of Theodosian coins.The position of the pit can be seen in Plate XCIX in the back of Bushe-Fox 1949.Bushe-Fox 1949, 104.

name: PAS: Richborough (Pit 98) 986
comments: Pit 98 in area XI. In top 5 ft. were 65 coins, a hoard of Theodosian period." 3 sil., 1 ant. & 62 AE. J.P. Bushe-Fox & W.P.D. Stebbing. 1949. Research Rep. Soc. Ant. 16: 87, 276, 279. Pit 98 in area XI, dug through the filling of the inner ditch of the third-century earth fort - in the top 5 feet of the pit. [NB described as pit 28 in Reece]. The pit was 17 feet deep in total and the bottom 5 feet were lined with stones. The contents included ceramic sherds, a comb, a bronze pin and two bone pins, as well as portions of two bone armlets. Position marked on Plate XCIX of Bushe-Fox 1949.Bushe-Fox 1949, 87.

name: PAS: Richborough (S Of Chalk House) 987
comments: R. Reece, following B.W. Pearce's manuscript & typescript lists of Roman coins found at Richborough in 1931-8, recorded "Hoard II South of Chalk House". 124 coins. Reece noted "no information available as to which individual coins formed this hoard. R. Reece. 1968. Research Rep. Soc. Ant. 23: 190.

name: PAS: Richborough (S Of Site IV) 989
comments: R. Reece, following B.W. Pearce's manuscript & typescript lists of Roman coins found at Richborough in 1931-8, recorded the following hoard: "Hoard I South of Site IV". 96 coins. Reece noted no information available as to which individual coins formed this hoard. R. Reece. 1968. Research Rep. Soc. Ant. 23: 189-91.

name: PAS: Richborough (W Of Site I) 990
comments: In 1926 during excav. of Saxon Shore fort, "Theodosian hoard found to W of site I.  The coins came from small pit about 3 ft. 6 in. in diameter cutting through & extending 3 ft. below surface of a heavily burnt layer. As they were found scattered in the soil they must have been in either a box, or bag of perishable material." The coins were 1 "first brass", 12 ant. & 1189 AE. J.P. Bushe-Fox & G.C.F. Hayter. 1932. Research Rep. Soc. Ant. 10: 34, 188-93. To the west of site I (within stone fort & outside ditches of the earth fort). The coins came from a small pit about 3 ft. 6 in. in diameter cutting through and extending 3 ft. below the surface of the heavily burnt layer (consisting of burnt wattle and daub buildings). The pit also contained ceramic vessels, thin glass, an iron hinge and 40 iron nails.Bushe-Fox 1932, 34

name: PAS: Aylesford 995
comments: Robertson 2000, 346 no. 1416:""A short time since, a labourer digging upon the hill above Kit's Coty House turned up an urn containing about 100 small brass Roman coins nearly all of which were obtained by Mr. Humphrey Wickham of Strood."The coins were 1 or 2 ant. and 96 or 97 small AE:Ant. AETetricus 1-2House of Constantine I 19-20Magnentius 1Valentinian I 20Valens 41Gratian 151-2 96-97C. Roach Smith, in NC, 1853, 59, some types, mints"

name: PAS: Stanley 996
comments: Robertson 2000, 280 no. 1181:""At Smalley Bight Farm, Stanley, near Wakefield, a ploughman at work in one of the fields turned up an earthenware vase, and exposed to view a large number of bronze coins. The vase, which was scarcely two feet below the surface of the ground, was, unfortunately, broken to pieces."-F. Haverfield, in Antiquary, XLI (1905), 455-7198 coins were collected from the broken pot, of which 4844, all AE, were:Constantine I 754Licinius I 3Constantia 1Licinius II 1Crispus 1Constantine II, Caes. 1125Constantius II, Caes. 674Helena (before AD 337?) 3Theodora (?) 3Constantinopolis 840Urbs Roma 1323Constans, Caes. 32Delmatius 3Constantius Gallus 1uncertain 804844(?)"The five rude or exceptional semi-barbaric coins found in the hoardare British imitations of Roman coins. These form a portion of the sixty specimens presented by Mrs. Wheatley to the Museum [i.e. the Leeds City Museum]."-A. Dodgson in Thoresby Soc. Misc., XV (1905-9), 103-10, types, mints,-These 60 coins are believed to have been on exhibition during the 1939-45 War, and to have been scattered beyond recovery when the Leeds City Museum received a direct hit by bombs.15 coins in Hull City Museum, and a few others in Wakefield Museum.Examined, 1938 (ASR)In view of the fact that there was no other coin in the hoard, so far as recorded, later than the reign of Constantine I, it seems likely that the single coin attributed to Constantius Gallus, was either wrongly identified, or came from some other source."

name: PAS: Armathwaite 1007
comments: Robetson 2000, 246-247 no. 1014:"3 May 1759"Mr. Lock communicated an Extract of a Letter addressed to him by Willm Milbourne Esq. wherein he acquainted him, that he had lately got 20 Roman Coins that were found within a Mile of his Seat, at Armathwaite Castle in Cumberland; they are all of Copper, 18 of them Constantinus, & 2 of Licinius."-Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., VIII (1757-62), 155"

name: PAS: Canterbury (Hythe Road) 1008
comments: Robertson 2000, 259 no. 1086:""On 31 October 1956 at the limeworks of Messrs. Frank Cooper, Ltd., in south Canterbury a hoard of 107 coins was found in what may be an ancient flint-mine shaft, nine feet from the top of the shaft. The coins were found scattered and the container, whatever it may have been, was presumably broken in the course of work in removing chalk."The coins were 1 ant. and 106 AE.Ant. AEProbus 1Constantine I 52Crispus 27Constantine II, Caes. 271 106(1 slightly irregular, BEATA TRANQVILLITAS)-R.A.G. Carson, in NC, 1957, 249-57, types, mints, die axes.-The site of the limeworks was said in JRS, XLVII (1957), 225, to be in Hythe Road, south of Canterbury. (For Canterbury 1956a, see no. 882.)107 coins in Royal Museum, Canterbury"

name: PAS: Canterbury 1010
comments: W of area excav. in Marlowe Theatre car park, 5 ft. of a series of undisturbed deposits from pre-Roman to early 5th C. were excavated: at the base, two Belgic levels, the lower containing 2 speculum coins & bronze of Dubnovellaunus, the upper containing Arretine & other imported pottery; above this, a series of clay floors belonging to timber buildings of Roman date, superseded in 2nd C. by a masonry structure with 2 tessellated floors at right-angles, the last forming part of the building discovered in the Rose Hotel yard; early in 4th C. century this adapted for a bath-wing, the hypocaust of caldarium being in a state of decay caused by firing without proper maintenance, & therefore long in use. In the debris, a scattered hoard of 80 worn coins, one at least of Arcadius, seems to take the occupation into 5th C." JRS 1958. 48: 149.

name: PAS: Canterbury 1011
comments: Hoard of late Roman silver found in 1962 during construction of road bridge close to angle of defences c. 70 ft SW of  London Gate, just outside line of city wall (sited from plan). Hoard consisted of 11 silver spoons, a silver implement with a prong, a gold hook & eye fastening, a silver pin, a gold ring, & 2 unstamped silver ingots. There were 8 coins of period AD 254-393/410 in vicinity but impossible to prove a direct connection. 5 more objects from same hoard were declared to authorities in 1983. They were 2 stamped silver ingots, a long-handled silver spoon, & 2 clipped silver siliquae. The clipped siliquae imply date after AD 410 for hoard. K.S. Painter. 1965. JBAA 28: 1-15. T.W.E. Potter & C.M. Jones. 1984. Arch Cant 99: 283-6.

name: PAS: Canterbury (Augustine House) 1016
comments: Site code AHRTC EX 07. Various contexts considered as Treasure - more than one hoard / successive deposition? 4 groups from 4 contexts identified (2 from pit fills & 2 from fill of polygonal enclosure ditch).

name: PAS: Canterbury (St. George's St. Bath Building) 1017
comments: The excavators, under supervision of S.S. Frere were working on clearance of Roman building at No. 6 St George's Street. It was a bath-house, with evidence of use from 2nd to 4th C. AD. In one room (No. 7), identified as an undressing-room, 261 coins found in about one-third of the room, where strat. was undisturbed. Mr. Frere and the writer are certain that coins cannot at any time have been a hoard. They were found singly, not in lumps, in crevices of & on flagged floor of the room. A thick layer of debris from collapse of building, lay upon floor & coins. The natural conclusion is that coins lost singly, by patrons of baths, whilst undressing in room. The 261 coins include 64 legitimate issues, 62 barbarous copies, 33 minimi, 60 small enough to be dubbed minimissimi, and 42 whole or fragmentary illegible coins of normal size. B.H.St.J. O'Neil. 1948. NC: 226-9. S.S. Frere & Sally Stow, in Arch. of Cant. 7 (1983), 34f., gave list of coins, & added of the room: "Perhaps it was the apodyterium, but more likely it was a room where gambling took place, for these coins were scattered all over the surviving portion of the floor; they had not been concealed. They might, however, conceivably have formed part of a hoard concealed in roof, which fell and scattered when building caught fire." Also "it is quite possible that 2 later coins in the group (Valens & Arcadius) are subsequent casual losses which sank into the ash."

name: PAS: Canterbury (Whitefriars) 1018
comments: 25 radiates and 673 nummi to 402. NC 2007, 52Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2006 T416Other PAS records associated with this hoard: KENT-0B9548

name: PAS: Hougham Without 1022
comments: 2 solidi (Magnus Maximus and Honorius). Roman coin found near St Radigund's. A 4th Century coin found, by metal detector. Field inspection and previous arch. work in the area suggests that there is not a LRB settlement in the area, an isolated find. A second coin, a solidus of Magnus Maximus, was subsequently found by the same metal detector user, Mr Phipps. The discovery of two solidi, struck within 20 years of each other, in the same field suggests strongly that this is likely to be a small hoard . Both coins were acquired by the owner of the land, Mr Moyle, and are now on loan in Dover Museum. AD 383-88 (1) 1. Magnus Maximus, rev.: RESTITVTOR-REI PVBLICAE, Emperor stg. facing, head r.; in l. field: *; exergue: SMTR, RIC Trier 76, 2, 4.5gAD 394-402 (1) 2. Honorius, rev.: VICTORI-A AVGGG, Emperor stg. r., in field: M D; in exergue, COMOB, RIC IX Milan 35(c) = RIC X 1206, 4.4g

name: PAS: Cobham 1023
comments: Robertson 2000, 329 no. 1357:""In the spring of the year 1883, as some labourers were grubbing the roots of a tree in Cobham Park they exhumed an earthen pot which was found to contain over 800 brass Roman coins."AEConstantine I 1Constantius II, Aug. 98Constans, Aug. 256Magnentius 419Decentius 11Constantius Gallus 51836(28 FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman)(1 FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman?)(1 FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman)C. Roach Smith, in Arch. Cant., XV (1883), 321-30, types, mints; and in NC, 1885, 108-117, types, mintsR.J. Brickstock, in BAR 176 (1987), 327f., no. 21, failed to note that fifty of the coins of Constantius Gallus were attributed to Constantius II by C. Roach Smith.P.J. Tester, in Arch. Cant., 74 (1960), 177f., added to his account of the 1960 excavations of the Roman villa in Cobham Park, the following: "The hoard of 836 fourth-century coins found in 1883 was not much more than 100 yards S.W. of the villa, and our recent discovery fulfils the prophecy made then by Roach Smith in his account, where he remarked that the owner of the coins probably had his dwelling near the spot where he buried them and that accident might one day bring to light the remains of his house.""This account is duplicated by Robertson 2000, 329 no. 1357A:VCH Surrey, IV (1912), 360, recorded that "in 1883, a hoard of 800 copper coins was found in Cobham Park, chiefly of the Emperors Magnentius, Constantius Gallus, Constantius II." This is really the hoard found at Cobham, 1883 (Kent) [no. 1357].

name: PAS: Doddington 1028
comments: "During the autumn of 1897, a labourer engaged in clearing away some dead stubs in Dully Wood, on the western side of the Doddington Valley, noticed on the margin of a shallow basin-shaped hollow some flints which he thought had been purposely inserted into a hole about eighteen inches in diameter. His curiosity being aroused, he pulled out the stones one by one, when, at two feet from the surface, he came upon a small portion of clay from which he extracted a fine solidus of Valentinian II, in the highest state of preservation."G. Payne, in Arch. Cant., XXIII (1898), 21f., type, mint, fig. of coin. It had obv. D N VALENTINIANVS P F AVG, and rev. VICTORIA AVGG, Two emperors seated front on throne, T/RCOMCp. G. Payne, 25 Jan. 1900, in PSA, (2), XVIII (1899-1901) 43f."Mr. Jarvis [i.e. the postmaster at Doddington, who had got possession of the above solidus] has secured a second gold solidus of Valentinian from Dully Wood, Doddington.It is almost in as fine condition as the one he obtained from the same place in 1897.Mr. Jarvis states that it was found by some children who were digging about in a hole near where the first specimen was met with."Rev. C.E. Woodruff, in Arch. Cant., XXV (1902), Proc., lxvif., types, mint and fig. of coin. It had obv. D N VALENTINIANVS (IVN?) P F AVG, and rev. VICTORIA AVGG, Two emperors seated front on throne, TROBS.The second solidus also was of Valentinian II. In 1959 it was presented by "Mr. R. Haynes to Maidstone Museum (Accession no. 9.1959).Description; Obverse: D N VALENTINIANVS P F AVG Reverse: VICTORIA AVGG; Exergue: TROBS (Trier mint)."L.R.A. Grove, in Arch. Cant., 73 (1959), 226f.These two solidi must have come from a scattered hoard

name: PAS: East Farleigh Roman Villa 1030
comments: This hoard of 153 mid-4th C. irregular nummi (& 1 regular nummus) discovered in the course of excavation by Maidstone area Archaeological Group, during August 2010. All are context number 247. HER: Remains of five buildings have been located. Building 5 consists of 2 adjacent rooms 4.6m x 4.6m in size, surrounded on N, E & S sides by 2.3m wide corridor. Construction believed to have been in early 3rd C. The original use of the building is still being investigated, but it has been proposed that it is a temple. [?]. Coin evidence indicates building demolished c. AD 400 when it was being used as a large kitchen. The W room in which coin hoard was found had a 0.45m diameter quern built into floor. The NW corner of room contained a stoke hole like furnace which may have heated a cauldron. The hoard found in a charcoal rich matrix between stones placed to fill a hollow in the floor where clay had been extracted, poss. to provide the daub to construct a small oven near-by.

name: PAS: Gillingham 1032
comments:
Robertson 2000, 379 no. 1542:

""A workman engaged in grubbing up a tree on the outskirts of the village of Gillingham came upon a small vase of reddish-coloured clay which he shattered with the pick. It contained 722 brass minimi, all in an advanced state of oxidation."
The coins were 6 ant., and 716 small AE, not true minimi:
Ant. AE
Tetricus (I?) 6
Constantine I 14
Crispus 1
Constantinopolis 1
Urbs Roma 1
Constantius II, Aug. 4
Magnentius 2
Valentinian I or II 62
Gratian 6
Theodosius 118
Magnus Maximus 3
Maximus or Victor 1
Arcadius 107
Honorius 51 uncertain 345

6 716
The notes on rev. types which followed the above list show that a coin attributed to Gordian, with rev. type SPES ROMANORVM Camp gate, must have been actually a coin of either Maximus or Victor, and that some at least of the coins attributed to Valentinian (I?) belonged to Valentinian II.
G. Payne, in Arch. Cant., 28 (1909), Proc., xcii-iv, some types
722 coins in Guildhall Museum, Rochester"

name: PAS: Gillingham 1033
comments: HER: 434 Roman coins retrieved from controlled archaeol. investigation, including a Roman radiate or nummus purse hoard of 10 radiates & copies (AD 260-296). This small roup of cu-alloy coins was fused & were initially considered to represent coins melted together. This unlikely, as X-ray shows that they still retain their integrity as individual units. More likely a small purse hoard. Context 201 small find 483 is the fused group. Of the 121 coins from this context, J. Gerrard writes "The large group of coins from this layer may be evidence of a dispersed hoard, resulting from ploughed out occupation deposits".Seddon 2007.

name: PAS: Tingrith 1034
comments: Robertson 2000, 283 no. 1201:" "An unusually fine hoard of fourth-century coins has been found in the course of sand extraction at Tingrith. While excavating with a mechanical grab, the find was revealed high up in the sand cliff. It consisted of about 30 lbs. weight of bronze coins contained in an earthenware pot, over which had been placed a second larger pot. Above it lay an ironstone slab, to mark the burial place of the hoard. Unfortunately in the mechanical operations the pots were smashed and the coins (estimated at something over 3,000) were scattered and dispersed. Through the efforts of Mr Tom Gardner, the Ampthill archaeologist, and Mr. C. Bunker, the pit foreman, with their helpers, 2,050 coins and fragments of pottery were recovered. A remarkable feature of all the coins was their mint-fresh condition, the features of the emperors, the details of the reverses, the inscriptions, and mint-marks being clear and clean-cut. By the kindness of the owners, Messrs. Inns & Co., the find is to reside in Luton Museum, probably one of the largest, if not the largest, collection from a single hoard in this country [sic]."-'Nicolas', About it and About, in Beds. Mag., 8 (1961), 73JRS, LIII (1963), 136 (inf. from Mr. T.H. Gardner), gave the find-spot as "in the sand-pit ½-mile N of Tingrith", the number of coins as "possibly 4,000", and added: "Of 2,050 coins recovered 995 were from the London mint and 752 from Trier; the date of deposition was c. AD 337."In Nov. 1988, Dr. R. Holgate, Luton Museum, provided photocopies of a long article on the circumstances of discovery of the hoard, and on its composition (T.H. Gardner, in Manshead Mag., 13 (1964), 28-30); together with photocopies of the relevant entries in the Accessions Register of Luton Museum (Acc. no. 73/62).The additional information in T.H. Gardner's article included the fact that "the spot was marked with a piece of ironstone roughly cut to the shape of a diamond" and that "about three feet from the hoard, and on what would have then been the surface of the ground, was found the remains of a cooking pot associated with burnt soil and fire-stained stones, which can be taken as evidence of a meal of sorts at the time of burial". He also noted that most of the coins from the Trier mint were virtually uncirculated, were in rouleaux of the same type and issue, and so suggested evidence of hoarding direct from the mint.The material from the Tingrith hoard, acquired by Luton Museum in 1962, included fragments of 2 pots, one containing the hoard and the other inverted over it; the marker stone; earth samples; calcined sand; the base of a pot found 3 ft. from the marker stone; and 1995 AE coins, from Maximinus Daza (1) to Theodora and Helena (rev. PAX PVBLICA)."

name: PAS: Chalk 1036
comments: During excav. of a RB building "Layer 3 shows that the hollow site was levelled with rubbish from elsewhere. The amount of early pottery shows that this is not a gradual accumulation of rubbish in situ; & not the demolition of a building but the clearance of an old rubbish dump.  R. Reece has suggested that a forgotten coin-hoard was scattered in process; the hoard had been buried about AD 360. By c. 395 the tiny coins would have become so corroded as to escape notice." D.E. Johnston. 1972. Britannia 3: 120f. R. Reece listed 44 regular coins of Aelius, Gallienus to Arcadius, & 119 irregular coins. Found in a hollow filled with material thought to have been a layer of redeposited rubbish, containing ceramics. Associated with a Roman period building, possibly a villa.

name: PAS: Westergate 1037
comments: There are 21 nummi of the House of Constantine in the British Museum with the provenance Westergate, Chichester (BM 1853,0706). Possibly related to the grave find from Westergate donated in 1853 (Pastscape 249071) but there is nothing in the acquisition information to connect the two finds.

name: PAS: Reculver 1039
comments: Robertson 2000, 311 no. 1280:""Roman brass coins found at Reculver in December 1727, on the fall of the earth over the cliff after much rain." Then came a list of 14 AE coins:"Second brass" "Third brass" "Smaller brass"Constantine (I?) 4 1Crispus 2Constantius II, Caes. (?) 1Urbs Roma 3Constantius II, Aug. 1uncertain 26 6 2The two smallest coins "appear by the work to be of a later age, and as they are not legible by me, I can form no conjecture about them as to the gradual diminution of the weight."Letter from Dr. J. Ward, to Rev. J. Lewis, Vicar of Minster, 9 June 1729, in BM Add. Ms. 6226, fol. 8JRS, XXII (1932), 68, gave the date of discovery, wrongly, as 1717."

name: PAS: Gravesend/Springhead 1041
comments: A small collection of 60 late Roman bronze coins, now held at Durham University, came to light in container marked ‘Gravesend, Watling Street find about 1880 or 1890.’ An Honorian hoard [Robertson no. 1542A] described as from Gravesend Watling Street, but almost certainly from Springhead or its immediate vicinity. Brickstock, R.J. 1989. A probable hoard of late Roman bronze coins from Gravesend. Archael. Cantiana 107: 51-62.

name: PAS: Bedford Area 1043
comments: 84 nummi to 356. TAR 2005-6, 1126.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2005 T143

name: PAS: Westgate 1051
comments: Robertson 2000, 351 no. 1437:""Mr. Rolfe exhibited two hundred Roman coins and a large quantity of broken fibulae, rings, buckles, and bracelets in bronze, which have been picked up on Westgate shore, near Margate, during the present year. The coins range from Tetricus to Gratian, and, with the exception of a middle brass of Maximian, and one of Magnentius, are all of small brass, a large portion being of the class termed minimi.One of the rings is set with glass, and one of the fibulae is enamelled in blue and red."Three of the coins described were an ant. of Allectus, a small AE of Helena and a plated den. of Maximinus. It is uncertain whether the so-called minimi were true minims.JBAA, I (1846), 146, types of 3 coinsIf these coins came from a hoard, it is uncertain whether all the hoard was found."

name: PAS: Snodland 1057
comments: 4624 nummi & associated pottery. Addenda of 10 nummi found during subsequent excavation. Another hoard of 16 nummi from same site [Hoard No. 2664]. Villa and bathhouse on site, followed by late Roman inhumation cemetery (hoards belong to this phase, though may have gone out of use before deposition).The hoard was placed in a small pit (ref: MMS/06/11), which was up to 0.45m in diameter, 0.18m deep with near vertical sides and a flat base. This pit was cut through the backfilled ditch (GP8.1) suggesting that cemetery may have fallen out of use by time the hoard was hidden. Dawkes 2010 (unpublished report).

name: PAS: Springhead (Temple V) 1058
comments: During excav. of Temples II [no. 1218] & V, in Temple V "The first indication that finds were to be unusual came at start of clearing of plaster rubble from just inside W wall of small room. On top of the plaster was found a small 'hoard' of 8 coins virtually the same date ending at AD 375." W.S. Penn. 1962. Springhead: Temples II and V. Arch. Cant. 77: 119. R.A.G. Carson, ibid., Table, 125f., identified the 8 AE of Valentinian I to Gratian.

name: PAS: Shapwick I 1059
comments: Robertson 2000, 390-391 no. 1584:""On May 18, 1936, James Crane, peat-cutter, of Meareway Lane, Meare, Glastonbury, Somerset, while cutting peat on Shapwick Moor, Shapwick, discovered, at a depth of about 2 feet, a hoard of Roman articles, comprising a plate, saucer, and cup with one handle, all of pewter, two fragments of leather with nail holes, probably parts of sandals, and a small beaker of smooth dark-brown ware, 3 3/8 in. high, containing 120 siliquae. The beaker had been placed inside the pewter cup, and the whole covered by the saucer and plate." It was 2 3/8 in. wide.The 120 sil. were:Constantius II 3Julian II, Aug. 4Valentinian I 3Valens 17Gratian 11Valentinian II 13Theodosius 11Magnus Maximus 15Flavius Victor 1Arcadius 16Eugenius 5Honorius 21120(1 cl.) (1 cl.) (5 cl.)(1 cl.)(2 cl., 1 b.)(2 cl.)(1 cl.)Anne S. Robertson, in NC, 1936, 245-50, types, mints, photo. of beakerH. St.G. Gray, in Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., LXXXII (1936), 165-8, photos, said the mouth of the beaker was covered by a wad of dried grass, and that dried grass wrapping was also found in contact with the pewter vessels. The pewter vessels were described, with photos:1. Pewter cup, 4 in. high, set on a hollow pedestal base, with one handle, maximum diam. 4 5/8 in.2. Pewter saucer, 5 in. in diam., and 1? in. high.3. Pewter platter, 5 in. in diam., with moulded edge, and slight ring foot.41 sil. in Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM (BM Register of Coin Accessions, June 1936)Re-examined, 1948 (ASR) The remaining 79 sil., the three pewter vessels and the beaker, in Somerset County Museum, TauntonRe-examined, and pot and pewter vessels drawn, 1958, 1978 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Springhead 1060
comments: Robertson 2000, 358 no. 1472:""During road works on the A2 at Springhead, a known Roman site near Gravesend, Kent, workmen on 22 October 1964 saw silver coins in the spoil heaps deposited by a trench excavator at the close of the previous day's work. A number of the coins were dispersed before the find was reported to the police, but many of the coins were subsequently recovered. An exhaustive search of the immediate area and the spoil by the Gravesend Historical Society brought a further 200 coins to light. The sum total of coins recovered was 447, made up of 3 gold solidi, 12 miliarensia, and 432 silver siliquae. No trace of the container which held the hoard was found despite careful search. At a Coroner's inquest the find was declared treasure trove."The 447 coins were of the following emperors:Sol. Mil. Sil. TOTALConstantius II, Aug. 16 16Julian II 26 26Jovian 1 1Valentinian I 1 28 29Valens 2 126 128Gratian 2 5 162 169 Valentinian II 1 31 32Theodosius I 1 1 7 9Magnus Maximus 2 35 373 12 432 447(5 Caes.)(1 b.)The 3 solidi, 12 mil., and 12 sil. in Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM (BM Register of Coin Accessions, Dec. 1965)420 sil. in possession of Gravesend Historical Society.R.A.G. Carson, in NC, 1965, 177-82, types, mints, wts. of 12 mil., fig. 1 of 2 mil. W.S. Penn, in Arch. Cant., 80 (1965), 111, added further details of the findspot:"B 12. Unknown building. This first building was only discovered during draining trench digging in 1964 when much of it was destroyed. The main interest of this building is that the coin hoard was discovered just outside the south wall. Quite clearly, the individual who buried it intended to return to retrieve the hoard and identified the burial site by means of the Watling Street and the building. He chose well and would recognise the spot even today."Cp. also W.S. Penn, in Arch. Cant., 82 (1967), 116f."

name: PAS: Sutton 1061
comments: Robertson 2000, 341-342 no. 1400:""Close to Sutton Hall. Two urns containing Roman copper coins found 1870."O.S. 6 in. LXXVII S.W.VCH Suffolk, I (1911), 318, suggested that this and the hoard listed under Sutton, c. 1870 (Suffolk) [no. 1249] were one and the same, but the latter find seems to have comprised only one pot of coins, while this find was of two. It is possible that the O.S. reference may relate to the two pots now in Ipswich Museum, and said to have been found at Butley. Butley and Sutton are neighbouring parishes. See Butley, before 1930 (Suffolk) [no. 1150].Alternatively, the 11 coins in Ipswich Museum, labelled "Sutton find 1870" and transferred from Warrington Museum in 1932, from the collection of Thomas May, may have come from this find. They were 5 ant. and 6 AE:Ant. AEGallienus 4Claudius II 1 Constantine I 3Urbs Roma/Constantinopolis 1Magnentius 1Valens 15 6(joint reign)(1 b. VOT XX in wreath)(hybrid)(LRBC, ii, 1717)Examined, 1978 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Chatham or Rochester 1068
comments: Robertson 2000, 280-281 no. 1183:""Through the kindness of Mr. W.
