He catalogued all 74 sil. known to have come from the hoard (with types, mints and wts.):Trier Lyons Arles Rome Milan TOTALConstantius II, Aug. 5 6 11 Julian II, Caes. 1 1Julian II, Aug. 4 16 16 36Valentinian I 2 2Valens 10 2 12Gratian 3 3Theodosius I 3 3Magnus Maximus 5 1 625 21 23 4 1 74A.M. Burnett, in CHRB VII, BM Occas. Paper 59 (1987), 199f.Dr. Burnett noted that "the latest coin in the group is a Milan siliqua of Magnus Maximus, minted in AD 387-88. This can, however, be regarded only as an approximate date for the hoard's burial, as it had a very weak end (compared with the heavy concentration of issues struck under Julian) and coins of the few years after 388 are rare. A date of about 390 may be suggested." All 74 coins acquired by Norfolk Museums' Service [i.e. in Norwich Castle Museum]"

name: PAS: West Norfolk 1441
comments: Robertson 2000, 387 no. 1570: " "This hoard, if hoard it be, comes from the collection of the late Mr. Edward M. Beloe of King's Lynn, and was presented to the Castle Museum, Norwich in 1908. Nothing more is known of the coins, but they came probably from some Norfolk site or sites. The composition of the group corresponds closely with that of the Theodosian hoards found at Richborough and elsewhere, and it is more likely that they form a single hoard rather than that they are the accumulation of several or many trivial finds." The coins were 4 ant. and 631 small AE:Ant. AEClaudius II 2Tetricus I 1Urbs Roma 5Constans, Aug. 1House of Constantine I 13Valens 1Gratian 1Valentinian II 25House of Valentinian I 7Theodosius 50Magnus Maximus 5Flavius Victor 3Eugenius 2Arcadius 97Honorius 44"Theodosian" 256uncertain 1 1214 631 b.)(b.)(cl.)(1 b.) (1 b., 1 cl.)(1 b., 1 minim)(b.)(3 b.)Of the 121 uncertain AE, B.W. Pearce said: "The vast majority of these are probably of the House of Theodosius." B.W. Pearce, in Norfolk Arch., XXVII (1941), 303-7, types635 coins in Norwich Castle Museum"

name: PAS: Chapmanslade 1442
comments: 5,200 bronze nummi to AD 337. NC 1996, 120.

name: PAS: Welney 1446
comments: The Washes North complex of small enclosures. Rescue operations while being bulldozed in 1953 produced 2 rectangular buildings. A section through habitation site dug by S.R. Hopkin & planned by T.C. Lethbridge. A small coin hoard in remains of a bag came from top band of humus, sealed by upper silt. Unfortunately hoard not kept separate from stray coins from site, & cannot now be dated. Further coin hoard found near surface disturbed by bulldozer & associated with broken pot (frags of 4th C calcite- gritted jar). This account of 1953 work is based on notes kindly lent by Messrs. Tebbutt, Lethbridge & Potter. C.W. Phillips (ed.). 1970. The Fenland in Roman Times, 231-3.

name: PAS: Wood Norton 1451
comments: 2 solidi (Valentinian II, 1; Theodosius I, 1). Found by while metal detecting on arable land at Wood Norton on 2 December 2001. Other metal-detected finds from site, Roman-post-medieval. NC 2003, 16; TAR 2001, 198. Hobbs 2006, 1467.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2002 T059

name: PAS: Caerwent (House XXIV N, Room 2) 1452
comments: On N wall of House XXIV N, near NW corner of Room 2, hoard of c. 430 small brasses found, ranging from Gallienus to Honorius. T. Ashby, A.E. Hudd & F. King. 1910. Archaeologia 62: 417.

name: PAS: Gatcombe I/Long Ashton 1460
comments: "Coins discovered during excav incl. 2 hoards, one of 7 AE coins, & one of 9 AE coins. The two hoards found as distinct deposits trampled into a single occupation layer on floor of building 3, & thus may have been lost at same time by same person. If this is so, they probably represent 2 purses, one mostly of larger coins, & other of small change. That they were lost at precisely the same moment is however unproven, & it is therefore safer to consider them as separate units. The loss of the two hoards seems unconnected with any large-scale events on the site, suggesting perhaps that the cause was an accident rather than a catastrophe." R. Reece, in B. Cunliffe, "Excavations at Gatcombe, Somerset, 1965, 1966", Proc. Univ. of Bristol Spel. Soc., II (1965-8), pp. 152-6"

name: PAS: Dorchester 1461
comments: Robertson 2000, 255 no. 1075:""On Oct., 1840, in a meadow adjoining Dorchester to the eastward, some men employed in cleaning out and lowering the bed of the river found a few mutilated Roman coins of the third brass with a fragment or two of dark ware and digging a little deeper in this spot they succeeded in discovering from 300 to 400 coins curiously intermingled with fragments of thin brass, portions of brass instruments, a fibula, brass rings, rings of twisted wire, the front of a heart-shaped clasp beautifully inlaid with enamel, fragments of Samian pottery, etc., all lying on a hard bed constituted of a rude kind of cement composed of the ordinary detritus of the river, with flints, sand, large nails, and other iron fragments firmly compacted together and bearing occasional indications of scoriae. The coins were nearly all of the third brass with a few of the first brass and comprised the reigns of Hadrianus, Antoninus Pius, Faustina the Elder, Faustina the Younger, Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus the Elder, Tetricus the Younger, Claudius Gothicus, Aurelianus, Tacitus, Probus, Carausius, Allectus, Maximinus, Crispus, etc.Though some few were in fine preservation, the great bulk of these coins were in the worst possible condition."-Gent. Mag., 1840, II, 528-The coins from Gallienus to Probus must have been ant., and those of Carausius and Allectus probably so."

name: PAS: Worlebury Camp 1468
comments: "In 1852, during excav of IA settlement of Worle Camp, "a workman struck his pick-axe into the ground & brought up a small piece of Roman coarse ware. …within an area the breadth of which was not more than 5 or 6 yards, we found similar frags of pottery, enough to fill several baskets: upwards of 200 coins of the later empire; a great many glass beads & frags of bronze ornaments." Rev. F. Warre, in Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., 2 (1851), 64-85. NC, 1946, 153-6, description by P.V. Hill in Somerset Museum, Taunton". See also Knight 1902.

name: PAS: Park Street Roman villa, St Stephens 1469
comments: In 1943-5, during excav of Roman villa at Park Street, in St Stephens parish, it was found that the villa destroyed c. AD 367. 17 coins found lying amongst burnt debris over southern flue of the hypocaust in Room V. Assoc. with hoard was a large lump of copper." The 17 coins were 1 ant., and 16 small AE. The lump of copper was a "rough block of metal weighing three and three quarter pounds. Dr. M.H. Hey comments, 'Block of metal, considerably weathered, with crust of malachite & perhaps a little brochanite (not certain); below this is a friable layer of red cuprite. The main mass is soft and malleable, and from its ready complete solubility in nitric acid is probably copper, not bronze.' H. O'Neill. 1945. The Roman villa at Park Street, near St Albans, Herts: report on the excavations of 1943-45. Arch J 102: 21-110. Saunders, A D. 1963. Excavations at Park Street, 1954-57. Arch J 118: 100-35. HER: Corridor villa of 5 rooms with a cellar, facing E to River Ver & Watling Street beyond. …coins found in burnt debris over southern flue of hypocaust in room V.

name: PAS: Groveley Wood (silver hoard) 1470
comments: Robertson 2000, 396 no. 1597:""The small hoard of silver coins described in the following notes was contained in an earthenware pot, which was found on July 25, 1906, by Samuel William Doughty, while digging for stones in Groveley Wood. In the same pot were the silver ornaments described below, with a piece of glass and two bronze coins.At the same time and place was found another pot, containing some 1000 bronze coins of the fourth century; these, however, are in too bad condition to repay the trouble of cleaning.The spot is situated in an old earthwork, which forms part of a very extensive set of works, running round the north side of Groveley Wood and overlooking the valley of the River Wylye.The silver hoard originally consisted of 300 coins, but one (said to be of the larger denomination) was unfortunately lost by the finder. The remaining 299 were 296 siliquae and 3 miliarensia":Mil. Sil.Constantius II 3Julian II 21Jovian 1Valentinian I 7Valens 1 63Gratian 2 53Valentinian II 33Theodosius 37Magnus Maximus 60Flavius Victor 7Eugenius 7Arcadius 43 296(1 Caes.)2 AE coins found in the same pot as the silver coins were of Constantius I, Caes., and of the House of Theodosius.The pot which contained the silver coins was a beaker with narrow neck, 4? in. high, and 3 in. wide. The silver items in the pot (now in the Dept. of Prehistoric and Romano-British Antiquities, BM), were:1. Silver ring, 1 in. in diam., oval bezel, with hands clasped in raised octagon, shoulders grooved with scroll edging.2. Silver ring, 1 in. in diam., with large circular plate for bezel which is missing.3. Silver ring, 7/8in. In diam., with transverse notches on hoop and shoulders, square bezel, mount missing.4. Silver bezel of ring, with sloping sides, 7/8 in. long.5. Silver bezel of ring, with notched flanges broken, 7/8 in. long.6. Silver ring, flat, plain, probably a bezel, 5/8 in. long.The glass frag. Was part of a glass rod, 11/8 in. long (or rim of a vessel?)(Sir) George Hill, in NC 1906, 329-47, types, mints, figs. Of pot and two rings36 sil. In Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM (BM Register of Coin Accessions, April 1907); 2 AE coins in Dept. of Prehistoric and Romano-British Antiquities, BMVCH Wilts., I (1957), 74, placed the hoard in the parish of Great Wishford.M. Henig described and illustrated silver ring no. 1 in Corpus of Roman Engraved Gemstones from British Sites, BAR 8 (1974), ii, 101, no. 776 and pl. XXII, and suggested that the coins were "probably down to the early fourth century." (Cp. Also M. Henig in Wilts. Arch. Mag., 72-3 (1977-8), 179 n.6)However, J.P.C. Kent and K.S. Painter in Wealth of the Roman World (1977), 61, no. 140 (silver ring no. 1), accepted the account in NC, 1906, 329-47 that the rings had been found in the pot with late 4th century silver coins. An early 4th century silver coin hoard would, in fact, be very rare indeed, whereas Roman coin hoards accompanied by other objects whose typology would suggest an earlier date are common."

name: PAS: Wrington 1471
comments: Robertson 2000, 344-345 no. 1411A:""The hoard was discovered in 1984 by Mr D Cook of Winford using a metal detector in the parish of Wrington, Avon. The total number of coins is 1,283, including 18 illegible pieces and fragments. The earliest coins in the hoard are three barbarous radiates in the style of the Tetrici, while the rest of the coins span the years 330-383, with the GLORIA ROMANORVM and the SECVRITAS REIPVBLICAE reverses of Valentinian I, Valens and Gratian from the mint of Aquileia (no. 999), which may be dated to 378-83. The date of deposition of the hoard is likely to be soon after 378 since there are no examples of the AE 4 SALVS REIPVLBLICAE and VICTORIA AVGGG issues of 378-402, which are very common in Britain.Three further coins were located by Mr Cook in the same locality, though these specimens can have no connection with the hoard..Trier Lyon Arles Aquileia Rome Siscia Thess. Con. 0Nicomedia 1Alex. 2Uncertain 3TotalConstantine I 2 1 0 1 22 35Constantine II, Caes 2 2 01 1 24 39Constantine II, Aug 1 0 1 2 31Constantius II, Aug 7 8 2 1 0 11 27 326Constans, Aug 16 3 1 1 0 1 2 321Urbs Roma 0 1 21 34Constantinopolis 1 0 1 2 3 1Helena 3 0 1 2 33Theodora 2 0 1 2 32Julian 2 0 1 2 32Valentinian I 1 77 157 32 8 29 0 1 215 331 9Valens 5 100 284 64 24 18 0 1 24 4 3539Gratian 65 152 6 5 18 0 1 214 3260House of Valentinian 0 1 238 338Irregular 0 1 234 334Illegible 0 1 219 319RULE 0 RUL E 1RULE 2RULE 3RULETotal 42 255 597 105 37 65 1 1 01 11 2178 31283R Hudson, in CHRB IX (1992), 345-55, types, mints.The Woodspring Museum, Weston-super-Mare, has acquired the hoard with the aid of a purchase grant from the Victoria and Albert Museum."

name: PAS: Farnham 1483
comments: Robertson 2000,  275 no. 1151:"There were in the Curtis Museum, Alton, Hampshire, "eight Roman Coins, Recd. per Dr. J. Law Adam of Camberley, Surrey, Feb. 1942, who bought them from a dealer at Farnham, Surrey. He said thy had, he believed, been found in his locality."These 8 coins were all small AE, unworn:AEConstantine I 2Constantine II, Caes. 4Helena 1Constantinopolis 18(GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand.)(GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand.)(SECVRITAS REIPVBLICE)Examined, 1947 (ASR)It is possible that these coins came from a hoard, but if so they probably did not form the whole hoard."

name: PAS: Duston 1486
comments: Robertson 2000, 321 no. 1329:""Mr. [Aquila] Dodgson reports that:-During the year the Society has acquired the following additions to its collection of Coins -From a recent find at Duston, Northamptonshire, a gift of 120 third Brass Roman Coins, dating from AD 254 to AD 378, issued by the following Emperors:-"Gallienus Constantine IPostumus LiciniusTetricus CrispusClaudius II Constantine IIVabalathus Constantius IIAurelian ConstansCarinus MagnentiusDiocletian Valens"Third Brass Roman Coins, 120 in number, being part of a hoard found at Duston, Northamptonshire, 1910 Presented"Rep. Leeds Phil. and Lit. Soc., 91 (1910-11), 7, 21; copy supplied, 1975, by Elizabeth Pirie, Leeds City MuseumIn 1975, Miss Pirie drew up a list of 87 coins in Leeds City Museum, mainly of emperors recorded by Aquila Dodgson, which may have formed part of the 120 presented to the Leeds Phil. and Lit. Soc.:Ant. AEGallienus (sole reign) 8Postumus 4Claudius II 8Tetricus I 4Tetricus II 1Aurelian 4 Tacitus 3Carinus, Caes. 1Diocletian 1Constantine I 1 14Licinius I 4Crispus 4Constantine II, Caes. 10Constantius II, Caes. 1Fausta 1Constans, Caes. 1Constantine II, Aug. 2Constantius II, Aug. 5Constans, Aug. 7Magnentius 1Valens 334 53(1 deified)The composition of the lists suggests a hoard ending with Constantius II and Magnentius, in which case the 3 coins of Valens would have to be considered intruders."

name: PAS: Nobottle 1495
comments: During excav. of R-B building in "Sharaoh" field, on E side of Nobottle, Mr Cavalier came upon a hoard of coins before one spadeful of soil had been removed. The coins seem to have been contained in cloth bag of some kind, of which slight traces were noticed, & concealed behind & beneath a wedge-shaped stone, which lay slantwise against the foundation of the cross-wall, which was being traced. Nothing found elsewhere to indicate occupation or date of the hoard. The coins were 7 ant. & 807 small AE. B.H. St J.O'Neil. 1930. NC: 275-81; 1931, 321f., with correction; & AJ 90 (1933), 282-305, revised lists.

name: PAS: Higham Ferrers 1496
comments: During excav. of small 4th C. building by E. Greenfield, the majority of 186 coins found belonged to short period in first half of 4th C, with large proportion of irregular copies. Since many of copies occured in one deposit, seems best to treat it as a scattered hoard. 129 coins - 1 sest., 8 ant., & 120 AE.

name: PAS: Northamptonshire 1499
comments: Valentinianic / Theodosian coins from Irchester region - police case. One group identified as possible hoard by S Moorhead.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2011 T540Other PAS records associated with this hoard: BM-11316A

name: PAS: Laxton 1502
comments: Robertson 2000,  387-388 no. 1571:""In January, 1936, during levelling operations on the cricket field at Blackfriars School, Laxton, Stamford, one of the workmen, C. Mason, found, at a depth of 18 inches, a number of small bronze coins, all lying together in the soil under a stone." The coins were 3 ant. and 336 small AE:Ant. AEClaudius II 2Tetricus I 1Constantine I (deified) 1Urbs Roma/Constantinopolis 1Helena (after AD 337) 1Constantius II, Aug. 3Constans, Aug. 2Constantius II, or Constans, Aug. 4House of Constantine I 1Valentinian I 2Valentinian I or Valens 7Gratian 2Valentinian II 15Theodosius 25Flavius Victor 1Maximus or Victor 1Eugenius 7Arcadius 70Honorius 50"Theodosian" 120uncertain 233 336(1 deified)(b.?)(GLORIA EXERCITVS, 1 stand.)(cl.) (1 cl.)(cl.)(1 b., 1 overstruck)(8 worn smooth)The coins from Valentinian II onwards included 100 with rev. SALVS REIPVBLICAE, and 169 with rev. VICTORIA AVGGG, one Victory.Anne S. Robertson, in NC, 1936, 156-63, types, mints 339 coins in Cambridge Museum of Archaeology and AnthropologyRe-examined 333 coins, 1978 (ASR). Those not seen were Valentinian I or Valens, 2; Valentinian II, 1; Theodosius, 1; Honorius, 2."

name: PAS: Naseby 1503
comments: Robertson 2000, 274 no. 1146:"In letters, 1954, 1958, D.T.-D. Clarke, Leicester Museums, stated that there were in the Museum of the Market Harborough Archaeological and Natural History Society, above the Public Library, Market Harborough, 57 small brass Constantinian coins, from a hoard found about 1924 at Naseby:AEConstantine II, Caes. 1Helena (before AD 337?) 1Constantinopolis 47Urbs Roma 857"

name: PAS: Wotton Cemetery 1506
comments: 20 cremations & 54 inhumations excav. Grave 1012 represented, as noted above, further excav. of one revealed in 1993 (numbered 105 there). It contained a probable female adult skeleton (1014) of uncertain age. Two bracelets & 10 ten mid-4th C. coins dated AD 337-364 came from grave (coin cat. nos 11–15, 18–22). These coins seem likely to have been together in a container of some kind giving a burial date close to that of the latest coin (see Wells, coin report). Residual 1st/2nd C. pottery was also present.

name: PAS: Caldecote 1513
comments: 54 nummi to Valens. NC 2007, 49.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2006 T215Other PAS records associated with this hoard: NARC-77B202

name: PAS: Weldon (Great Weldon villa) 1518
comments: Roman villa, just before or after AD 200, "A larger house was then erected, which endured, on evidence of coin list & scattered hoard of c. AD 350, until about that date, when it too was burnt down." JRS 1954. 44: 93, 95. 225 identifiable coins (out of 230) can safely be regarded as the bulk of the hoard. The Weldon hoard was collection of best AE coinage available at time of deposition, & unlikely to have been a savings hoard of slow accumulation." (Footnote: "The report on the excavation of this villa 1953-6 by Dr. D.J. Smith is in preparation."). P.E. Curnow. 1974. Excavation of the Roman Villa in Gadebridge Park, Hemel Hempstead, 1963-8. Research Rep. Soc. Ant. 31, 105f.

name: PAS: Corbridge (Site XI, S Range) 1535
comments: In S range of Site XI, many stones laid out with some regularity to form a floor during last period of Roman occupation. About 40 burnt coins, ranging from Gallienus to Constantius II, found scattered in soil immediately below them. H.H.E. Craster. 1911. AA (3) VII: 148. Some coins ant., others prob. small AE.

name: PAS: Corbridge 1536
comments: Robertson 2000, 293 no. 1235B:"The following details of a hoard of bronze folles come from the Newcastle Museum of Antiquities:Constantine I 1 RIC VII, Aquileia 65Constantine II (Caes.) 1 RIC VII, Trier 527Constantine I 1 as RIC VII, Trier 526Constantine I 1 as RIC VII, Heraclea 351Constantius II (Caes.) (barb.). 1 as RIC VII, Trier 521Constantine II 1 RIC VII, Lyons 271Constans 1 RIC VIII, Trier 196M.F. Sekulla (unpublished)"

name: PAS: Somerleigh Court Estate IV 1536
comments: During 1968-9 excavs. at Somerleigh Court, principal discovery was rectangular Roman building 16m long by 8m wide, which pottery & coins suggest built in late 2nd century & destroyed in the late 4th century; the substantial foundations consisted of flints packed with clay, & two internal cross-walls with similar foundations were found. Floors, where present, consisted of trampled chalk. Within the building there were six furnaces built of stone, 2 slight semi-circular structures; other 4 well-built & large - 1.50m long, surviving to a height of 0.60m. …probably used for metal-working. A hoard of more than 650 4th-century coins found scattered amongst destruction rubble." W.G. Putnam, N.J. Sunter & J. Patrick Greene. 1969. Proc. Dorset Nat. Hist. and Arch. Soc. 91, 182f.

name: PAS: Corbridge 1537
comments: Robertson 2000, 298-299 no. 1248:"There were in Newcastle Museum of Antiquities, 7 worn bronze Constantinian coins, thought to have been found as a hoard in the period 1880-1914:AEConstantine I 3Constantine II, Caes. 2Constantius II, Caes. 1Constans, Aug. 17(VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN)Letters, 1961, from (Prof.) M. Todd"

name: PAS: Corbridge (East Granary) 1538
comments: A third burnt mass, found on loading platform of E granary, comprised c. 50 coins. This circumstance renders accurate dating difficult. The chief value of these burnt hoards lies in evidence for the occurrence of a fire at about AD 340. H.H.E. Craster. 1910. AA (3) V: 361.

name: PAS: Corbridge (Site Vi) 1539
comments: Hoard close to outer face of N wall of site VI, a few yds W of point at which Roman street cuts the present field-hedge. The hoard rested in loose earth, at a depth of 2 ft 9 in below present surface, and 6 in below upper street level, of cobbled pavement breaks away before reaching the wall. It formed a solid mass of metal, the coins welded together, many burned to a brick-red, showing that the whole had been subjected to intense heat; with small pieces of charcoal embedded in the mass. Prob. a bag or wooden box containing the coins had fallen among burning timbers. Not poss. to describe hoard in detail or give total number of coins, but were c. 490 small AE & minims. H.H.E. Craster, in R.H. Forster & C.L. Woolley 1908. AA (3) IV: 282f.

name: PAS: Corbridge (Site XI, Court 3) 1540
comments: Hoard of c. 400 Constantinian copper coins found in court 3 of S range of site XI, strewn over floor of the second period & below a later floor. Like 500 coins found in 1907 on opposite side of street [Hoard No. 1608], had been exposed to fire, but had suffered less, and identification easier. In both cases majority of coins forgeries. H.H.E. Craster. 1909. AA (3) V: 361.

name: PAS: Corbridge (Site XII) 1541
comments: In or near small furnace in Site XII, about 14 inches below present field surface, hoard of 48 gold solidi coins discovered. The package showed no signs of having been subjected to heat, & furnace, & poss. whole building, must have been abandoned before date of deposit. The coins wrapped in piece of lead sheeting & accompanied by a gold ring with a plain, small round hoop & a large bezel which once held an intaglio ornamented by beading round it. H.H.E. Craster. 1909. AA (3) V: 343, 351, 408; NC 1912, 275-8, 309-12.

name: PAS: Heddon 1547
comments: Robertson 2000, 363 no. 1494:""DonationsFeb. 6, 1856 - Monthly Meeting.Rev. James Raine, Jun.- Thirty-one Roman Coins, in third brass, from Heddo-o-th-Wall. - Seven ditto ditto, from Hawk's Nest, near Brampton, in Cumberland. - Defaced Roman Silver Coin from Housesteads."(Footnote: "One of these Roman coins was of Constantinus Junior, with the celebrated reverse of 'Hoc signo victor eris'. Another (from Heddon) was of Arcadius, who reigned just before the recal [sic] of the eagles from Britain.")AA, n.s., II (1858), viiCp. PSAN, I (1856), 95f."On February 6th, 1856, the Rev. James Raine, jun. presented thirt-one Roman coins, in third brass, discovered at Heddo-o-th-Wall.These were believed to have been found about the year 1820. They are small copper coins, in good preservation, belonging to the reigns of Maximian, Constantine, Constans, Magnentius, Constantius junior, Valens, and Arcadius. The latest of them belongs to the year 394, and bears the emperor's head laureated, and the inscription [D.N.ARC]ADIVS P.F.A[VG; on the reverse is [V]RBS RO[MA], with an armed figure standing, holding the Labarum in his right hand, a Victoriola in his left, (see Birago, p. 593). Secreted probably during that disastrous period which culminated in the final withdrawal of the legions from Britain, the unfortunate owner never returned to claim them."Rev. Cadwallader J. Bates, in AA, n.s., XI (1886), 242 n.; partly quoting Rev. J. Collingwood Bruce, Roman Wall, 3 ed. (1867), 125C.E. Stevens, in JRS, XXVI (1936), 71-3, threw doubt on this find as a true hoard, and on the association of the coin of Arcadius as evidence for so late an occupation of Hadrian's Wall. He also observed that "Mr G.H. Askew, Keeper of the Coins to the Newcastle Society of Antiquaries, has kindly informed me that the Heddon coins have been merged in the Society's collections and are not specifically identifiable.""

name: PAS: Heddon 1548
comments: Robertson 2000, 326 no. 1350:""With one or two notable exceptions, the press is of little assistance in 1752 though the Newcastle Journal of 4th Nov. contained a rare item which its competitor, the Courant missed:'A few days ago the workmen employed in making the Military Road to Carlisle, found a great number of curious Roman coins and medals in the Ruins of the Old Wall near Heddon. They had been deposited in wood boxes which were almost decayed; yet several of the medals are as fresh and fair as if but newly struck. Some of them are made of silver; but the most part of copper and a mixture of coarser metal. They are thought to be as valuable a collection as has been discovered for some centuries past.'All trace has vanished although [J.] Sykes (Local Records (1832), I, p. 204) says that several of the most curious coins were purchased by the Royal Society."W. Lawson, in AA (5), I (1973), 18330 Nov. 1752"The 3rd [i.e. letter] gives some acct. of the coins found in digging gravil for the Carlisle Turn-pike in Northumberland Nov. 1752. supposed to be in a box sticking close together."Then came a list of about 23 coins, all AE:AEConstantine I 2Constantius II, Caes. 2Constantinopolis 1Constantius II, Aug. 3Constans, Aug. 3Magnentius 8Decentius 423(or more?)(or more?)Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., VII (1751-6), 29, typesThe coins were said to have numbered about 3000, and to have been found about a mile from the Wall.Letter from J. Walton, Corbridge, to W. Stukeley, dated 5 Feb. 1754, quoted in W. Stukeley, Family Memoirs, II (ed. Surtees Soc., vol.76) (1883), 131J. Brand, Hist. and Ant. of Newcastle (1789), I, 607, said that the hoard was found "in the ruins of the old wall near Heddon. They had been deposited in wooden boxes, which were almost decayed; yet several of the medals were as fresh and fair as if but newly struck. Some were silver, but the most part of copper, and a mixture of coarser metal."Rev. Cadwallader J. Bates, in AA, n.s., XI (1886), 242 n., paraphrased the account in the Newcastle Journal, and in J. Sykes, Local Records (1832), I, 204, followed by later writers."

name: PAS: Moel Fenlli 1553
comments: Robertson 2000, 284-285 no. 1212:""Accounts of some Roman coins lately found on Moel Fennli. They were discovered by the tenant of a farm called Bryn Saeson Uchaf in the parish of Llandverres, on his sheep walk, near the summit of the mountain just named.They are all that were left out of about four times as many originally found by the farmer but which he had sold before Mr. Ablett happened to hear of them."Then came a description of 14 coins:- 1 gold, 1 silver, and 12 small AE - along with engravings of a few of them:AV AR AENero 1Elagabalus *1Constantine I 2Constantine II, Caes. 2Constantius II, Caes. 1Constantinopolis 1Urbs Roma 3Constans, Caes. 2Theodora 11 1 12(den.)(1 GLORIA EXERCITVS, 1 stand.)(GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand.)(after AD 337)*The den, of Elagabalus was attributed to Antoninus Pius, but the engraving of it shows it to have been of Elagabalus."Several other coins offered only repetitions to the above types and were more or less worn."Arch. Camb., 2 (1847), 109-11, figs. of coins"We have erroneously stated in this present number p. 109 that the gold Nero was found on Moel Fennli. It was discovered in 1823 in a field on a farm at Llanrhydd in the vale of Clwyd not far however from the base of that mountain."Arch. Camb., 2 (1847), Miscellaneous Antiquarian Notices, 188Willoughby Gardner, in Arch. Camb., 76 (1921), 247f., gave the no. of coins found as "about 100, but whether they were all unearthed together is unknown." Like subsequent writers, Dr. Gardner wrongly attributed the den. of Elagabalus to Antoninus Pius.It seems likely that the den. of Elagabalus, like the aureus of Nero, came from a different source than the hoard."

name: PAS: Stanground 1554
comments: Robertson 2000, 320 no. 1327: ""STANGROUND: 15 coins, probably a hoard (Trajan and Victorinus to Magnentius or later) deposited c. AD 350-370 (inf. Dr. Bell)."C.W. Phillips ed., The Fenland in Roman Times (1970), 187The presence of a coin of Trajan in a mid 4th century AD hoard seems unlikely."

name: PAS: Tamworth 1562
comments: IARCH record for a hoard of 33 copper alloy nummi of the House of Constantine. For full details and images see WMID-778A93.

name: PAS: Darlington, Near Piercebridge 1563
comments: Robertson 2000, 407-408 no. 1627:""An interesting discovery of Roman coins has recently been made on a farm five miles north of Piercebridge near Darlington. The coins were unearthed when land was being ploughed and about 250 were collected. The coins date from AD 254 down to 379 and 214 of them have come into the possession of Alderman Edward Wooler the Darlington antiquarian. They are of the following denominations:" Then came a list of 209+ coins.Northern Echo, 21 Dec. 1921, 5; quoted by M. Sekulla, in Trans. Archit. And Arch. Soc. Of Durham, Northumberland, n.s., 5 (1980), 51f.There were further brief refs. To this discovery in JRS, XI (1921), 202, and in JBAA, n.s., XXVII (1921), Arch. Notes, 231f.Dr. H. Mattingly had a note of 215 small brass coins, found at Darlington, which he examined in the Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM, about 1930 (BM Notebook, II, 39). Of these 215 coins, 203 were radiates, which, from their range, appeared to have come from a hoard [no.619]. The other 12 coins were small AE of fourth century date, which might have come from a second hoard or from a site find. Dr. Mattingly listed the 203 ant., and the 12 fourth century small AE.More recently, M. Sekulla identified 214 coins (out of the 215 listed by Dr. Mattingly) in Darlington Museum, and drew attention to a museum note which included information about the findspot which was at variance with the location given above:"Horde [sic] of Roman coins found at Kneeton Hall [...] on Roman Road, near Barton in 1920 by Mr. R.G.S. Simpson of Croft Spa, whilst tractor ploughing on the farm. The coins were deposited in an urn and covered with a flag about 18" deep. Mr. Simpson gave the lot to Mr. Wooler."M. Sekulla observed that Barton was 5 miles south of Piercebridge, and gave a list of the coins in Darlington Museum, 203 ant. And 11 fourth century AE. "These [latter] are certainly separate finds, being of a different patina."M. Sekulla, loc. Cit.The three lists of fourth-century coins, in Northern Echo, by Dr. H. Mattingly, and by M. Sekulla, are:Northern Echo H. Mattingly M. SekullaAE"Constantine I" 3(1 b.)Constantinopolis 1Urbs Roma 1Constantius II (or Constans, Aug.) 1 1 2House of Constantine I 2Valentinian I 1 1 1 Valens 1 1 1Theodosius (?) 2 2Arcadius 1Honorius (?) 1"Theodosian" 3"late 4th century AD" 59+ 12 111 of the 3 coins listed as "Theodosian" had rev. blank

name: PAS: Besthorpe 1568
comments: Robertson 2000, 329-330 no. 1358:""In 1964 a hoard of 1,347 Roman coins crammed into a pot evidently used as a money box, was found in the course of gravel extraction in the pits at Besthorpe operated by Messrs, Inns and Co. The pot was broken at the time, but most of the sherds were recovered. The pot and the coins were very kindly deposited at the University of Nottingham, so that both could be examined and recorded. Thanks are due to Mr. John Wallis of the company for this facility; pot and coins have now been returned to him.It has become evident, from the quantity of pottery recovered from the gravel pits at Besthorpe, which are between the river Trent and the Fosse Way and four miles north-north-west of Crococalana [...], that a large and important Roman site has now disappeared in the workings..The hoard must have been buried in the late summer of AD 354 - perhaps not very long before the execution of the Caesar Gallus for maladministration in the east (autumn or early winter)."Then came a full discussion of the 978 regular AE coins in the hoard, ranging from Constantine I, Aug. to Constantius Gallus, and of the 369 AE copies, including their place of manufacture, followed by a list of the 978 regular coins arranged according to chronological periods, Pl. I of 36 regular and irregular coins, and a description and fig. of the coarse ware container:"Ovoid flask in medium grey ware, broadest in middle of vessel. Base is flat, except that throwing rings have been obliterated round edge. Neck broken off in antiquity. The pot was broken in recovery from ground and a few sherds are missing from the side. The fabric is medium grey and incorporates tiny black specks of grit. The surface is slightly burnished.The black grit specks superficially resemble those in the common grey ware of 3rd and 4th century date known at the neighbouring sites of Mansfield Woodhouse, Gringley on the Hill, and Hayton, but the fabric of the Besthorpe flask is darker in colour. The neck is probably to be reconstructed as short and cylindrical, ending in a gently out-curved rim. The basic form is very common early in the Roman period and is evidently one of these forms which were revived in the 4th century by Romano-British potters. From about 350 onwards this flask form enjoyed renewed popularity.The firm mid-4th-century date evidenced by the Besthorpe vessel is welcome confirmation on this point."A. Cotterill, H.B. Mattingly and M. Todd, in Trans. Thoroton Soc., LXIX (1965), 40-9, types, mints, full discussion, pl. I of 36 coins, description and fig. of potRearranged according to emperors and mints, the 978 regular AE coins were:AE 0 1 2 3 4 5 6Lon. Tr. Ly. Ar. Amiens Rome Aq. Sis. 0Her.1Nic. 2Con. 3Cy. 4Th. 5Uncertain 6TOTALConstantine I, Aug. 18 3 6 1 1 0 12 3 41 53 633Licinius I 0 1 2 31 4 5 61Crispus 1 1 0 1 2 3 4 5 62Constantine II, Caes. 26 10 3 02 1 23 4 56 647Constantius II, Caes. 11 8 9 3 0 1 23 4 5 631Constantinopolis 32 8 3 4 01 1 231 4 54 653Urbs Roma 36 13 5 1 0 1 2 3 45 655Constans, Caes. 6 1 1 0 1 2 34 5 68Delmatius 1 1 0 1 2 3 4 562Helena (after AD 337) 3 0 1 2 34 53 66Theodora (after AD 337) 6 0 1 23 4 5 66Constantine II, Aug. 1 0 1 2 34 5 61Constantius II, Aug. 72 155 56 21 9 6 2 013 22 3 4 520 6346Constans, Aug. 134 9 6 21 8 1 0 1 23 41 54 6184Magnentius 72 22 7 42 0 1 2 3 4515 6158Decentius 5 4 3 7 0 1 2 3 451 620Constantius Gallus 1 6 6 2 1 2 01 1121 31 41 53 625RULE 0RULE1RULE 2RULE 3RULE 4RULE 5RULE 6RULE1 423 235 105 76 41 16 6 04 14 23 33 42559 6978One coin of Constans, Aug. entered under "uncertain mint" had rev. uncertain.Trans. Thoroton Soc., LXIX (1965), 47, gave the nos. of coins from the Trier mint as 422, but 423 appear to be actually listed.The irregular coins were described (loc. cit., 48) as follows:AE "Gloria Exercitus (2 and 1 stand. types) 4Victoriae dd Augg q nn (with obv. legend of Constans) 3Constantinopolis (Victory on prow) 1Fel. Temp. Reparatio 'Galley' (Constans and Constantius) 28Fel. Temp. Reparatio 'Falling horseman' (Constantius: 1 Gallus) 246Magnentius Felicitas (37), Victoriae (16), Gloria (16), Salus (7) 76Decentius Victoriae (2), and Gloria Romanorum (1) 3hybrid Magnentius/Constantius copies" 8369"

name: PAS: Blyth 1569
comments: Robertson 2000, 268 no. 1123:""Through the kindness of Viscountess Galway, a small hoard of Constantinian coins in her possession has recently been examined in the British Museum. This hoard of 94 pieces, of which details are given below, was dug up many years ago near Blyth in Nottinghamshire.The types which form the bulk of the hoard were issued between AD 330 and 333."The coins were all AE:AEConstantine I 11Licinius I 1Constantine II, Caes. 24Constantius II, Caes. 3Constantinopolis 23Urbs Roma 30reign of Constantine I 294(b. GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand., 1 with VRBS ROMA on obv.)-R.A.G. Carson, in NC, 1947, 179f., types, mints"

name: PAS: Warsop 1599
comments: Robertson 2000, 268-269 no. 1124:""On 11 January 1973 in the excavation of a trench on a building site on the Glebe Estate, Bury Lane, Warsop (Notts.), an earthenware pot (Figs. 2,3) was discovered containing 341 Roman coins. The coins, Constantinian reduced folles in an unusually good state of preservation, retaining their silvering to a remarkable degree, were subsequently declared a Treasure Trove by a Coroner's Inquest."Then came a full discussion of the 341 coins, with types, mints, average wts., metallurgical analyses, photos. of 2 coins of Helena, photo. and fig. of pot.-R. Bland and R.A.G. Carson, in NC, 1974, 53-64 - Lon. Trier Ly. Ar. Rome Tic. Aq. Sis. 0Sir.Constantine I, Aug. 14 90 19 10 2 3 3 3 01Licinius I 1 0Licinius II 1 0Crispus 17 19 11 1 2 1 2 0Constantine II, Caes. 18 43 8 8 1 1 1 3 0Constantius II, Caes. 21 2 1 0Helena (before AD 337) 10 1 0Fausta 2 1 0Constantinopolis 2 0Urbs Roma 2 0RULE 0RULE51 189 38 21 3 6 5 11 01+ 3 b.+ 1 b.+ 4 b.+ 2 b.+ 2 b.+ 1 b.+ 1 b.Th. Her. Nic. Cyz. Ant. TOTALConstantine I, Aug. 2 1 2 150Licinius I 1 2Licinius II 1Crispus 53 Constantine II, Caes. 1 84Constantius II, Caes. 24Helena (before AD 337) 1 12Fausta 3Constantinopolis 1 3Urbs Roma 23 1 2 2 1 334+ 6 b.+ 1 b.+ 7 b.The 7 b. coins were 6 of Constantine I, Aug., with rev.BEATA TRANQVILLITAS Trier 3, D N CONSTANTINI MAX AVG / VOT XX Arles 1 Ticinum 1, VIRTVS AVGG Arles 1; and one Urbs Roma Trier 1"Most of the body of the pot survives, though a large piece is missing from the side and a smaller one from the shoulder. The neck of the pot is broken off.Fabric. Hard, slightly gritty and a light cream colour. There are small red and black (or very dark) inclusions. The interior is unslipped and cream-coloured, the marks of the coins which the pot contained being clearly visible.Slip. Thin, matt, and variable in colour, ranging from dull brownish-orange, through brown to blackish and purplish shades.Form. The body is almost globular and has no footring. There are two light grooves on the shoulder, which has a very slightly angled profile. There is now no trace of a handle, but a small handle could have been attached to the area of the shoulder which is now lost.The vessel is clearly a product of one the Nene Valley potteries, and the fabric accords well with manufacture at or near Stibbington, Hunts., in the late third or early fourth century. A globular jug of slightly earlier date (mid third century) from Stanground Park Farm shows some similarities to our vessel. It has a profiled foot and rouletted decoration on the body, but the very rounded shape is similar, and it is likely that the vessel from Warsop also had a short, narrow neck and a small handle. Thanks are due to Mr. G.B. Dannell for the parallel and the suggestion that the pot was made at Stibbington."-Catherine Johns, in NC, 1974, 58f., photo. and fig. of pot-122 coins in Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM (BM Register of Coin Accessions, Sept. 1973)219 coins in Nottingham Castle Museum"

name: PAS: Worksop 1601
comments: Robertson 2000, 313 no. 1302:""A pot containing 940 bronze Roman coins of the reigns of the Emperors of the Constantine family, dating about AD 340 or thereabouts, from the mints of Rome, Lyons, Arles, Treves and Amiens was found while trenching the ground to plant a belt of trees along the north side of the Retford and Worksop turnpike road near the third milestone from Worksop, on 21 December, 1835. The road had then been straightened and the park carried up to it. The coins are now in a glass case at Osberton."Lord Hawkesbury, in Trans. Thoroton Soc., V (1901), 11The mint of Amiens opened in AD 350Constantinian (not earlier than AD 350)"

name: PAS: Barton Court Farm 1603
comments: LIA & ERB farmstead, re-occupied through to LRB period, becoming a villa. Villa complex, reorganised in mid-4th C. to include the enclosure-ditch and paddock boundary-ditches. 4 paddocks, which appeared to be an addition to original villa layout. In one of these were much-damaged remains of a small 4th C. building with stone footings, containing 2 rooms, 1 with an oven, the other floored with plaster. This building appeared to function as a smithy and was 37m E of main villa building. D. Miles. 1974. Oxfords. Arch. Unit, in Arch. Excavations, 61f. D.R. Wilson. 1975. 'Roman Britain in 1974'. Britannia 6 (1975), 279, with plan of villa complex, fig. 19, condensed D. Miles' account, & added that in the stone building E of the main villa building was found a scattered hoard of Theodosian coins. P.J. Casey ed. CH II (1976), 76, no. 318. Coins were worn & thought to have been deposited in 5th C by excavator, dated on (now incorrect) assumption that coins did not reach Britain after AD 395. The 33 coins from the central cluster in a 1m square area. There are 30 further from wider room from a 2m square area, and 26 further coins from building thought to show "a fairly close agreement in date and type of pieces recovered". Of the coins from the building, 44 are dated to AD 388-395 and a further 17 illegible are thought to be Theodosian.

name: PAS: Ashwell 1604
comments: Robertson 2000, 320: "In a letter, 1937, A.W. Sheldrick, Ashwell Village Museum, stated that in 1934, "a bag of assorted coins was given to us by an old widow, whose late husband had collected coins from the local farmworkers. Among the coins were thirteen of Magnentius. I think this is undoubtedly another Ashwell hoard but, once again, unfortunately, the site and time of finding is unknown. The coins were all AE. They have since been incorporated in the general coin collection in Ashwell Museum."

name: PAS: Bicester 1606
comments: Robertson 2000, 294 no. 1237:""The Bicester hoard is composed of 440 fourth century coins minted between AD 317-348. The hoard was discovered while workmen were removing a tree stump on a farm near Bicester in July 1979. The dislodgement of the stump resulted in the coins being scattered and they were recovered with the farmer's permission by means of a metal detector by Mr. P.A. Cartwright, Mr. G. Grimes and Mr. N. Grimes. Three hundred and eighty seven coins were recovered initially and an additional 53 coins were found on a return visit to the site a few days later. There was no sign of a container but this may have resulted from the manner of their discovery. The finders had hoped the hoard might be much larger since the action of pulling out the stump had caused a large quantity of earth to fall into the hole created by the tree's removal which in their view could have reburied some of the coins. However, despite vigorous efforts they were unable to locate any additional pieces..The complete hoard of 440 coins was brought back to the Ashmolean for detailed examination and listing. Unfortunately the time available to study the hoard was very limited since the finders were anxious to have it back as soon as possible but the coins were classified, weighed, photographed, and the die-axes recorded before their return."The 440 AE coins (404 regular coins and 36 copies) were listed according to rev. legends, types, mints and mintmarks, with wts., die axes, many tables, and 3 pls. of 36 copies.Cathy E. King, in CHRB II, BM Occas. Paper 31 (1981), 77-106Rearranged according to emperors, etc. the 404 regular coins were:London Trier Lyons Arles Rome Ticinum AquileiaNic. 0Cyz. 1Uncertain 2TOTALClaudius II (deified) 1 0 1 21Constantine I, Aug. 21 2 9 1 0 1 233Licinius I 01 1 21Crispus 1 1 0 1 22Constantine II, Caes. 22 19 4 1 1+1? 0l12 251Constantius II, Caes. 12 4 4 0 1 220Constantinopolis 38 8 4 1 0 1 251Urbs Roma 25 7 3 1 1 0 1 237Constans, Caes. 2 4 0 1 26Delmatius 1 0 1 21Helena (after AD 337) 12 0 1 212Theodora (after AD 337) 10 0 1 210Constantine II, Aug. 1 0 1 21Constantius II, Aug. 29 10 8 1 0 1 248Constans, Aug. 111 7 7 3 0 1 2128uncertain 1 0 11 22RULE 0RULE1RULE 2RULE1 282 58 46 6 1 3+1? 1 02 13 2404The latest coins were of Constantius II, and Constans, Aug. (VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN).The 36 copies were listed by Dr. Cathy E. King as follows:Constantinopolis 9Urbs Roma 1GLORIA EXERCITVS, 1 stand. 21VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN 536The 36 copies, illustrated on pls. 1-3, included 4 copies catalogued as nos. 117-20 "Cp" for Constantinopolis. The 4 copies illustrated, however, were of Constantine I, Aug. 1; and Constantine II, Caes. 3, all 4 with GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand.."

name: PAS: Combe 1612
comments: Robertson 2000, 262-263 no. 1102:""April 15 [1712]. About 20 Years since a Fellow found a Pot or Urn of small Brass Coyns under the Root of an Oak in the Parish of Comb by Woodstock - Coyns I saw today:CONSTANTINUS IVN NOB C Constantini Junioris cap[ut]: Nummus autem quem nunc ob oculos habemus est moduli medii, & est plane perelegans.In aversa p[ar]te VOT X DOMINOR NOSTROR CAESS: INTRA LAUREAM. A.C. 326.Hoc anno Constantini Jun. decennalia celebrata."T. Hearne's Remarks and Collections III (ed. Oxford Hist. Soc.) (1889), 332.Including Constantine II, Caes.2

name: PAS: Dorchester-on-Thames 1615
comments: During excav. of walled settlement, hoard of 43 coins found above Roman layers, but otherwise unstratified. The corroded condition of several would support notion hoard was deposited in a leather bag or wooden box, whose decay would have assisted chemical attack on coins. The latest coins in hoard of Honorius, & they are very worn, so must have been in circulation for c. 10 ten years. They were 1 irregular ant., & 42 R. Reece. 1984. AJ 141: 132.

name: PAS: Dorchester-on-Thames 1616
comments: During excav. of walled settlement this small hoard of 14 coins found, typical of early 5th C. hoards. 1 worn but identifiable coin of Honorius takes date of hoard up to AD 400; other worn or badly struck Theodosian coins suggest slightly later date." The 14 coins were 1 quin. of Allectus, 1 irregular ant. & 12 AE. R. Reece. 1984. AJ 141: 132. "It is possible that this is a group of coins put together in post-Roman times." N. Shiel. 1977. The Episode of Carausius and Allectus. BAR 40, 63.

name: PAS: Dorchester-on-Thames 1617
comments: R. Reece. 1984. AJ 141: 132f., recorded a 3rd "hoard" of 857 coins, ending with Honorius, and including 1 sest. of Trajan & 15 irregular radiates, besides 841 AE.  These coins were found in a pit dateable to the 5th C. AD, on site E X11.2.

name: PAS: Drayton 1618
comments: Robertson 2000, 335 no. 1369:""A great number of Roman coins, of the middle and smaller brass, from the time of Maximian to that of Julian (some of them rare) were found, in perfect preservation, in the sandy soil at Drayton, about fifty years ago, and were preserved by the late Mrs. Metcalfe and the Rev. E.G. Walford."A. Beesley, Hist. of Banbury (1841), 44"

name: PAS: Bishops Wood 1620
comments: Robertson 2000, 298 no. 1247:""In the spring of 1895 a large hoard of late Roman coins was discovered on the estate of Mr. McCalmont, at Bishop's Wood, near Ros-o-Wye, a few yards on the Herefordshire side of the boundary between that county and Gloucestershire. The coins were found by some workmen who were getting surface stones to mend a road, and an accidental blow from a pick struck a large earthenware jar in which the coins had been placed, and scattered them in all directions. Two other jars lay in fragments beside it with the coins they had originally contained mixed with soil and debris. All had been enclosed by rough walling built against the hill-side, but if they had ever been covered by a stone, it had disappeared. The coins are all third brass of the Constantine series (except three single coins), and Captain Partridge (Mr. McCalmont's agent) handed me a box containing 17,550 coins, added to which there are a considerable number which I have been unable to examine, as they were found by schoolchildren and others early the next morning, before the men went to their work, and are now scattered about the neighbourhood."The 17550 coins were 2 ant. (not 3 ant.) and 17548 small AE:Ant. AEClaudius II 1Diocletian 1Maximian 1Constantine I, Aug. 2455Licinius I 21Licinius II 7Crispus 4Constantine II, Caes. 3680Constantius II, Caes. 2195Helena 3Constantinopolis 3512Urbs Roma 4214Constans, Caes. 438Delmatius 30Helena (after AD 337) 312Theodora (after AD 337) 271Constantine II, Aug. 3Constantius II, Aug. 6Constans, Aug. 12uncertain 3842 17548(deified (under Constantine I, c. AD 317-8))(27 deified, 2 b.? VOT XX)(1 b.? Urbs Roma rev.)(1 b.? Constantinopolis rev.)(1 b.? Constantinopolis rev.)(VIRTVS AVGG NN 4; SECVRITAS REIP 1; hybrid, with Constantinopolis rev. 1)(GLORIA EXERCITVS, 1 stand. 4 (1 b.); VIRTVS AVGG NN 4; VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN 40)"There are examples of careless workmanship upon these coins.On the whole they are in an excellent state of preservation."The 3 coins attributed to Constantine II, Aug. were of Constantine I or II Aug. 1; Constantine II or Constantius II, Aug. 2.Mrs. M.E. Bagnal-Oakeley, in Trans. Bristol and Glos. Arch. Soc., XIX (1894), 399-420, types, mints, fig. of pot; and in NC, 1896, 209-37, types, mintsThe pot was a large jar, 12 1/2 in. high and 10 1/4 in. wide, with gently curving neck and plain flat base.135 coins in Blackgate Museum, Newcastle, 63 in Hereford City Museum, 44 in Bristol City Museum, 29 in Gloucester City Museum, and a few in Norwich Castle MuseumExamined 29 coins in Gloucester City Museum, 1958 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Frilford (Noah's Ark Field) 1624
comments: In 1937-8, during excav. of an IA & R-B site in Noah's Ark Field, an A-S grave found, with scramasax & knife. The presence of a scattered 4th C. hoard in filling of later grave was difficult to explain until, after removal of skeleton, a marked discoloration of soil underneath grave showed that a narrow trench or gulley had been dug into the silt of the IA pit before interment of skeleton. Some Roman sherds and two 4th C. coins proved gulley of Roman date. The 7th C. grave diggers accidentally chose a part of site already disturbed at end of Roman period, used for concealment of coin hoard. The grave cut diagonally across the R-B gully & coin hoard was scattered, some coins finding their way into fill of grave. Whether majority of coins were retained by the finders, and/or remaining 50 intentionally thrown back into grave, difficult to say. However, 7 coins including 2 not belonging to hoard, were found in such close juxtaposition to skeleton as to suggest they were deliberately placed on corpse. Second, coins found among stones at top of grave were so close together & conspicuous that they could hardly have been missed. One is tempted to conclude that Anglo-Saxons who dug grave found a large hoard, & left a residue as offering to their dead kinsman. The coins were all small AE. J.S.P. Bradford, R.G. Goodchild & C.H.V. Sutherland. 1939. Oxoniensia 4: 38, 50.

name: PAS: Frilford (Grave 2) 1625
comments: To N of R-B site temple at Frilford where grave & Hoard 1695 was found, 1 ft above & behind skull of grave 2 was hoard of 34 coins so placed that burial could not have taken place subsequent to its concealment. This hoard not earlier than AD 440, & since we may assume the grave to be contemporaneous, it provides valuable evidence of continued use of the cemetery up to the middle of 5th C. The coins were 1 ant. & 33 small AE. J.S.P. Bradford, R.G. Goodchild & C.H.V. Sutherland. 1939. Oxon. 4: 56, 62.

name: PAS: Wallingford Area 1633
comments: A probable dispersed small hoard or purse drop of 26 Roman copper alloy nummi. Currently 26 have been found in an area c. 100 x 50ft, in a field with no other Roman finds. All coins date to c. AD 317-329 and all are in a similar condition. The vast majority of the coins were minted in Trier.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2012 T773Other PAS records associated with this hoard: BERK-0CF822

name: PAS: Kiddington 1635
comments: Robertson 2000, 389 no. 1575:""In the Bodleian Library copy of Warton's Kiddington, ed. 2., 1783, there is a Ms. note in the author's hand recording 'Roman coins, several of silver, of Honorius' found in apparent association with an unidentified structure 'abutting on the Turnpike road [presumably the Oxford-Enstone road] opposite a lane going to Ditchley'. The note adds: 'No urn appeared for the workmen confounded everything. - Lady Mostyn has some few of the coins.' This hoard was probably of the same general date as the analogous AE hoard found at Kiddington [i.e. no. 1577]."(VCH Oxfords., I (1939), 329)"

name: PAS: Compton Downs 1636
comments: Robertson 2000, 368-369 no. 1514:""During the 1981 August Bank Holiday weekend [the finder] was metal detecting over a section of the Ridgeway to the north-west of Compton, Berks. when he found a number of late Roman silver coins. He subsequently detected over a large area several times and discovered 245 coins spread over an area of about 60 yards by 30 yards - the Ridgeway being in excess of 30 yards wide at this point. The coins were taken to Newbury District Museum and subsequently reported to the Coroner for West Berkshire. At an inquisition held on 19th January 1982 the coins were found to be not treasure trove and were awarded to the finder by the coroner. Mr Clark offered the hoard to Newbury District Museum at a very reasonable price and they were acquired with the aid of a V & A grant..There is considerable evidence of Roman activity on the Downs but no habitation sites have been positively identified in the vicinity of the hoard. However on Roden Down, 2 miles to the west, ten inhumations of fourth/fifth century date were found adjacent to and superimposed on a first-second century cremating place which was excavated in 1944-47. Seven of the burials were accompanied by a total of 30 coins. Unfortunately only ten of these coins (including five minims) are now available for examination, but from the report it appears that three Theodosian coins from one grave may have exhibited clipping found in the hoard..The hoard consisted of coins which were almost entirely clipped, and as such can be dated to about 410..As the coins have been so heavily clipped it is often impossible to determine the identity of the emperor."The 245 coins were all sil.A.M. Burnett and A.R. Higgott, in CHRB V, BM Occas. Paper 54 (1984), 145-50, types, mints, wts., figs. of 5 sil."A further 36 coins have been found in addition to the original 245. The new coins cover the same span, and are as heavily clipped, and have also been acquired by the Newbury Museum." The 36 coins were all sil.A.M. Burnett, in CHRB VII, BM Occas. Paper 59 (1987), 207f., types, mints, wts.Added together, the two groups, of 245 and 36 sil., were:Sil.Constantius II 8Julian II 17Valentinian I 4Valens 29Valens (?) 1Valentinian I or Valens 5Gratian 12Valentinian I, Valens or Gratian 18Valentinian II 10Theodosius 10Magnus Maximus 29Flavius Victor 1Eugenius 12Arcadius 44Honorius 32Arcadius or Honorius 41uncertain 8281(3 Caes; 1 b.) (not cl.)(VOT V MVLT X 3; VRBS ROMA 2)(VRBS ROMA, throne 15, cuirass 1; uncertain 2)(1 b.)(1 not cl.)(1 not cl.)(VIRTVS ROMANORVM 5; VRBS ROMA, cuirass 3)latest coins: Arcadius or Honorius"

name: PAS: Kiddington (Wood Farm) 1637
comments: Robertson 2000, 389 no. 1576:""Found in 1921 in Not Oak field.Part of a very large hoard. The finder apparently disposed of a large number." Note and coins in Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, seen, 1978 (ASR)16 sil., and 87 AE and a few fragments; the AE were 4th century Constantinian-Theodosian, including Honorius (and 1 b.).Cathy E. King, in BNJ, 51 (1981), 21f., listed 14 of the 16 sil.:Sil.Julian II 2Valens 2Gratian 1Valentinian II 1Magnus Maximus 2Theodosius 1Arcadius 2Honorius 314(1 copy, cl.)(cl.)(cl.)(cl.)(cl.)"

name: PAS: Ram's Hill 1638
comments: During excav. of R-B enclosure at Ram's Hill, Kingston Lisle, 2 adult skeletons found, buried one above other, in a ditch of which 3 sides were defined, suggesting a square 260 ft. across. There had evidently been occupation within this (although a trench encountered no foundations) – prob. a wooden building on analogy with Ditchley; & the pottery in the ditch was 1st C, with abundant Belgic types. Into fill of ditch, or rather a cleared-out portion of it (since no grave dug through the filling could be detected in section), the 2 burials were deposited, the upper on his back with no grave-goods, the lower on left side with coins. Two coins, 1 silver & 1 bronze, were enclosed between 2 thin silver-foil discs folded over each other in the mouth; other coins (7) were together in compact mass up against ribs, which suggests there was a bag or purse slung round neck. There is no doubt of strict contemporaneity of the whole group. Nothing else to suggest late Roman occupation of site. The coins were 7 sil., 1 bronze core of a sil., & 1 small AE. The 7 sil. & the bronze core of a sil. all severely clipped, not long before burial. The 2 sil. of Arcadius & Honorius showed only slight wear. C.H.V. Sutherland. 1940. Ant. J. 20: 481-5. Pastscape: Three sides of a quadrilateral ditch, abutting E side of the hillfort, enclosing an early Roman settlement, probably a timber built house. Belgic pottery dating to 1st half of the 1st C AD found in the ditches, possibly indicating a ‘Romanized’ settlement. Three Roman burials were found in the ditch, one with a number of silver coins dating the burial to AD 400-410 (2) (1-3).

name: PAS: North Leigh Roman Villa 1648
comments: During excav. of Roman villa tile supports for boilers [does this mean pilae for a hypocaust?] survived in praefurnium (Room 23), where, on top of the final layer of ash, was found a coin-hoard of 'Fallen-horseman' type copies of mid 4th C. date. Assoc. with coins were pieces of bronze, prob. blanks for the production of copies. J. J. West. 1978. Britannia 9: 44.

name: PAS: Shakenoak Farm/Wilcote 1649
comments: During excav. of R-B Building C (poss. bath-house), & fishpond (I) to its north, hoard of 17 AE coins (Hoard B) found in black deposit 75 ft. E of Building A & 20 ft. south of fishpond (in deposit (b)). They were closely packed together in a roll & had obviously been wrapped in something. The date of loss prob. c. AD 343-345. The coins were in greatly decayed state, but none showed more than slight wear. A.C.C. Brodribb, A.R. Hands & D.R. Walker. 1973. Excavations at Shakenoak Farm, near Wilcote, Oxfords. IV: Site C, pp. 35, 40.

name: PAS: Shakenoak Farm/Wilcote 1650
comments: During excav. of R-B Building A, found that bath wing was extended. Confirmatory evidence came from large deposits of builders' debris (roof-slates, mortar, painted plaster, nails, window-glass & dressed stone, as well as large quantities of broken flue-tile) which lay a few feet W of building. This debris contained a coin of Magnentius, & a hoard of 15 coins (Hoard A) lost in c. AD 355. As there was much building activity on site in middle 4th C., debris may be result of this & Hoard A may give us the exact date of alterations." A.C.C. Brodribb, A.R. Hands & D.R. Walker. 1968. Excavations at Shakenoak Farm, near Wilcote, Oxfords.  I.  25, 34f.

name: PAS: Radley 1651
comments: The westwards extension of gravel pit revealed in spring of 1945 an inhumation cemetery of 35 graves. The centre of this cemetery lay 110 ft. W of hedge which divided Barrow Hills Field (& passes further S. through barrow 4) & 570 ft. N. of centre of barrow 2. In grave 9, of a young adult, a group of 9 coins lay by the left elbow, stacked in a roll, & tightly sewn up in piece of coarse linen cloth. The cloth, though brittle, was very well preserved due to proximity of metal & fact it lay in loose gravel on floor of grave, not in contact with soil filling. The weave is a plain 'tabby' with approximately 28 threads to the inch. The coins, all AE, fall within period AD 317-24, & were all in mint condition, evidently selected for their fine state & variety of reverses. The burial with which they were assoc. cannot be much later than AD 330. R.J.C. Atkinson. 1952-3. Excavations in Barrow Hills Field, Radley, Berks, 1944-45. Oxon. 17-18: 32-4.

name: PAS: Stanton Harcourt A 1657
comments: Robertson 2000, 254 no. 1071:""These two groups of 22 and 23 pieces respectively were discovered by metal detectors in the same field but c. 25 metres distant from one another. The topsoil is a thin layer of gravel, beneath which is a solid layer of clay and it is on the latter that the coins were resting. Despite the similarity of their contents, the fact that the two hoards were discovered by separate individuals and at a considerable distance from one another suggests they are 2 distinct finds. No container was located, nor were any more coins recovered despite an intensive search of the surrounding area."Then followed a catalogue of the coins in the two hoards [nos. 1071, 1088], all small folles, with mints and types.FollesLondon Trier Lyons Arles Ticinum TOTALConstantine I, Aug. 13 4 2 1 20Licinius I 1 1 2Crispus 1 115 5 2 1 23-Cathy E. King, in CHRB VI, BM Occas. Paper 59 (1987), 35-43, types, mints, wts., die axes"

name: PAS: Stanton Harcourt B 1658
comments: Robertson 2000, 260 no. 1088:"For the circumstances of the find, see hoard 1728.FollesLondon Trier Lyons Arles Ticinum TOTALConstantine I, Caes. 1 1Constantine I, Aug. 11 3 2 1 1 18Licinius I 1 1Constantine II, Caes. 2 215 3 2 1 1 22-Cathy E. King, in CHRB VI, BM Occas. Paper 59 (1987), 35-43, types, mints, wts., die axes"

name: PAS: Stanton St. John 1659
comments: Robertson 2000, 429 no. 1878:""About 6 years agoe there was an urne of coins found in Stockherst wood near Stanton St. John's. Mr (Samuel) Lee and Mr. (Charles) Moorton of Wadham College had most of them.Quaere (Remember) to write to Mr. (Leonard) Tate (parson) of Cuxham whether or noe he hath any Roman coins that were found in Stockherst Wood (in) 1651. It was in the year 1647. Amongst some of the coines there was one of Romulus and Remus. The man that found them vizMarton of Odington, butcher, sold them to a scholler of C.C.C. This information I gave to Dr. (Robert) Plot."-A. Clark, Life and Times of Anthony Wood, ed. Oxford Hist. Soc., I (1891), 265In Jan. 1953, Dr. J.N.L. Myres, when Bodley's Librarian, drew attention to the fact that "Stockherst" in fact means"Stowwood".The coin with Romulus and Remus was possibly but not certainly a small AE of Urbs Roma.Undatable"

name: PAS: Wychwood Forest 1662
comments: The excav. by Rolleston of barrows at South Lawn, c. 3 miles N of Asthall in June 1872, resulted in discovery of a number of late Roman AE 3 coins. It is difficult from extant records to piece together history of these 22 coins in the Ashmolean Museum, described as having been found at South Lawn: & there were 22 when examined in 1923. The Rolleston Mss., however, speak of only 19. But the 3 additional coins may be either previous finds amalgamated with Rolleston's, or finds made later. In any case the bulk of the coins seem to have come from the main South Lawn barrow (Rolleston letters and Manning Mss. in the Ashmolean). It is poss. that these coins do not constitute a hoard in the usually accepted sense, but coins form a compact series & were buried within a limited area. Moreover, the group has an unmistakably homogeneous appearance - the more so if we segregate the 2 worn Theodosian issues, as 2, perhaps, of the 3 intruders. VCH Oxfords. I (1939), 328. This find, if a hoard, may not be a complete hoard. The hoard cannot be identified with any specific barrow in South Lawn area.

name: PAS: nan 1664
comments: Robertson 2000, 324 no. 1340:""The coins listed below are the property of Mrs. [...] of Long Wittenham Berks.On a recent visit the family 'coin collection' was produced and it proved to be the sort of accumulation that might have been found in any country house in times past. Among it was a small box labelled 'Roman Coins' in the script and faded black ink of possibly a century or more ago, containing a number of Roman bronze coins.As these coins were badly corroded they were taken away for cleaning and identification after which it was apparent that they must have formed a small hoard, or part of one. Apart from the fact that they must be an old find, and almost certainly a British one, nothing at all is known of their origin."The coins were 24 in number, 2 ant. and 22 AE:Ant. AECarausius 1Maximian 1Constantinopolis 1Urbs Roma 2Constantius II, Aug. 3 Constans, Aug. 8Magnentius 82 22(1 b., FEL TEMP REPARATIO, Emperor in galley)(1 b., FELICITAS REIPVBLICE)E.J.W. Hildyard and P.V. Hill, in NC 1954, 211-13, types, mints, die axes"

name: PAS: Wantage 1668
comments: Robertson 2000, 339 no. 1389:""Mr. Akerman exhibited two silver coins of Valens and Julianus, found some years ago, with many other coins, in an urn, near Wantage."NC, 1864, Proc., 7On 12 Dec. 1867, J.Y. Akerman, Local Secretary for Berks., exhibited to the Society of Antiquaries a silver ring, said to have been found near Wantage some years before, and added the following comment:"I can learn little respecting the discovery; but I suspect that it formed part of a hoard discovered near Wantage upwards of ten years ago. I have seen several of the coins which form part of that hoard, which are in the hands of different individuals, and which range from Julianus II onwards."A fig. of the ring shows it to have been 7/8 in. in diam. with a square bezel. "The design on the signet represents two sea-lions, regardant, placed feet to feeteach with a rudder on the shoulder, and holding a circle between the forefeet of the pair."PSA, (2), IV (1867-70), 38, fig. of ring"

name: PAS: Woodeaton 1675
comments: Robertson 2000, 328 no. 1354:"Mr. A.J. Evans read a paper 'On a Hoard of Coins of the usurpers Magnentius and Decentius, found near Oxford'."NC, 1875, Proc., 7"Mr. A.J. Evans has a small hoard of bronze coins of Magnentius and Decentius, said to have been found on the Roman site at Middle Hill, Wood Eaton, about 1874. It is alluded to erroneously under the name Water Eaton in the Proceedings of the Oxford Architectural and Historical Society (iii, 174, 223)."Berks. Bucks. and Oxon. A.J., IV (1898-9), 43"Many years ago Sir Arthur Evans obtained from an Abington dealer a number of coins said to have been found together near Islip. On examination the coins proved to be of Magnentius or his son Decentius. Those in the possession of Sir Arthur Evans in 1937 numbered 28; they clearly form a homogeneous group, and their patination, which is uniform, is also distinguishable from the peculiar and characteristic Wood Eaton patina..The coins are all AE2; 21 are of Magnentius, and 7 of Decentius. The Trier mint claims 15 coins, and Lyons 8, while 5 were struck at Amiens."(Footnote: "Since the preceding text was written, Sir Arthur Evans has deposited at the Ashmolean Museum his original MS. description of the hoard, composed in 1874, and listing what were presumably the entire original contents of the hoard - 1 Constans, 203 Magnentius, and 56 Decentius.")VCH Oxfords., I (1939), 328, 328 n.28 coins: of Magnentius 21, and Decentius 7, are in Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. In addition, irregular copies of 2 ant. and 9+ AE. They were:Ant. AEVictorinus 1Tetricus I (?) 1Magnentius 26Decentius 9Magnentius or Decentius 1Constantius Gallus (?) 12 37(b.)(b.)(VICTORIAE DD NN AVG ET CAE(S), 6 or more b.) (rev. as above, 2 or more b.)(rev. as above, b.)(rev. as above?, b.)Examined, 1978 (ASR)Cp. J.P.C. Kent, in RIC, VIII (1981), no. 171"

name: PAS: Woodeaton 1676
comments: Robertson 2000, 294-295 no. 1239:""The whole area [i.e. of the Romano-British site at Woodeaton] has yielded many small bronze objects, as well as many coins and much coarse pottery, mostly turned up by the plough since the land was first brought under cultivation fifty or sixty years ago." (Footnote: "These finds for the most part passed into private hands.Mr. Windham Hughes of Bicester, formerly of Watereaton, has recently presented his collection to the same institution [i.e. the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford].")."Two hoards of the fourth century, one Constantinian and one of Magnentius and Decentius [no. 1354] suggest contemporary disturbance.."Two hoards have been turned up, both late, one Constantinian in the Windham Hughes collection, and the other of Magnentius and Decentius."Margerie V. Taylor, in JRS, VII (1917), 98f., 101, 119Following a reference to Miss M.V. Taylor's article in JRS, VII (1917): "In regard to coins, however, a good deal can now be added to her accountthe important collection of Mr. Windham Hughes is also at the (Ashmolean) on loan.A find made at Woodeaton supplies some evidence as to the nature of the currency there about AD 340. It consists of 1551 coins, nearly all being of the last issues of Constantine the Great and the first of his sons - i.e. the 'Gloria Exercitus' type with 2 stand. and with one: the majority are of the earlier type with 2 stand.. From issues before this there are only 8 coins of Constantine and Licinius and their sons, 2 of Tetricus, much worn, and 3 rough copies with radiate heads. Among the 'Gloria Exercitus' pieces there are 13 which can definitely be regarded as unofficial.."This hoard suggests that copies were made from any official coins that were current, and circulated alongside of them."A list was given of 5 ant., and 1546 AE.J.G. Milne, in JRS, XXI (1931), 101, 104, 108f., some types, mints, and pl. XIV of irregular copiesThe hoard of 1551 coins, at first on loan from Windham Hughes to the Ashmolean Museum, was later presented to the Museum, where it was exhaustively analysed by Dr. Cathy E. King."Milne's published account of the hoard's contents listed 1,551 coins. When the hoard was recatalogued 1,565 pieces were counted. It is uncertain whether the additional fourteen coins were part of the hoard or modern intrusions although in view of Milne's careful listing of the contents by period and by mint the latter seems more likely. Regrettably it is impossible on physical grounds to distinguish the extra coins which may have found their way into the hoard as none can be obviously excluded on the basis of wear, patina, etc. One can, however, thanks to Milne's method of recording the hoard, identify by mint and period the discrepancies between his totals and the new figures. Thus where Milne recorded five radiates, the hoard now has 6; and there are 10 more coins from Lyons than appear in his totals (which included the copies, listed by him as genuine issues). The totals from Arles, Rome, and Heraclea all have one more coin than Milne noted, Cyzicus has one less, and the remaining extra piece belongs in the group of uncertain mintmark."Cathy E. King, in NC, 1978, 38-65, types, mints, officinae, sizes, wts., metrology, alloys, pls. 12-16 of coins; cp. Cathy E. King, in PACT, I (1977), 86-100, alloys, diagramsThe two lists, of 1551 coins (5 ant. and 1546 AE) by Dr. Milne, and of 1565 coins (6 ant. and 1559 AE) by Dr. King (but rearranged according to emperors, etc.), are:Dr. Milne Dr. KingAnt. AE Ant. AETetricus I 2 6Constantine I 197 191Licinius I 2 2Licinius II 1 1Crispus 1 1Constantine II, Caes. 303 325Constantius II, Caes. 182 125 Constantinopolis 322 321Urbs Roma 351 356Constans, Caes. 40 53Delmatius 5 5reign of Constantine I 10GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand. 1GLORIA EXERCITVS, 1 stand. 2Helena (after AD 337) 60 60Theodora (after AD 337) 63 62Constantine II, Aug. 8Constantius II, Aug. 1 37Constans, Aug. 9uncertain 3 85 1546 6 1559(b.)(4 deified)(3, frags.)(4 b.)(7 b., 6 GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand., 1 with rev. of Constantinopolis; 4 deified)(21 b., 1 CONSTANTINVS CAESAR, 19 GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand., 1 ditto, 1 stand.)(5 b., 4 GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand., 1 ditto, 1 stand.)(34 b.)(18 b.)(1 b.)(b.)(1 b.)(GLORIA EXERCITVS, 1 stand.)(36 GLORIA EXERCITVS 1 stand., 1 VIRTVS AVGG NN)(GLORIA EXERCITVS, 1 stand.)"

name: PAS: Breiddin Hill 1695
comments: Robertson 2000, 252 no. 1054:"In 1875, William Fisher presented to the Powysland Museum, Welshpool, "four Roman coins found near the Breiddin Hills viz:- 1 and 2 Constantine the Younger, third brass, 3 Victorinus, third brass, 4 Defaced, third brass."The coins were "found in a rocky fissure on the east side of the Breidden, where stone is now being obtained by Mr. Francis for paving purposes. It is believed the workmen found many more; but these are all that have been rescued."-Montgomerys. Coll., VIII (1876), xxxvi, 291-B.H. St.J. O'Neil, in Arch. Camb., 92 (1937), 117, noted that the coins presented by William Fisher cannot now be identified with certainty in the Powysland Museum, but that the two attributed to Constantine II were probably one of Constantine I (rev. GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand.) and one of Constantinopolis, which are labelled as coming from Breiddin Hill. Mr. O'Neil suggested that the coins were found, not on the east, but on the west side of the hill, for in about 1910, Mr. Jim Walton and a friend found a number of Roman coins (12 or more) "half way up the hill on the north-west side at a spot now quarried awayon a ledge by an overhanging rock 'adjacent to an old lane' (probably only a footpath) 'which led up the crag, over a shoulder, and down again.' Mr. Walton considered it likely that his find was made at the same place as the older discovery. There were old workings close at hand."Two of the coins found c. 1910, now in the Powysland Museum, Welshpool, are an Alexandrian billon coin and a follis:Billon AEAurelian 1Constantine I, Aug. 11 1(SOLI INVICTO COMITI)-Arch. Camb., 92 (1937), 119, types-These coins may be regarded as coming from the hoard. Those of Constantine I and Constantinopolis probably, but not certainly, did.G.C. Boon, in a letter, Jan. 1964, cast doubt on the association of the Alexandrian coin of Aurelian with the hoard."

name: PAS: Llanfair Caereinion 1700
comments: Robertson 2000, 280 no. 1178:""In a field near the river Banwy, a Roman urn was dug up in 1740, containing a great number of copper coins of several Roman emperors: The urn was broken but many of the coins are at present [1833] in the possession of Mrs. Jenkins of Crosswood."-S. Lewis, Topog. Dict. of Wales (1833), s.v. Llanvair Caerinion-In 1898, "a sale was held of the effects at Crosswood. The coins were erroneously stated in the auctioneers' catalogue to have been discovered at Ystrad near Newtown. They were purchased by Miss Naylor of Leighton Hall, Welshpool, who has furnished the following list."They were 2 ant. and 378 small AE:Ant. AE"ANTONINVS PI AVG" 3Gallienus (sole reign) 1Postumus 1Maximinus Daza 1Constantine I 81Crispus 5Constantine II, Caes. 69Constantius II, Caes. 85Helena 1Fausta 1Constantinopolis 97Urbs Roma 28Pop. Romanus/Constans 4Pop. Romanus/Const2uncertain 12 378(including 5 wrongly attributed to Constantine II)(SECVRITAS REIPVBLICE)(identified by rev. legend SALVS REIPVBLICAE)(1 with rev. GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand.)-RCHM Montgomeryshire (1911), 87f., no. 445, types"

name: PAS: Moel Fenlli 1706
comments: Robertson 2000, 300 no. 1252:""In July, 1816, there was a conflagration of the heather on the hill top which brought to light about 1500 coins found lying on the inner side of the main rampart [i.e. of Moel Fennli]. The bulk of the finds cannot now be traced but fortunately 43 coins are preserved in the Chester Museum, presented by Rev. M. [sic] A. Potts." Then came a list of 43 small AE coins.Willoughby Gardner, in Arch. Camb., 76 (1921), 247-52, types; cp. Davies and Longbottom, Cat. of the Roman Coins in the Chester Museum, in Journ. Chester Arch. Soc., n.s., XXIV (1922), 154f.; and Cat. of Grosvenor Museum, Chester (1923), 44f., types, mintsExamined 43 coins in Grosvenor Museum, Chester, 1948, 1978 (ASR)"Among the collection of Roman coins, which formerly belonged to the Chester antiquarian, Mr. Frederick Potts, were a group of forty-three pieces, acc. no. 91. C. 1899, presented to the Museum on 4 April 1899, by his son the Revd. F.A. Potts. The original entry reads '33 [sic] coins of Constantinus Max (fourth brass)(from) Moel Ventle, Llanferesfound on Roman encampment in July 1816.' A slightly revised description is given by Davies and Longbottom (1922), pp. 154-5."Then came a list of 41 Constantinian AE, plus 1 ant. of Gallienus (sole reign) and 1 den. of Nero. The two last coins were probably intruders.Glenys Lloyd-Morgan, in CH IV (1978), 42, no. 167; 59-61, no, 167, types, mints; also in BBCS, XXIX (1980-2), 184-6, types, mintsThe earlier lists, of 43 AE, and the recent list, of 41 AE, are:AE AE (Glenys Lloyd-Morgan)Constantine I 10 9Constantine II, Caes. 9 8Constantius II, Caes. 4 3Constantinopolis 8 8Urbs Roma 4 4Constans, Caes. 1 1Helena (after AD 337) 1 2Constantius II, Aug. 3Constans, Aug. 3 3uncertain 343 41(after AD 337)(VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN)"

name: PAS: Cae Bardd 1707
comments: Robertson 2000, 263-264 no. 1106:""In September 1981, Mr. F. Jones observed a scatter of coins whilst ploughing on his farm at Cae Bardd, near Guilsfield, in the same field where 288 coins had come to light in 1935 [no. 1105]. A hole some 2m. in diameter was dug at the spot by Mr. Jones and members of his family, and this revealed two Roman earthenware vessels containing the bulk of the hoard. Several more coins scattered by the plough up to 10m. from the vessels were retrieved with the use of a metal detector. The coins, numbering some 4,102 were reported to Mr. K. Mason (then Curator of the Powysland Museum, Welshpool) in April 1982, and were brought to the National Museum of Wales for identification and study. Subsequently a further 614 scattered coins came to light and are included in the catalogue. Therefore, 4,716 coins have been identified, a total probably not far off the number originally buried.The two earthenware containers were found buried just below the surface. The upper parts of both vessels had been disturbed by the plough, and sherds from these scattered. Although it was possible to reconstruct both vessels to some extent, the only rim sherd to be collected came from the globular beaker. Circular impressions of the coins remain on the interior surface of both vessels.1. Lower half of a storage jar in an orange fabric with a grey core. There are traces of exterior burnishing but most of this has been removed by over-zealous cleaning. This vessel is probably an example of Severn Valley ware, but unfortunately not enough survives for a positive identification by its form. However, the spot where it was found is well within the area where products of this ware were being distributed in the fourth century AD.2. Most of a globular beaker in an orange-brown fabric with a thin buff core and a darker red-brown exterior slip, most of which has been removed after its discovery. Rouletted decoration covers the upper part of the body. This is a common form of the later third and fourth centuries, and is either a product of the Oxfordshire kilns or a related regional group.The Cae Bardd hoard is composed of 4,716 argentiferous bronze coins minted between AD 316 and 328. However, the two SOLI INVICTO COMITI pieces of 316 and 317, and the CLARITAS REIPVBLICAE of 317 are outliers, and the hoard in effect begins with the VICTORIAE LAETAE PRINC PERP issues of 318-9. The latest coins present are the PROVIDENTIAE AVGG, PROVIDENTIAE CAESS and SECVRITAS REIPVBLICE pieces of Trier with the mint-mark PTRE, dateable to AD 327-8.A complete absence of specimens of GLORIA EXERCITVS, VRBS ROMA and CONSTANTINOPOLIS indicates that the hoard was deposited shortly before or very soon after the minting of these new issues commenced in AD 330."The 4716 coins included 4648 regular AE coins, and 68 irregular.
