The 4648 regular coins were as follows:FollesLondon Trier Lyons Arles RomeConstantine I, Aug. 448 998 76 76 17Licinius I 16 17* 2Licinius II 17 2 1Crispus 606 389 63 31 9Constantine II, Caes. 903 408 30 25* 6 Constantius II, Caes. 20 63 1 5Helena (before AD 337) 3 62Fausta 7 37 11987 1990 170 157 35FollesTicinum Aquileia Siscia Sirmium ThessalonicaConstantine I, Aug. 60 6 50 2 27Licinius I 2 7 6 7Licinius II 1 2Crispus 6 4 39 7Constantine II, Caes. 5 10 37 11Constantius II, Caes. 1Helena (before AD 337) 1 1 1Fausta75 28 135 2 53FollesNicomedia Uncertain TOTALConstantine I, Aug. 10 1770Licinius I 57Licinius II 2 25Crispus 1 1 1156Constantine II, Caes. 2 1437Constantius II, Caes. 90Helena (before AD 337) 68Fausta 453 13 4648* The summary Table of emperors and mints listed 8 coins of Licinius I, and 34 of Constantine II, Caes., from the mint of Arles, but the detailed Catalogue of coins seems to include 17 of Licinius I and 25 of Constantine II, Caes. The 10 coins of Constantine I from an uncertain mint included 2 brockages.The 68 irregular coins were:FollesLondon Trier Lyons Arles Rome Constantine I, Aug. 7 12 2 6 2Constantine I, Aug. (?)Licinius I 1Licinius II 1Crispus 5 7 1 2Constantine II, Caes. 3 4 2Constantius II, Caes. 1Helena (before AD 337)Fausta 115 25 3 12 2FollesTicinum Siscia Uncertain TOTALConstantine I, Aug. 2 2 4 37Constantine I, Aug. (?) 1 1 Licinius I 1Licinius II 1Crispus 15Constantine II, Caes. 1 10Constantius II, Caes. 1Helena (before AD 337) 1 1Fausta 14 3 4 68-R.J. Brewer, in CHRB VII, BM Occas. Paper 59 (1987), 45-129, types, mints, some wts., diams., tables, map of findspot, figs. of two pots"

name: PAS: Ogof-Yr-Esgryn 1711
comments: Glyntawe, Brec. Coins from a scattered hoard, poss. incl. some of Constantinian pieces listed in Arch. Camb. 97 (1968), 42 [no. 161], found in a crevice of cave known as 'Ogof yr Esgryn', Dan-yr-Ogof Caves. In good condition, with slight traces of wear only. G.C. Boon. 1976-8. BBCS 27: 631f. Robertson has split this find into two distinct deposits, this one ending with Hadrian and the other the fourth century coins IARCH-92FCFC. The two coins under the slab are treated by Guest and Wells as a distinct hoard (2007, 271 no. 830) and the other first / second to fourth century coins combined as no. 831. The records linked here from Guest and Wells are therefore the As of Vespasian and the denarius of Hadrian only. EG has followed Robertson as the coins seem to have been dispersed throughout the cave, possibly relating to two distinct periods of gradual accumulation.

name: PAS: Reading (Bobs Mount) 1718
comments: Robertson 2000, 365 no. 1500:""The vessel was observed during the severe frost of the middle of February, lying on some ice in an old unused gravel pit on Bobs Mount by some lads who were sliding there. Around it was some thinly scattered gravel; which, loosened by the frost, had evidently fallen from the gravel cutting, which extended along the border of the ice, carrying the vessel with it. Unfortunately, one of the lads gave it a kick, and broke it when a quantity of coins were revealed, as many as fifty or more it was stated: but such statements are to be received with caution being usually exaggerated. There is no doubt there was a greater number than was recovered: but immediate attention being given to the matter, the urn which has since been carefully repaired, was secured for the museum; while of the coins, eleven were obtained and others will be added if possible."J. Stevens, in Berks. Bucks. and Oxon. A.J., I (1895), 62T. May, The Pottery found at Silchester (1916), 129, and fig. 102, described and illustrated the pot.The pot, a small jug of rough brown clay, 3 ¾ in. high and 2 ¾ in. wide, and the 11 coins are still in Reading Museum. The coins are all sil., slightly worn, and, with the possible exception of one coin, they do not appear to have been clipped:Sil.Julian II, Aug. 3Valentinian I 1Valens 2Gratian 2Valentinian II 1Magnus Maximus 1Arcadius 111(frag.)(1 twice perf.)(in 2 frags.)(cl.?; of AD 392-5, in 2 frags.)Examined, and pot drawn, 1948 (ASR) Cp. G.C. Boon, in Oxon., XIX (1954), 41f., types, mints"

name: PAS: Reading (Milman Road) 1719
comments: Robertson 2000, 369 no. 1516:""The second [i.e. hoard] in Swainston Road, on December 11th., 1895.About 120 coins have been traced, of which 50 and the vessel are in the museum."J. Stevens, Descriptive Cat. of Reading Museum (1896), 44In the Reading Museum Register, p. 218, Stevens, after noting the accession of the pot and 50 coins, gave a list of 70 (or more) coins from the hoard which had passed into private hands, adding that "the preceding coins were found in digging out foundations, in Milman Road, Whitley, a continuation of the same elevation at Bob's Mount".T. May, The Pottery found at Silchester (1916), 124, fig. 89, and P1. LIII, described and illustrated the pot.The pot, an indented beaker of New Forest ware, 5 ¼ in. high and 3 ½ in. wide, and the 50 coins, 1 solidus and 49 sil. are still in Reading Museum. The coins are only slightly worn, and do not appear to have been clipped. A list of these 50 coins, and Stevens' list of the coins in private hands, are here placed alongside one another.Reading Museum Mr. Swain Mr. Swain, Mr. OliverJunr.Sol. Sil. Sol. Sil. Sil. Sil.Constantius II 4Julian II, Aug. 7 6Valentinian I 6Valens 4 10Gratian 5 10Valentinian II 1 5 1 6Theodosius 5 9Magnus Maximus 4 17Flavius Victor 1Eugenius 3 1Arcadius 3 7Honorius 2 1uncertain 13? 21 49 1 67 13? 2In 1924, Mr. Swain's grand-daughter gave some coins from this hoard to Mr. G.W. Smith. On Mr. Smith's death, in 1948, his collection of coins was examined by Reading Museum, and was found to consist of a series of Roman coins ranging from the 1st to the 4th century AD, and included a number of sil. unaccompanied by any record of their provenance. It is quite uncertain which, if any, of these sil. came from the hoard.Examined 50 coins, and pot drawn, 1948 (ASR).One coin was a rare sil. of Gratian, rev. CONCORDIA AVGGG, TRPS.G.C. Boon, in Oxon., XIX (1954), 42-4, types, mints, of the 50 coins in Reading Museum, cast doubt on the number said to be in other hands."

name: PAS: Great Casterton Roman villa 1722
comments: Discovered in debris a hoard of 327 minims. "About 300 of these were found as a hoard with the sestertius of Marcus Aurelius and the AV forgery of Valentinian I. Rest scattered nearby, but prob. from this hoard. 'So little can be seen on the coins that it is not possible to say that they were in use at any particular time other than after AD 350-3 (Magnentius). P. Corder (ed.) 1958. The Roman Town and Villa at Great Casterton, ed. P. Corder, pp. 22. To judge from Mr. Pearce's account, the hoard consisted of minims only, and did not include the sestertius of Marcus and the AV forgery of Valentinian I. HER: In 1948 Roman building was discovered & excav. began under Messrs Barber & Bolton. In 1950 excavs. taken over by Notts. Uni. Summer School & continued to 1958, revealing much but not all of a villa complex incl. houses, barns, corn driers & bath house. There were mosaic pavements & finds of slag, rope, an incised bone plaque, glass, a hoard of 317 minims, 204 other coins, a skeleton from fill of the cold bath, 2 silver pennies of Burgred of Mercia, top of a ?Saxon glass drinking horn, base of a stone column, wall plaster, tiles, Collyweston slates, etc. Occupation probably continued into 5th C. In 1997 metal detecting finds from field incl. 11 2nd-3rd C. coins, pottery, frag. of box flue tile & a tessera, a dolphin brooch & poss. Roman key handle. The Great Casterton excavation reports seem to map villa to NE of site marked on modern OS map.

name: PAS: Ketton 1723
comments: 8 radiates & 1356 nummi to 402. Associated with an inhumation burial Grave 1 (excavated). Initial find made by farmer during machine excav. of field drain. This disturbed 2 inhumations in stone-lined cists & 126 Roman coins. Northamptonshire Archaeology subsequently excavated & recorded the site (previous work had been carried out ahead of extraction in quarries to W at Castle's Cement works - see report for references. This was a settlement with possible commercial beer production activity. 15% of one individual, found in remains of stone-lined cist, with green staining on right femur, indicating coins prob. orig. in a perishable bag. Also remains of another femur, & some juvenile bones. HER: As result of discovery of coin hoard & human remains, a programme of archaeological work undertaken, incl. excav., metal detecting, geophysical & fieldwalking surveys. This work identified 5 graves, one destroyed during machining of drainage, with 11 inhumations recovered & at least 3 graves re-used. 3 bracelets, 1 of shale & 2 cu alloy & 17 sherds of pottery from at least 4 vessels were recovered from the graves, giving a date for burials from the 3rd C. onwards. Total number of coins recovered 1418; hoard deposited in one of graves, either during burial or as later insertion, prob. during first decades of 5th C. (the latest coins in the hoard were Theodosian, c. AD 395-402). Poss. the largest & latest hoard recorded from a grave in Britain.

name: PAS: Thistleton Dyer, Market Overton 1725
comments: At two ironstone quarry sites at Thistleton Dyer, Rutland in Black Wong Field (Quarry no. 5), 2 groups of buildings with rectangular rooms, & a road to E of east building. 2 small 3rd C. coin hoards found in top of large pit. JRS 1958. 43: 137. HER: Excavation in 'Black Wong' field in 1950s, by E Greenfield, recorded 2 groups of buildings 500 yards apart. A huge amount of remains were found - coin hoards, pits, 23 hearths, 62 oven bases (furnaces?), post holes, wells, quarries, burials... Finds incl. 111 Roman coins, 31 bronze brooches & many iron objects incl. a spear blade, a shield boss & a pilum. Excav. in 'Black Holme' field revealed one of buildings on APs was a temple. IA coins also found during excav. In total 8 acres of occupation uncovered. In 1963 further excav. on temple site revealed earliest shrine dated from 1st C. & was followed by 2 other stone phases. In 1970s site was systematically metal detected - IA coins recovered. During metal detecting in 1985 a circular brooch & RB coins found. In 2001 fieldwalking found 4000 sherds of pottery, brick & tile, 42kg of iron slag & burnt stone. Geophysical surveys in 2002 & 2003 revealed extensive archaeol. features incl. buildings & enclosures, a prob. road & building plots; & numerous strongly magnetic patches with light halos, which could be RB quarry pits, or for ore roasting.

name: PAS: Uppingham 1728
comments: Robertson 2000, 360 no. 1480:"6 Sept. 1814"As a poor woman of Uppingham was, with her son, gathering nuts in a small wood, called Holyoak Spenney, about four miles from that place, the boy perceived part of an earthen vessel emerging from the bed of a small stream, which, on examination, proved to be a Roman vase, filled with silver coins of the Emperor Valentinian, Valens, Gratian, Theodosius and Maximinus [sic]. The coins are, consequently, from 1430 to 1450 years old, and the whole are in most excellent preservation."Annual Register, 1814, 84"In the year 1814, a woman found in a wood near Uppingham, a Roman vase which contained 600 silver coins of various emperors."A.J. Waterfield, in Rutland Magazine, I (1904-6), 160This hoard, and the circumstances of discovery, are very similar to the hoard found in 1799 in Holyoke Wood, Stockerston, Leicestershire [no. 1506], but the dates of discovery are about 15 years apart."

name: PAS: Whitwell 1730
comments: A hoard containing one gold finger-ring, two solidi of Valentinian II and Honorius and 1,091 siliquae of emperors from Constantius II to Honorius was discovered by Mr and Mrs R V Stubbs, Mrs J R Holmes and Mr W Finbow while using metal detectors on a ploughed field between Grange Farm and the A606 in the parish of Whitwell. The initial discovery of the gold ring and 786 coins was made between September and October 1991 and further coins were recovered during subsequent visits to the site in October 1992 (86 coins) and July - September 1993 (221 coins). The coins were found widely scattered over a 15-acre field, mostly about three inches below ground level. Many of the coins had been bent by the rotovator. The hoard was submitted to the British Museum in January 1992 and was the subject of Treasure Trove Inquests held at Oakham on 21 May 1992 and 24 February 1993. Many of the coins were clipped and the date of deposition is thus not likely to have been before c.AD 410. 2 solidi (Valentinian II, 1; Honorius, 1); 1091 siliquae (Constantius II, 17; Julian Caesar, 4; Julian Augustus, 55; Jovian, 7; Valentinian I, 12; Valens, 75; Gratian, 75; Valentinian II, 31; Theodosius I, 64; Magnus Maximus, 79; Flavius Victor, 12; Eugenius, 42; Arcadius, 226; Honorius, 281; Anonymous, 1; illegible, 66; irregular, 44); 1 gold finger-ring. Addenda of: 86 silver siliquae to Honorius(1992) and 221 silver siliquae to Honorius (1993). Solidi: AD 383-88 (1)1. Valentinian II, rev.: CONCORDI-A AVGGG?, Constantinopolis std. facing; in exergue: CONOB, RIC Constantininopolis 67(b), 1, 4.13gAD 394-402 (1)2. Honorius, rev.: VICTORI-A AVGGG, Emperor stg. r., in field: M D; in exergue, COMOB, RIC IX Milan 35(c ) = RIC X 1206, 4.44g

name: PAS: Bridgnorth Area 1736
comments: 2,891 nummi to 355 in a pot with copper alloy ring. PATAR 2007, 507; NC 2010.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2007 T664Other PAS records associated with this hoard: HESH-881F86

name: PAS: Shrewsbury area 1738
comments: 18 radiates & 9297 nummi to AD 335, found by a detectorist, contained in a broken ceramic jar & dug up by finder in area of a SAM (no. 3491) without permission from EH or landowner. A subsequent archaeol. excav. recovered scatter of coins in immediate area & some assoc. sherds from the jar. The pot originally placed in pit & covered by a large flat stone. Some prior disturbance (poss. animal or root action) had caused coins to be scattered around the pot.

name: PAS: Kynnersley 1740
comments: Robertson 2000, 274 no. 1148:""After the earlier portion of the present volume was printed, some Roman coins were found on the wild moors near Kinnersley, the estate of his Grace the Duke and Earl of Sutherland.The coins in question belong to the lower empire, and are of that kind so commonly found in Great Britain. They belong to the reign of Constantine. Some were of the GLORIA EXERCITVS types, others were of Constantinopolis (TRS) or Urbs Roma."-C.H. Hartshorne, Salopia Antiqua (1841), Introd., xvi, some types-The coins were probably all small AE."

name: PAS: Knockin 1741
comments: 22 nummi to 329. NC 2006, 26.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2005 T071

name: PAS: Wroxeter 1755
comments: This small hoard from excav. at Palaestra at Wroxeter comprises 58 billon & bronze coins, found in S aisle during 1983 excav. season. No trace of container discovered, but all came from within a single 1m square & none shows more than a slight degree of wear, as such they represent a scattered hoard. Several similar coins found in area could be accepted as from hoard without materially affecting its composition or date. Brickstock, R.J. 1992. CHRB 9: 339-44.

name: PAS: Wroxeter 1756
comments: 47 AE from excav. spoil heap.    Burnett, A.M. & Casey, P.J. 1981. CH 6: 38.

name: PAS: Wroxeter (Hypocaust) 1760
comments: During excav, 3 skeletons found in hypocaust. One was skeleton of an old man, apparently crouching in a corner, at least 1 other was female. Near old man lay a little heap of Roman copper coins, in such a manner as shews they must have been contained in a confined receptacle; and a number of small iron nails lying among them, with traces of decomposed wood, leaves no doubt that this was a little box or coffer." Coins were 1 sil., 2 ant. & 129 small AE. Roach Smith, C. 1858. NC: 79-83. R.J. Brickstock (1987) in BAR 176, 405f., nos. 107-8, separated Wroxeter (Hypocaust) find into 2 hoards.

name: PAS: Coopers Row 1761
comments: 134 nummi to 358 in a pot. NC 2010.

name: PAS: Charlton Horethorne 1770
comments: 6 nummi to 328.

name: PAS: Cheddar (Gough's Old Cave) 1773
comments: "376 coins, part of the Cheddar collections of the Marquess of Bath, at the museum at Gough's Cave...found during excavation of Gough's Old Cave behind the restaurant, and in the precipitous slope known as the Slitter, adjacent to the cave. The large number of coins of the House of Valentinian due to presence of remains of two small rouleaux (now broken apart). A good part of the bronze coins making up the 'Valentinian' total probably came from a disturbed hoard, and the same would probably apply to the '4th century' silver and gold." G.C. Boon, in NC, 1957, 231-7. In NC, 1961, 199. Boon doubted provenance of some of coins; though remainder are entirely acceptable."

name: PAS: Cheddar 1774
comments: Robertson 2000, 284 no. 1210: ""Twenty-five 'third brass' coins, Roman, of the earlier half of the fourth century AD, found in quarrying between Tutter's Hill (Milkway) and the foot of Chelm's Combe, Cheddar. They consist of"AEConstantine I 5Constantine II, Caes. 5Constantinopolis 4Urbs Roma 4Constans, Caes. 2Theodora (after AD 337) 1"Constantine period" 3"Defaced" 125"Given by Mr. R.F. Parry, Cheddar."Report of Curator of Somerset County Museum, Taunton, from 10 July 1929, to 22 July 1930 (Annual Meeting), in Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., LXXVI (1), 1930, lxxxvii25 coins in Somerset County Museum, Taunton"

name: PAS: Chilton Polden 1781
comments: Robertson 2000, 390 no. 1580:""Another hoard of coins was found early in the last century in a field belonging to the late Mr. Norris, adjoining some of the pottery mounds, but appears to be unrecorded by Stradling.Mr. Norris's son has now forty-eight coins in his possession, forty-one of which are silver, and of these thirty-two belong to the fourth or very early fifth century. These coins are presumably only part of the hoard found in a pot which was placed on a post and broken by workmen throwing stones at it."A. Bulleid, 26 March 1914, in PSA, (2), XXVI (1913-14), 142In Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, from the Spenser George Perceval Bequest, 1920, are 6 siliquae, labelled "Denarii of Valens, Theodosius, Magnus Maximus, Eugenius, Arcadius and Honorius, portion of hoard found in a pot (?) at Huntspill Somerset - Bought of Farmer Norris - in 1859?. Gave I think £1 for the 6 coins. Oct. 3, 1900. S.G. Perceval."1 sil. seen in 1978 (ASR) was of Valens (RIC 27 b.)"

name: PAS: Chilton Polden 1782
comments: "Two small leather purses found in the Turbary last year, which soon fell to dust on exposure to the air; they were in two of the mounds containing fragments of pottery; one contained silver coins of the later Emperors, and the other the smallest size copper of the same era, both so much clipped that but few of the inscriptions are left." W. Stradling, Description of the Priory of Chilton-super-Polden (1839), 14. In 1945, a parcel of the siliquae was sold at B.A. Seaby's to E.J.W. Hildyard. In 1885 Morland & Bulleid excavated a mound at ST 3700 4329 (PRN 10985) and surveyed 40 others. In 1914 Bulleid published a plan & description. Excavation showed deposit of large nos. of potsherds mingled with briquetage debris & fine ash. The briquetage included tiles & bricks, bars, saggers etc. No structural remains, other than one clay floor. Observation of clay-working and the Huntspill Cut in 1935-1945 revealed that debris-mounds, on surface of peat & covered by clay, marked a 3rd C AD marine transgression, extending to Burnham-on-Sea.

name: PAS: Crewkerne 1784
comments: Robertson 2000, 262 no. 1097:""One of the most recent and interesting manifestations [i.e. of the Roman occupation] was the finding, in June, 1872, of a large number of Roman coins - at least one hundred and thirty - upon Combe Farm, within a few hundred yards of Lady Down and of the road from Clapton and Wayford to which I have just referred. The coins were found in digging sand on the hill-side, close to a row of labourers' cottages north-west of the farm-house. They were all what is known as third-brass, and were in almost perfect preservation. The greater part were of the reign of Constantine the Great.The rest were of the reigns of Licinius and Crispus. From the mintmarks 'PLon' and 'PTre' the coinage was at London and Tr[e]ves. No trace of any urn, or of any other remains to throw light upon the hoard were discovered, and fragments of what were first thought to be human bones lying beside the coins were proved to be those of a pig."-G.P.R. Pulman, Book of the Axe (1875), 72-"Roman coins to the number of 150 have been recently discovered in a field belonging to Combe Farm, Crewkerne, Somerset. They are principally of the reigns of Constantine and are in a good state of preservation. Some of them were coined in London, and others at Tr[e]ves."-Arch. Camb., 27 (1872), Collectanea, 272-A ref. in Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., XVII (1872), (2), 124, to "six Roman coins (copper Antoninus Augustus) found on Combe Farm, near Crewkerne, by Mr. Penny", must be either a record of a different find from the Constantinian hoard, or an incorrect description of 6 coins from the hoard.In Royal Albert Memorial Museum, Exeter, were 6 Constantinian AE coins "found about 5 feet deep on Coombe Farm, Crewkerne, Somerset. Presented by Mr. Penny." They were of Constantine I 2; Crispus 1; Constantine II, Caes. 3. The rev. legends were BEAT(A) TRANQ(VIL)LITAS, D N CONSTANTINI MAX AVG VOT XX, and CAESARVM NOSTRORVM VOT X. The mints were London, Trier, and Rome.Cp. P.J. Casey, in CH IV (1978), 42, no. 164.Examined 5 out of 6 coins in Royal Albert Memorial Museum, Exeter, 1978 (ASR)"

name: PAS: White Woman's Hole 1785
comments: "White Woman's Hole is in Asham Wood, in a long valley between Cranmore and Chantry. Entrance in N side of valley, 9m below valley lip...cave revealed evidence of counterfeiting in Constantinian period, with c. 200 coins, coin frags, droplets of bronze, and sections of cast rod. J.H. Barrett, Proc. Univ. of Bristol Spel. Soc., 13 (1972), 61-9. …location of material carefully recorded by M. Barrett..deposits in cave thoroughly turned over, so post-med pot and clay pipe lay beneath some R-B objects. About 120 small scraps, snippets and runners of bronze, also found; twist of fine bronze wire, scrap of twisted iron wire, latter perhaps modern. G.C. Boon, in Proc. Univ. of Bristol Spel. Soc., 13 (i) (1972), 70-8. Hoard in Bristol Museum.

name: PAS: Mendip Hills 1787
comments: Robertson 2000, 269-270 no. 1126:"In the autumn of 1865, "a workman employed in the Mendip Hills about six miles from Frome, came upon a hoard of Roman brass coins, about a foot beneath the surface, and, according to the description given 'with some dust surrounding them'.In the present instance the number of coins found appears to have been about 452." The 452 coins were 1 ant. and 451 small AE:Ant. AETetricus I 1Constantine I 225Licinius I 4Crispus 73Constantine II, Caes. 97Constantius II, Caes. 18Helena 16Fausta 12Constantinopolis 4reign of Constantine I 21 451(SECVRITAS REIPVBLICE)(Types not given)-(Sir) John Evans, in NC, 1866, 157-69, types, mints-Forty of the coins came into the possession of Mr. C. Moore of Bath; the remaining 412 were acquired by (Sir) John Evans." NB the other hoard is listed as Frome.

name: PAS: Ilchester 1792
comments: Robertson 2000, 274 no. 1149:"[For Ilchester, 1949b, see no. 1508.]On 7 July 1949, "some workmen digging a trench in Church St., Ilchester, for a new water main, found ten coins associated with three bones. They were not in a container. I have no doubt they represent a small hoard or part of a scattered hoard.They were at 3 feet from the surface among debris of the Roman period which contained a very large quantity of Samian, New Forest and coarse ware. I examined the earth that was excavated and found bone pins, whetstones, and some 150 sherds of Samian worth preserving, Kimmeridge shale bracelets and various indeterminate objects of iron. Substantial Roman period foundations were visible."-Letter, July 1949, from J.S. Cox, Ilchester-The 10 coins, 7 ant. 3 AE, were:-Ant. AETetricus I 1Carausius 2radiates (irregular?) 3Constantine I 1Constantine II, Caes. 1Constantinopolis 1uncertain (radiate?) 17 3(GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand.)Examined, 1949 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Ilchester 1793
comments: Robertson 2000, 367 no. 1508:"On 30 Oct. 1949, some workmen digging a trench for a water main in Church Street, Ilchester, found, at a depth of 2 1/2 feet, 33 small brass Roman coins, all lying together, but not enclosed in any container. With the coins were two scraps of bone, stained green, and half of a crossbow brooch of bronze, with the hinged pin missing. [For Ilchester, 1949a, see no. 1149]:AEConstantinopolis 1Urbs Roma 1Constantius II, Aug. 1 Valentinian I 2Valens 1Valentinian I or Valens 3Valentinian II 1Eugenius 1Arcadius 1Arcadius or Honorius 1"Theodosian" 15uncertain, probably "Theodosian" 533(VICTORIA AVGGG)(SALVS REIPVBLICAE)(VICTORIA AVGGG)(SALVS REIPVBLICAE)(SALVS REIPVBLICAE 2; VICTORIA AVGGG 2; uncertain 11)(4 in frag.s)Letter, Nov. 1949, from J.S. Cox, IlchesterThe coins were all very badly corroded. Those from Valentinian II onwards included 4 with rev. SALVS REIPVBLICAE; 4 with rev. VICTORIA AVGGGExamined, 1949 (ASR). An additional 24 coins recorded on the HER from the same days' excavation (possibly part of the same scattered hoard) are included here."

name: PAS: Martock 1798
comments: 425 nummi and two ceramic vessels. Found in two distinct groups but mixed before reporting.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2012 T520Other PAS records associated with this hoard: SOM-8D3931

name: PAS: Milverton 1800
comments: Robertson 2000, 364 no. 1496:""Sir Walter C. Trevelyan, Bart., has forwarded to the Committee the annexed list of Roman coins recently found in an urn, on Mr. Gordon's estate, at Milverton, Somersetshire." The coins were all sil.:Sil.Julian II 3Valentinian I 3Valens 7Valentinian II 2 Theodosius 6Magnus Maximus 16 Arcadius 1"Faustina" 745AJ, IV (1847), 145f."

name: PAS: North Curry 1804
comments: Robertson 2000, 390 no. 1582:""At North Curry, near Taunton, Somersetshire, July 12, 1748, there was ploughed up, in a field where a hedge had stood, an urn in which were contained several silver coins, viz. of Gratianus, Valentinianus, Valens, Theodosius, Honorius, Arcadius, Constantinus, Constans, Julianus, Mag. Maximus, and many others. They are all of the same size, excepting one of Gratianus, with this inscription D N GRATIANVS P F AVG and on the reverse, a sort of an angel standing with one of his feet on a globe, with a shield in his hands; in which are these words VOT V MVLT X and in the round VICTORIA AVGVSTORVM and in the bottom S M TR. This piece is three times as large as any of the others, and weighs very near a shilling. There have been found about 150 of the smaller pieces, and the greatest part of them are now in the possession of the Rev. Mr. Woodforde, vicar of North Curry above mentioned. They have been viewed by several learned gentlemen and are reckoned to be some of the greatest curiosities of that kind hitherto found. They are as perfect, and free from decay, as if they were but very lately coin'd, notwithstanding the latest of them is above 1350 years old."J. Pile, in Gent. Mag. 18 (1748), 405The description of the coin of Gratian shows it to have been a miliarensis.8 sil. in Somerset County Museum, Taunton:Julian II, Aug. 6Valens 1Magnus Maximus 18Examined, 1958, 1978 (ASR)"

name: PAS: North Petherton 1805
comments: 24 nummi of 318-24. TAR 2002, 203; NC 2003, 13.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2002 T074

name: PAS: Whatley Combe Villa 1808
comments: "During excav. of Roman villa at Whatley Combe, central rooms: "In the room completely excavated several coins found in destruction layer above [floor?], a coin of Constantine I (AD 317-20) & a 'small hoard' of five coins deposited c. AD 350. 'hoard' and coins from burnt layer provide evidence for destruction c. AD 350. Marion Archibald, in Proc. Som Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., CXIV (1970), 42-4, 47". ER: Roman corridor villa found in 1837 in ‘Chessils Field’ in Whatley Combe. Partly excavated in 1837, 1848 & 1958 (see PRN 28414). Triclinium at NW end contained Orpheus mosaic now mostly destroyed, belongs to first phase apparently dating to late C3. Extensions in the first half of the C4 & basic changes to the plan in the mid C4. The villa fell into disuse by third quarter of the C4.

name: PAS: Seavington St Michael 1812
comments: 9 nummi to 325. Find was made in an area 100m square and although the majority are clearly typical late Roman site losses, there is possibly a core of Tetrarchic-Constantinian purse hoard of nine nummi which appear to be in similar condition and make sense as a hoard. However, given the mix of intruders there is some room for doubt: it is not impossible that some of the radiates might have formed part of the group, and likewise it is difficult to be certain whether the nummi of the AD 320s should be classed as hoard coins as they are here. NC 2010.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2009 T116Other PAS records associated with this hoard: SOM-EA41A5

name: PAS: Shapwick II 1813
comments: Robertson 2000, 364 no. 1497:""At a distance of 6 feet from the spot where the hoard of 120 siliquae describedin Num. Chron., 1936, 245-250, was found [Robertson no. 1584], a further discovery of 125 siliquae was made on June 18, 1937, by Percy Spiller Mullins of Meare, while cutting peat on Shapwick Moor. They had been placed in a pottery beaker - now repaired - and the whole enclosed in a pewter jug of typical Roman design."The 125 sil. were:Sil.Constantius II 4Julian II 7Valentinian I 2Valens 34Gratian 36Valentinian II 10Theodosius 4Magnus Maximus 26Flavius Victor 1Arcadius 1125(1 Caes.)J.W.E. Pearce, in NC, 1938, 53-8, types, mintsH. St. George Gray, in Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., LXXXIII (1937), 148-52, gave a full description, with photos., of findspot, pot and pewter jug. The pot was a beaker of soft buff clay, with darker brown slip, 4 5/8 in. high and 3 1/8 in. in diam. It had a bulbous body and rounded rim. The pewter jug, 7 3/8 in. high and 4? in. in diam., had a grooved handle and narrow neck. Its shape had been much distorted when the little beaker was placed inside with the coins.Dr. Cathy King, when referring to the Shapwick, 1937, hoard in BNJ, 51 (1981), 6, 9, 12f., 15, 18, 21f., gave the total of coins of Valens as 33, and stated that some of the 125 sil. were clipped, contra J.W.E. Pearce.105 sil. in Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM, presented by P.S. Mullins (BM Register of Coin Accessions, Aug. 1937)The remaining 20 sil., the beaker and the pewter jug are in Somerset County Museum, Taunton.Examined, and pot drawn, 1958, 1978 (ASR) NB a fourth hoard consisting of vessels was found at the same time."

name: PAS: Abergele 1814
comments: Robertson 2000, 342-343 no. 1405:"In the College Museum, Bangor, "associated with the cabinet containing the silver (i.e. the denarii from the Abergele (1842) hoard) [no. 383], is a small collection of 34 Roman bronze coins, which has always been supposed to be from Abergele. In the Museum also, but not definitely associated in the same manner, is another bronze collection of 22 coins. These two collections agree exactly in type and range of date (c. AD 260-c.380), the only difference being in condition and legibility. It is, therefore, considered certain that they are portions of the same original collection, traditionally from Abergele..The bronze must, then, be regarded as a separate hoard found at Abergele perhaps at the same time as the silver quite by chance and not in association with them, but more likely at some other date before the earliest reference to the find."The coins were 25 ant., and 31 small AE: Ant. AEGordian III 1Gallienus (sole reign) 1Postumus 3Victorinus 2Claudius II 3Quintillus 1Tetricus I 9Tetricus II 4Constantine I 9Licinius I 1Constantine II, Caes. 3Constantinopolis 1Urbs Roma 1Constantius II, Aug. 3Constans, Aug. 2House of Constantine I 1Magnentius 1Valentinian I 2Valens 5uncertain 225 31(As, very worn)(clipped)(1 deified)(1 b.)(b.)(b.?)(GLORIA EXERCITVS, 1 stand.)(1 b.)B.H. O'Neil, in BBCS, VII (1933-5), 64-72, types, mintsOne coin listed as Tetricus I (b.) seems to ASR to be of Tetricus II (b.).One coin listed as uncertain seems to ASR to be of Victorinus?.The coins are now in the Museum of Welsh Antiquities, Bangor.Examined, 1978 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Halifax 1815
comments: Robertson 2000, 302-303 no. 1256:""On May 21st, 1915, some schoolchildren, playing at 'The Rocks' Halifax, found a few coins lying loose on and among the scree at the foot of the upper 'pitch' of the outcrop of millstone grit which gives its name to the spot. The actual place of discovery is situated about 400 yards east of the quarry at the westerly end of the Drive, and less than twenty feet below the level of the modern road. A rough path leads down 'The Rocks' here, and the coins were lying on and near the path.No trace of a vase or other receptacle was found, and it is obvious at a glance that no Roman habitation ever occupied the site. The most natural explanation of the find is that the coins were hidden in a bag of leather or some other perishable material, in a crevice at the foot of the rocks, which have in the interval disintegrated."The coins were 1 ant, and 1074 small AE:Ant. AETetricus I 1Constantine I 30Constantine II, Caes. 67Constantine II, Caes. 33Constantinopolis 27Urbs Roma 32Constans, Caes. 14Delmatius 5Helena (after AD 337) 39Theodora (after AD 337) 33Constantius II, Aug. 205Constans, Aug. 473Constantius II, orConstans, Aug. 86House of Constantine I 301 1074(4 b.?)(3 b.?)(including 2 FEL TEMP REPARATIO, phoenix, galley or hut)(including 3 FEL TEMP REPARATIO, phoenix, galley or hut)(1 with FEL TEMP REPARATIO)(of AD 330-40)All the coins except the ant. were later than AD 330.Some of the 547 coins with VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN were irregular.A.M. Woodward, in Yorks. A.J., 23 (1915), 444-51, types, mintsCoins were said to have been deposited in Bankfield Museum, Halifax, but have not been located there.Cp. R.J. Brickstock, in BAR 176 (1987), 348, no. 45, incorrect total of 1054."

name: PAS: Caerwent (Temple) 1817
comments: During excav. on temple in Insula IX beside forum, E of temenos was a shop contemporary with temple but overlying earlier strip-buildings; it yielded a hoard of 30 coins terminating in AD 378-83." Brewer, R. 1986. Britannia 17: 369f.

name: PAS: Shipham 1818
comments: Robertson 2000, 314 no. 1305:""A hoard of c. 840 billon coins down to c. 355 is recorded."Britannia, XVIII (1987), 343; from A.M. Burnett"The hoard was found in 1986 by Mr L Hayes whilst renovating and extending Kulu Lodge, Horseleaze Lane, Shipham, Somerset. The coins were inside a colour-coated flagon which was discovered whilst Mr Haynes was using a mechanical excavator to dig trenches for drains. Only a small proportion of the vessel was recovered The hoard comprises 860 coins, of which 26 were retained by the finder and the remaining 834 were purchased by the Somerset County Museums Service (accession number TTNCM 172/1986) All but six coins in the Shipham hoard post-date the reform of AD 348. Absence of coins minted later than AD 355 provides a close indication of the date of burial..The coins were as follows:Constantine I Crispus Constans Constantius Magmentius Decentius Gallus TotalAmiens - - - 13 32 2 3 50Trier 2 - 41 91 37 6 2 179Lyons 2 - 16 110 10 6 2 146Arles - - 3 40 4 2 2 51Rome - - 48 8 - - 6 62Ostia 1 - - - - - - 1Aquileia - - 18 7 - - 5 30Siscia - - 5 4 - - 1 10Heraclea - - - - - - 2 3Nicomedia - - - 4 - - 1 5Antioch - 1 - - - - - 1Uncertain - - 9 26 18 2 4 59Total 5 1 140 304 101 18 30 599Irregular 261Grand Total 860S. Minnitt, in CHRB IX (1992), 324-38, types, mints, weights834 coins with the Somerset County Museums Service."

name: PAS: Bourton-On-The-Water (Whiteshoots) 1819
comments: Robertson 2000, 250 no. 1035:""Group of coins found together in field west of the Fosse Way opposite Whiteshoots House:"Ant AETetricus II 1Constantine I 13Urbs Roma 11 14(semi-b.)(1 BEATA TRANQVILLITAS)(b.)"The thirteen Constantine I coins in this last group (with one exception) are in an excellent state of preservation, four still retaining traces of the original silvering. All are folles of the period AD 309-22, and are obviously part of a disturbed hoard."-D.W. Burge, for Mrs. Helen O'Neil, Trans. Bristol and Glos. Arch. Soc., 87 (1968), 54, types, mints"

name: PAS: Holway 1832
comments: Robertson 2000, 391 no. 1585:""The Reverend Henry Christmas laid before the Society a list of Roman Silver Medallions and Coins, found in 1830, in a field at Holwel [sic], near Taunton, on the estate of Downing Blake, Esq. They were deposited in an urn of red Samian pottery, which was shattered to pieces by the plough." Then came a list of 33 mil, and 285 sil..NC, 1845, Proc., 9-14, types, mints"It was in the year 1821 that a Roman urn containing a great number of silver coins was ploughed up at Holway in a field called the Ten Acres, belonging to Mr. Blake, the ploughshare striking against the urn and breaking off the top of it. Near the urn were found also the remains of two human skeletons. The earliest of the coins found in the urn was one of the fifth year of Constans AD 342, and the latest of them was one of the tenth year of Honorius, bearing the mintmark of Constantinople AD 405. The coins were in perfect preservation and were of the following emperors:- Constans, Constantius II, Julian, Jovian, Valentinian, Valens, Gratian, Valentinian II, Theodosius, Arcadius and Honorius..Many coins passed into private hands.Rev. J.H. Pring, in Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., XXIV (1879), (2), 104f.; XXVII (1882), (2), 51-9VCH Somerset I (1911), 356, followed by others, have taken the date of discovery as 1821.Somerset County Museum, Taunton, acquired 232 coins (1 mil. and 231 sil.) from the Holway, Taunton, hoard.The two lists, of 33+285, and of 1+ 231, coins are here set alongside one another:NC, 1845 TauntonMil. Sil. Mil. Sil.Constantius II 16 16Constans 2Julian II 2 42 44Jovian 7 8Valentinian I 10 38 1 20Valens 4 22 21Gratian 7 34 27Valentinian II 2 18 14Theodosius 4 42 23Magnus Maximus 1 12 13Flavius Victor 10 6Eugenius 1 10 11Arcadius 29 17Honorius 5 1133 285 1 231(2 Caes.) (2 Caes.)(2 perf.)(1 perf.)(1 perf.)None of the coins in Somerset County Museum, Taunton, were worn, except for the perforated coins, which were very worn from rubbing."From the account given above, it must be clear that the 430 coins listed below do not constitute the whole find..R Bland and S Minnit, in CHRB VIII (1988), 232Bland and Minnit, ibid. pp. 231-38Milarenses Argentei SiliquaeConstantius II - 1 27Constans 3 - -Julian 2 - 71Jovian - - 13Valentinian I 9 - 26Valens 10 - 40Gratian 7 - 42Valentinian II 6 1 42Theodosius 2 - 36 plus 2 half-siliquaeMagnus Maximus 3 - 18Victor - - 9Eugenius 1 - 16Arcadius - - 26Honorius - - 14Irregular - - 411 of these coins in Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM, and 4 in Somerset County Museum, TauntonCp. G.C. Boon in Coins and the Archaeologist (1988), 143f.; 173, n. 225; 187, pl. VIII, 143, for FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman copy in silverCp. G.C. Boon in Coins and the Archaeologist (1988), 143f.; 173, n. 225; 187, pl. VIII, 143, for FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman copy in silverExamined, 1958, 1978 (ASR)."The total number of coins in the hoard is disputed (notes in BM file). VCH mentions 1870s find of 15 coins of this date, with charred pottery, elsewhere in Holway (Taunton, Pastscape 190766 - possibly not a hoard). There may be some confusion with this find. A further portion of coins was sold at auction in 1991 and is listed in a file in the BM.

name: PAS: Ickham 1835
comments: Robertson 2000, 346 no. 1418:""During archaeological excavations being carried out at Ickham, Kent during 1974 an intensive search was made of a large area which had been mechanically stripped of topsoil in advance of gravel extraction. A large number of potsherds were found in the surface of the gravel, all dating to the mid-fourth century AD. As part of this search the whole area was investigated using a metal detector and readings plotted. The group of coins detailed below were found as a result of this search. Although there was no sign of a container the coins were in close proximity to one another and undoubtedly belong together..The coins, 29 in all, were AE3 of only three emperors:"Lyons Arles Rome Aquileia Uncertain TOTALValentinian I 2 6 2 1 11Valens 6 1 2 2 11Gratian 2 4 - - 64 16 3 3 2 28There was also 1 irregular copy of a coin of Valentinian I, Lyons mint."One-third of the hoard, amounting to more than half of the Arles mint coins in particular, belong to the last years of the period AD 367-375. In fact all the coins in the hoard from this period belong to one mintmark series which has been assigned to the final issue before the death of Valentinian features in the coinage. This then is remarkably dissimilar to a normal hoard pattern where a tailing off process is more usual; and if explanation be required, the hoard could well represent the contents of a purse accidentally lost, perhaps by a traveller freshly arrived from the Continent."K.J. Elks, in CH II (1976), 53-5, no. 186, types, mints"

comments: 61 siliquae and 1 half-siliqua to 395. Addenda: 11 siliquae to 395; 65 siliquae (20 frags) and 1 miliarensis (frag) to 395; 13 siliquae to 383-8. It was found in the same field as the large radiate hoard known as the Frome hoard. NC 2011.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2010 T278; 2011 T233; 2012 T732; 2013 T785Other PAS records associated with this hoard: SOM-6E89B0; SOM-111833; WILT-D4D963; WILT-C90386

name: PAS: Yeovil 1846
comments: Robertson 2000, 310 no. 1276:""On September 16th., 1916, I received information from Yeovil that a large number of Roman coins had been found on Friday, September 15th., by a man employed by Messrs. Steel and Pearce, contractors of Plymouth, who were laying a 6-inch water-main for the Corporation of Yeovil..The labourer found the coins in digging a 11/2 foot trench in the field at a point about 144 feet south of the nearest point of the pavement of Seaton Road, at a depth of 3 feet below the surface and about 3 feet east of a sewer which had recently been laid. The foreman also informed me that a few coins had also been found at intervals along the trench between Seaton Road and the hoard, and along the side of the trench here I observed some remains of ancient mortar and small earthenware tile..No definite evidence of the manner in which the coins were buried was forthcoming, some saying that the decayed remains of a box were observed, others that the coins were contained in a crock of earthenware."(Footnote: "The men who were present when the coins were found state that the coins were 'not in any crock or thing whatever'.")Out of a total of at least 1000 coins, 852, all small AE, were identified:AEConstantine I 31Constantine II, Caes. 40Constantius II, Caes. 25 Constantinopolis 15Urbs Roma 10Constans, Caes. 15Delmatius 3Helena (after AD 337) 28Theodora (after AD 337) 23Constantine II, Aug. 2Constantius II, Aug. 152Constans, Aug. 468House of Constantine I 31uncertain 9852(1 b., with Victory on rev.; 3 deified)(2 b.)(1 FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman)(1 VOT XX MVLT XXX)(2 b. or semi-b., GLORIA EXERCITVS, 1 stand. (1); VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN (1) )(2 b.)Close by were found tiles, potsherds, shells, etc., and 13 other small AE coins:Constantine II, Caes. 1Theodora 1Constans 5House of Constantine I 4uncertain 213"Judging from their colour and decayed condition I am of opinion that these coins did not form part of the hoard."H. St. George Gray, in Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., LXII (1916), 86-112, types, mints)111 coins in Somerset County Museum, TauntonExamined, 1978 (ASR) Known site of a villa"

name: PAS: Alveston 1849
comments: During fieldwork on the line of the M5 Motorway, at Lodge Farm, Rudgeway, Alveston, prehistoric activity was established, preceding a Romano-British settlement.27 Roman coins were found: 1 ant. and 26 fourth century AE:Ant. AETetrici (probably) 1Constantine I 13Constantine I (?) 1Constantine II, Caes. 1"Constantinian" 114Constans, Aug. 1Constantine II, Constantius II, or Constans, Aug. 1Gratian 1Theodosius 1uncertain 11 26(2 Constantinopolis)(PROVIDENTIAE (AVGG?))(Constantinopolis)(GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand.)(VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN)(VIRTVS AVGG NN?)"Most of the coins are in relatively good condition, indicating that they went out of use not too long after minting. The coin range suggests occupation from at least the beginning of the fourth century to the time of Theodosius and possibly later.The concentration of coins of c. 320-330 suggests that there may have been a small hoard - a purseful of coins? - either lost or deposited c. 332." -M. Hebditch, on the Coins, in P.J. Fowler, J. Bennett and V.S. Hill, "Archaeology and the M5 Motorway. Fourth Report"-In Trans. Bristol and Glos. Arch. Soc., 94 (1976), 47-91 especially 68f., some types

name: PAS: Tredington 1852
comments: Robertson 2000, 361 no. 1484:""At Talton, five coins, Julian (2), Valentinian I, Flavius Victor, Valentinian III (votis XXX mult XXXX) found 1861 (J.H. Bloom)."VCH Worcs., I (1901), 220The rev. legend, VOT (is) XXX MVLT XXXX, showed that the coin did not belong to Valentinian I or II. Although the legend is recorded on gold coins of Valentinian III, it is more likely, in this case, to have been present on a siliqua of Constantius II."

name: PAS: Hawkesbury 1853
comments: 1 radiate, 41 nummi to 402, forger's coin mould, copper alloy brooch and pendant. PATAR 2007, 520; NC 2008, 41.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2007 T566Other PAS records associated with this hoard: GLO-2AD8F2
