The site consisted of a WB area in 1982, and a fieldwalking survey in '83, between school site & Clothall Road to the footpath to SE, conducted with local metal detectorists & members of North Herts. Arch. Soc. Pit 266 was small & steep-sided with a flat bottom, & contained a coin hoard consisting of at least 23 coins deposited in a pot around AD 350. The pit was truncated by a later Roman rubbish pit 265. (Burleigh & Stevenson 1995: 11).

name: PAS: Cunetio 2974
comments: Small hoard of 32 late 3rd to mid-4th C. coins found in excavs by Ken Annable at Cunetio (Black Field, Mildenhall,), a few miles east of Marlborough, in 1960. The hoard was located about a foot above the surface of large limestone paving at W gate of the fortified town. Moorhead, S.T. and Kent, Cunetio (1960) hoard.

name: PAS: Wenvoe 2978
comments: Hoard of 45 nummi.

name: PAS: Church Farm 2980
comments: A hoard of five nummi from the upper fill of a boundary ditch of an excavated farmstead. Find spot on edge of Caldicot, on a SE facing slope of a gentle valley extending SE towards Rver Severn, with Nedern Brook 450m to E, & River Severn itself 1.9km to SE.

name: PAS: Bristol (Ashton Vale) 2982
comments: Robertson 2000, 279 no. 1174:""Roman coin hoard - Ashton ValeOn 19th June one of the machine drivers on my Chelmsford excavations informed me of a number of archaeological finds he had made over the course of many years, including a coin hoard from Ashton Vale. He has some of the coins in his possession and I have attempted to extract a description of the site from him..The site location is vague, but I took down what the man said:'stand with your back to Bristol Aircraft Factory in Ashton Vale; walk towards Bedminister White Horse; about half way there are buildings on the right hand side which were originally constructed for "Metal Agencies" of London.' The hoard was found there, he reckons about 1945/6, but is rather vague about the date. During a bulldozing operation in connection with these buildings 'a pot containing hundreds of coins was found and smashed by the bulldozer'. The coins were dispersed at the time. This man bought a quantity from another workman. He has 25 coins, the majority of which are in good clear condition."-Letter from W. J. Rodwell to L. V. Grinsell, City of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery, 12 July 1968-The 25 coins were taken to City of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery, where they were identified by M. Hebditch as 1 ant. and 24 AE:Ant. AEuncertain radiate(Tetricus I (?)) 1Constantine I 2Constantine II, Caes. 5Constantius II, Caes. 1Constantinopolis 7Urbs Roma 5Constans, Caes. 2reign of Constantine I 21 24(b.)(1 GLORIA EXERCITVS, 2 stand.)Letter, May 1969"

name: PAS: Cockerton 2985
comments: Robertson 2000, 264 no. 1107:""In later times a vast quantity of Roman third brass coins have been discovered in the Cockerbeck, between Mowden Bridge and Darlington and in Baydalebeck near the same bridge. They were in the most perfect preservation and are all of the Constantine family."-W.H.D. Longstaffe, Hist. and Ant. ofDarlington (1854), 187-A note stated that Longstaffe had seen coins of "Helena, Flavia, Maxima Fausta, Constantine I and II and Crispus."This is probably the hoard referred to in JBAA, n.s., XXVII (1921), Arch. Notes, 104:"Some 75 years ago a large number of Roman coins were found near the same spot [i.e. Cockerton].""

name: PAS: Newport 2991
comments: 34 nummi of the House of Theodosius found before 1988.

name: PAS: Cowbridge High Street 2993
comments: Five coins found during GGAT excavations outside Woodstock House.

name: PAS: Eynsham 2995
comments: Robertson 2000, 82 no. 1198:""The Ashmolean Museum has acquired twenty-six coins which, supplemented by Mr. A. Thompson's gift of a further seven, form almost the whole of a small hoard of Roman coins found recently at Eynsham, near Oxford. It is probable that only one or two coins are now lacking from the original total. The hoard was unearthed by a labourer in a field, the pot in which it was contained being thereby smashed."The coins were 1 sest., 1 ant. and 31 AE:Sest. Ant. FollesNerva 1 1Probus 1Constantine I 8Licinius I 1Crispus 3Constantine II, Caes. 15Constantius II, Caes. 1Constantinopolis 31 1 31(1 GLORIA EXERCITVS, 1 stand.)-C.H.V. Sutherland in NC, 1936, 251, types, mints-33 coins in Ashmolean Museum, OxfordExamined, 1978 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Whitesands Bay 2999
comments: A hoard of 112 coins have been identified from a scattered hoard found on the beach at Whitesands Bay between 1983 and 1996.

name: PAS: Llanelieu 3000
comments: A group of 132 coins & a flint spearhead found with an ‘earthen vessel’ in a cairn. Listed as a group by Guest & Wells but they note that it is likely to represent a hoard with some intrusive material. Some/all of coins may have been an accumulation.

name: PAS: Llangattock Park 3001
comments: Six nummi of the House of Constantine found washed out of a disturbed cairn (Carn Goch) by rainwater. Only one dated.

name: PAS: Llangwin 3003
comments: Record of a single nummus of the House of Constantine that was said to be part of a hoard of at least 100 coins found in a bog in the parish of Llangwm Dinmael.

name: PAS: Llys Awel 3005
comments: Coins metal-detected from a spring. Not a hoard but an accumulation.

name: PAS: Caernarfon (Constantine Road) 3007
comments: Four coins found in a garden, considered to be "at least part of a hoard" (Guest and Wells 2007, 1043).

name: PAS: Tywyn 3009
comments: Five nummi removed from the beach by mechanical excavator in 1988.

name: PAS: Din Lligwy 3013
comments: Five 4th C. bronze coins found 'all close together' in Area 8 during 1908-1930 excavations by E. N. Baynes of R-B settlement at Din Lligwy (Guest and Wells 1102).

name: PAS: Castor 3021
comments: HER report of a hoard of about 50 copper alloy coins of Valens, Gratian, Valentinian I and II (mints of Arles and Siscia). Found in one of two parallel ditches alongside two aisled barns (interpreted as part of a palace site).

name: PAS: Thetford 3024
comments: HER record of (variously) "a large number" or "about 20" silver coins found on the outskirts of Thetford whilst hoeing sugar beet in 1962-3. Only partial details given, without findspot. This does not appear to be a hoard already recorded by Robertson or at the BM. Only 7 recorded in Norwich.

name: PAS: Terling 3032
comments: HER record of an unpublished hoard of 30 "early fifth century coins ploughed up in 1898" according to an informant twenty-five years later.

name: PAS: Colchester (Cups Hotel) 3035
comments: Excavs on site of Cups Hotel. Succession of Roman walls found, occup. lasted to early 5th C. Early N-S Roman street observed in section, also early timber-framed wall. Finds incl. a late Roman bone comb & bronze belt mount. Comb stratified with over 100 coins (prob. part of dispersed hoard) enabling object to be dated to after c.350- 360. Assoc. pottery indicates a secure Roman date. Crummy, P, 1981. Colchester Archaeological report 1. Aspects of Anglo- Saxon and Norman Colchester, No 39 (CAT Rep 1), p7, 22.

name: PAS: Colchester (Artillery Folly) 3037
comments: A hoard of 15 clipped siliquae from Artillery Folley area of Colchester (an area used as a cemetery in R-B period). Crummy (1987: 71) states that the latest issues are of Arcadius and Honorius. However, Radford and Gascoyne (2013) describe this as 15 siliquae of Constantine III (apparently a mis-reading of Crummy 1987's comments).

name: PAS: West Bergholt or Great Horkesley 3038
comments: A hoard of 21 Fel Temp Reparatio falling horseman copies found in 1965 either in West Bergholt or Great Horkesely parish and acquired by Colchester Museum (Crummy 1987, 71). No further information available.

name: PAS: Colchester (Lion Walk site K) 3039
comments: A group of 9 coins of Constans corroded into a ‘neat pile’, as if in a rouleau, all regular. Found in Colchester Lion Walk site K (insula 36) in post-Roman topsoil. Interpreted as a purse or bag hoard.

name: PAS: Colchester (Lion Walk site R) 3040
comments: A group of 13 cu alloy coins in poor condition, thought to have possibly been contained in a bag or pouch. Found in Colchester Lion Walk site R (between insulae 29 and 37/388a), in a post-Roman pit.

name: PAS: Colchester (Butt Road) 3041
comments: Six coins found grouped on the chest area of an inhumation in the Butt Road Roman cemetery in Colchester (Grave 431, C1653). The coins are 3 Fel Temp FH copies and 3 Magnentian copies. Thought not to have been in a container due to pattern of scatter.

name: PAS: Colchester (22 Crouch Street) 3049
comments: Building in the garden of 22 Crouch Street excav in 1935. Opposite S end of an apsidal ended building was a pit 6-7 ft. deep, 3 ft in diameter. Remains of wood at bottom showed it had been shuttered to hold back soft sand. It was most probably a well, though there was no peaty sludge at bottom. The contents of the pit were remarkable. Scattered throughout filling, but with earliest examples near bottom, were c. 132 coins of Trajan to Theodosius, plus 41 barbarous issues. Hull considered these votive deposits in a well, as they were spread throughout fill, but with earliest near bottom. There was also a human skull & thigh bone, a silver ring & a silver armlet, iron stylus, knife, bowl & nails, painted wall plaster, a piece of marble, pottery frags. incl. fine wares, & bird bones. Hull, M.R. 1958. Roman Colchester. Oxford: Soc of Ants, pp. 245-246. Votive deposit not hoard. Artefacts not listed separately yet. It is uncertain how many ceramic vessels were present.The 'medallion' of Constantine II MM TRS (24mm diameter) may be a misreading of RIC 8 Thessalonica 49 (a miliarensis). This type is not know for Trier.Latest coin Honorius VICTORIA AVGGG.

name: PAS: Hanham 3058
comments: Robertson 2000, 320 no. 1324:""At the beginning of May 1951 excavation was being made for the construction of Westfield Close Road (Kingswood Urban District Council housing estate) at right angles to Greenbank Road, Hanham, and parallel to the Bristol/Bitton/Bath main road, A 431[...]. The bank of a hedgerow was being grubbed up approximately 100 yards from the present main Bath road, and the workman employed came upon 'half a bucketful' (according to another account, 'a couple of shovelsful') of coins: it is doubtful if there was any trace of a container. The find was not reported to the Kingswood U.D.C. for at least a week, by which time a number of coins had been distributed, or thrown into the excavation refuse as being too much corroded. Ultimately the Council, as owners of the land and employers of the workmen, recovered nearly 200 coins, which I am able to list here by their kind permission."The coins recovered were 1 ant., and 198 small AE:Ant. AETetricus I 1Constantine I 4Constantine II, Caes. 7Urbs Roma 1Helena (after AD 337) 2Constantius II, Aug. 28Constans, Aug. 92Constantius II, orConstans, Aug. 46House of Constantine I 8Magnentius 3uncertain 71 194(after AD 337)(including 1 frag.)(including 2 frags.)(including 1 frag.)(2 b., GLORIA EXERCITVS, 1 stand.; FEL TEMP REPARATIO, Emperor in galley, overstruck on diademed head)and 4 frags.C.H.V. Sutherland, in NC, 1954, 213-15, types, mints"

name: PAS: Spaldington 3062
comments: IARCH record for a hoard of 14 clipped siliquae YORYM-F6AE88. All the coins were worn and heavily clipped.

name: PAS: Dutton 3072
comments: IARCH record for a scattered hoard of 36 siliquae and one (stray?) nummus found with a metal detector. The site was later investigated by test-pitting but no features were found. Two ceramic sherds were found during this work but it is not certain if they relate to a container for the hoard. See LVPL-B38AFC for details and images.Unpublished catalogue by Vanessa Oakden, David Shotter and Richard Abdy.

name: PAS: Kingsdon 3073
comments: IARCH record for two silique found together in 2014 (for full details and images see SOM-B72B90). The two coins were found at a depth of c. 2-3" in the same field, amongst a large number of contemporary coins in base metal. The coin of Jovian appears to be a copy.

name: PAS: Telford 3074
comments: IARCH record for a hoard of 24 nummi. The coins were in poor condition and could not be fully identified. For further details and photos see WMID-C6D2A6.Unpublished catalogue by Riccardo Caravello  & Teresa Gilmore.

name: PAS: Thruxton 3076
comments: IARCH record for a hoard of 8 milarenses and 45 siliquae found in two batches in 2014. For further details see GLO-9D7F36. The 9 uncertain siliquae are fragments.R. Abdy (unpublished catalogue) writes: "The latest coin is not fully legible but probably takes the hoard just into the joint reign of Honorius and Arcadius. If so this sole specimen would place Thruxton near the beginning of the sizable body of British siliqua hoards, which end with the period 395-402. Furthermore, the siliquae in this hoard are virtually unclipped ('clipping factor 1' just possible on one specimen) and this, together with the presence of miliarenses alongside the siliquae, supports an earlier date for the deposition of the hoard, before the AD 395-402 coinage had much chance to spread into the circulation."

name: PAS: Spilsby area 3077
comments: IARCH record for a hoard of 206 Constantinian nummi. For full details and images see DENO-6F8801.Found whilst metal detecting on ploughed land up to 8 inches down. Coins were found scattered over 30-40 metres with most within a 15 metres area. The coins were possibly contained in a pot as suggested by just one undiagnostic rim sherd from the same findspot, though this was uncertain.Unpublished catalogue by V. Drost.

name: PAS: Thames Foreshore (Wandsworth Park Area) 3080
comments: Robertson 2000, 385 no. 1564:""A hoard of 203 bronze coins was found on the Thames foreshore in the area of Wandsworth Park. The coins range in date from the 280s to AD 402. The bulk of them date to AD 386-402, and in the main consist of coins of Valentinian II, Theodosius I, Arcadius and Honorius.":Trier Lyons Arles Rome Aquileia Constant. Cyz.Uncertain 0TOTALClaudius II 1 0Tetricus II 1 0House of Constantine I GLORIA EXERCITVS, 01 stand. 2 02Helena after AD 337) 1 01Constantius II, or Constans, Aug. 0 (VICTORIAE) 2 02Constantius II, Aug. 0(FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman) 2 02Magnentius 1 01Julian II, Caes. 1? 01Gratian 1? 01Valentinian II 2 3 2 6 013House of Valentinian I 1 3 04Theodosius 5 2 1 6 014Theodosius (?) 8 08Magnus Maximus 1 2 03Eugenius 1 or 1 01Arcadius 2 2 2 1 1 1 31 040Honorius 2 1? 5 08"Theodosian" (?) 1 12 1 86 0100RULE 0RULE3 or 9 23 6 3 3 1 156 0203(ant., b.)(ant., b.) (1 b.)(b.)(b.)(1 b.)M. Hammerson and Jenny Hall, in CHRB VII, BM Occas. Paper 59 (1987), 201-4, types, mints, wts."

name: PAS: Wraxall 3081
comments: Robertson 2000, 306-307 no. 1266:""Another discovery of Roman coins was made on the same hill and in the same year [i.e. 1815]. The place is about a mile westward from the spot last mentioned, on that prominent point of Wraxall-hill, which overlooks the Parsonage-house. A gentleman who lives in the neighbourhood, and who possesses the coins mentioned below, writes thus. 'They were all found within a circle of 300 yards in diameter, scattered near the surface, and mostly in a patch of black earth. This elevated spot had probably been used as a beacon, as none of the adjoining mould has the dark appearance of this circle.' How many coins in all were found at this place I am not informed; I examined the following." Then came a list of 4 ant. and 26 small AE:Ant. AEAntoninus Pius (?) 1Claudius II 4Constantine I 2Crispus 1Constantine II, Caes. 8Constantius II, Caes. (?) 1Constantinopolis 2 Urbs Roma 5Constantius II, orConstans, Aug. 1House of Constantine I 2uncertain 34 26("Middle brass")("Phoenix on globe")S. Seyer, Memoirs Historical and Topographical of Bristol (1821), I, 161f., some types"

name: PAS: Whittington 3083
comments: 8 nummi to 408. A small hoard of 8 coins found north of Hadrian's Wall, only the latest of which has a full record. PATAR 2007, 527.Other PAS records associated with this hoard: NCL-EE2655

name: PAS: Tintagel Castle 3110
comments: A purse hoard recorded by Penhallurick as being found during Radford's excavations in 1955 of the Great Ditch below the Lower Ward's outer bank on the mainland part of the Castle. The purse was not recognised as such until later on and is thought to have been a leather draw string purse which contained 10 coins. Thomas (1993) noted "So far, no structure excavated on [Tintagel] Island... can be put forward as a Roman-period settlement, native-peasant or otherwise." However, apparently R-B pottery has been found on the site, & the drawstring purse find with 10 low denomination Roman coinsfrom Tetricus I (270–272 CE) to Constantius II (337–361). This suggests that "...either the Island or the landward area of later Castle (or both...) formed the scene of third-fourth century habitation" even if no evidence of any buildings from this period has been found

name: PAS: Dorchester, County Hospital III/ Hascombe Court 3115
comments: Approx. 409 cu alloy coins found in layer of rubbly dark soil (4030) above in situ deposits of Building 12, a rectangular aisled building 14m wide & 18m long. Some 3rd century radiates and earlier 4th century coins, but most nummii of House of Theodosius, AD 388-402. Scattered hoard, prob. originally concealed within superstructure of Building 12 – its walls, or more likely its roof. Other finds in layer incl. a gilded disc brooch, bronze & silver finger rings, pottery & glass vessel frags., tile & brick frags. worked shale, iron chain, drill bit & punch, animal bone & shellfish remains. Trevarthen, M. 2008. Suburban Life in Roman Durnovaria. Excavations at the Former County Hospital Site, Dorchester, Dorset 2000-2001. Salisbury: Wessex Archaeology, pp. 40-41.

name: PAS: Lydney Park 3117
comments: Mosaic in main cella of temple. First excav. in 1805, by Bathurst, who noted that there was a circular opening near an inscription in mosaic, surrounded by alternate borders of red, white & blue tesserae. This circular perforation was formed by a funnel of earthenware 3 3/8th in. in diameter & 4 in. deep, placed in mioddle of circle of coarse tesserae, forming a shallow basin slanting in one direction. In the filling of the funnel were found 21 coins of Antoninus Pius to Honorius, & a ‘small rude brass figure of a dog’. Mosaic & funnel lost by 1932, but Wheelers note that “it must have lain nearly opposite to existing remains of some sort of stone pedestal which may have borne an altar. The funnel may have been a piscine for offerings/libations.    Wheeler, H.E.M. & Wheeler, T.V. 1932. Report on the Excavation of the Prehistoric, Roman, and Post-Roman Site in Lydney Park, Gloucestershire. Soc. of Ants., pp. 28, pl. xix, pl xxvi no. 120.

name: PAS: Nettleton (Shrine of Apollo) B 3119
comments: See hoard 2311, IARCH-609FAE – this is second record for the split hoard, for hoard B.

name: PAS: Giant's Cave, Luckington 3122
comments: Six copper alloy coins found during excav. at the long barrow known as Giant's Cave, in Luckington. Their association together is uncertain but may relate to ritual deposition at the site. It is also notable that sherds of over 100 3rd & 4th century vessels were found.

name: PAS: Richmond 3125
comments: Robertson 2000, 400 no. 1606:""Suaserit aliquos Romanam ei fuisse originem magna argenteorum vis numismatum, ad radices montis qui innititur Castellum. Egesta ineunte anno 1720, sed cum nullum aliud umquam Romani nominis hic indicium at Cataractonium, celeberrimam in vicinia stationem offendamus, subit suspicari potius Romanum quendam Cataractoniensem rebis florentibus, nemorum et aquarum amoenitate delinitum villam hic posuisse suam; aut locorum saltem solitudini confisum adventante Saxone, thesauros suos defodisse. Erant numismata numero plus sexcenta sequioris aevi et post Constantinum omnia. Inscriptiones autem ad nos advectorum Lectoris oculo subjicimus."Then came a description of 11 sil.:Sil.Constantius II 1Julian II 1Valentinian I 1Valens 2Gratian 2Valentinian II 1Theodosius 1Magnus Maximus 1Honorius 111(wrongly attributed to Valentinian I)R. Goslin(g), Registrum Honorius De Richmond (1722), 252, some types15 Feb. 1720/1"Mr. Roger Gale gave us an account of many Silver Coyns of the Romans found last month in digging on the south side of Richmond Castle, Yorkshire, among which there were sent him one of Gratian, Maximus, Constantius, Valentinian, Valens, Julian, Honorius, all very fine, together with a silver kind of Ladle or Instrument of Sacrifice as we conjectured from the description. There were about 600 Coyns found."1 March 1720/1"Mr. Gale brought a drawing of the Silver Ladle found among the Roman Coyns at Richmond in Yorkshire."Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., I (1718-32), 41"Richmond...L.P. Wenham reports the discovery some twenty years ago by D. Clarke of a silver Roman coin, a siliqua of Gratian (AD 367-383) of Cohen type 86 with Urbs Roma reverse and mintmark of Trier. It was found on Castle Bank, the steep slope between the castle and the River Swale.It seems reasonable to link the two finds."Yorks. Arch. Register: 1975, compiled by R. Thorp, in Yorks. A.J., 48 (1976), 4"

name: PAS: Cobham 3126
comments: Robertson 2000,  310 no. 1277:""The Rev, H.P.B. Chubb reports that the four coins described below were shown him by Mr. E. Partridge, of Chilbrook Farm, Cobham, who stated that coin no 2 had been found by him embedded in the bank of the River Mole in Meadow No. 3 westward of Cobham Bridge in the autumn of 1931. Next year he found another coin in a mole-hill, and by digging and sifting the soil he found the other two some 2 feet below the surface. There was no trace of any pottery or other container, or of any discoloration of the soil."The coins were all AE:AEGreek (Rhodes, c. 334-304 B.C.) 1Constantine I 1Constantius II, Aug. 24(PROVIDENTIAE AVGG)(1 FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman, overstruck on earlier coin of Constantius II)"As they were all found together, the presumption is that they formed the whole or part of a hoard, which was lost or buried about the middle of the fourth century AD"Surrey Arch. Coll., XLIV (1936), 139f., types"

name: PAS: Kelston 3130
comments: Robertson 2000, 336 no. 1375:"Kelston - copper coins of Constantine I and Valentinian I in grounds of John Harington (Guidott (1676), 68)."VCH Somerset, I (1906), 363."

name: PAS: Chester (Hunter Street) 3131
comments: In Hunter Street, near Odeon Cinema, a group of 11 coins & a plain bronze finger-ring found lying together in upper Roman stratum, in a cut made for the water-main, April 23rd, 1936. The coins were all of bronze (3 AE) & in fair condition. R. Newstead. 1939. J of the Chest. & N. Wales Archit., Arch. & Hist. Soc., n.s. 33: 61.

name: PAS: Harlington, Cranford Lane 3164
comments: HER: Late Roman enclosures (AD 250-400) at Cranford Lane, Harlington, excav. by MoLAS in 1997. RB deposits confined to S & W parts of site. A series of complex enclosures, poss. for stock management, were clustered around S & W sides of a large rectilinear enclosure. Most feature within enclosure, & incl. 3 wells, posthole structure, & 13 pits. 7 minims, all irregular ‘fallen horseman’ types of ad 355-365, found in one of pits, whilst another contained prob. hoard of metalwork. MoLAS. 1994. Archaeological excavs at Cranford Lane, Harlington, Aug-Oc 1994: prelim summary of results. Site Code CFL94. Elsden, N. 1996. Cranford Lane, Harlington, London Borough of Hillingdon: Post-excavation assessment report.  London Archaeologist 1994-5. London fieldwork & publication round-up 1994. Vol 7 (13): 341.

name: PAS: Hillingdon 3164
comments: During excavations of an enclosure by the MoLA, a group of 7 barbarous minims were found in a pit. Another pit contained a possible metalwork hoard. (Information from HER).

name: PAS: Filey Brigg (Signal Station) B 3166
comments: See details for Hoard 2441,  IARCH-F2BBEB, Filey Signal Station A. This record is for the second hoard mentioned by Robertson.

name: PAS: Ivy Chimneys, Witham 3189
comments: Depression F3321 contained 7 re-deposited (curated?) Palaeo. handaxes in lowermost gravel fill, pottery & coins. Upper dark fills contained tile frags., mortar frags., a copper alloy brooch, finger rings, bracelet frags.,  tweezers, nail cleaner, pins and a key; a lead-filled bronze head, a bronze priest’s head moulding, iron knife blades, an iron buckle, bone pins & pieces of antler. Also 78 coins from F3321 – 17 of AD 270-284 & 10 of AD 293-296 in lower fills, 9 of AD 330-345 & 42 of AD 388-402 in upper fills.  Turner, R. 1999. Excavations of an Iron Age Settlement and Roman Religious Complex at Ivy Chimneys, Witham, Essex 1978-83. EAA Report 88, 60.

name: PAS: Lydney Park 3190
comments: “Two coins of Valentinian lay within top of one of the prehistoric postholes” – this was the remains of a structure pre-dating the main RB temple at Lydney. These coins may thus be a foundation deposit.    Wheeler, H.E.M. & Wheeler, T.V. 1932. Report on the Excavation of the Prehistoric, Roman, and Post-Roman Site in Lydney Park, Gloucestershire. Soc. of Ants., pp. 30.

name: PAS: Frocester Court Roman Villa 3198
comments: Mattingly (2000) lists 3 other poss. hoards from Frocester. These included 4 coins of ‘falling horseman’ type found in contact in ploughsoil over N corner of courtyard, poss. from a ploughed out hoard. Mattingly, H.B. 2000. The radiate minim hoard. In E. Price Frocester: a Romano-British Settlement, its Antecedents and Successors. Stonehouse: GADARG, pp. 20.

name: PAS: Frocester Court Roman Villa 3199
comments: Mattingly (2000) lists 3 other poss. hoards from Frocester. These included 2 coins found in contact in fill of later of the two gullies on NE side of Room 12, Building A. Mattingly, H.B. 2000. The radiate minim hoard. In E. Price Frocester: a Romano-British Settlement, its Antecedents and Successors. Stonehouse: GADARG, pp. 20.

name: PAS: Claydon Pike 3200
comments: Coins include 27 well-stratified late 4th coins from cobbled surface clustered within one area of circular stone shrine, where there was a complete miniature beaker buried within a cobbled surface, & a miniature copper alloy axe found nearby. 248 coins in total were found in the general area of the shrine. There was probably a dispersed hoard of coins of AD 364-378. Miles, D., Palmer, S., Smith, A. & Perpetua Jones, G. 2007. Iron Age and Roman Settlement in the Upper Thames Valley: Excavations at Claydon Pike & Other Sites Within the Cotswold Water Park. OA, pp. 181-183, 189-190.  Shrine some 200m NW of a substantial villa complex, itself built on an earlier complex.

name: PAS: Kingscote IV 3203
comments: At Site 2, Pit 328, dug into top of Quarry 4 & poss. within Building VI, contained 76 coins from AD 260-8 to AD 351-60, incl. 21 radiates. Also pottery, cu alloy bracelet & sheet frag., but not clear what other objects were found. Timby, J. 1998. Excavations at Kingscote and Wycomb, Gloucestershire. Cotswold Archaeology, pp. 66-67.

name: PAS: Blakeney, Millend Lane 3204
comments: 9 coins, all contemporary types dating to AD 330s with no copies, frags. of poss. 2 more coins present. Found within small irregular pit 1029, prob. placed in a wooden bucket, as there were also 2 iron hoops. Coins within arc of the two hoops, which were both at same height, plus a conc. some frags. of copper alloy sheet & iron, poss. from a stud. Barber, A.J. & Holbrook, N. 2000. A Roman iron-smelting site at Blakeney, Gloucestershire: excavations at Millend Lane 1997. Trans. of Bristol & Glos Archaeol. Soc.

name: PAS: Winchester, Hyde Street 3211
comments: Excav by Wessex Archaeology Oct 2000-May 2001. Evidence for Winchester to Silchester Roman road, & structures fronting onto road. Deposit of late/post- Roman 'dark earth' across much of site, but small hoard of 5 silver siliquae & 1 cu alloy coin suggested it was at least partly formed by AD 363 AD or shortly after. Bitbeck, V. & Moore, C. 2004. Hampshire Studies 59: 77-110, 91-92.

name: PAS: Canterbury, Marlowe Car Park Area M I 3213
comments: Marlowe Car Park Area M I, scattered hoard of 59-67 Theodosian & Honorius coins, deposited soon after AD 395-6. Hoard ‘reconstructed’ from coins scattered in A-S & medieval features, prob. originally deposited in waste ground. Anderson, I. 1995. The Roman coins. In Blockley, K. et al. Excavations in the Marlowe Car Park & Surrounding Areas. The Archaeol. of Canterbury Vol. V. Canterbury Archaeol. Trust, pp. 928-929.

name: PAS: Canterbury, Marlowe Car Park Area MT 3216
comments: Marlowe Car Park Area MT, scattered hoard of 87 Theodosian coins, & 1 of Honorius from disturbed layers used to backfill medieval pit 21. Deposition date of AD 402 or later (though single Honorius could be intrusive). Anderson, I. 1995. The Roman coins. In Blockley, K. et al. Excavations in the Marlowe Car Park & Surrounding Areas. The Archaeol. of Canterbury Vol. V. Canterbury Archaeol. Trust, pp. 930.

name: PAS: Canterbury Rose Lane Site E XXI, B (1a) Hoard 1 3218
comments: Rose Lane Site E XXI, B (1a) Hoard 1. 23 coins from Constantine II to House of Theodosius, deposit AD 390-420. Anderson, I. 1995. The C.E.C. coins. In Blockley, K. et al. Excavations in the Marlowe Car Park & Surrounding Areas. The Archaeol. of Canterbury Vol. V. Canterbury Archaeol. Trust, pp. 945.

name: PAS: Rose Lane Site E XXI, A (1) Hoard 2 3219
comments: Rose Lane Site E XXI, A (1) Hoard 2. 19 coins from Constantine II to House of Theodosius, also incl. 2 radiates. Deposit AD 388-420. Anderson, I. 1995. The C.E.C. coins. In Blockley, K. et al. Excavations in the Marlowe Car Park & Surrounding Areas. The Archaeol. of Canterbury Vol. V. Canterbury Archaeol. Trust, pp. 945.

name: PAS: Canterbury Rose Lane Site E XXI, B (1) Hoard 3 3220
comments: Rose Lane Site E XXI, B (1) Hoard 3. 117 coins from Claudius II to House of Theodosius, with 47 of latter; & incl. 33 illegible 4th C. coins. Deposit AD 368-385.

name: PAS: Canterbury Rose Lane Site E XXI, D (11) Hoard 4 3221
comments: Rose Lane Site E XXI, D (11) Hoard 4. 6 coins from Constantine I to House of Valentinian, deposit AD 368-385. Anderson, I. 1995. The C.E.C. coins. In Blockley, K. et al. Excavations in the Marlowe Car Park & Surrounding Areas. The Archaeol. of Canterbury Vol. V. Canterbury Archaeol. Trust, pp. 945.

name: PAS: Lullingstone Roman villa I 3223
comments: 13 coins sealed in pit that occupied NW corner of back corridor before gravel floor of vestibule laid over it, in the ’Northern Group’ of villa rooms. A single coin of Tetricus II, & remaining coins of Constantine II to 2 Fel. Temp. Rep. coins, suggest pit not filled in before c. AD 361. Meates, G.W. 1979. The Roman Villa at Lullingstone, Kent. Kent Archaeol. Mono. 1, pp. 41-42. There were 3 small, coarse handmade cooking vessels, animal bones & portions of skulls, with cut marks, iron knives, & 13 coins. Unclear why Allen & Reece state in coin report that “…it has not been possible to group the coins according to the context in which they were found”, unless they mean the detailed strat. account was not available to them. Allen, D.F. & Reece, R. 1987. The coins. In G. W. Meates et al. The Roman villa at Lullingstone, Kent. Volume II: The Wall Paintings and Finds, pp. 47f.

name: PAS: Lullingstone Roman villa II 3224
comments: “ on the level, heavily carbonised, but at a time much earlier than the final destruction, and beneath the floor boards of the ante chamber, 2 of which had actually survived, fallen & sealing some of the coins, no less than 31 coins.” All of Constantinian period – 4 of Constantius II, 1 of Magnentius, & 1 of Constantius Gallus. A date not much before AD 361 indicated for flooring of ante chamber. Meates, G.W. 1979. The Roman Villa at Lullingstone, Kent. Kent Archaeol. Mono. 1, pp. 42. 31 coins of within a deposit consisting of thin laminations of charcoal, burnt clay & reddened sand, on base of floor of Room 10 in ‘Northern Group’ of villa rooms. This heating activity poss. related to a temporary framework of postholes. Some coins in small clusters. Coins from Constantine I to Constantius Gallus, plus 1 minim, all date to AD 330-354. Meates, G.W. 1979. The Roman Villa at Lullingstone, Kent. Kent Archaeol. Mono. 1, pp. 51-52, fig. 9.

name: PAS: Lullingstone Roman villa III 3225
comments: In Room 14, part of ‘Northern Group’ of villa rooms, there were 2 shallow, circular pits 0.55m in diameter & c. 0.20m deep, along W wall. Southern pit contained 18 coins from Crispus (AD 320-324) to Constantinopolis (AD 330-337), with 1 coin of Urbs Romana (AD 330-337) 0.15m E of pit & poss. from it. Coins fresh & in uniform condition. Each group of coins concentrated within its pit, & may have been within cloth bags.  Meates suggests [somewhat imaginatively] that these hoards were buried underneath beds of servants. Meates, G.W. 1979. The Roman Villa at Lullingstone, Kent. Kent Archaeol. Mono. 1, pp. 58, fig. 12.

name: PAS: Lullingstone Roman villa IV 3226
comments: In Room 14, part of ‘Northern Group’ of villa rooms, there were 2 shallow, circular pits 0.55m in diameter & c. 0.20m deep, along W wall. The northern pit contained 4 coins from Constantine I (AD 320-324) to Constantine II (AD 320-324). Each group of coins concentrated within its pit, & may have been within cloth bags.  Meates suggests [somewhat imaginatively] that these hoards were buried underneath beds of servants. Meates, G.W. 1979. The Roman Villa at Lullingstone, Kent. Kent Archaeol. Mono. 1, pp. 58, fig. 12.

name: PAS: Lullingstone Roman villa V 3227
comments: In Room 15, part of ‘Central Group’ of villa rooms, there was a semi-circular pit 1.22m wide & c. 0.80m deep, dug through an earlier concrete op. sig. floor. In pit was a large Alice Holt storage jar at angle of 30°, with top broken away & wedged in place with a brick; & major part of a colour-coated Gaulish bowl. 20 coins in pit scattered throughout fill, but with some conc. between the 2 ceramic vessels. Coins from Constantine I to Constans Augustus, with 1 minim; of AD 330-350. Also a bronze ‘lion mask’ axle cap, an iron padlock & chain, frags. of 4 glass beakers & a glass bowl, a mortarium, & 2 metallic-glazed, rouletted Castor-ware box lids. Meates interpreted this feature as a latrine near the dining room, but it was later re-sealed beneath another surface, and seems a very odd, ad hoc toilet. The coins & other objects might suggest some sort of deliberate deposit, which although contains broken objects/refuse, may have held some other meaning. Meates, G.W. 1979. The Roman Villa at Lullingstone, Kent. Kent Archaeol. Mono. 1, pp. 87-88, figs. 17a & 17b.

name: PAS: Springhead 3232
comments: Group of 57 coins recovered from dump layer in upper fill of ditch 3321, part of LIA enclosure 400012. Upper fill may have suffered some truncation. Coins from discrete deposit in one corner of ditch. 2 latest coins are nummi of House of Valentinian. Some earlier coins may have been part of this scattered hoard, or were residual in ditch. Fill also contained 1st & 2nd C. metalwork & 3rd C. pottery, so coin hoard may have been inserted later into this fill.

name: PAS: Rudston Roman villa 3234
comments: The excavation of the well was concluded in 1966. It was 99ft deep and its diameter below the weathering cone average 9ft to within 6ft of the bottom. Two radiate coins of late 3rd C. & iron fittings of several buckets found within bottom 6 ft thick silts, along with large group of late 3rd & early 4th C. ceramics, at approx. 95 ft depth.  In layer between 81ft and 85ft were masses of broken Huntcliff vessels & 3 Valentinian coins – matching sherds of pot throughout this dump imply it was a single event.

name: PAS: Wattle Syke 3236
comments: 2 coins of Valens AD 364-78, found near hand of SK33 (3-5 year old child) in double grave with mature adult female (SK34). Child also had 3 cu alloy bracelets. Grave 3050.SK33 14C dated to AD 250-420.

name: PAS: Wattle Syke 3237
comments: 3 4th C. coins (1 of House of Constantine I AD 335-47, 2 uncertain AE, found in single homogenous fill of 'working hollow', assoc. with poss. hearth/fire pit. Also late 4th C pottery. Poss. a small purse hoard, but not found in a tight group.

name: PAS: Winterton Roman villa 3243
comments: Building D was a stone-walled rectangular structure with an aisled area & a series of separate rooms, & a bath-suite.Room 21 was in the NE corner, and originally 11 ft long and 14 ft wide, with heavily robbed wals & an op. sig. concrete floor, replaced twice by similar floors. In use with the second of these floors was a large pit 3 ft 16 in. wide, 9 ft long & 1 ft 9 in deep, with sharp sides & a cleanish filling. This may have held some form of tank or container. In final phase of room the pit was filled in & covered with concrete to bring it to level of surrounding floor, & in this concrete was found a small hoard of 5 coins (AD 330-341). Stead, I.M 1976. The Roman villa at Winterton. In I.M. Stead  Excavations at Winterton Roman Villa and Other Roman Sites in North Lincolnshire 1958-1967. DoE Archaeol. Reports 9. London: HMSO, pp. 46.

name: PAS: Dorchester, County Hospital I 3253
comments: "Several coins of the House of Theodosius" found in the fills of oven 4 in Building 1 in the Somerleigh Court excavations of 1969-1970. This assemblage has been treated separately from hoard IARCH-D61D2D ((Robertson 2000, 410 no. 1644) coins from the rubble layer of the same building) although in the publication of that hoard by Cooke (2007) he has treated them as one hoard: "However, using the published coin list (Patrick Greene 1993, 93), it is possible to suggest the likely composition of this hoard. In order to do this, only coins recovered from rubble contexts or those recovered from within oven 4 (see above) have been included. This excludes all the coins recovered from topsoil deposits (some of which may relate to the hoard) but does allow us to examine those coins most likely to be part of the hoard. Using these criteria, a minimum of 304 coins can be suggested as belonging to the hoard".   AC: Hoard found in backfill of oven 4 within a 4th century building (Building 1, Site C, Trench 1), south of Building 12 from Hascombe Court excavs. in 2001-2003 (see below). Also contained stone rubble, limestone roof slabs, charcoal, mortar & wall plaster, & a balance bar. Not clear from the text or Reece’s coin report (just a table) exactly where coins were within layers in this feature (in clusters, or distributed throughout it?), but there were at least 159 coins, 143 from one upper fill alone. Patrick Green, J. 1993. Excavations at Dorchester Hospital (Site C), Dorchester, Dorset. PDNHAS 115: 71-101. N.B. Gentle E facing slope, R. Frome c. 800m to N.

name: PAS: Chesters Roman villa 3255
comments: What is mentioned in Garrett & Harris 1938 and shown on a plan (p. 97, fig. 1) is a small group of coins associated with a ‘hole in upper flagged floor’ in Room I. This hole was ‘filled with various debris, amongst which coarse pottery, pseudo-samian ware, late coins (Decentius, Constantius II, barbarous, & minimi), twisted copper bracelet wire etc’. Also two glass beads. The 6 coins were 1 AE, 3 radiates & 2 miminimi.

name: PAS: Winchester, The Brooks II 3256
comments: Scattered coin hoard deposited c. AD 350-365, on a late phase of Building VIII.9, when it was ruinous but not completely levelled & buried. May have been on a surface formed by re-used roofing slabs. Scobie, G.D., Zant, J.M. & Whinney, R. 1991. The Brooks, Winchester. A Preliminary report on the Excavations, 1987-88, pp. 30.

name: PAS: Winchester (Victoria Road) 3260
comments: Hoard of at least 52 coins, part of a deposit of 61 coins recovered from backfill of a well in Victoria Road, Winchester (F1093) during archaeol. excavs. in 1970s. No evidence for a container. Summary (p.380) mentions that well contained half the carcass of a horse, a buckle & a shale spindle whorl as well as architectural frags. Rees, H., Crummy, N., Ottaway, P. and Dunn, G. 2008. Artefacts and Society in Roman and Medieval Winchester: Small finds from the suburbs and defences, 1971-1986. Winchester Museums, 135.

name: PAS: Lincoln 57
comments: West Parade site Area III, Roman interval tower. In late Roman period, interval tower became derelict, & much of upper part prob. demolished/ robbed. Lower part of tower infilled with demolition debris, incl. ceramic tile frags. & mortar, animal bone waste from food consumption, & bird & animal skeletons, incl. ravens & dogs, frogs & toads, & remains of owl pellets. 3 silver denarii in fine condition also found amongst demolition debris, of Trajan, Hadrian & Faustina, minted in early to mid 2nd C. before tower even built; & it is likely that they were hidden & subsequently lost, poss. as part of a larger hoard, whilst tower was still in use. Gilmour, B. 1999. Excavations. In C. Colyer, B.J.J. Gilmour & B. Jones The Defences of the Lower City. Excavations at The Park and West Parade 1970-2 and a Discussion of Other Sites Excavated up to 1994. The Archaeology of Lincoln VIII-2. CBA Res. Report 114, pp. 191.

name: PAS: Dean Hall 76
comments: ?hoard of over 115 3rd- & 4th-century coins (Gordian III to Arcadius) found disturbed in NW corner of 'temple' site." Britannia 1988 19: 467.

name: PAS: Heytesbury 77
comments: Ten nummi found during excav. of a round barrow by Cunnington in 1800. A layer of flint and coarse pottery was found, but (earlier) samian sherds were also found with the coins.

name: PAS: Silchester 78
comments: G.C. Boon, Silchester, The Roman Town of Calleva (ed. 1974), 311, no. 21, following J.G. Joyce, Journal of Excavations at Silchester, 21 Sept. 1869 (in Reading Museum), noted hoard of Theodosian bronze ending with Arcadius ("omitted by me in NC, 1960, 24").

name: PAS: Buxton 79
comments: Accumulation of Roman coins in natural fissure in rock below the Thermal Baths in Buxton. Poss. a votive deposit though not strictly a hoard. Found in the underlying rock pool in which the spring had formed, below 20th century swimming pool. Post-medieval objects included a ring dated 1704 & hundreds of pins (thought to be 19th century).

name: PAS: Leafield 129
comments: Mr R. Earle Way exhibited a curious stone mortar, found about 60 years ago in excavating an ancient tumulus which still exists at Leofield [sic], Oxon. It was filled with Roman coins, specimens of which were shown. They range from Domitian to Constans. The tumulus, which is elliptical in form, is 120 yds wide at base & 50x12 yds at summit, which is truncated; aperture made by the excavation, in which the mortar was found, being still apparent. The mortar is broken, prob. by use, & was mended with lead." JBAA 1889, 45: 364. The coins were probably AE, although it is unlikely that they ranged from Domitian onwards, if they ended with Constans.

name: PAS: Settle 138
comments: "H. Ecroyd Smith, "The limestone caves of Craven and their ancient inhabitants", in Trans. Hist. Soc. Lancs. and Chesh., (n.s.) 5 (1864-5), 199-230, noted (p. 205): "The Victoria is the largest of the (known) Settle caverns, and consists of 2 main chambers, each exceeding 100 ft in length." The artefacts, found in large numbers, incl. coins of Gallienus, Victorinus, Claudius II, Aurelian, ?Maximus? (Maximian?), Constantine Max., ?Constantius II?, Crispus & illegible". Raistrick, A. 1932-34. YAJ 31: 220f., assumed best known finds had been made in Victoria Cave, & repeated above list of coins, with substitution of Constantine II for Constantius II. "In the museum of the Pig-Yard Club at Settle there is a Dales Ware pot rather bigger & coarser than this one [i.e. Mytholmroyd 1952 pot, no. 592], which contained a hoard found somewhere near Settle, ending, I think, with Constantine the Great." Letter, Oct. 1958, from J.P. Gillam. Dearne, M.J. & Lord, T.C. 1998. The Romano-British Archaeology of Victoria Cave, Settle. Oxford: BAR British Series 273.

name: PAS: Nettleton 148
comments: A small hoard of 9 coins of Faustina to Gallienus, found at base of stone-lined pit at SE corner of ambulatory wall of later octagonal temple (building VI). Wedlake, W.J. 1982. The Excavation of the Shrine of Apollo at Nettleton, Wiltshire, 1956-1971. Soc. of Ant. Of London, pp. 44-45.

name: PAS: Wroxeter 154
comments: During excav. of Roman town, "another heap of 38 coins found at entrance of what appeared to be shop of a worker in metal or enamel, evidently dropped by a citizen in his eagerness to escape. They had been placed in a small vessel of earthenware, the fragments of which were scattered around."  The coins were 2 den., 19 ant., & 17 small AE from Caracalla to Gratian. Scarth, H.M. 1860. AJ 17: 243, & JBAA 16 (1860), 162; gave brief descriptions of find in which the number of coins is stated to have been "about sixty".

name: PAS: Kenchester 160
comments: During excav. of Roman Magnis"on Dec 13th, 1912, hoard of 51 coins unearthed in ruins of hypocaust numbered 4 on the plan. ..slight trace of their being contained in textile which vanished on exposure. The majority of the coins vary from moderate to poor, this may be due to their position in the hypocaust." The coins were 4 ant. & 47 small AE.  HER: Date range Claudius II Gothinus (268-70) - Gratian (367- 383). G.H. Jack & A.G.K. Hayter 1913. Excavations on the site of the Romano-British town at Magna, Kenchester. Trans. of the Woolhope Naturalists? Field Club 1912-13: 54f. Pastscape: Finds of pendants for military horse trappings suggest military origin for Magnis. Excavs in 1956-62 by F.G. Heys &M.J. Thomas revealed occupation in 1st & 2nd C. along line subsequently taken by the rampart. Not earlier than the middle of 2nd C. an earth rampart & ditch constructed, & a stone wall added in front of the rampart between then & mid-4th C.? bastions at intervals along the wall. Occ. continued into 5th C.

name: PAS: Lower Beeding 161
comments: ?Money Mound', a BA barrow 1¼ miles NE of Lower Beeding in Weald, found to contain pottery of IA & 2nd-3rd C. date, as well as over 150 bronze coins from Trajan to Gratian. JRS 1963: 155. 16 different pots, poss. a roadside shrine. Beckensall, S.G. 1967. The excavation of Money Mound. SAC 105: 13-30.

name: PAS: Colesbourne 162
comments: In hypocaust of RB building at Combe End, ?the paces between the piers were filled with rubbish, between 2 of the piers, ?more than 200 Roman coins of lower empire found lying all together among the rubbish." S. Lysons, 5 May 1808, in Ms. Min. Soc. Ant. 31 (1806-8), 501. Building was the Roman villa at Combe End Farm. Arch. 9 (1789), 319-32, & S. Lysons Arch. 18 (1815), 112.

name: PAS: Corbridge (South Of Site XI) 163
comments: Group of 17 coins found in soil, 3 ft below present surface, S of site XI [forum], deserves separate notice. The coins all small AE. H.H.E. Craster. 1912. AA (3) VIII: 234f.

name: PAS: Canterbury (CXXX EXXI DII H) 164
comments: Unpublished notes of R. Reece Hoard 8 CXXX EXXI DII H. This ranges from Claudius II to Gratian & includes 1 Carausius (RIC 880)." N. Shiel. 1977. The Episode of Carausius and Allectus. BAR 40, pp. 62. C.E.C. Rose Lane Site E XXI. D (11) Hoard 5. 11 coins from Claudius II to Gratian, deposit AD 368-85. Anderson, I. 1995. The C.E.C. coins. In Blockley, K. et al. Excavations in the Marlowe Car Park & Surrounding Areas. The Archaeol. of Canterbury Vol. V. Canterbury Archaeol. Trust, pp. 946.

name: PAS: Corbridge (Pottery Store) 165
comments: During excav. of Pottery Store, between brown wares & mortaria, within a few square feet against E wall, were 19 coins from Claudius II to Gratian. R.H. Forster, from C.L. Woolley. 1908. AA (3), IV: 251. F. Haverfield & H.H.E. Craster. 1909-11. PSA (2) XXIII: 115, gave corrected list of the coins, 2 ant. & 17 small AE. C.L. Woolley, the discoverer, was inclined to regard them as remains of shop till. This not very likely. Coins in a burnt till would prob. be melted or fused together, & these coins showed no marks of having been burnt. Moreover, they are from 1-2 centuries later in date than prob. age of potsherds, which were certainly in the fire. It seems probable that they came into the deposit after the fire. They may be a small hoard or part of a hoard buried here late in the 4th C., but the 10 dateable coins stretch over 100 years, & might be due to a variety of accidents." M. Brassington. 1975. A reappraisal of the western enclave and environs, Corstorpitum. Britannia 6: 62-75.

name: PAS: Canterbury Rose Lane Site E XXI, D (12) Hoard 6 218
comments: Rose Lane Site E XXI, D (12) Hoard 6. 16 coins from Tetricus I to House of Constantine, incl. 3 corroded & illegible & 2 4th C. copies. Anderson, I. 1995. The C.E.C. coins. In Blockley, K. et al. Excavations in the Marlowe Car Park & Surrounding Areas. The Archaeol. of Canterbury Vol. V. Canterbury Archaeol. Trust, pp. 945.

name: PAS: Landbeach 276
comments: Assemblage of nummi of House of Constantine in upper & lower fills of midden with 2nd-3rd C. pottery. Possibly a dispersed hoard. Three coins together suggest a purse. All coins from midden included here apart from a sest. of Antoninus Pius found in a deposit pre-dating the midden. Near a temple. Excav.of 2.6 ha in the NW part of the site revealed further evidence for R-B activity. The site was dominated by R-B occupation activity, dating to 2nd to 4th centuries, with a peak in activity during 3rd C. The midden measured at least 7m by 15m, & contained a single homogenous fill which yielded over 5000 sherds of pottery, 2000 fragments of animal bone, including some worked bone artefacts, 40 copper alloy objects and 75 coins. The finds recovered suggests that the midden may have been used as more than a rural settlement rubbish tip, and may have been associated with the nearby temple and its related activities" [HER]Ranson 2008.

name: PAS: Rowler Manor Roman villa, Croughton 282
comments: Roman settlement at Rowler Manor Estate first recorded in 1991 during archaeol. watching brief, when Roman pottery & 2 coin hoards were recovered. Later investigation revealed stone building remains & 4th C. mosaic floor. APs suggest this just one of many buildings in much larger complex over 5ha in extent. During work in 1991, 6 sestersii found as small hoard, initially by detectorists. Coins stuck together in a column after prob. being kept in a narrow textile wrapping/bag. Coins from Trajan to Lucilla, prob. deposited c. AD 161-200. Guest, P. 2008. The Roman coins. In M. Dawson Excavation of the Roman villa and mosaic at Rowler Manor, Croughton, Northamptonshire. Northamptonshire Archaeol. 35: 45-93.

name: PAS: Attermire Camp 285
comments: During unpublished excavations at R-B settlement of Attermire Camp in 1948-50, a hoard of 21 "2nd & 3rd century" copper alloy coins is said to have been found contained in a ceramic vessel (Pastscape 45765). The same account also describes this as a hoard of 17 coins from Vespasian to Constantine. The finds were in the Settle Pig Yard Club Museum and cannot now be located. It is therefore possible that this is the hoard container referred to by Robertson 2000, 255-256 no. 1079 (IARCH-C19BC4) as that hoard was not reported as being in a container.

name: PAS: Kingston upon Thames, 82 Eden Street 286
comments: HER: Excav. by P. Emery for DGLA, 1989; site code EDE 89. A river channel, infilled with a sequence of water laid deposits. Amongst other finds were over 350 bronze coins, mostly of 4th C. House of Constantine. It has been suggested that these could represent a single dispersed sequence of water laid deposits. Amongst other finds were over 350 bronze coins, mostly of 4th C. House of Constantine. It has been suggested that these could represent a single dispersed hoard, or individual offerings at a crossing, or to a river deity. Heathcote, J. Excavation round-up 1989: part 2, London Boroughs, pp. 188-195. Emery, P.A. 1989 - unpublished site report. Coins found in discrete spatial area, so not transported far by water etc. Found in series of silt & gravel alluvial layers with large quantities of unworn pottery, a bronze fibula, child?s cu alloy bracelet, a silver ring with glass inset, iron objects, a broken decorated shale bracelet, & interestingly, several lead objects with scratch marks etc on them. Also building rubble, tile, plaster etc too; but also a partial articulated cattle/horse skeleton. Some coins appear to have been pierced &/or defaced. No full post-ex ever undertaken, & coin catalogue not even completed, but in his provisional report, Emery does indeed suggest this was a ritualised deposit, or more likely a series of small-scale votive events mixed in with more general deposits.

name: PAS: Pembroke (Castle) 297
comments: Mr Cobb, while excav. at Pembroke Castle, found a Carausius used to fix a blade of some kind on to its handle. With it were a Constantine, a Constantine II, a Constans & 2 uncertain coins. E. Laws. 1888. Little England beyond Wales, 46. BBCS, II (1923-5), 92, suggested that these coins "may (very doubtfully) have formed a small hoard." The coin of Carausius prob. an ant., thers prob. small AE.

name: PAS: Morvah 298
comments: During excav of a barrow, a 'kist-vean' containing urn was found, about 18 inches deep, the bottom formed of hard natural clay, & sides of granite stones set on edge. The breakage of urn was, in some degree compensated for by discovery among earth in cist of 8-9 Roman coins. ?many, on being touched, fell to pieces. Whether they are clay casts, or actual brass coins in a state of corrosion, can hardly be determined. W.C. Borlase, Arch. Camb. 24 (1869), 35f. W.C. Borlase, Laregan Sale Catalogue (1882), mentioned 5 AE coins, one being of Constantius II, & a flint from this find. 5 coins, & a frag. of the urn of pre-Roman date, in County Museum, Truro.

name: PAS: Uley 299
comments: Near highest part of cairn, within 6 inches of surface, & nearly over side chamber No. 3, was a skeleton lying NE & SW, with 3 Roman coins of three sons of Constantine the Great." J. Thurnam, A.J. 11 (1854), 321. Repeated by J. Maclean, in Trans. Bristol & Glos. Arch. Soc. 5 (1880-1), 92.

name: PAS: Great Staughton 300
comments: Two scattered hoards identified in villa excavated in 1950s, Rushey Farm. The site produced an unusual amount of coins (850). It is not clear from published account how many belonged to each hoard. Full coin report by Carson in archive (listed in HER as held by HBMC - uncertain where now ? EH?). JRS 49 (1959): 118 plan. Late Iron Age hut & assoc. bath house, post-Roman burials. This hoard in room 5 scattered on floor surface and in occupation layer above.Greenfield et al 1994 RB buildings marked on OS maps ? very gentle N facing slope of ridge, with springs c. 760m to SW, stream 150m to NW & River Kym 844m to N.

name: PAS: Chester 301
comments: In remains of large Roman building in Bridge Street, "a number of coins (chiefly Constantines), frags of Samian ware, etc. found." H. Taylor 1899-1901. PSA (2), 18: 97. Three 4th century AE coins, preserved with ant from the Chester 1858 hoard in the Grosvenor Museum, Chester, may be from this find.

name: PAS: Tarrant Hinton 302
comments: Within parish of Tarrant Hinton a low British barrow, 2 feet in height, examined at instance of Mrs Farquharson. The principal interment was skeleton at full length in cist cut in the chalk; by the side were the fragments of a rude urn, and it was protected by a cairn of flints.  But the circumstance of most interest was the discovery of a small Roman urn, filled with coins of Constantine, Constantius, and others of the same period; the hidden store of some Roman or Romano-Briton, deposited between nucleus of flints & outer coating of barrow." J. Hutchins 1861. Hist. and Ant. of Dorset, 3 ed., I, 318. Also C. Warne. 1866. Celtic Tumuli of Dorset, 75f. The unlocated barrow, 'about ¼ mile E of Pimperne Long Barrow', contained extended inhumation, with 'frags. of a rude urn' at its side, covered by cairn of flints. Above cairn was pot containing hoard of Constantinian coins. Tarrant Hinton: an Inventory of the Historical Monuments in Dorset, Volume 4: North (1972), pp. 96-101.

name: PAS: Brislington 303
comments: As far back as 1829, Dr Fox of Brislington presented to Bristol Philosophical Institution 23 Roman copper coins of same period [as those found in excav. of Roman villa at Brislington], part of the metallic urn in which they were found & six pieces of Roman pottery. ?found on his Brislington estate about a mile E of this villa & are still in Bristol Museum to which they were transferred from the philosophical Institution." W.A. Barker, Trans. Bristol and Glos. Arch. Soc., XXIII (1900), 290. EG notes: Technically City of Bristol.

name: PAS: Canterbury 346
comments: During excavs. in Roman city, "a pit containing small hoard of 19 early 4th C. bronze coins found cut through tail of Roman loam bank behind city wall in St George's Lane, S of St George's Street. In the levels above was much Saxon & medieval material." (Information from Mr. S.S. Frere, who directed excavs. for Canterbury Excav. Committee). JRS 1950. 40: 113. Pit was cut into Roman bank "behind the city wall"

name: PAS: Canterbury, Marlowe Car Park Area M III 352
comments: Marlowe Car Park Area M III, scattered Theodosian hoard of 215 bronze coins & 1 illegible 4th C. silver issue, from ?dark earth? build up. Anderson, I. 1995. The Roman coins. In Blockley, K. et al. Excavations in the Marlowe Car Park & Surrounding Areas. The Archaeol. of Canterbury Vol. V. Canterbury Archaeol. Trust, pp. 930.

name: PAS: Canterbury, Marlowe Car Park Area M III 353
comments: Marlowe Car Park Area M III, 259 Theodosian coins recovered from Anglo-Saxon Structure S15 which had been built inside laconicum of Roman Structure R26. Prob. orig. deposited against one of walls of RB building, & had then gradually fallen into A-S structure after its construction [presumably after A-S structure had also gone out of use!]. Anderson, I. 1995. The Roman coins. In Blockley, K. et al. Excavations in the Marlowe Car Park & Surrounding Areas. The Archaeol. of Canterbury Vol. V. Canterbury Archaeol. Trust, pp. 930.

name: PAS: Verulamium 396
comments: In 1956 during excav. beyond town wall in water meadow lying between two branches of the River Ver, a wooden revetment & clay bank found, from Roman river maintenance. Bordering bank were deposits of sandy silt which must mark the Roman bed of the Ver. Here were found 249 late Roman coins, vast quantities of 4th-century pottery, & a large number of small objects including fibulae, a silver spoon, 4 bronze rings & a bronze bell, 2 pewter plates (one inscribed VIVENTIA VICTORICI) & a pewter cup, an iron hook & knife. The number & condition of objects does not suggest that they have been washed downstream as casual losses. It is more likely that they were intentionally devoted to the spirit of the waters." S.S. Frere. 1957. Ant. J. 37: 14f., pl. IVb. "It seems probable that rubbish & votive offerings were cast into the river in the late 4th C." S.S. Frere. 1983. Verulamium excavations vol. II. Research Rep. Soc. Ant. 41 (II), 277-281. HER: represents Roman canalization of river. Pottery suggests 3rd C. date for bank construction, poss. assoc. with building of city walls. By c. AD 375 drainage broken down & bank & track covered in clay & peaty flood deposits. On surface of grey clay was hoard of 28 coins which had been in small wooden box. 94 other coins also found in the 1956 excavation, including a 2nd probable hoard.

name: PAS: Richborough (S Of Site III) 397
comments: In 1924 during excav. of Saxon Shore fort: "74 coins found lying together to south of Site III." J.P. Bushe-Fox. 1928. Research Rep. Soc. Ant. 7: 26f., 118f.

name: PAS: Wanborough II  424
comments: HER: Excavation by Surrey Arch Soc following on from geophys. survey by EH, directed by D Williams, assisted by David Graham, & aided by volunteers, of a new circular temple a short distance from square temple complex robbed for several years by metal detectorists. The original purpose of excav. was to define area to be Scheduled, but due to history of vandalism, it was decided to fully excav. temple. A hoard of coins of c. AD 50-60 may indicate when temple was first built, & a pit cut into its backfill after it had probably gone out of use is of 2nd C. date. Howe, T., Jackson, G., Maloney, C. & Saich, D. 2000. Archaeology in Surrey 1998-9. Surrey Arch. Coll. 87: 185.

name: PAS: Clarkly Hill 425
comments: F. Hunter notes: This field on S side of Clarkly Hill, near Burghead had escaped archaeol. attention but produced a rich range of metal finds from LBA to medieval period, incl. Roman brooches & a scattered denarius hoard. A weekend of trial trenching in 2008 confirmed the presence of a settlement & showed hoard was scattered in antiquity. Geophysical survey by Dr Tessa Poller revealed series of roundhouses over area of 400x100m, as well as other activity; excav. from 2011-13 revealed well-preserved site thanks to the effects of late and post-med. sandstorms which had blanketed the area. Post-ex. has only just begun but in many respects site seems similar to Birnie, with major craft activities (notably iron-smelting, attested here in a separate industrial zone), bronze-casting, wide-ranging contacts & a wealth of Roman finds. The coins are still to be conserved and studied, but there are around a hundred denarii with a terminal date in the mid-late 2nd century. Unusually, there are also a few bronze coins ? three sestertii and a dupondius. These are clearly from the hoard, as three are corroded together. Silver and bronze were rarely co-hoarded beyond the frontier ? Kippilaw, noted above, is the only possible Scottish parallel, but there are rare examples from elsewhere in barbaricum (e.g. Komnick 2008, 120). In many respects the sequence resembles Birnie, but there are clear differences: there are two later Roman coins and evidence of an extended post-roundhouse sequence, with a series of standing stones erected over one roundhouse succeeded by an ephemeral settlement of small sub-rectangular houses, not yet dated.

name: PAS: Canterbury, C.E.C. Site St Margaret's Street Baths 449
comments: C.E.C. Sites, St Margaret?s Street Baths. Poss. hoard of 96 coins, recovered from contexts 16, 16A 7 16B ? layers of wood ash covering an op. sig. floor.  Form a sequence from Gallienus to barbarous radiates; & a follis of Maximinian, though latter prob. intrusive. ?Whether they were originally a hoard scattered amongst the ashes cannot be determined with any certainty. Anderson, I. 1995. The C.E.C. coins. In Blockley, K. et al. Excavations in the Marlowe Car Park & Surrounding Areas. The Archaeol. of Canterbury Vol. V. Canterbury Archaeol. Trust, pp. 942.

name: PAS: Gloucester 455
comments: On site of the Telephone Exchange extension, 13-17 Berkeley St., observation of contractors' trenches revealed parts of 3 more houses of 2nd quarter of 2nd century. One, which corresponded closely in size to the centurion's quarters which lay beneath it, had a colonnaded street-entrance & a paved courtyard flanked by dwarf colonnades. Its destruction was later than a small coin-hoard deposited after c. 350-70." Britannia 3 (1972), 339, 341; from H.R. Hurst and J.F. Rhodes H.R. Hurst, Ant. J., 52 (1972), 42, noted that "a hoard of 652 mid-late 4th-century coins found disturbed in a robber trench."

name: PAS: Cardiff Castle B 510
comments: 11 coins of 1st-3rd C. AD in remains of amphora. Excavation by GGAT.

name: PAS: Great Chesterford 511
comments: At the southern end of the Borough Field, Neville recorded pottery, fibulae, styli etc, as well as 326 coins ranging in date from AD 41 to 565 (Medlycott 2011: 228). In Richard Hobbs? coin report in Medlycott 2011 it is suggested that out of the 372 IA & Roman coins from Borough Field, found during Neville?s excavs & published by him in his book Antiqua Explorata for 1847, the coins of the Tetrici & the late 3rd C came from a scattered hoard. Medlycott, M. 2011. The Roman Town of Great Chesterford. EAA Report 137, pp. 256.

name: PAS: Cefn Cwmwd 512
comments: Excavs. as part of the A55 road scheme revealed BA funerary & ceremonial complex, & a LIA & R-B settlement of roundhouses & pit groups alongside a metalled trackway. Site relatively rich in finds, with glass beads, spindle whorls & a large pottery assemblage also recovered. Prob. 5th-7th C. occupation too. A dispersed hoard of 6 late 3rd C. coins also discovered in rubble layer backfilling Roundhouse S6, along with Cheshire briquetage frags. & a sherd of D-ware pottery of 5th-6th C. AD. Roberts, H., Cutler, R. & Hughes, G. 2004. Cefn Cwmwd, Rhostrehwfa: pit circle, early Bronze Age cremation cemetery, Iron Age/Romano British farmstead and early medieval occupation. In R. Cuttler, A. Davidson & G. Hughes 9eds.) Excavations on Anglesey 1999: the Anglesey DBFO Scheme. Unpublished report: GAT/University of Birmingham, 24.

name: PAS: Fordcroft, Orpington 513
comments: 25 coins  of AD 260-290 from Poverest Road West site, thought by R. Reece to be a scattered hoard. Majority (21) found scattered on surface of an upper metalling deposit (Feature 8), other 4 were from deposits above metalling & may have been derived from it. Some tile frags. among stones of metalled surface, & RB pottery, a bronze stud, iron nails & 2 glass beads. Philp, B. and Keller, P. 1995. The Roman Site at Fordcroft, Orpington. West Wickham: Kent Archaeological Rescue Unit, pp. 15, 28-29.

name: PAS: Ivy Chimneys, Witham 515
comments: 254 radiates & a single ant. found as dispersed hoard over 4x1.5m area, within depth of up to 0.20m of soil. No sign of a container. No further contextual details. Turner, R. 1999. Excavations of an Iron Age Settlement and Roman Religious Complex at Ivy Chimneys, Witham, Essex 1978-83. EAA Report 88, pp. 74-76.

name: PAS: Ivy Chimneys, Witham 516
comments: 17 radiates found assoc. with remains of a ceramic container & human infant bones in fill of a ditch. Poss. a foundation deposit under a timber building.  2 bronze scrap frags. & a bronze hook also mentioned, but not clear if assoc. Turner, R. 1999. Excavations of an Iron Age Settlement and Roman Religious Complex at Ivy Chimneys, Witham, Essex 1978-83. EAA Report 88, pp. 41, 76.

name: PAS: Frocester Court Roman Villa 517
comments: During excav of Frocester Court Roman villa, in 1961-7, publication mentions deposits in ditch 1, especially layers V & VI, which also contained much pottery, animal bone, charred wood, burnt stone, frags. of box tiles, building debris & (in layer V) a cu alloy bracelet. Sherds from a glass beaker present in both layers, along with coins, incl. 6 radiates from layer V. Gracie, 1970. Frocester Court Roman villa. Trans. Bristol & Glos. Arch. Soc. 89: 32-33.

name: PAS: Gresham Street 574
comments: 13 illegible dup/asses found within an almost complete Roman amphora from Spain, by Wessex Archaeol. on 27th January 2006 from a test pit at 54-66 Gresham Street, City of London EC2. Amphora securely stratified within Roman deposit, lying horizontally. Subsequent removal of fill of amphora under controlled conditions revealed 13 coins, a cu alloy disc, & 2 pottery sherds from 2 other vessels. Wessex Archaeology. 2006. 52-66 Gresham Street, 25-26 Old Jewry and 13 Ironmonger Lane, London EC2: archaeological evaluation report.

name: PAS: Coventina's Well 575
comments: Recovered by John Clayton & others in 1876 from a stone-lined well, prob. assoc. with a shrine or temple, to W of Roman fort at Carrawburgh. The finds from Coventina?s Well incl. a human skull ?filled with coins?, animal bone, pottery incl. ritual thurible vessels, bronze brooches, rings, studs, bracelets & buckles, a bronze mask & fittings, an EBA axe hammer (curated?), 24 stone altars dedicated to Coventina & Minerva plus stone reliefs, 2 gold & 3 silver finger rings, glass vessels & beads, jet & shale rings, bracelets & beads, bone pins, leather shoes & sandals. The coins incl. 4 gold aurei, 184 silver coins & c. 16000+ cu alloy coins, from Augustus to late 4th C. The coins have some non-Roman issues, & may incl. a specific hoard of c. 11413 coins. Coins & some smaller objects thrown into the Well as votive offerings, whilst some other artefacts used in infilling of the Well, as a reaction to Theodosian edicts against paganism, other items poss. thrown in as rubbish. Allason-Jones, L. & Mackay, B. 1985. Coventina?s Well: a Shrine on Hadrian?s Wall. Hexham: Trustees of Clayton Collection. Lindsay Allason-Jones and B. Mackay suggested (68f.) that in view of high proportion of bronze coins of c. AD 98-193 The list of 13490 coins incl. 4 gold aurei, from Galba to Julia Domna, but also 55 den. of period AD 193-222. There does not seem sufficient evidence for a large bronze hoard ending in c. AD 180-93 having been placed in Coventina's Well.

name: PAS: Great Walsingham 576
comments: HER: Roman finds made at this site since the 1950s. Extensive metal detecting has recovered Roman coins, pottery, votive objects, brooches & building material. The enormous volume of finds of a religious nature indicate that this was a temple site. The site is part of a much larger Roman town (NHER 42850). Ritual objects include representations of Mercury, & satyrs & cupids, prob. relating to the god Bacchus. Pottery dating from 2nd to 4th C. AD may relate to offerings of food & drink or ritual feasting. Over 6000 R-B coins, many perhaps gifts to the gods left at the temple. Bagnall-Smith, J. 1999. Votive objects from Great Walsingham. Britannia: 21-57.

name: PAS: Hockwold 577
comments: HER: Site of a substantial R-B settlement with strong religious focus, known from cropmarks, excavs, fieldwalking & metal-detected finds. APs of site show cropmarks of an organised settlement, bisected by the linear earthwork known as the Fossditch, of probable post-Roman date (NHER 1089). In 1950s several diadems & a crown were discovered on site after ploughing, excav. revealed chalk floors & pits. One of buildings close to findspot either a temple or related religious structure. Coins, brooches & votive objects recovered from immediate area, & another diadem, found inside area of the building. 2 pewter hoards have also been found on site, & another nearby (NHER 5588). Finds suggest temple connected to cult of Attis & Cybele, & incl. large number of coins, brooches, pottery, CBM & tesserae, & other R-B metal finds. Clarke R.R. 1955. The Foss ditch - a linear earthwork in south-west Norfolk. Norfolk Archaeol.: 184-187. Gurney, D. 1986. Settlement, Religion and Industry on the Fen-edge: Three Romano-British Sites in Norfolk. East Anglian Archaeology.

name: PAS: Walkington Wold 578
comments: Between 1967 and 1969 two Bronze Age barrows at Walkington Wold excav. by Bartlett & Mackey on behalf of East Riding Archaeol. Soc. Late Roman occupation at Barrow 1 consisted of 726 coins & 1000s of sherds of late 4th C. Huntcliff ware pot, also brooches, bronze rings, bronze & glass bracelet frags, sheet lead & lead spindle whorl, but also prob. A-S belt mounts, knifes etc. Suggested by excavs. that the barrow, in a commanding position with views across Humber, may have been an inland Roman signal station (Bartlett and Mackey 1973, 27). Seems more likely to be a shrine/votive deposition.  Bartlett, J.E. & Mackey, R.W. 1973. Excavations on Walkington Wold 1967?1969. East Riding Archaeologist 1 (2): 1-93. Buckberry, J.L. & Hadley, D.M. 2007. An Anglo-Saxon execution cemetery at Walkington Wold, Yorkshire. OJA 26 (3): 309-327. Site very heavily disturbed, both by ploughing & badgers, but also be A-S activity when it was used as an execution cemetery ? skellies on site 14C dated by later work. Seems to have been a BA barrow, re-used in RB period, but unlikely to have been a beacon given coin loss ? more likely a site for deposition, or a shrine (e.g. barrows in Leic. with IA pots inserted into them). Large portions of pots. Some coins in barrow ditches, not just in mound, & conc. to NE & SE. Re-used & disturbed again in A-S period, but poss. because of myths etc surrounding the site. Coins from Sestersius to Honorius, & may have built up over time, though there was a cluster of late 4th C. coins to NE. Some IA ditches to W & N.

name: PAS: Piercebridge river deposits 579
comments: A large quantity of votive objects & pottery recovered from the River Tees by 2 divers, near remains of poss. wooden structure(s) or a bridge. Cropmarks of the alignment of Dere Street indicated likelihood of a bridge in this place. Finds concentrated in 5m x 5m area towards middle of river, & incl. 1021 coins of AD 70-350, 72 brooches, bronze, silver & iron rings, some with garnets & intaglios, gold earring & necklace frags., 10 bracelets, medical & cosmetic instruments, seal boxes, weighing equipment, household equipment & fittings, military belt fittings, sword chapes, lead seals, iron arrowheads, copper alloy & lead figurines, bronze & bone pins, together with 1st to 4th century pottery. Some of coins were defaced, bent & deliberately cut, 20 lead discs also recovered ? forgeries, votive stand-ins for coins, or rolled up curse tablets? A large number of the denarii in the assemblage were plated or silver-washed copies. Some artefacts found in fine silt covering the riverbed, whilst others found within ceramic vessels, but majority encased in concretions of organic material & iron corrosion products. The concretion also encased more than 80 box studs & furniture fittings, poss. indicating that at least some coins & artefacts were positioned carefully on river bed in wooden boxes or chests (Walton 2008). So rather than one hoard, these coins may actually represent many different hoards over time.  Casey, J. 1989. A votive deposit from the River Tees at Piercebridge. Durham Archaeol.  J 5: 37-42. Walton, P. 2008. The finds from the river. In H.E.M. Cool and D. Mason (eds.) Roman Piercebridge. Excavations by D.W. Harding and Peter Scott 1969-1981. Durham: Architect. & Archaeol. Soc. of Durham & Northumberland, pp. 286-293. Wessex Archaeology 2010. Piercebridge, County Durham. Archaeological evaluation & assessment of results.

name: PAS: Haddenham, Upper Delphs III 580
comments: 7 coins of Gallienus, Claudius II, Constantine I & 2 radiates, found together in short c. 4m) excav. section of shrine enclosure ditch near entrance, with a glass bead & a cu alloy knife handle. Poss. another small hoard. The Snow?s Farm/HAD III shrine complex was an octagonal shrine within a sub-square enclosure, built on top of a BA round barrow. Investigated by Bromwich in 1950s, then fully excav. in 1983. Evans, C. and Hodder, I. 2006. Marshland Communities and Cultural Landscapes from the Bronze Age to the Present Day. Cambridge: McDonald Institute for Archaeological Research, pp. 352-363. Coin report by Reece.

name: PAS: Ashford 582
comments: Roman burial discovered in spring of 1929 in widening S side of Ashford-Maidstone-London road at Potter's Corner; finds included a whitish urn, 15-18 inches high, a small urn, an inkpot & a cup of Samian ware & 18 gold coins or discs (JRS 19, 1929, p. 210). A burial group found at Potters Corner, almost certainly represents an untouched cremated deposit, but it is suggested [by whom?] that it formed part of a quantity of old pots etc. which were tipped down the bank near where it was found, from an adjacent house called 'Woodside'. But pots were found unbroken, & against a patera which had tilted was found a heap of burnt bones. The terra sigillata found in the deposit consisted of a Dragendorff 33 & an 'inkpot' c.150 AD or earlier. Kent SMR.

name: PAS: Uley 583
comments: Structure I Phases 5e(i) & 5e(ii), in 5e(i) demolition contexts 60/148, 140-61, 70, 69, 45, 37, 80, 85, 97, 84 & cess pit deposit 187; and in 5e(ii) contexts 22, 32, 38, 38, 62 & 155 respectively, latter a ?debris deposit? characterised by dense concentrations of animal bones, including many horn cores of goats? & a cu alloy figurine, lead tablets, cu alloy bracelets, votive objects & decorated plaques, brooches, miniature pots, glass beads & spoons, furniture fittings, & many coins, incl. ?a hoard of four? (Woodward & Leach 1993: 47).

name: PAS: Uley 584
comments: Structure IV Phases 4 & 5a-b. Demolition layers contained coins, some from small rooms? (Woodward & Leach 1993: 54), ?four which may have been scattered votive ?hoards?.

name: PAS: Caerwent (House XII S) 585
comments: At NE angle of Room 5 in House XII, c. 36 small coins found at level of top of the wall, 6 inches below grass level. T. Ashby. 1904-5. Archaeologia 59: Undated.

name: PAS: Halsham 586
comments: A tumulus was opened in which several urns found, containing a great number of copper coins: urns taken to Burton Constable with some of coins, rest carried away by the workmen. At same time a considerable number of skeletons were found, with urns placed at their heads." G. Poulson, Hist. of Holderness (1841), II, 387. Pastscape: The tumulus was opened when digging out the foundations for the mausoleum in 1802. A considerable number of skeletons were found, several having urns containing a great number of copper coins placed at their heads.

name: PAS: Dorchester, Somerleigh Court Estate III 587
comments: During excav. of villa at Somerleigh Court Estate, Dorchester, 1966-7, 3 frag. silver coins in bad state of preservation recovered immediately about small area of burned clay which rested on grey clay. ?remains of coins adhered to each other & may represent part of a small hoard, either deposited there or accidentally scattered." H.S.L. Dewer. 1967. Proc. Dorset Nat. Hist. and Arch. Soc. 89, 165f.

name: PAS: Silchester 588
comments: In 1833, during excav of the baths, in the natatio or cold-water bath at Silchester was found a human skeleton, & in leaden pipe connected with the bath upwards of 200 Roman coins of brass." A.J. Kempe. 1838. Archaeologia 27: 418. A ref. in Gent. Mag. 1833 I, 125, established 1833 as date of discovery.

name: PAS: Burnby Lane, Hayton 589
comments: 9 coins found together in flue of a corn drying oven. Research project with Peter Halkon.

name: PAS: Nettleton  590
comments: Nettleton report describes that in ?the priest or custodian?s house? (building IX), in the southern part of the building the stone floor was laid after AD 350. 45 coins were recovered from layer containing charred wood & fire ash immediately below it. Wedlake, W.J. 1982. The Excavation of the Shrine of Apollo at Nettleton, Wiltshire, 1956-1971. Soc. of Ant. Of London, pp. 29.

name: PAS: Welney 591
comments: The Washes North complex of small enclosures. Rescue operations while being bulldozed in 1953 produced 2 rectangular buildings. A section through habitation site dug by S.R. Hopkin & planned by T.C. Lethbridge.  This account of 1953 work is based on notes kindly lent by Messrs. Tebbutt, Lethbridge & Potter. C.W. Phillips (ed.). 1970. The Fenland in Roman Times, 231-3. WELNEY, The Washes north: Complex group of small enclosures..Rescue operations while the surface was being bulldozed in 1953 produced structures at three points: (a) Planned by CFT [i.e. C.F. Tebbutt]:2 rectangular buildings..(b) Section through habitation site dug by S.R. Hopkin and planned by T.C. Lethbridge.A small coin hoard [no. 1778] in the remains of a bag came from top band of humus, sealed by upper silt. Most unfortunately the hoard was not kept separate from stray coins from the site, through no fault of the excavators, and cannot now be dated. This site was on the highest part of the field...C.W. Phillips ed., The Fenland in Roman Times (1970), 231-3". This is the second hoard (see IARCH-8AF572).

name: PAS: Appleshaw 592
