comments: Pastscape record of Appleshaw villa 28060 - coins associated with pewter hoard? In Nov 1897, G.H. Engleheart cut trench through heavy scatter of RB building material near E. edge of the Ludgershall-Andover road, locating a cement floor. In shallow pit dug through floor he found hoard of 32 4th C. pewter vessels, 2 of which bore Chi Rho & fish symbols. No further mention made of this site but 80 yards to N., Engleheart excav. a detached bath-house with bath adjoining. There is local tradition of treasure find in field & Colt Hoare's note of hoard of gold & silver coins contained in 2 lead pots found 1775 by a ploughman prob. applies. The pewter hoard now in BM. Record of lead vessels containing gold & silver coins also.  Engleheart, Read & Gowland 1898. Soc of Antiquaries of London Archaeologia 56: 6-20. Engleheart, G.H. 1920-24. Hampshire Studies 9: 215-6.

name: PAS: Trevelgue Head 594
comments: Reece (2011) does not think all the 88 coins found during excav. are from a hoard, which is fair enough, but I think some small coin groups are hoards, according to our definition.  Coins 80, 83 & 84 ? 3 coins found in small pit/posthole [148] outside doorway of House 1. No other finds from feature, & coins may have been deposited after removal of a post (pp. 360). These coins were approx. 20 years later in date than those used in house infill. Nowakowski suggest that many of coins in house fill were deliberately placed on floor, & there are some discrete groups, but as excavs. were in 1939 I have not counted these as hoards as contextual info. is not good enough.

name: PAS: Black Piece Roman villa, Clipsham 595
comments: Site discovered c.1897 by Thomas Halliday, who found pottery & coins. In Sept 1926 quarrying at 'Black Piece' revealed layer of iron slag & charcoal in large mound assoc. with steelyard & 2 lead weights, oyster shell, tile frags, RB pottery & a stylus, samian pottery & mid 3rd C. bronze coin. In c. 1975 Mr A L Tabor described work carried out & finds, incl. various walls. A rough wall of slag found in 1929, & in 1940 Mr Tabor reported excav. of remains of a building assoc. with 2nd C. pottery & coins, robbed then covered with 1.5 to 4 ft of soil & slag. This deposit contained numerous coins of 2nd half of 4th C. & pottery, also another steelyard & a bronze buckle. J K St Joseph noted soil marks indicating ancient disturbance of the surface over a considerable area. Material donated to Rutland County Museum in 1970. Tabor?s c. 1975 notes detail various stone walls, longest of which 150' long & 2' wide. Tabor suggests this is a courtyard villa. A small room in SE corner c.10' square contained a pit with human neonate. Tabor says villa dismantled & covered by deposit of clean soil 2-8 inches thick (a natural deposit?) & then by deposit of slag, 6-in thick in S & thinning to N, which artefacts date to AD 340-400. 67 Roman coins are listed in an appendix, incl. a coin hoard (7 coins). Other finds incl. pottery, knives, brooches, bracelets, a spoon, dice,  buckles, tweezers, pins, shears,  brooches, a needle, an ear pick, a spearhead, & glass. Tile includes flue and roof and Collyweston slates. A project was undertaken on the pottery in 1994-5. Personal recollections of the dig at Black Piece were provided to the HER in 2010.

name: PAS: Enfield, Churchfields, Edmonton 596
comments: Edmonton Churchfield: during gravel working in 1929 pottery and roof and hypocaust tiles found in quantity, as well as a 'hipposandal', key, and horse bit. Coin hoard (AD 150-200) found between the sleeper beams of a hut. LM 28.137/4."-VCH Middlesex, I (1969), 69. HER: Timber structures, inhumation, pottery, ditches & coin hoard excav in 1929,1938, 1951 & 1952. Surface finds led to trial trenching by H Randall in 1973. This revealed 2 pockets of Roman tile & pottery. Coins & other small finds found along with 2nd-4th C. pottery, & 3 bronze coins of 3rd/4th C. date. Further excav. in 1974 under J Ivens revealed Roman ditch, 10 metres of which was cleared, with 3rd to 4th C pot & a skull. Excav by G Deal for Enfield Archaeol Soc 1972-74 found Roman tile & kiln wasters (dated to AD 150-250). Ivens, J. and Deal, G. 1977. Finds & Excavations in Roman Enfield. VCH: Pottery & roof and hypocaust tiles found in quantity, during gravel quarrying in 1929 as well as a 'hipposandal', key, & horse bit. Coin hoard (A.D. 150-200) found between the sleeper beams of a hut. Excavs by Mr G R. Gillam & others in 1951 proved presence of small settlement of late 3rd-mid 4th cent. A.D. A second hut with latrine trench was noted. Further work in 1952 confirmed this dating. 'Archaeology: The Romano-British Period ', A History of the County of Middlesex: Volume 1.

name: PAS: Redlands Farm Roman villa & settlement, Stanwick 597
comments: The temenos in Field I was focused on an earlier BA round barrow constructed in turf & revetted with a ring of posts. In 1st C. AD the mound surrounded by polygonal temenos wall. Robbing destroyed most of wall so not possible to establish number of sides of original enclosure, but there was a monumental entrance on W side, assoc. with architectural frags. & prob. originally capped with tegulae & imbrices. Around the ambulatory, mixed with rubble, were c. 500 coins largely of 1st & early 2nd C. On E side 2 copper-alloy leaves were found, & around temenos & extending W towards a small building were huge deposits of oyster shells up to 0.20m deep. The coins almost certainly offerings. Neal. D.S. 1989. The Stanwick villa, Northants. Britannia 20: 149-168.

name: PAS: Walbrook 598
comments: During builders' excavs for Bucklersbury House, Walbrook, City of London in 1955, clearance made to great depth. Excav. in a limited area by Prof. W.F. Grimes, located Roman stream-bed of River Walbrook, which flowed southwards immediately W of Temple of Mithras & c. 30 yds. W of street of Walbrook. The stream was subject to silting & thick deposit of black mud had extraordinary preservative effect on metal objects. Of coins found in Walbrook: "It will be observed that apart from half a dozen coins of widely different dates before Roman conquest of Britain, & 3 - also of scattered dates - after AD 160, there is a remarkably continuous series from middle of 1st C to middle of 2nd C. After this date the additions were very few & widely spaced in time." R. Merrifield. 1962. Ant. J. 42: 39-52.

name: PAS: Wimbledon Common 599
comments: Robertson 2000, 235 no. 964:"15 June 1865"Augustus W. Franks, Esq. Director, exhibited the remains of a small Roman Urn or Cup of grey earthenware together with several First Brass coins of early emperors which were found within it at Wimbledon."PSA, (2), III (1864-7), 145Undated. Probably 1st - early 3rd century AD". There is confusion between hoard of 16 2nd C. coins associated with a ceramic vessel given to BM by Franks found in garden of a house in Albert Drive in Wimbledon (presumably 1865,0620.1.b "Wimbledon Park") see IARCH-B2D2AC; & a hoard of 8 "early brass" coins found in excavs at Caesar's Camp on Wimbledon Common in a ceramic vesssel. The hoard was said also to contain a bronze ingot fragment.This record refers to the Caesar's Camp hoard.

name: PAS: Wanborough 600
comments: A 2nd C. hoard of 8 bronze coins found when a bowl barrow was opened in 1858, prior to destruction by road works of A31, when a rescue excavation was carried out by the Surrey Archaeol. Soc. Details from Pastscape.  An extended inhumation found overlying the ditch & a Roman coin was found two inches above it suggesting a Roman date for the burial [or perhaps a Roman coin in an Anglo-Saxon burial]. R-B sherds were found as well as a Roman iron spearhead, an `early brooch' & 8 bronze coins which are considered to represent a 2nd C. hoard. Surrey Archaeol. Collections 1864. 2: 25-27.

name: PAS: Uley 601
comments: 3 late 1st century coins, an early 2nd century coin & 4 brooches found in clay deposit 255 (Woodward & Leach 1993: 23). N.B. Not clear from text if these objects found together or dispersed throughout context, &/or whether they were deliberately incorporated within it. Springs 450m to W & NW.

name: PAS: Wroxeter 602
comments: The excavators also picked up this curious skiff-shaped bronze article, which seems adapted to suspend from a lady's arm. It has a lid, fastened down by a small flat bolt. When found it contained coins. Can this be a lady's purse? Corbet Anderson, J. 1867. The Roman City of Uriconium, pp. 84f. The accompanying fig. showed this to have been a bronze arm-purse. Undated. Prob. 1st or 2nd C. AD.

name: PAS: Norton 603
comments: HER: 26th May 1956 (presumed to be part of NNHS&FC excavation) a hoard of 40 coins found in 2nd C. pot buried beneath pebble floor; details given; finds in Northampton Museum. In Northampton Museum there is also a small grey-ware pot which contained hoard of ant. RCHME. 1981. An Inventory of The Historical Monuments in The County of Northampton. p.152

name: PAS: Nettleton  604
comments: Nettleton report describes that in ?house of the Strong-room? (building XIII), the east wing was constructed in form of cellar or strong-room, with access & a window at W end, & its S & E walls against the solid rock face. A wooden floor had been laid over this cellar & its charred remains, containing coins ranging from AD 370-385, were found in the lower cellar floor. Wedlake, W.J. 1982. The Excavation of the Shrine of Apollo at Nettleton, Wiltshire, 1956-1971. Soc. of Ant. Of London, pp. 17.

name: PAS: Kelvedon 606
comments: A series of archaeol. excavs initiated as major rescue/ research programme in/& around Kelvedon following excavs by Rodwell in 1968 & 1975. In Trench D, excav. by Eddy, after  outwork of town defence had been filled with rubbish a soil layer developed over site, dated by a disturbed coin hoard to 4th C. Eddy, M.R. 1982. Kelvedon. The Origins and Development of a Roman Small Town.  The fills of defences also produced an unusual lead object with a chi-rho symbol, but it is not clear from Eddy?s poor report if this was from same layer as coin hoard. There is no contextual info., & the number of coins & their issues is not even recorded! Rodwell, K.A. 1988. The Prehistoric and Roman Settlement at Kelvedon, Essex. CBA Research Report 63 (Eddy?s trenches not mentioned in this report, but shows trench locations).

name: PAS: Ivy Chimneys, Witham 607
comments: Depression F2409. Contained 12 re-deposited (curated?) Palaeolithic flint handaxes in gravel at bottom of feature, also 3 3rd C. coins. Then an octagonal stone font inserted. After font fell out of use, depression filled with series of black upper fills, poss. derived from midden material, containing large quantities of animal bone, oyster shell & pottery; but also objects incl. a silver pin, a copper alloy enamelled fitting, decorative strips & frags. of finger & ear rings & bracelets (some chopped up), pins, copper beads, door fittings, and an iron latch lifter, hand saw, auger & trowel, an iron wool carding comb, a stone cult figure, & 32 4th C. coins. Turner, R. 1999. Excavations of an Iron Age Settlement and Roman Religious Complex at Ivy Chimneys, Witham, Essex 1978-83. EAA Report 88, pp. 63.

name: PAS: Frocester Court Roman Villa 608
comments: Mattingly (2000) lists 3 other poss. hoards from Frocester. These included 2 4th C coins found in contact on the pebble/gravel surface under Building E. Mattingly, H.B. 2000. The radiate minim hoard. In E. Price Frocester: a Romano-British Settlement, its Antecedents and Successors. Stonehouse: GADARG, pp. 20.

name: PAS: Kingscote II 609
comments: Small hoard of coins found in NW corner of Building 1 Site 1 below a red sandstone tile, poss. within a black accumulation of soil that may be abandonment layer. Number of coins not noted in main text. This black soil layer also contained 4th C pottery, copper alloy brooches, bracelets, rings & buckles, scrap copper-alloy offcuts & globules from metalworking, plus iron saw blades, knives & an awl, an iron lamp, styli, bucket mounts & 2 snaffle bits. Timby, J. 1998. Excavations at Kingscote and Wycomb, Gloucestershire. Cotswold Archaeology, pp. 29, 400.

name: PAS: Kingscote III 610
comments: A second small coin hoard (Hoard S) of 26 coins recovered from under cobbling at E end of Building 1, Site 1. Timby, J. 1998. Excavations at Kingscote and Wycomb, Gloucestershire. Cotswold Archaeology, pp. 29, 400.

name: PAS: Old Place, Sleaford 611
comments: Over 700 late Roman coins  recovered from ditch 535 during excavs in 1984-1985, & it was suggested that there are too many for casual loss. 500-520 coins at least make up hoard, dispersed either because original container broke or it was organic & subsequently decomposed. Further Roman features incl. field enclosures & burials. Davies, J.A. 1997. The Roman coins from Old Place, Sleaford. In S.M. Elsdon Old Sleaford Revealed. A Lincolnshire Settlement in Iron Age, Roman, Saxon & Medieval Times: Excavations 1882-1995. Oxbow, pp. 39, 176-180.

name: PAS: Wood Meadow Roman villa, Thurgarton 612
comments: HER: Excavation at Wood Meadow Roman villa, Thurgarton. A hoard of 40 coins of latter half of 4th C. The majority of retained finds, less the coins, held by S. Revill & Mr Coulthard. The coins held by Mr Mattingly, Nottm Univ. Pastscape: Roman villa with a north aisle containing a 3 room bath suite, & a range of rooms annexed to the south. Excavs. between 1960-66.

name: PAS: Lullingstone Roman villa VI 613
comments: In Room 15, part of ?Central Group? of villa rooms, there was a small, very shallow subcircular grave 0.43m long & 0.38m wide, cut into earlier concrete floor. This contained skeleton of a neonate, disturbed & mostly removed at later date, accompanied by 4 minims, 2 minimi, a bronze vessel frag., a pot sherd & a small amount of carbonised wheat grains. In same room there was also a small hoard of copper & lead ingots & a casting, placed in a small pit together with a pottery vessel. Meates, G.W. 1979. The Roman Villa at Lullingstone, Kent. Kent Archaeol. Mono. 1, pp. 88.

name: PAS: Fenny Stratford By-pass 614
comments: 3rd century. HER: Forger?s hoard of coin blanks & iron dies found in 3 local sand-tempered pots. 1st held 0. 6kg of bronze pellets. 2nd contained 246 blanks, hammered but not ready for striking. 3rd held 352 finished blanks ready for striking. Intended end product prob. late 3rd C. counterfeit ant. Ponting, M. 1992. The Fenny Stratford hoard. Because of circumstances of discovery, it was not possible to ascertain details of burial of hoard, which had presumably been deposited in pit or ditch cut into subsoil. 50m to SW, also under line of Galley Lane, 10 late Roman inhumation burials were recorded prior to discovery of the hoard. 598 cu-alloy coin blanks found in Pots I & 2.  Pot 3, which was almost complete, was emptied in the Unit's conservation lab & contained c. 1,250 cu-alloy pellets, & small number of waste off-cuts & swarf, with a total weight of 608 g. Zeepvat, R.J. et al. 1994. A Roman coin manufacturing hoard from 'Magiovinium', Fenny Stratford, Bucks. Britannia 25:1-19.

name: PAS: Salford Priors 615
comments: Excavs. in advance of A435 Norton Lenchwick bypass, now part of A46. In Area C3, rectangular stone Building i was aligned E-W & 15 x 7m in size, with clay bonded walls with loosely dressed faces. Inside Building i there was a large deep cess pit 329, into which stone slab floor partly subsided, but it was not clear if this was from an early phase of building, or a phase pre-dating it. There was a soil-filled hollow to E. To S was Building j, of aisled posthole construction & timber form, at least 16 x 6m in size, with a central drain gullly. These 2 structures may have been agric. buildings assoc. with a larger complex ? Building j could have been a byre. During excav., however, controlled metal detecting & archaeol. recording around the two buildings plotted concs. of coins & brooches, with a particular focus on the NE corner of Building i, but also with groups to the N 7 SE; & to the E of Building j. The coins & brooches were sometimes individual but also in groups of c. 10-16 coins, which in several cases were spatially close to brooch finds. The coins & brooches were sometimes in soil layers, sometimes in very shallow ?scoops? in underlying natural subsoil.  Some brooches were broken, others complete; & between Buildings i & j were 2 human skull frags. In Mays coin report in excav. volume (pp. 126-134) she comments that ?the spatial distributions of neither the broken nor the unbroken brooches (Fig. 55) corresponds to that of the coins?, even though that figure actually shows that some did! May identifies 9 groups of coins (A-I) from Area C3 that were found in dense scatters over radius of c. 0.15m. She only considers 4 of these to be hoards using her criteria, & the brooches not as votive depsits, but this would seem to be a very conservative interpretation. The coin groups are: Scatter A ? 16 coins of AD 260-378; Scatter B ? 9 coins from AD 313-393; Scatter C ? 16 coins of of AD 260-402; Scatter D ? 13 coins of AD 253-378; Scatter E ? 4 disparate coins of AD 271-375; Scatter F ? 9 coins of AD 271-375; Scatter G ? 5 coins of AD 269-375; Scatter H ? 5 coins of AD 271-340; & Scatter I 6 coins of AD 260-348. To S was Building j, of aisled posthole construction & timber form, at least 16 x 6m in size, with a central drain gullly. These 2 structures may have been agric. buildings assoc. with a larger complex ? Building j could have been a byre. During excav., however, controlled metal detecting & archaeol. recording around the two buildings plotted concs. of coins & brooches, with a particular focus on the NE corner of Building i, but also with groups to the N 7 SE; & to the E of Building j. The coins & brooches were sometimes individual but also in groups of c. 10-16 coins, which in several cases were spatially close to brooch finds. The coins & brooches were sometimes in soil layers, sometimes in very shallow ?scoops? in underlying natural subsoil.  Some brooches were broken, others complete; & between Buildings i & j were 2 human skull frags. In Mays coin report in excav. volume (pp. 126-134) she comments that ?the spatial distributions of neither the broken nor the unbroken brooches (Fig. 55) corresponds to that of the coins?, even though that figure actually shows that some did! May identifies 9 groups of coins (A-I) from Area C3 that were found in dense scatters over radius of c. 0.15m. She only considers 4 of these to be hoards using her criteria, & the brooches not as votive depsits, but this would seem to be a very conservative interpretation. The coin groups are: Scatter A ? 16 coins of AD 260-378; Scatter B ? 9 coins from AD 313-393; Scatter C ? 16 coins of of AD 260-402; Scatter D ? 13 coins of AD 253-378; Scatter E ? 4 disparate coins of AD 271-375; Scatter F ? 9 coins of AD 271-375; Scatter G ? 5 coins of AD 269-375; Scatter H ? 5 coins of AD 271-340; & Scatter I 6 coins of AD 260-348.

name: PAS: Parwich 616
comments: On 9th August, we examined remains of tumulus in plantation on summit of Saint's Hill, near Parwich, which has been destroyed by getting stone for walls enclosing the plantation, when about 80 small brass coins of later Roman emperors were found scattered about the barrow." T. Bateman. 1861. Ten Years? diggings in Celtic and Saxon grave hills, in the Counties of Derby, Stafford, and York, from 1848 to 1858, with some notices of some former discoveres hitherto unpublished and remarks on the crania and pottery from the mounds. London: John Russell Smith, 61

name: PAS: Ketteringham 617
comments: On 22 April 1908, there was exhibited to the British Numismatic Society by "William Charlton - 12 Roman minimi found in a tumulus at Ketteringham, Co. Norfolk. BNJ 1908. 5: 430. "Minimi" ("Theodosian"?).

name: PAS: Housesteads (hoard 3) 618
comments: Hoard 3 from Housesteads. Brickstock and Casey in Rushworth ed. 2009, 375-6 describe hoard:"from the 1974-81 excavations, & now missing, is recorded from just west of the interval tower at eastern end of the North Rampart (H20:7:2; SF No. 5637). The surviving description speaks of 'a purse (very black soil) & bronze slivers = minimissimi.' The term 'minimissimi' is an unfortunate one, dating to a period when archaeologists evinced the notion that very small coins were of very late date... Lacking further information, Hoard 3 can be assigned only to late 3rd or mid- to late 4th C. Of the above categories, the most common is the first (AD 273-86), & such a date would be largely consistent with limited evidence for chalet construction in Buildings XIII and XIV nearby. A further leather purse (SF No. 7394) is recorded from the same context (H20:7:2), though, with no record of coins found in association with it, it is possible that this represents a duplication in the finds record."

name: PAS: Castle Combe 620
comments: Hoard of 300 brass coins, also stone relief of a hunter spearing deer found 1825/6, perhaps an altar to Diana. 182 coins in Devizes Museum, some from this site. A manuscript notebook by William Newman a surgeon; and George Poulett Scrope in  history of Castle Combe, says that 'in field called 'The Plain', Colt Hoare, William Crocker and Newman found a Roman villa. Pennant stone and pottery found in great abundance. The 1841 tithe map of Castle Combe shows field called 'The Plain' covered R-B settlement site ST87NW307 & it is poss. that this was ?villa? referred to by Scrope et al; or villa in plantation was outlying building connected to settlement. Moorhead (2001, 98) believes that the majority of 182 coins in Devizes Museum with the provenance "Castle Combe (1825) and North Wraxall villa (1859-60)" come from this hoard. The villa coins are described by Scrope (1860, 161) as consisting of a brass of Trajan and coins of the House of Constantine and Valens.

name: PAS: Andover (Clanville) 621
comments: Roman villa discovered in 1897 when ploughing revealed Roman floor levels. Excavs revealed large courtyard 60m by 45m with detached wings on 3 sides. The W of these was 29m long & 16m wide, an aisled house with mosaic floors & 2 rooms with hypocausts. To N of courtyard an irregular building 55m long & 12m wide. E side of complex not fully excav., but was building 33m by 12m) with some mosaic floors & at least one room heated by hypocaust. ?there was found in E wing a large urn of ordinary black ware, 2 feet in height, buried upright in ground, & covered with large flanged tile, which had been crushed down into mouth of jar, by pressure from above, prob. by plough. Six small bronze Roman coins were found in it, mostly adhering to its sides, part perhaps of a large hoard which had been discovered & removed." G.H. Engleheart, Archaeologia 56 (1898), 1-6.

name: PAS: Steyning 622
comments: In 1826, during removal of a barrow, "An urn containing burnt bones was found, & in different parts of the barrow, about 50 coins of small brass, chiefly of the Lower Empire. A style, about 5 inches in length, was found." E. Cartwright. 1830. Hist. of Arundel II, 170, in J. Dallaway, Hist. of W. Division of the Co. of Sussex  II. This seems to have been a scattered hoard.

name: PAS: Uley 623
comments: Structure II Phase 6e. ?The large number of coins included 683 late-Roman issues? which may have derived from one or more single hoards offered up in the temple? (Woodward & Leach 1993: 65).

name: PAS: Bowes Roman Fort 624
comments: Group of 6 coins (silvered antonini) stuck together into 'a column', with a 7th found close by, found in topsoil just outside of apse of bath house in commander's praetorium in Bowes Roman fort, excav. by Hartley & Frere in 1966-67. Latest coin an issue of Constantinus II of AD 332. Coins may have been originally wrapped in linen (in Shotter's coin report). Topsoil above a rubble layer containing pottery, wall plaster, iron nails & building stone, but no other topsoil finds mentioned. Frere, S.S. and Fritts, R.L. 2009. Excavations at Bowes and Lease Rigg Roman Forts. Yorkshire Archaeological Report No. 6, pp. 39. Fort on slightly flattened area of gentle S facing slope, with S facing slope of a ridge behind, and ground sloping away to W, S & E. A spring 400m to N, & River Greta c. 250m to S, also many springs opposite on S side of river.

name: PAS: Dummer 625
comments: Roman settlement site excav. in 1969, poss. ahead of construction of M3 motorway. Site revealed refuse pits, ditches & a roundhouse. There were finds of pottery, animal bone & a hoard of 106 coins, mostly late 3rd - late 4th century AD.

name: PAS: Twyn y Parc 626
comments: In late 1930s, Meyrick undertook small-scale excavation at Twyn y Parc promontory fort on Anglesey, just inside rampart on NE side. Finds incl. a sherd of mortarium, an iron spearhead, & a group of late 3rd & early 4th C. coins referred to as a hoard. Hughes, H.H. 1939. Twyn y Parc. Archaeol. Cambrensis 94: 98-9.

name: PAS: Richborough 632
comments: R. Reece, following B.W. Pearce's manuscript & typescript lists of Roman coins found at Richborough in 1931-8 recorded "Hoard III, 1937". 12 coins. Reece noted no information available as to which individual coins formed this hoard. R. Reece. 1968. Research Rep. Soc. Ant. 26: 190.

name: PAS: West Kennet 633
comments: During excav. of West Kennet long barrow, 6 Roman coins found in topsoil of facade area, scattered but in two locations. 3 coins, of Constantius II, Constans & unidentifiable of late 4th century, were found near Stone 1 of facade; 3 coins of Claudius Gothicus, Gratian & Valentinian II, were in disturbed area over & E of stone-hole 39. With exception of Claudius Gothicus coin, all mid-late 4th C. S. Piggott, The West Kennet Long Barrow (1962), 55f.; coins by M. Grant.

name: PAS: Aitnock/ Coalhill 657
comments: Found during excav. of IA dun or fortified dwelling at Coalhill/ Aitknock. Site stands on watershed between Dalry & Ardrossan, close to E side of road, & on summit of a cliff which rises about 60 feet perpendicularly from the waters of Rye stream at the SW angle of Hindog Glen near Dalry in Ayrshire. To SW defended by a deep ditch & stone wall, latter nearly circular, & c. 30 feet in diameter. From within came various objects of stone, bone, charcoal, charred wheat, iron scraps, a coarse potsherd (Roman?), fragment of samian platter, 18 or 18/31, etc., and 4 Roman coins. At several parts of interior an upper black layer of occupation observed above the level debris. From centre of the black layer, however, came 4 denarii. The coins had been wrapped in some material, and were sticking together in a mass. J. Smith 1919. PSAS 53: 130-2. Also 1 sherd of samian & another RB sherd, a glass bead, quern frags., hammerstones & a stone spindle whorl, worked bone G. Macdonald 1924. PSAS 58: 327.

name: PAS: Broch of Lingrow 658
comments: During excavs in different parts of outbuildings of broch there were found 4 silver Roman denarii. J. Anderson. 1883. Scotland in Pagan Times: the Iron Age, pp. 244, 244. These 6 den. may have come from a scattered hoard.

name: PAS: Grouville Hoard, Jersey 659
comments: New excav. hoard of IA coins. In early 2012, detectorists found 60 silver & one gold Iron Age coins, possibly minted by the Curiosolitae tribe at Saint-Malo in France. Subsequent detecting by Mead and Miles in the area of the initial find led them to discover a huge mass of Iron Age and Roman coins embedded in clay. The pair notified Jersey Heritage of the find, and in June 2012 archaeologists from the Société Jersiaise and Jersey Heritage, together with Celtic coin expert Philip de Jersey, worked to remove the clay mass of coins. The Grouville Hoard is a hoard of an estimated 70,000 late Iron Age and Roman silver coins reported in June 2012. Weight c. 75kg. Excavation of large pit containing hoard revealed evidence of timber posts, possibly from a hut, & large quantities of burnt daub, LIA & early Roman pottery. The presence of slag and furnace linings along with some coins which have been cut in half, could suggest that the coins were being melted down. Slow excavation in lab on Jersey has revealed 8+ gold torcs, 2 gold rings & a silver brooch amongst coins ? more prob. within mass. Outside UK NGR system.

name: PAS: Sark 661
comments: Hoard of 18 Celtic & Republican coins & silver phalerae. Allen, D. 1971. Archaeologia (2nd Series) 103: 1-31; NC 1968. Recent excavations by Cunliffe. Discovered in 1719.  William Tanquerel, Henry de Carteret, Pierre de Carteret, Philippe Guille & Nicollas Guille appeared before the Seneschal, & ordered to yield up to the Seigneur ?all such treasure as they have found in the ground in making a bank in an enclosed field commonly called ?la voroque? belonging to the said Tanquerel. After having been sworn in, have declared   all five with a single voice   that they found there thirteen  pieces of beaten metal, round as if they could have been plates,  but of different sizes, and one long piece in the shape of a fish, and one little ingot weighing about two ounces, which was a yellow colour and all pitted, and eighteen little pieces of  money.? 18 silver coins (17 Celtic, 1 Roman), 1 silver-gilt mount in shape of dolphin/fish, 13 silver or silver-gilt discs (phalerae), & 1 ?shapeless yellow lump? (amber?). Deposited c. 40-30 BC (at earliest) at end of 1st century BC, or early 1st century AD at latest.  Outside UK NGR system.

name: PAS: Hemingstone 710
comments: HER record (from Milne 1948, 38) of six "semi-autonomous" Greek bronze coins: two of Athens, one each of Aegina, Melos, Carteia and Boeotia. No further information on context.

name: PAS: Southbourne 951
comments: De Jersey writes:"On the index card for CCI 79.0098, Melinda Mays refers to a letter of 14 June 1913 from G.F. Hill, in the Red House Museum archives, mentioning the discovery of that coin "in a broken pot not preserved, with a Constantius and 6 SW British type". If the association with the Roman coin is correct then this might be better regarded as a Romano-British deposit. It is possible that one of the other coins was CCI 79.0225, a struck bronze stater (ABC 2175) found by Mr Pester at Pokesdown Cliffs, Southbourne, in 1912 (Haselgrove 1984, 137), but the precise location of the find is not certain; it is tempting to think that it may have been made at Hengistbury, just two kilometres east of Southbourne."

name: PAS: North West Norfolk 959
comments: Preliminary record for the material derived from recent Treasure cases from 2003 to 2007. This includes a mixture of Iron Age and Roman coins and artefacts and presumably includes several hoards within the group.The material is to be published by the British Museum.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2003 T169; 2005 T487; 2007 T695

name: PAS: Rushford 989
comments: De Jersey (2015): "Chadburn (2006, hoard 12) notes that the Norfolk SMR (15843) has a record of "a grey pot containing hundreds of small silver coins", found between 1910 and 1930 to the south of the village of Rushford. Rushford is about two kilometres south of Brettenham (175), where there have been a number of finds of Iron Age coinage. This might be an otherwise unrecorded Iron Age hoard."

name: PAS: Liddington 990
comments: De Jersey (2015) writes:""A labourer, while digging near Liddington Camp in May, 1887, dug up three gold British coins and sold them in London for 10s., 10s. 6d., and 12s.; not long afterwards another labourer found two or three gold coins near the same spot, but was forced to give them up to the landowner, who obtained information about them.Brooke 1888, 146"Robinson (1975, 6 n.3) has drawn attention to this account by J.W. Brooke, in the Report of the Marlborough College Natural History Society. No further detail is known."

name: PAS: Godmanchester 991
comments: c.100 bronze radiates from unknown location reported at metal detector club meeting.

name: PAS: Bembridge 1037
comments: Robertson 2000, 55 no. 270:""26 Roman imperial bronzes, all extremely worn, were found with the aid of a metal detector in 1985. The coins are mostly second century and made of orichalchum; they may represent the remains of a hoard."There were 21 sest. (of which, however, 8 may have been much worn dup.), 4 dup., and 1 As:Sest. Dup. As TOTALDomitian 1 1Nerva 1 1Trajan or Hadrian 1 1Hadrian 1 1Antoninus Pius 3 3Faustina I (deified?) 2 2Faustina II 1 1Faustina II (?) 3 3 Marcus or Commodus 1 1uncertain 8 4(?) 1221 4 1 26(1 dup.?)(2 dup.?)(5 dup.?)-I.A. Carradice, in CHRB VI, BM Occas. Paper 58 (1986), 37, wts."

name: PAS: Freshwater 1038
comments: 17 sestertii/dup/asses to late Antonine period. NC 2010.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2009 T366Other PAS records associated with this hoard: IOW-2278E5

name: PAS: Polesworth 1039
comments: Robertson 2000, 56-57 no. 277:"10 May 1849"Mr. Wright exhibited some denarii, found on the property of the Earl of Beauchamp at Hall End, Polesworth, Warwickshire - a portion, it was stated, of a large hoard recently ploughed up. Those received by Mr. Wright were of Vespasian, Hadrian, Pius, and Faustina Junior. Every exertion was used to obtain an inspection of the bulk, but without success."-JBAA, IV (1849), 151"

name: PAS: Brading 1040
comments: 20 sestertii/dup/asses, to Antonine period. BNJ 2012, 23.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2011 T181Other PAS records associated with this hoard: IOW-CBEB57

name: PAS: Wanborough(?) 1041
comments: Robertson 2000, 75 no. 354:""A concealed hoard of 22 aurei of 'Nero, Hadrian and the Antonines' found c. 1888 and shown in secrecy to A.D. Passmore as a boy. Passmore believed that the hoard was from Wanborough/Durocornovium, but this is of course, far from certain."-P.H. Robinson in Wilts. Arch. and Nat. Hist. Bi-annual Bull., Autumn 1977From A.D.Passmore (omitting Nero), Notebook in W.A.N.H.S. Library, and The Roman Road from Caerleon to Silchester (1948), 3"

name: PAS: Heddon-on-the-Wall 1042
comments: NMR record of a cairn containing two stone coffins on Turpin's Hill, in one of which in 1795 were found two urns and copper alloy coins of the first to second century.

name: PAS: Northamptonshire 1043
comments: Robertson 2000, 56 no. 273:""The coin [i.e. a large brass of Antoninus Pius] was found, some years since, with others, of Pius, the Faustinae, &c., in a vase in the county of Northampton."-NC, 1845, Proc., 5At the British Archaeological Association's Second Congress, at Winchester in 1845, there was exhibited by J. Newington Hughes: "a large brass coin of Antoninus Pius: reverse, BRITANNIA. A figure seated, holding a standard and spear; behind the figure a shield. It is in the finest condition, and was discovered with other large brass coins, and a pair of silver ornamented bracelets, in Northamptonshire."-Winchester Volume, 1845, 473"

name: PAS: Carlisle 1044
comments: Robertson 2000, 37-38 no. 188:"Re. the Roman Cemeteries of Luguvallium:"On Thursday, July 2nd, 1829, a fall of earth took place on the east side of the new cutting through Gallows Hill..[...text omitted, see note below](c) "About a fortnight later [i.e. than 29 Sept.], a glass bottle, much broken, was found, with lettering on it; and also a large number of silver coins - one account says several hundred, the other a small urn, full of silver coins; many of these were in good condition, but they were dispersed without their dates or legends being recorded, except that one was a Faustina. It is possible that some of the coins and other relics may be in the Morton Collection of local antiquities, given by Mr. Robert Ferguson to the Museum in Tullie House, Carlisle. The Morton Collection had incorporated with it a collection both of coins and other relics, made by the late Mr. Christopher Hodgson (brother of the historian of Northumberland) who, as county surveyor, was connected with the cutting of the road through Gallows Hill."(Footnote: "It was found on the eastern side of the road, 4? feet below the surface, at the highest part of the hill, about 15 feet from the late hedge, and nearly opposite the spot where the milestone stood."Chancellor Ferguson, loc. cit., 367f.; from Carlisle Patroit, 23 Oct. 1829, and Carlisle Journal, 19 Dec. 1829Finds (a) and (b) [no. 1723] may not be regarded as hoards in the strictest sense.Find (c) [no. 200] was certainly a hoard."

name: PAS: Gedney 1105
comments: Robertson 2000, 46 no. 222:""To Maurice Johnson.At Gedney hill several Roman coyns have been found, some of Antoninus are in your collection. In the same hamlet about two mile north of Southea bank is a pasture call'd the high doles, being a square doubly moted, where antient foundations have been dug up and some Roman coyns."-W. Stukeley, Itin. Cur. (1724), 11C.W. Phillips ed., The Fenland in Roman Times (1970), 303 gave the grid ref. as [...], noted that the hoard was recorded in a letter from J. Britain, 1723, to Maurice Johnson, as above (in the Spalding Gentlemen's Society Ms.), and added "Johnson, in a footnote to the letter, attributes the coins, then in his collection, to Gallienus to Theodosius II."Including "Antoninus" (or Theodosius, or later)"

name: PAS: Bath (Lansdown) 1149
comments: "Mrs. D.P. Dobson, Arch. of Somerset (1931), 154, attributed a hoard, containing a coin of Arcadius, to Lansdown, Bath, but the coins found at Lansdown constituted, not a hoard, but a site find.T.S. Bush, in PSA, (2), XXII (1907-9), 34; and JBAA, n.s., XII (1906), 289; giving date of discovery as 1905; and XIII (1907), 112, 251" Robertson 2000, 1495A

name: PAS: Redford 1320
comments: Robertson 2000, 279 no. 1175:"At Redford, "the reservoir of this spring was being cleared out in the autumn of 1855, when in the bank, and a short distance from the surface of the ground, a mass of small coins was discovered, loosely adherent with their own rust, and ranged in the manner of rouleaux, as if they had been packed in a box which was rotted away. They were found to be 1800 in number, all of third brass, and some of them in good preservation. They were sent to the British Museum for inspection and to be catalogued, and a few were retained to enrich the cabinet of that institution."Then came a list of emperors represented, as follows: Gallienus, Claudius II, Tetricus I and II, Constantine I, Licinius, Crispus, Constantine II, Constantius (II?), Helena, Fausta and Constans.-P.J. Martin, in Sussex Arch. Coll., XI (1859), 140-W. Figg, in Sussex Arch. Coll., VIII (1856), 277, gave the exact date of discovery as 23 Sept. 1855.The coins of Gallienus, Claudius II and the Tetrici must have been ant.It has not been possible to trace any coins from this hoard in the British Museum. Sussex Archaeological Collections states that they were returned."

name: PAS: Coombe Neville 1346
comments: Robertson 2000, 251 no. 1046:""At Combe-Nevil (a seat of the Harvey's) and a little distance from the Thames, have been found Coins and Medals of several of the Roman Emperors, especially of Diocletian, the Maximian's, Maximus, Constantine the Great, &c."-J. Pointer, Britannia Romana (1724), 38-Gough's Camden (1789), I, 176, recorded what is presumably the same find: "Another [i.e. urn] full of coins of the lower empire was dug up in a gravel pit within a mile of the town at the end of Combe lane leading to Combe Nevill."The authority for this was said to be J. Horsley, but a reference to the find in Horsley's works has not been traced.The coins were apparently folles and small AE. "Maximus" should presumably be Maximinus."

name: PAS: Llanymynech 1347
comments: Robertson 2000, 253 no. 1061:""A number of Roman coins of Constantine were found in the earth which was washed down the side of the hill some years ago."-W.T. Watkin, in Shrops. A.J. II (1879), 353-VCH Shrops., I (1908), 266, gave the date of discovery as about 1815.The coins were probably AE.Including Constantine (I?)"

name: PAS: Barnton 1352
comments: Two 'denarii' of Constantine I mentioned as having been found in a pot along with others.

name: PAS: North Littleton 1353
comments: Robertson 2000, 253 no. 1064:"The hoard "was discovered in the 1920's by Mr Sid Cook while digging asparagus beds in the area of Cleeve Hill, North Littleton, Worcs. The hoard consisted of about one dozen low value Roman coins in a coarse ware pot. The coins were identified by the British Museum, then returned to the finder and have since been lost. Some of the coins are believed to have been of the Emperor Constantine but nothing precise is known about them."-Letters, Feb. and March 1981, from B. Watson, EveshamIncluding Constantine (I?)"

name: PAS: Holbrook 1354
comments: Robertson 2000, 243-244 no. 1005:""Discovery of Ancient Coins - last week, a boy tending sheep in the marshes of Holbrook, close to the River Stour, discovered a large quantity of brass coins, slightly covered by the sand and shingle on the shore of the river. The coins, which bear the names of Dioclesian, Maximian, Constantine I, Constans and Constantius, are of the middle size and in fine preservation."-Ipswich Journal, 20 March 1841-Followed by NC, 1841 Miscellanea, 63f."Four third brass were found at Holbrook, on the bank of the Stour.Those found at Holbrook are - 1. Maximinus Daza, struck at Tr[e]ves (IMP MAXIMINVS P F AVG/GENIO POP ROM) 2. Constantine the Great, struck at Tr[e]ves (CONSTANTINVS P F AVG/S P Q R OPTIMO PRINCIPI Three standards) 3. The same Emperor, struck at London (CONSTANTINVS AVG/SOLI INVICTO COMITI) 4. A different mintage of the same coin."-Proc. Suff. Inst. Arch., I (1853), 151-Coins "of the middle size" seem likely to have been large folles."

name: PAS: Dunster Park 1355
comments: Robertson 2000, 251 no. 1044:""In Local Museum Roman Coins Found in Dunster Park".-Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc. XXXV (1890) (1), 47-"'Small copper coins of Maximian and Constantine found about 1863 concealed under a stone in a gully in the park, near the Old Carhampton road' now apud Mr. Luttrell (Note from Sir Henry Maxwell Lyte)."-VCH Somerset, I (1906), 362-It is possible that other emperors were represented besides Maximian and Constantine."

name: PAS: Morley St. Botolph 1356
comments: Robertson 2000, 248 no. 1021: " "A labourer was digging an under-drain and a number of coins fell out of the soil, about one foot below the present surface: many of these are now in my possession. They are brass Roman coins most of Constantine, some of Licinius, and others in which nothing can be deciphered. Indeed they were in such a state of decomposition that many crumbled into dust in the act of removing. Nothing but a very black earth could be discovered near them; which leads to the supposition that they were enclosed in a wooden and not an earthen vessel. I find from an old labourer that a mound is recollected on the spot, which extended for some considerable distance until cut through by the turnpike road: and that it was laid flat at the time of the enclosure of the parish in 1816."-Letter from Rev. C. B. Cooper, Morley St. Botolph, 3 March 1847 -Quoted in Norfolk Arch., II (1849), 3971 or 2 coins in Norwich Castle Museum"

name: PAS: Vaynor 1357
comments: Robertson 2000, 252 no. 1051:""A hoard of seven bronze coins was found in Vaenor (Brecknock) early in 1945, of which three surviving coins are folles of Maximinus II Daia (AD 305-313), Maxentius (306-312), and Constantine I (307-337) respectively."-JRS, XXXVI (1946), 133; from V.E. Nash-Williams."

name: PAS: Cringleford 1358
comments: Robertson 2000, 251 no. 1041: " "In January several bones, and about 100 small brass Roman coins, chiefly of Constantine the Great, were dug up near Cringleford Hall."-Norwich Guide (1842), 42"

name: PAS: Pin Dale 1359
comments: Roman coin hoard found in 1936. Discrepancy in location of findspot. HER reports that 18 coins, including an AE of Constantine the Great, were found in 1936 in Hadfield's Quarry in Pindale near a cottage called the Black Rabbit.

name: PAS: Lancaster 1361
comments: Robertson 2000, 247-248 no. 1019:""In this same yard [i.e. the churchyard], have been picked up in this century about a hundred coins of Constantine and Probus, with others of Licinius, Diocletian, Maximian, Antoninus Pius, Domitian, Vespasian, Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius and Commodus."-E. Baines, Hist. of Co. Palatine and Duchy of Lancaster (1868-70), ed. J. Harland)-Some of these coins must have been ant., others must have been AE."

name: PAS: Madeley 1364
comments: Robertson 2000, 262 no. 1100:""In 1817 two urns, containing a quantity of Roman copper coins, were turned up by the plough on a farm called Little Madeley Parks, about three miles from Chesterton. The urns were destroyed; a horseshoe and a key were found at the same time. The coins identified were": Maximinus Daza, Constantine I, Licinius I, Crispus, and Constantine II.-VCH Staffs., I (1908), 191-After W. Pitt, Topog. Hist. of Staffs. (1817), I, 447, some typesJ. Ward, The Borough of Stoke on Trent (1842), 17 illustrated 9 of the coins: 2 ant. of Postumus and Tetricus I; and 7 AE of Maximinus Daza 1, Constantine I 3, Licinius I 2, and Crispus 1.A.J.H. Gunstone, in N. Staffs. Journ. of Field Studies, 4 (1964), 29, provided RIC and LRBC refs. for the 9 coins illustrated by J. Ward, and added that it was possible that some coins from this hoard were preserved in the Newcastle-under-Lyme "

name: PAS: Elm 1365
comments: Robertson 2000, 262 no. 1098:""There is a camp overlooks Stanton-drue call'd Mizknoll, another at Elm two miles west from Frome. In 1691 a pot of roman coyn found there, most of Constantin junior."-W. Stukeley, Itin. Cur. (1724), 141-The coins were probably small AE."

name: PAS: Todmorden 1434
comments: A hoard of 3000 coins found in what was thought to be a leather bag in Kitson Wood, Todmorden in 1838. The coins are said to have been of Hadrian, Antoninus and Gallienus, so the date of the hoard is uncertain.Source: http://www.pastscape.org.uk/hob.aspx?hob_id=46097

name: PAS: Wookey Hole 1469
comments: Robertson 2000, 352-353 no. 1444:""15 Jan., 1863"Mr. T. Venables exhibited some Roman silver coins forming a portion of a hoard lately discovered near Wookey Hole, Somersetshire. They comprised coins of Constantius II, Julianus, Valens, and Gratianus, including a fine silver medallion of the latter emperor, with the reverse legend GLORIA EXERCITVS."NC, 1863, Proc., 819 Feb. 1863"Mr. Venables exhibited some Roman small brass coins found at Wookey Hole, Somersetshire, with the silver coins and medallions shown at a former meeting. They comprised coins of 'Urbs Roma', struck under Constantine, of Constans, Valentinian, Valens, and Gratianus, and a few barbarous imitations of Roman coins."NC, 1863, Proc., 11W. Boyd Dawkins, in Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., XI (1861-2), (2), 201, gave a different account of what was presumably the same find: "A pot of Romano-British money was also found near the cave, which being of about the same workmanship, form, and size as a large common flower pot, was broken, as is usually the case, and the silver coins of Allectus and Commodus were divided among the workmen."The last account of the range of coins in the hoard does not agree with the two others, and must be regarded as incorrect.In Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, is 1 sil. of Gratian (RIC 27c), from the Spenser George Perceval Bequest, 1920, with the note: "From hoard found in Wookey Hole, Wells. Gave £1 for this coin, Ap: 15, 1862.""

name: PAS: Cymyran 1470
comments: 1 radiate and 9 nummi to 383. TAR 2001, 197.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2002 T123; 01.04

name: PAS: Trebursye 1471
comments: Report of a hoard of 5 (or 9, depending on reports) coins found in a garden in Trebursye along with the bowl of a spoon. The variation in reports is between 5 and 1 coins of Carausius. Metals not specified.Two coins of Valens, two of Gratian and 1 (or 5) of Carausius.

name: PAS: Dryslwyn 1472
comments: 13 nummi to GratianTreasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2006.01

name: PAS: Lincoln (Broadway) 1473
comments: Robertson 2000, 346 no. 1420:""At the rear of no. 91, Broadway, Lincoln, workmen digging a drain trench during May, 1956, found a number of small bronze Roman coins. Most of these have been secured for the museum by gift or purchase, and a small trial excavation was undertaken by members of the Lincoln Archaeological Research Committee under the writer which also produced some coins and other material.The total of coins recovered by all means was 6827 of the coins, more than a third of the total, were copies, and 22 were copied (at various dates after c. 348) from the same original."Then came a list of 66-8 coins, including 26, not 27 copies."The coins were found in a uniform layer of dark occupation material rather over two feet thick containing fourth century pottery and animal bones."D.F. Petch, in Reps., Papers, Lincs. Archit. and Arch. Soc., 7, 1 (1956-7), 10f., types"Eight further coins belonging to the hoard of fourth century bronze coins found in the garden of 91 Broadway, Lincoln in 1956 have been presented to the museum by Mr. L. Aldred (28-59). The coins are of Victorinus, Claudius II, Valentinian I,Valens,Gratian,and Theodora. The original find included a large proportion of copies, and the gift includes two of these, one of the Constantinopolis series (c. AD 330-5), the other a small cut down copy, presumably of a fourth century prototype.A small bronze coin of Constantine II found in the garden of 93 Broadway in 1960 has also been presented to the Museum (1-60) and as this is undoubtedly from the hoard the total now stands at 67 [sic] coins."D.F. Petch, in Reps., Papers, Lincs. Archit. and Arch. Soc., 9, 1 (1961), 19f., some typesThe no. of coins in Lincoln City and County Museum, from the Broadway find, 78 in total, included 1 AE coin, 1 den., 5 ant. and 71 small AE:AE Den. Ant. AE (small)Faustina I (deified) 1Severus 1Gallienus 1Victorinus 1Tetricus I 1Claudius II (deified) 1Carausius 1Constantine I 5Crispus 1Constantine II, Caes. 1Constantius II, Caes. 1Constantinopolis 2Urbs Roma 2Theodora (after AD 337) 1GLORIA EXERCITVS 1Constantius II, Aug. 8Constans, Aug. 5Constantius II, or Constans, Aug. 25Valentinian I 4Valens 9Gratian 5uncertain 4th cent. 11 1 5 71(b.)(1 b.)(1 stand., b.)(b. VICTORIAE DD AVGGQ NN 1; FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman 24) (b.)(b.)The fourth century copy, cut down, had on the obv.VS P F AVG, and on the rev. a Chi-Rho monogram.Examined, 1978 (ASR)If the 78 coins included a hoard, it is uncertain which of the coins belonged to it."

name: PAS: West Hill 1474
comments: Robertson 2000, 350 no. 1432"""Occupation debris comes from ploughing above the 300 ft. contour on the crest of the narrow ridge overlooking the Corfe gap. Romano-British sherds, some of the 3rd or 4th century, flint flakes, part of an unfinished hand-cut shale armlet, and 26 bronze coins (all of the 4th century down to Gratian (367-83) save two of the 2nd and 3rd centuries, have been found since 1952 on the crest of the hill."RCHM SE Dorset, II.3 (1970), 599"

name: PAS: Bourton 1475
comments: Robertson 2000, 350 no. 1433:""He himself [i.e. Mr. George Witts] opened a villa at Bourton for the Cotswold Field Club. While wielding a pickaxe he came on a nest of Roman coins, and covered them up as quickly as possible, and shovelled earth on the top of them. The next day the Field Club came. He first discoursed on the wonders of the Roman villa and then said in a casual way 'Let's see if we can find anything.' He took up a pickaxe and immediately found the coins."G.B. Witts, in Trans. Bristol and Glos. Arch. Soc., XX (1895-7), 349The hoard consisted of "upwards of one hundred coins principally of Valens, Valentinian, Constantine, Gratian etc., but some belonging to Licinius, Probus, Crispus, Tetricus, and Salonina."G.B. Witts, Arch. Handbook of the Co. of Glos. (1905), 56The coins of Salonina, Tetricus and Probus must have been ant., the others were probably small AE."

name: PAS: Hambledon 1478
comments: HER record of a small hoard of 33 nummi ending with Gratian, found by the side of the road in Hambledon before 1942. Probably Valentinianic?

name: PAS: Welford 1479
comments: Robertson 2000, 349 no. 1429:""In the month of February, 1825, as some labourers were employed in repairing a bank in this lane [i.e. Hangmanstone Lane], near the ruins of Poughley, they found about 18 inches below the surface of the ground, between the middle of the road and the bank, a grey earthen vessel, containing nearly 800 coins of Constantine, Julian, Valens, Valentinian, Gratian and others, the whole of which were in good preservation."E.W. Gray, Hist. and Ant. of Newbury (1839), 268S. Palmer referred to this find in Trans. Newbury and Dist. Field Club, II (1872-5), 62, adding "and one [i.e. coin] of Maximianus was recently sent to me", but whether the coin of Maximian was actually part of the hoard is not certain.H.J.E. Peake, Arch. of Berks. (1930), 121, suggested that this hoard was the same as the hoard listed as Chaddleworth, 1850 (Berks.) [no. 1428]. The Chaddleworth hoard, however, contained about 100 silver coins, while the Welford hoard contained almost 800 coins, of unspecified metal. Moreover, the Chaddleworth pot was broken, with only a fragment surviving, while the Welford pot is still intact.The Welford pot is in Newbury District Museum. It is a long-necked flagon, 12? in. high and 6 3/8 in. wide, of a clear red colour, but showing grey patches where it has been worn. It has a thick bright red slip, and is highly polished and decorated with girth grooves, cordons, and mouldings.Examined, and drawn, 1948 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Kirmington 1480
comments: Robertson 2000, 343 no. 1406:""In 1955 this Society [i.e. the Society of Antiquaries of Newcastle on Tyne] purchased a small collection of coins, and in this collection there were several packets which had been confined specially to a small bag. All these packets were marked 'Roman copper coins found at Kirmington Field about 1780'. The total number is 11 coins, 7 of which are Constantinian issues and the remainder are composed of 1 of Valentinian I and 3 of Valens.The evidence for stating that they constitute part of a hoard is to be taken from a note inscribed on one of the packets, as follows:'These Roman coins were found among othersin Kirmington field on the right side of the road leading to Brigg near to Yarborough Camp about the year 1780.'Kirmington is about 12 miles W.N.W. of Grimsby, Lincolnshire, and Mr. F.T. Baker of the Lincoln Museum and Art Gallery advises me that 'the coin hoard was evidently found in the open field of Kirmington before enclosure. There is a road from Kirmington to Brigg, a distance of about 9 miles. The hoard is thus in the north-east of the county near to Grimsby. This is the first recorded coin find from the area of Kirmington."Then came a list of the 11 coins in Newcastle.D. Smith, in AA (4), XXXVIII (1960), 236f., types, mintsThe Lincoln City and County Museum also acquired 21 coins from Kirmington. They were said to have been "found c. 1948 or 1780. Schoolboy gave 21 coins to Mr. Kirkby (donor) - he had received them from an uncle.""Could it be that the 1780 hoard and the 21 in LM are two separate finds from the same hoard?"Notes in Lincoln City and County MuseumThe two lists, of 11 and 21 coins, are:Newcastle LincolnAE Den. Ant. AESeveran period (?) 1Tetricus I 1Tetricus II 1Constantine I 1Constantine II, Caes. 1 1Constantius II, Caes. 2Constantinopolis 2 1House of Constantine I 1Constantius II, Aug. 1Constantius II, Aug. (?) 2Constans, Aug. 2 2Valentinian I 1 3Valens 3 3Gratian 311 1 2 18(plated)(b.)(GLORIA EXERCITVS)(b. FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman)Examined, 1978 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Chaddleworth 1481
comments: Robertson 2000, 349 no. 1428:"1 March 1850"Mr. C. Long exhibited also several silver coins, of Constantius, Valens, Valentinian, and Gratian, part of a hoard (about one hundred in number) discovered in the parish of Chaddleworth, Berks., deposited in an earthen vase, of which a fragment only was preserved. The spot is on a bye-road about two miles north of the 'Upper Baydon Road', which appears to be a continuation of the Ermine Street, leading from Corinium to Speen (Spinae)."AJ, VII (1850), 87. See also Welford, 1825 (Berks.)" [Robertson no.1429]

name: PAS: Cheshunt 1482
comments: Robertson 2000, 351 no. 1436: " "A hoard of about 280 'third brass' coins, Gallienus-Constantine, placed in a blue-grey urn 8 in. high, was found somewhere in the neighbourhood of Cheshunt (the precise site being unknown) about 1904. The urn and twenty-four of the coins are now in the Hertford Museum, and are of the following emperors." Then came a list of 24 coins ranging from Gallienus to Constantine II.VCH Herts., IV (1914), 152Herts. County Museum, St. Albans had only 20 coins from this hoard, along with the pot, a narrow-necked handle-less jar of fine grey ware, 6? in high and 6? in wide, burnished in such a way that a series of horizontal rings appear round the body. A label inside the pot read:- "Urn with narrow neck which contained when found 280 Roman third brass coins, ranging from Gallienus to Valentinian II. From Cheshunt, Herts. Acquired by exchange."The list of 20 coins, 14 ant. and 6 small AE, and the list of 24 coins given in VCH Herts., IV (1914), 152, are:Ant. AE Ant. AEGallienus (sole reign) 5 5Salonina (sole reign) 1 1Claudius II 9 6Aurelian 1 1Probus 1 1Constantine I 1 1Crispus 2 1Constantine II, Caes. 1 1Constans, Aug. 1Valentinian I 1Gratian 1uncertain 317 7 14 624 20Examined 20 coins, and pot drawn, 1947 (ASR)The museum label was probably incorrect in including Valentinian II among the emperors represented."

name: PAS: Collingham 1630
comments: A fused group of 11 nummi to c.360. Detail is visible on two coins as follows:]TIVS NOB[. Constantius II as Caesar, 324-37.]CAES. Could be c. 320s to 337, or possibly c. 355-61/ The coins may therefore date c. AD 320-60. NC 2010.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2009 T688Other PAS records associated with this hoard: LIN-1497F2

name: PAS: Canterbury, Marlowe Car Park Area M II 1638
comments: Marlowe Car Park Area M II, scattered hoard of 119 coins, found in flood silts sealing Structure R22. Contains coins of Constantine & Valentinian (intrusive), but also of Carausius, Gallienus & barbarous radiates, latter make up approx.. half of group.

name: PAS: South Cadbury 1693
comments: Robertson 2000, 262 no. 1099:"In 1906, the Rev. Preb. W. Farrer presented to the Somerset County Museum, Taunton, a group of 13 coins "found by a workman on Cadbury Camp, S. Somerset." They included 3 ant. and 10 Constantinian small AE.Ant. AEVictorinus 1Claudius II (deified) 1Tetricus II 1Constantine I 4Crispus 2Constantine II, Caes. 43 10The 10 Constantinian coins all retained some silvering and had a uniform appearance. They may have come from a hoard.Cp. (Sir) George Hill, in NC, 1906, 338, Little Langford?Examined, 1958 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Pembroke (Military Road) 1694
comments: Robertson 2000, 311-312 no. 1282:"The NMW, Cardiff, has three coins found in the garden of 96 Military Road, Pembroke:Ant. AEClaudius II (deified) 1Constantius II, Aug. 1Constans (?), Aug. 11 2Examined, 1947 (ASR)."

name: PAS: Grassington 1758
comments: Robertson 2000, 296 no. 1240A:"18 bronze coins were:"Found by workmen in 1877 when foundations were laid for an extension to the post office. There is no record of them having been found in a pot or container, but their proximity to one another and their closeness in date suggests that they were deposited together, possibly in a leather purse.M.J. Sekulla (unpublished), personal communication from the Craven Museum, Skipton."Some years ago, Mr Inman of Kettlewell dug up a group of Roman coins, mainly of Constantine Maximus with some of Tetricus, Flavii Fausta etc..A. Raistrick, Roman remains in west Yorkshire, in YAJ 31 (1934), 216.The coins are as follows:Constantine I 9 LRBC Trier as 38, Const as 1005, Antio. As 1356, Alex. As 1428 (3), as 1431Licinius II 1 PROVIDENTIAECAESSCrispus 1 LRBC 1 Trier 15/16Constantine II 3 LRBC I Thess. As 856, Alex. As 1429 (2)Constantius II 3 LRBC I, Nicom. As 1119, Antio. As 1358, Alex. As 1430Fausta 1 LRBC I Antio. As 1330"

name: PAS: Llanegwad 1767
comments: Robertson 2000, 252 no. 1052:""At a place called Llwyn y Ffortun, or the Grove of Fortune, a pot of Roman coins was found, containing coins of Domitian, Probus, Aurelian, Constantine, Constantius, and Carausius."-Rev. Preb. Scarth, in JBAA, XXIV (1868), 116-Copied by Arch. Camb., 28 (1873), 130The coins of Domitian, if correctly identified, may have come from some other source than the hoard. The coins of Aurelian and Probus must have been ant., those of Carausian probably so, and the coins of Constantius (I?) and of Constantine (I?) were probably small AE."

name: PAS: Hastings 1768
comments: A hoard of 30 coins in a ceramic vessel, "principally of the reigns of Constantine and Hadrian" dug up in allotments in an enclosure formerly known as "St George's churchyard" in Hastings in or before 1840.

name: PAS: Wakefield 1853
comments: Robertson 2000, 267 no. 1117:""Gentlemen, By this Night's Mail you will receive a Parcel, containing 40 Roman Copper Coins, which were found in an Earthen vessel on Thursday the 30th of April last by a person who was planting Quickwoods. By taking up a sod accidentally to put against the young plants, upon the Estate of the Marquis of Hertford on the Wakefield Outwood, in the Township of Stanley and Parish of Wakefield, and about 3 miles from the latter place. It is also nearly a mile from Lingwell Gate, where formerly was a Roman Station. The field in which they were found is about 150 yards to the left of the road, leading from Wakefield to York, and nearly at the top of a hill, below which, at a little distance, runs the river Calder. I was this morning on the place, and informed by a person who works there, that about 7 years ago, they ploughed up some ancient coins, near the spot where the present were discovered; but they, thinking them of no value, made no further search.A considerable quantity, however, was dug up on Thursday, last, and sold to different people in this neighbourhood; and I am sorry to say, two pounds weight was melted down by one of the purchasers of them.I have also inclosed you a piece of the Vessel or Earthen Jar which contained the Coins. It must have been broken some time."-Letter from T. Pitt to the Society of Antiquaries, 14 May 1812-In Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., XXXIII (1811-17), 137f.The 40 coins exhibited to the Society of Antiquaries were of Licinius I, Constantine I, Crispus, Constantine II and Constantius II.Arch., XVII (1814), 333T. Pitt, in Arch., XIX (1821), 412, said that "there were upwards of forty pounds weight of the coins found at that time [i.e. c. 5000-6000 coins] .""

name: PAS: Bath (Bathwick Street Bridge) 1854
comments: Robertson 2000, 251 no. 1042:"A few days since, as the workmen were excavating the ground for the foundations of the New Bridge, at the bottom of Bathwick Street they discovered, about 10 feet below the surface, a metal pot containing about half a peck of Roman copper coins, many of them in excellent preservation: some of them bear the superscription of Constantine, and others are of a more ancient date. The pot that contained them was very much corroded. Mr. Goodridge, Lord Darlington's steward, being present when the discovery was made, took possession of the coins."-Gent. Mag., 1826, II, 160"

name: PAS: Kineton 1855
comments: Robertson 2000, 313 no. 1299:"28 May 1857"Evelyn Philip Shirley, Esq., Local Secretary for Warwickshire, communicated a short account, which had been furnished to him by Mr. Jesse Kingerlee, of the discovery of Roman Coins in the parish of Kineton, on the left of the road going to Banbury, in a small ploughed field, called Bankey Meadow, forming part of the estate belonging to Lord Willoughby de Broke. Of six specimens of these Coins exhibited four were of copper of the age of Constantine, and one of the Emperor Claudius the first. The sixth, in silver, was a Coin of Julian the Apostate, found on Castle Hill, about a quarter of a mile out of Kineton, on the side towards Warwick."PSA, (1), IV (1856-9), 92If this find was a hoard, it is likely that only the Constantinian coins belonged to it.Constantinian, or later"

name: PAS: Aston Ingham 1856
comments: Robertson 2000, 264 no. 1108:""In 1855, a deposit of many thousands, of the same period [i.e. as the coins discovered at Goodrich, no. 1664] were found during draining operations in the Combe Wood at Aston Ingham, in the south-east corner of the county, on the Gloucestershire border. They appeared to have been deposited in two chests, and ready for transport. Thirty-seven of them (now in the Gloucester Museum) were exhibited at the Gloucester meeting of the Institute by J. Irving, Esq. They were all small brass, and were of the reigns of Maximianus, Maximinus Daza, Licinius, Constantine the Great, his wife Fausta, Crispus, Constantine II, and Constantius II."-W.T. Watkins, in AJ, XXXIV (1877), 365-Trans. Bristol and Glos. Arch. Soc., XXX (1907), 168, gave the no. of coins found as 2000.37 coins from this hoard in Gloucester City Museum, incorporated in the general coin collection."

name: PAS: Dunstable 1857
comments: Robertson 2000, 249 no. 1027; ""In 1770, great quantity of copper coins of Antoninus and Constantine with many small ornaments of bridles and armour were found in a down near Dunstable digging for gravel."-J. Nichols, Bibl. Top. Brit., IV (1790), 202-"It was about the year 1770, that a labourer of the town of Dunstable, digging for gravel near the Shepherd's Bush, discovered an earthern urn or pot, formed of red clay, and nearly full of small copper coins of several Roman emperors."The pot was broken.-H. Brandreth, in Arch., XXVII (1838), 104-These two accounts seem to refer to the same find."

name: PAS: Nailsea 1858
comments: Robertson 2000, 253 no. 1062:""Three urns of Roman coins, some of Constantine, and others of different ages were dug up in Nailsea and Ken-moor not far from the camp [i.e. Cadbury Camp], at a place called Nailsea-wall, which divides Ken-moor and Nailsea-moor. These coins are many of them now in the possession of Mrs. Hinkes, of Nailsea; and a far greater quantity, to the amount of several hundred, were given to the late Sir J. Smith, of Ashton-Court, by Mr. Chatterton.."-W. Barrett, Hist. and Ant. of City of Bristol (1789), 19f.-Text also in S. Seyer, Memoirs Historical and Topographical of Bristol (1821), I, 163The coins were probably AE.Including Constantine (I?)"

name: PAS: Hooton 1859
comments: Robertson 2000, 313 no. 1295:"In 1953, Dr. G. Webster, when Curator of the Grosvenor Museum, Chester, drew attention to the following reference:"In the course of the excavation [i.e. for the Manchester Ship Canal] in this township [i.e. Hooton] now in progress, an urn containing a large number of Roman copper coins in fine preservation was unearthed. The urn was unfortunately demolished by the blow of a pickaxe but of the coins which were recovered from the navvies, the bulk appear to belong to the reign and period of Constantine the Great."P. Sulley, Hundred of Wirral, XX, appendix 2, c. 1889Dr. Webster added: "I am a little doubtful about the Hooton hoard as I can trace no other reference to it and there are still people living in the area who remember the canal being cut and who have no recollection of this discovery."Constantinian, or later"

name: PAS: Over 1860
comments: Robertson 2000,249-250 no. 1030: ""A great number of the copper coins of the lower empire, contained in the remains of a metal box were obtained by Mr. J. Symons. I was informed by Mr. E. Litchfield that so far as could be made out they were mostly coins of Constantine."-C.C. Babington, Ancient Cambs. (1883), 82"

name: PAS: Llandeilo Castle 1861
comments: Robertson 2000, 313 no. 1301:""Some years ago a deposit of Roman coins was found within the castle, in a spot close to the wall, not far from the iron gate which leads to the cave staircase. I believe they were all brass but could not receive a distinct account of the transaction. Two specimens were given to me by Mr. Francis Green of Court Henry. They are both brass coins of the Constantine family of emperors."J. Williams, in Arch. Camb., 12 (1857), 346Constantinian, or later"

name: PAS: Carlby 1862
comments: Robertson 2000, 253 no. 1060:""Feb. 1837. At Carlby were found 100 copper coins of Constantine the Great, in fine preservation; half of them were in a small urn 4 ins. in height, and the rest were loose. They were discovered in an enclosure called Holmes Paddock, which is intersected by an elevated ridge.The ridge having lately been pared away, the treasure was thus brought to light."-Justin Simpson, Obituary and Records for the Counties of Lincoln, Rutland and Northampton (1861), 330Including Constantine I"

name: PAS: Guilthwaite Common 1863
comments: Robertson 2000, 416 no. 1701:""The frequent discovery of Roman money on the surface of this common [i.e. Guilthwaite Common], and the recent disinterment of an earthen jar containing sixteen hundred pieces of the small brass of the Roman empire, seems to show that if not constructed it [i.e the entrenchment] was at least used by the Romans."J. Hunter, South Yorks: Hist. of Doncaster, I (1828), Int., ivf.dated.Undated. Probably 3rd or 4th century AD"

name: PAS: Streatley 1864
comments: Rpbertson 2000, 313 no. 1294:""A small hoard of Constantinian coins was turned up in the garden of Cleeve Court, north of Streatley, in a natural bank or ridge, 90 yards west of the R. Thames, not far from the line of the road from Dorchester (Oxon.) to Silchester."JRS, XXIII (1933), 207It is possible that this hoard and the Streatley, 1931 (Berks.) hoard [no. 1626] are one and the same, in which case JRS has given an incomplete account of the coins contained in it.If it was a different hoard, the coins were probably small AE.Constantinian, or later"

name: PAS: York (Mount School) 1865
comments: Robertson 2000, 256 no. 1079A:""Several skeletons were found in 1818 in a gravel pit in the neighbourhood of Holgate railway bridge, at a depth of four to six feet below the surface... twenty-nine coins, chiefly of Constantine and Crispus, were also found..RCHM York I (1962), 100f., quoting W. Hargrove, The new guide for strangers and residents of the City of York (1838)"

name: PAS: Southwark (Union Road) 1866
comments: Robertson 2000, 250 no. 1039:""Mr. [R.E.] Way also submittedsome Roman coins of Carausius, Constantius, and Constantine, found lately in excavating for a sewer in Union Road, Southwark."-JBAA, n.s., III (1897), 305-The coins of Carausius were probably ant., those of Constantius (I?) and Constantine (I?) probably small AE."

name: PAS: Llanfihangel Din Sylwy 1867
comments: Robertson 2000, 429 no. 1884:""Numerous fibulae, coins and other Roman relics have been discovered. In the summer of 1831 a great number of silver and copper coins were found, among which were some of Nero, Vespasian, Constantius and Constantine together with several rings, keys, buckles and clasps of copper and other relics of Roman antiquity."-S. Lewis, Topog. Dict. of Wales (1833), s.v. Llanvihangel Din SilwyUndatable"

name: PAS: Thornton 1868
comments: Robertson 2000, 313 no. 1300:"27 March 1789"About two years ago, many Roman coins were ploughed up at a place called Thornton, near Darlington. I believe they amounted to some hundreds, were deposited in an urn, and mostly of Constantine and his sons in very fine preservation." J. Cade, in Arch., IX (1789), 288The coins were probably small AE.Constantinian, or later"

name: PAS: West Wickham 1869
comments: Robertson 2000, 250 no. 1031: ""In the parish of West Wickham, several Roman coins were found in 1862, chiefly of the lower empire, those of Constantine, Tacitus and Claudius were deciphered."-C.C. Babington, Ancient Cambs. (1883), 34-The coins of Tacitus must have been ant., those of Claudius (II?) probably so, and those of Constantine (I?) were probably small AE."

name: PAS: Winchester 1870
comments: Robertson 2000, 253 no. 1059:"3 March 1785Mr. Willis of Andover:"Upon digging the Foundations of the Palace there, intended by K. Charles the IId. the Workmen discovered a Pavement of Brick, and several Coins of Constantine the Great."-Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., XX (1784-5), 171-It is not absolutely certain that all the coins were of Constantine I. They were probably AE.Including Constantine I"

name: PAS: Llangynin 1871
comments: Robertson 2000, 254 no. 1067:""Coyns - Brass Pieces of Constantine ye Greats Coyn were found in ye next parish of Llangynning."-E. Lluyd, Parochialia (1699), no. 10-Printed in Arch. Camb., 66 (1911), Suppl. III, 59RCHM Carmarthenshire I (1917), 168, no. 496, followed by BBCS, I, (1921-3), 347, and IV (1929), 254, wrongly assumed the number of coins found to have been 10.Including Constantine I"

name: PAS: Isleham 1872
comments: Robertson 2000, 249 no. 1028: ""ISLEHAM, New Mill: Small hoard of early 4thC coins from bed of extinct stream, 1942 (Inf. G[ordon] F[owler], recorded [Lady] G[race] B[riscoe])."-C.W. Phillips ed., The Fenland in Roman Times (1970), 237Undated. Early 4th century AD, Constantine (I?), or later"

name: PAS: Southam 1873
comments: Robertson 2000, 312 no. 1289:""Part of a hoard (?) '15 coins of Trier Mint', presumably House of Constantine, found in a garden at Southam (In the Harvey Bloom collection (B. 26, fo. 147)"W.A. Seaby, Notes, Aug. 1977; cp. Warwicks. Sites and Monuments Records (H.J. Usher, Southam)Constantinian?"

name: PAS: Cheddar 1874
comments: Robertson 2000. 313 no. 1298:""The workmen employed by Messrs. Tanner brothers, in excavating the bed of a river, at their paper mills, Cheddar, Somerset, have lately discovered a considerable number of ancient coins, chiefly Roman, some of the Constantine family."NC, 1840, Miscellanea, 206Mrs. D.P. Dobson, Arch. of Somerset (1931), 236, recorded this find as a "hoard of 26 Roman coins from Constantius to Constans", giving as authority the passage from NC, 1840, p. 206. There is no mention there, however, of the number 26, or of Constantine or Constans. The hoard Mrs. Dobson meant may have been the Chelm's Combe, Cheddar, before 1929, hoard [no. 1210].The coins were probably small AE.Constantinian, or later"

name: PAS: Compton 1875
comments: Robertson 2000, 253 no. 1057:""A great number of Roman coins had been dug up, and as many as 500 were found in an earthenware jar. They were copper coins of Constantine and other Roman sovereigns."-L. Lowsley, in Trans. Newbury and Dist. Field Club, I (1870-1), 128-Dr. C.H.V. Sutherland, in NC, 1936, 318, suggested that this hoard and the Compton, 1852 (Berks.) hoard [no. 519] were one and the same. The latter hoard, however, was said to have consisted of silvered coins, i.e. billon antoniniani, of about the time of Victorinus, i.e. c, AD 270, while this hoard was made up of copper coins, including some of Constantine.Including Constantine (I?)"

name: PAS: Arundel 1876
comments: Robertson 2000, 312 no. 1288:"7 March 1744"Mr. Virtue shew several coins of the Age of Constantine, lately found in a small Pot near Arundel in Sussex, in the Estate of Sir John Shelley, Bart."Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., IV (1740-4), 221The coins were probably small AE.Constantinian"

name: PAS: Ilchester 1877
comments: Robertson 2000, 266-267 no. 1116:""During the time of the Romans it [i.e., Ivelchester] seems to have flourished, for very many of their coins and meydalls have bin and almost daylie yet are digged up, of which I have receaved some from my good friend Mr. Dawe, who dwells there, and hath seene them taken out of foundations betweene the stones whereof the feilds adjoyning are full especially towards the East and South. Theis coins some were of Constantine ye Emperor called ye Greate, and faire meydalls of most pure copper of Constantius his third sonne,as also of his second wife the lovely Faustina [sic], and of others."-T. Gerard, Particular Description of the County of Somerset (1633)-Printed in Somerset Record Soc., XV (1900), 203; ref. supplied, 1947, by J.S. Cox, Ilchester"

name: PAS: Broughton 1878
comments: Robertson 2000, 313 no. 1296:""A Broughton (Hampshire) resident has found a number of old coins and tokens dating back to the reign of Constantine."JBAA, n.s., XXII (1916), 238, Congress at SouthamptonThe coins were probably small AE."Reign of Constantine" I, or later"

name: PAS: Chatteris 1879
comments: Robertson 2000, 277 no. 1165: ""In 1824, an earthen vessel, which contained about 1000 small copper coins chiefly of Constantius, many of Constans and Constantine, and a few with theemblem of Romulus and Remus suckled by the wolf was ploughed up near the (same) ferry, two miles from the town, on the site of the ancient river or West Water."-W. Watson, Hist. Account of theTown and Port of Wisbeach (1827), 578"

name: PAS: Sleaford 1880
comments: Robertson 2000, 313 no. 1297:""At Sleaford they have found many Roman coyns, especially of the Constantine family and their wives, about the castle and the springhead a little above the town."W. Stukeley, Itin. Cur. (1724), 8In the second edition of Itin. Cur. (1776), 9, Stukeley stated "Mrs. Tichmus of Stanford told me she had once had many Roman coins, from a great parcel found at or near Sleford."The coins were probably small AE.Constantinian?, or later"

name: PAS: Newton Kyme 1881
comments: Robertson 2000, 264 no. 1109:""There are others who place the Roman Calcaria at Newton Kyme, in the water fields, near St. Helen's Ford; for many Roman coins have been plowed up there, particularly of Constantius Helena and Constantine, also an urn or box of alabaster, with only ashes in it; melted lead and rings one of which had a key of the same piece joined to it."-Gibson's Camden (1695), II, 94-The coins were probably AE."

name: PAS: Chard 1882
comments: Robertson 2000, 312 no. 1287:""In 1836 as many as three hundred Roman copper coins of the reign of Constantine were found in a field of Chard Farm called Court Pits, abutting on the Axminster road, and about a quarter of a mile from Chard Church. They were in a heap, about twenty inches below the surface of the soil."G.P.R. Pulman, Book of the Axe (1875), 460In Somerset County Museum, Taunton, "Twenty-two 'third brass' coins of the Constantine period, in a poor state of preservation. Found in digging chalk in a field called 'Court Pits', Chard, February, 1836.The field is numbered 1174 in the parish map, and adjoins the Axminster Road, about half a mile from Chard Church. They were found about 20 ins. below the surface in a heap; many of them had decayed so much that they 'crumbled to dust'."H. St. G. Gray, in Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., LXIII (1917), 119"Reign of Constantine I/Constantine period""

name: PAS: Gogarth Abbey 1883
comments: Robertson 2000, 312 no. 1292:""South Gogarth Abbey. Several small brass and one third brass of Constantine period."BBCS, I (1921-3), 348Constantinian"

name: PAS: Brighstone 1907
comments: HER records a verbal report made in 2013 of a hoard found by the informant's late father in Brighstone. The hoard was of 60 coins, some of which "might have been Constantine" and was dispersed among the workers who found it;

name: PAS: Stalbridge 1908
comments: HER record of a hoard found whilst digging for gravel in Gomershay, Stalbridge, around 1869. Over 1000 coins "from the age of Constantine" were contained in an urn "inside four great slabs of stone". A quernstone was found in the same place.

name: PAS: Benham Valence 1909
