comments: Report of a hoard of Roman coins found in a jar by soldiers digging a practice trench in Benham Valence park. The hoard was said to have contained "thousands" of coins, and was dispersed locally. Said to be "antoniniani of Constantinus and Constantius" [sic].

name: PAS: Alresford 1910
comments: An HER record of a hoard of 100 Constantinian nummi reported to Essex Museums in 2000. They are said to have been wrapped in lead but this container was not recovered after being discarded by the finder.

name: PAS: Streatley 1951
comments: Robertson 2000, 407 no. 1626:""Streatley Farm, c. 83 AE.c. 27 Constantinianc. 32 Valentinian (House of?)c. 20 Theodosianc. 4 radiateB.M. 4.3.31."From H. Mattingly's Ms. Notebook, IV, 9"Theodosian""

name: PAS: Cheltenham 1974
comments: Robertson 2000, 356 no. 1461:""Mr. Gomonde forwarded some notes on ancient coins, recently discovered in Gloucestershiresmall brass coins of Julian, Theodosius, Gratian, and Valens, found near Cheltenham, in the Wickham Field, called Wacrescomb in ancient writings."JBAA, I (1846), 157"

name: PAS: South Ferriby 1975
comments: Robertson 2000, 367 no. 1507:"There is in Scunthorpe Borough Museum, a rusticated jar, with the lower part missing, which was said to have been found at the foot of the cliffs at South Ferriby, with 9 small brass coins inside it. The surviving part of the jar is of hard grey clay with a darker slip, with outcurving rim, 6 5/8 in. in diam., girth groove on shoulder and parallel vertical rows of rustication, as on jars from the Rossington kilns, near DoncasterInf., 1958, from J. Lidster, Doncaster MuseumThe 9 coins were 2 ant. and 7 small AE:Ant. AETetricus II (?) 1Constantinopolis (?) 1FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman (?) 1Valentinian I or later 1Gratian 1Arcadius (?) 1"Theodosian" (?) 1uncertain 1 12 7Examined, and pot drawn, 1958 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Cosgrove 1976
comments: Robertson 2000, 360 no. 1479:""Some workmen, digging in the front of Major Mansel's house at Cosgrove, near Stony Stratford, in Northamptonshire, found, one foot and a half underground, an urn, containing 60 silver denarii, very old, but in good preservation. A few weeks before, they dug up a human skeleton near the same place."Gent. Mag., 1801, I, 76"During the excavations for the Grand Junction canal, numerous Roman coins were found in fine preservation on the lower part of Major Mansel's lawn; amongst others were silver medallions of Magnus Maximus, Constantine 1st, and Valentinian IId, denarii of Valens, Julian, and Gratian, and 3rd brass of Tacitus, Diocletian, Constans, and Magnentius with various reverses. From its vicinity to the Watling St. it was not improbably the site of a Roman villa."G. Baker, Hist. and Ant. of Northants., II (1841), 136The "medallions" were probably miliarenses, and the "denarii", siliquae.The coins of Tacitus must have been ant. It is possible that the "third brass" did not come from the hoard."

name: PAS: Alcester 1994
comments: Robertson 2000, 406-407 no. 1622:""When I was rector there, about 1638, my next neighbour, whose house joyned to the Churchyard being about to sink a cellar, I lent him one of my men to assist him therein, and after they had digged about three or four feet deep, they encountered with two urns not far asunder. In the one there was nothing but some ashes: the other was full of medals, set edglong as full as it could be thrust. My man judging it only to be of that Copper money which they find so oft about the town, set it carefully upon the ground by him: and the Town, consisting of Knitters, some of them coming to see the Work, picked out some pieces of this money: at last one brought in a piece to me, which upon tryal I found to be silver and thereupon sent for the pot into my House.In the midst whereof I found 16 pieces of gold, as bright as if they had been lately put in, and about 800 pieces of Silver, and yet no two of them alike, and the latest of them above 1400 years old. They contained the whole History of the Roman Empire from Julius Caesar till after Constantine the Great's time. Each of the Silver pieces weighed about sevenpence, and each of the gold, about fifteen or sixteen shillings."S. Clarke, Geological Description of all the Countries in the Known World (1671), 167"After Constantine the Great's time" Probably the coins were solidi and siliquae.'THEODOSIAN'"

name: PAS: Canterbury (7 St George's Street) 1996
comments: A reference to the discovery of a small Theodosian hoard in a pot that does not seem to be the same as the hoard from 6 St George's Street (1060). Discovery date uncertain but probably the 1940s - 1950s.

name: PAS: Croydon (Park St.) 1997
comments: Robertson 2000, 413 no. 1678:""An old inhabitant (Dr. Westall), writing on the 16th of January, 1874, observes: 'Still later [i.e. after the finds of nos. 1816-17], say fifteen or sixteen years since, several bags of small bright silver coins were dug out of a gravel pit in Park Street; these latter were all of two or three late emperors."J. Corbet Anderson, Croydon: prehistoric and Roman (1874), 71It is very doubtful whether "bags" is to be taken literally. It may be simply an indication of quantity.Late Empire"

name: PAS: Canterbury (St Martin's Cemetery) 2041
comments: Six gold coins, all looped, found at St Martin's cemetery, Canterbury in c. 1844 and now in National Museums Liverpool. The other coins are: a Kentish medalet of Bishop Liudhard; a west German termissis imitating a 4th century Roman bronze coin; a Frankish solidus and 2 Merovingian tremisses. See a full discussion see Abdy and Williams 2006, 5 on pp. 15-16, who interpret this group as a grave deposit, buried about AD 600-30. M Warhurst, Sylloge of Coins of the British Isles 29. Merseyside County Museums, London, 1982, no. 5 (Mayer gift 1867, ex Rolfe collection); C Roach Smith, Collectanea Antiqua I, London, 1848, pl. xxii, 1; P Grierson, `The Canterbury (St Martin's) Hoard of Frankish and Anglo-Saxon Coin-ornaments', BNJ 37, 1952, pp. 39-51; Hawkes, Merrick and Metcalf, Archaeometry 9, 1966, p. 104; Rigold 1975, 16; C Haith in L Webster and J Backhouse, The Making of England, London, 1991, pp. 23-4. Lafaurie and Morrisson 1987, p. 93; Abdy and Williams 2006, no. 5 on pp. 15-16.

name: PAS: Doncaster 2042
comments: 40 nummi of Justinian I - see comments - DELETE. Yorks Arch J 44, 1972, 219.

name: PAS: Croxton 2046
comments: Robertson 2000, 249 no. 1026:""Two miles west of Thornton is a great roman camp, call'd Yarborough, which surveys the whole hundred denominated from it, and all the sea-coast. Vast quantitys of roman coins have been found here. Mr. Howson of Kenington [i.e. Kirmington] hard by, has pecks of them, many of Licinius."-W. Stukeley, Itin. Cur. (1724), 95-C. Knowles, in Lincs. Hist. and Arch., 3 (1968), 23, observed that the evidence for the discovery of a hoard seemed "far from conclusive."Including Licinius (I?)"

name: PAS: Bembridge 2170
comments: HER record of a group of 9 coins found in Bembridge in 2006:"3 Ases of Marcus Aurelius1 As of Vespasian1 As of Lucilla1 As of Lucilla or Faustina2 illegible ases1 nummus of either deified Constantius or Maximian[Object entry IOW.2006.63.1]"

name: PAS: Princes Risborough 2236
comments: A scattered hoard of "late fourth century local imitations" found by a metal detector user in the Princes Risborough area. Identified by Daphne Nash at the Ashmolean, identifications are held by the HER (not seen).

name: PAS: Great Tew 2417
comments: Robertson 2000, 236 no. 976:""During the preparation of a site for a new barn at Beaconsfield Farm, further Romano-British remains were brought to light.Traces of a north-south wing [of a large courtyard house] with a corridor facing east on to a yard were discovered.A hoard of 72 coins provide a terminus post quem late in the third century for the destruction of this wing."-D. Benson and P.D.C. Brown, in Oxon., XXXI (1966), 153f.Undated. Late 3rd century AD?"

name: PAS: Chester (White Friars/Bollands Court) 2418
comments: Robertson 2000, 215 no. 874:"(a) "The Bollands Court hoard (Acc. no. 396.C.1930), previously in the collection of the local antiquary Frederick Potts, is said to have been found in a jar at Bollands Court, in Chester. It consists of a fused mass of about 50 pieces. About a dozen were detached and cleaned in August, 1930, and were described as follows: 'eight exhibit radiate heads. One is of the PAX AVG type with hind running to r. Another FIDES MILITVM with Fides holding military standard in 1. hand. Period 260-97 AD'."(b) "Another group of coins which may have constituted in part another hoard was found during excavations on the site of White Friars Cottage, Bollands Court in 1884. The Bullin collection of finds from the site includes ca. 52 coins ranging from an antoninianus of Gordian III to the House of Constantine, and a heavily worn example of Valens or Valentinian I. The majority of pieces appear to be antoniniani of Victorinus, the Tetrici, a few poor examples of Carausius and other unidentifiable radiates. A check list is given in Davies' Catalogue (Journ. Chest. and N. Wales Arch. Soc., n.s., XXIV (1922), 153f., reprint (1923), 43f.), though not all the coins have been isolated. W. Thompson Watkin gives an account of the excavations, though there are some discrepancies in the number (35?) and description of the coins (Roman Cheshire (1886), 147-50)."Inf., 1978, from Dr. Glenys Lloyd-Morgan, Grosvenor Museum, ChesterThe passage relating to the White Friars coin finds in W.T. Watkin, Roman Cheshire (1886), occurred on p. 149:"Besides the architectural fragments which were found in the soil covering the (large) platform (of stones), a great quantity of broken Roman pottery of all descriptions, 'Samian' ware, amphorae, mortaria, etc., occurred, but no perfect specimens; also a number of tiles bearing the stamp of the Twentieth Legion, all more or less broken, and one or two armillae and fibulae of bronze. In the same superincumbent soil thirty-five coins were found, with the exception of a 2nd brass of Carausius, all of the '3rd brass' series. They were in wretched condition, and only the reverse of one could be made out. They appear to be of the following reigns:- Gallienus, 1; Postumus, 1; Victorinus, 2; the Tetrici, 8; Claudius Gothicus, 3 (one with reverse of CONSECRATIO); Carausius, 3; Constantine the Great, 5; Constantinopolis, 1; illegible, 11."31 coins (24 ant. and 7 AE) in Grosvenor Museum, Chester, appear to have come from the White Friars site.The three lists, of 35 coins (Watkin), c.52 coins (Bullin), and 31 coins (Grosvenor Museum) are:Watkin Bullin ASR 0Ant. AE Ant. AE Ant. 0AEGordian III 1 1 0Gallienus 1 1 1 0Postumus 1 1 1 0Victorinus 2 6 7 0Claudius II 3 8 0Tetricus I and II 8 25 12 0Carausius 3 1 0uncertain radiates 11 1 or 1 1 0Constantine I 5 6 04Crispus 1 01Constantine II, Caes. 2 0Constantinopolis 1 0Constans, Aug. 01Valentinian I 01RULE 0RULE35 52 31 0 (1 deified)(2 deified)(?)(b.)It is uncertain whether (b) the group of coins from the White Frairs excavations (1884) was a hoard.Examined 31 coins in Grosvenor Museum, Chester, 1978 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Haddiscoe 2419
comments: HER record of an unrecorded late third-century hoard found by a metal-detectorist along with pottery sherds, a bracelet and a finger ring "with opposed dolphins".

name: PAS: Catterick 2420
comments: Robertson 2000, 415-416 no. 1700:""I was shewn the brass pot found many years ago, full, as is said, of Roman coins."J. Horsley, Britannia Romana II (1732), 4001 April 1802"A Brass pot full of coins was found some years ago, and they pretended here, as at Walbury in Essex, and other Stations, to have been stopped in their Search by a Pair of Iron Gates, over which the Earth fell, while the workmen went to dinner. The Level plot, near the Farm house, may be about 20 acres: among the coins ploughed up in it, was a Gold Nero, Reverse, Jupiter Custos. Great Quantities were given away by Sir John Lawson's predecessors and by himself to Charles 1st's Cabinet. The brass pot was redeemed by the Sequestrators of his Estate in the Civil War for £8 being an unusual metal. It is fixed in a brewing furnace and contains about 24 gallons of water."J. Towneley, in Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., XXIX (1801-3), 181H. Mac Lauchlan, in AJ, VI (1849), 216 , also recorded this find:"As early as the reign of Charles I a large bronze caldron, full of Roman 3rd brass coins, was discovered on this spot; the caldron is preserved at Brough Hall, but the coins have disappeared."The cauldron later came into the possession of Edward Wooler, and was illustrated in JRS, XII (1922), 246, pl. X.Undated. Probably 3rd or 4th century AD"

name: PAS: Whickham 2421
comments: Robertson 2000, 236 no. 973A:""Mr Mc Kenna, a member of the staff of the Public Library and Museum, South Shields, informs me that in 1927 a friend showed him 10 radiate coins said to have been dug up near the Seven Sisters, Whickham. I have not been able to trace these coins..K.A. Steer, The Archaeology of Roman Durham (1938), unpublished PhD Thesis, Durham.Undated. Late 3rd century"

name: PAS: Croydon 2422
comments: This record has been created for the HER record of a hoard of 36 third century Roman coins found in the Waddon New Road, Croydon. The details of this find seem to differ from those associated with Robertson 2000, 235 no. 963: (apparently a fourth century hoard found in 1903) and the tetrarchic hoard of 34 coins found before 1914 associated with Robertson 2000, 251 no. 1047.Seaby's Coins and Medals Bulletin 1961, 234 reports 36 coins found in the Waddon New Road area during the excavation of a cutting between West Croydon and Pitlake in 1814 and in a private collection. Details are unfortunately vague: "All were Antoninianii and the range of dates encompassed only thirty years...Several rulers were represented and all coins with the exception of one originated from the same mint - Rome".

name: PAS: Heather 2423
comments: Uncertain number of radiates referred to in file correspondence only. Mentioned in letter to R. Bland in BM file for Coalville hoard dated 9 Nov 1993. "in an awful condition and is coming in in batches from a detectorist". Presumably never received or studied.

name: PAS: Tisbury II 2755
comments: 19 miliarenses and 1 siliqua to 378. Addenda of 2 light miliarenses 2012. The coins were scattered and fragmented probably due to agricultural activity presumably over many years. The latest coin recovered was a miliarensis of Theodosius I perhaps indicating a deposition date in the 380s. All the pieces showed only slight wear and no evidence of clipping. Three of the miliarenses and the siliqua, all from prototypes of the Trier mint, appeared to be cast copies. BNJ 2012, 42.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2011 T006; 2012 T506Other PAS records associated with this hoard: WILT-C3AC08; WILT-5E83F4; WILT-C3AC08

name: PAS: Amesbury 2757
comments: Ronertson 2000, 356 no. 1463:""Sir Edmund Antrobus, Bart., by the hands of Frederic Ouvry, Esq., Treasurer, exhibited three silver Finger Rings found in the month of February, 1843, on his estate at Amesbury, Wilts., in a spot called Long's Farm, by labourers engaged in trenching for planting. They were discovered in a rude urn, with a number of silver and small brass Roman coins, ranging from Posthumus and Tetricus to Theodosius the Second, son of Arcadius.The greater part of the copper coins are much worn by circulation; but the silver coins do not indicate the same amount of wear; and the reign of Theodosius the Second is the nearest approximate date that we can assign to the rings."PSA, (1), IV (1856-9) 27f., fig. of 1 ringSome, at least of these coins appear to have been ant. The latest must have been of Theodosius I, not II.The 3 silver rings are in Dept. of Prehistoric and Romano-British Antiquities. They were described and illustrated by M. Henig, in A Corpus of Roman Engraved Gemstones from British Sites, BAR 8 (1974), 103, nos. 801-3, and pl. LIII:801. "Intaglio - Griffin walking left and looking over its shoulder. Beaded border. Silver ringSquare bezel. C. 10 x 10 mm."802. "Intaglio - Stag seated left, looking over its shoulder right at a bird. Beaded border. Silver ringSquare bezel. C. 9 x 9 mm."803. "Intaglio - Four very stylised, helmetted heads. Beaded border, Silver ringSquare bezel. C. 10 x 10 mm."In op. cit., I, 51, M Henig stated, mistakenly, that the hoard continued to Valentinian III.Cp. J.P.C. Kent and K.S. Painter, Wealth of the Roman World (1977), 62, nos. 141-3, photos."

name: PAS: Kingweston 2759
comments: "Francis H. Dickinson, Esq., M.P., communicated an account of a discovery of Roman coins recently made on his estate at Kings Weston, Somersetshire, a spot about a mile and a half from Somerton on the London road, adjoining to the sites of two buildings supposed to have been Roman villas, in one of which a tesselated pavement exists. The recent discovery comprised about forty coins of the Lower Empire, as stated by Mr. Hassell of Littleton.The coins forwarded by Mr. Dickinson for the inspection of the Committee comprised a small brass coin, apparently of Constantius II, one of Gratian, struck at Siscia, in Pannonia and one of Theodosius (?)."AJ II (1845), 209f.VCH Somerset, I (1906), 356, gave the date of discovery, wrongly, as 1814.King's Weston should be Kingweston.

name: PAS: Wickwar 2809
comments: HER record of a hoard "said to contain coins up to the fifth century".

name: PAS: Bude-Stratton 2810
comments: A hoard reportedly found by quarry workers around 1890 at a place known as "Earthquake" in Bude-Stratton. Initial accounts detailed the discovery of a cist containing a burial and Roman coins. However subsequent reports suggest that this story covered up the discovery of a hoard of 130 coins. 88 coins from the hoard were later examined by Penhallurick, who supplies a complete list. Unfortunately it is by no means clear which of these coins if any could be said to belong to a hoard, as they range from Vespasian to Arcadius.

name: PAS: Burton Wood 2811
comments: Robertson 2000,  61 no. 299A:""A letter from Ashbourn, in the Peak of Derbyshire, mentions that as some men were digging at a place called Burton-Wood, about four miles from that place, they found an urn, containing about seventy Roman coins and medals, chiefly those of Adrian, Severus, and the younger Constantine: they were found within the boundaries of a specious Roman camp, which the country people pretend has once been a large town."-Gent. Mag., 1784, II, 791W.T. Watkin, in Derbs. A.J., VIII (1886), 204, suggested that this hoard may be the same as that which is listed under Parwich, c. 1769 (Derbs.) [no.299].VCH Derbs., I (1905), 255, pointed out that the site of "Burton Wood" cannot be identified."

name: PAS: Liverpool (Otterspool) 2812
comments: Robertson 2000, 409 no. 1635:""Towards the end of the year 1863, some navvies employed in the construction of the new line of railway from Liverpool to Manchester, via Garston, found, near the inner reach of this old creek, [i.e. at Otterspool] some coinslittle beyond the bare fact of the discovery has at length leaked out, - too late, possibly, to be of use in tracking the coins. These are stated to be very small in size and with large letters for such a limited disc, which would lead to the conclusion of their proving Stycas of the Saxon kingdom of Northumbria or Deira. It is more probable, however, that should any of these pieces, reported to have been divided between the finders, be ever available for examination, they will be found to be of the same class as the preceding small lot [i.e. Liverpool, 1863a], viz., small brass of the later Roman empire, or imitations made to supply a dearth of small change in the troublous times succeeding the retirement from this country of the Roman legions, in the fifth century."H.E. Smith, in Trans. Hist. Soc. Lancs. and Chesh.., n.s., VI (1865-6), 199"Theodosian"?"

name: PAS: Tiddington 2813
comments: Robertson 2000, 411 no. 1652:""Mr. Cove Jones of Loxley has about 100 copper coins said to have been picked up at intervals from 1846-56 on the 'Church Leys', Tiddington. They include one 'first Brass' of Trajan, one 'first' and one 'second brass' of Pius, one Alex. Severus, several small coppers of 250-280 AD and many of 280-380 AD, especially Constantinian. They may possibly belong to a hoard which had been broken and scattered by the plough before it was noticed and which was therefore picked up piecemeal."VCH Warwicks., I (1904), 248If this was a hoard, it was probably of the late 4th century AD"

name: PAS: Nanskeval 2814
comments: Robertson 2000, 430 no. 1887:"Some silver coins were found in an earthen pot at Nanskeval about 1829, and were given to Truro Museum, but are not now to be found there.Rep. Royal Inst. Cornwall, V (1829), 30In a letter, Sept. 1958, H.L. Douch, County Museum, Truro, stated that "Nanskeval is the neighbouring estate to Carnanton and belonged to that manor. At Carnanton in 1821 was discovered a treasure trove hoard of silver coins ranging from the reigns of Elizabeth to Charles II. I know that it is tempting to think the Nanskeval coins Roman because of the Roman tin ingot from Carnanton but I would prefer to think that coins presented to the Museum in 1829 by a Willyams of Carnanton were more likely some of the 1821 English hoard."Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Poltimore 2815
comments: Robertson 2000, 417 no. 1731:""Greek and Roman coins in considerable number...A hoard in 1838."R.N. Worth, Roman Devon (1891), 60Undated"

name: PAS: Caergwrle 2816
comments: Robertson 2000, 429 no. 1885:"At Caergwrle"In levelling this dyke [i.e. Offa's Dyke] in 1828, twenty-two Roman coins of copper were discovered, among which were some of the Emperors Nero, Vespasian, Trajan, Julius, Agricola, and Maximilian [sic]: here were also found silver coin of Agrippa, several fibulae highly ornamented, rings of gold, silver and copper, pins of ivory and silver, beads of glass and amber, part of a lamp with the words NINVS impressed on it, a votive altar with a mutilated inscription, and several urns containing calcined bones and ashes."-S. Lewis, Topog. Dict. of Wales (1833), s.v. HopeTo judge from the varied collections of finds, and the wide range of the coins, this find was probably not a hoard.Undatable."

name: PAS: Skipton 2817
comments: Robertson 2000, 426 no. 1854:""In Skipton during the alterations to the road near the Unicorn Inn, on the banks of Waller Beck, a number of Roman coins were found, of mixed dates, (not all determined yet but lodged in the Craven Museum)"-A. Raistrick, in Yorks. A.J.., 31 (1932-4), 219The coins have not been located in Craven Museum, Skipton.Undated"

name: PAS: Long Crendon 2821
comments: Robertson 2000, 9 no. 40:""Within the last few weeksa pot of small Roman coins (some of Claudius, but the greater number much corroded) was found at Crendon, near the spot of the former discoveries [i.e. the Roman cemetery at Long Crendon]."G.L., in Gent. Mag., 1831, I, 582Including Claudius (I or II?)"

name: PAS: Hemingford Abbots 2822
comments: Robertson 2000, 6 no. 21: ""There was found about 1870 by the vicar in what is now the 'park' a stone coffin containing, it is said, a skeleton of an abnormally tall man and an indented Castor beaker of third century date. A story goes that gold coins dated about 50 AD were in the beaker and were claimed by the Crown as treasure trove; enquiries fail to substantiate the truth of this statement, and the coins cannot be traced in the British Museum. (Inform. From Mr. C.F. Tebbutt, of St. Neot's. The coffin and beaker are now in the church at Hemingford Abbots.)."VCH Hunts., I (1926), 266"HEMINGFORD ABBOTS, Hemingford Park (Rectory Field?): Male in stone coffin, 3rdC colour-coated beaker (PS, 1963); perhaps from digging lake in 19thC; note with coffin and pot in Hemingford Abbots church suggests [...] and c. 1889 (cf. VCH Hunts. I, 266)"C.W. Phillips ed. The Fenland in Roman Times (1970), 184PS is Peter SalwayDate uncertain (were coins present?)"

name: PAS: Lanhydrock 2823
comments: Robertson 2000, 415 no. 1694:"At the Annual General Meeting of the Royal Institution of Cornwall, 29 Nov. 1892, the following gift to the Museum was recorded:"8 Roman coins (3rd. brass) found about 50 years ago near Llanhydrock, Cornwall. Rev. F.A. Allen, Meadow House, Fareham, Hants."Journ. Royal Inst. Cornwall, XI (1891-3), 241These 8 coins have not been located in County Museum, Truro (1958, 1978, ASR)Undated. Probably 3rd or 4th century AD"

name: PAS: Minster In Thanet 2824
comments: "A little more than a hundred years ago, a farmer of Minster, ordering his servants to go to plough on a holiday, they, out of Revenge, were resolved to try to break their Plough, and for that Purpose let it down to a greater Depth than ordinary into the Ground: when they had not gone far, before they struck against a Pot, which they brought up full of Roman Coins of the lesser and larger Silver [probably den. and ant.]. These the Country People called Bald-pates, and of them many years after were some found, after a Shower of Rain, which were supposed to be dropped by those who first discovered them. Another parcel of these coins [no. 312]was found not far off".-J. Lewis, Hist. and Ant. of the Isle of Tenet (1736), 27f.Undated. Probably 3rd century AD

name: PAS: Lythe 2825
comments: Robertson 2000, 57 no. 280A:"2 May 1793"Mr. Gibson of Hartlepool exhibited to the Society four Coins which were found about 4 Miles from Mulgrave Castle, very near the Great Roman Road which terminated at an Arx or Station, where Mulgrave Old Castle stands very near the fine Bay, the Dunus Sinus of Ptolemy now Dunsley Bay or Sandsend Road. These coins were found by a Countryman about 3 ft. under the Surface of the ground. He broke the Earthen Urn which contained them with his Spade, & sold the coins to a Silversmith."-Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., XXIV (1791-3), 444As Lythe and Ugthorpe are only a few miles apart, it seems just possible that this hoard and no. 280, Ugthorpe, 1792 (Yorks.), found at about the same time, were one and the same."

name: PAS: Carlisle 2826
comments: Robertson 2000, 417 no. 1722:"Re. Carlisle "great quantity of Roman coin dug under St. Cuthbert's church."W. Stukeley, Itin. Cur., 2 ed. (1776), Iter Boreale, 55Undated"

name: PAS: Dyserth 2827
comments: Robertson 2000, 427 no. 1861A:""I am informed... that a hoard of Roman coins was unearthed at a spot about 400 yards south-of the castle [Dyserth Castle] quite recently..Arch. Camb., (1915), 63Undated"

name: PAS: Holyhead 2828
comments: Robertson 2000, 414 no. 1687:""Near this spot [i.e. Trearddur, near the cromlech called Coetan Arthur] in 1837, a vessel containing a great many Roman copper coins was found, of the later emperors. I took them to the British Museum, but there was none peculiar; and I regret that they were purloined in transmission by post to the owner."W.O. Stanley, in Arch. Camb., 22 (1867), 234Later Empire"

name: PAS: Horncastle, Near 2829
comments: Robertson 2000, 420 no. 1771:""in 1734, a girl digging sand by the road side going from Les Yates to Horncastle, and near Horncastle, dug up an earthen urn full of Roman coins, rings,. &c. Mr. Terry collector gave me some of them"W. Stukeley, Itin. Cur., 2 ed. (1776) Iter I, 31Undated"

name: PAS: Killington 2830
comments: Robertson 2000, 424 no. 1826:"13 Jan. 1859"Killington Hall, where it [i.e. the Tenth Iter] again crossed the River Lune; near this spot an urn containing Roman coins had been found upwards of thirty years since."-T. Revely, in PSA (1), IV (1856-9), 255Undated"

name: PAS: Hinderclay 2831
comments: "3 aurei and one other shown to Basil Brown and G Maynard in c 1935." (Bland and Loriot 2010, 248, quoting HER?)

name: PAS: Barham Downs 2832
comments: Robertson 2000, 74-75 no. 352:""A short time since [i.e. since before 1841], some labourers on the road crossing Barham Downs had occasion to remove for highway repairs a heap of stones, which had remained there undisturbed for ages, without any suspicion as to their origin; when, on clearing them away, they discovered a cist or grave beneath. Its tenant had mouldered to dust, but there were found about 30 denarii, of the reigns of the Antonines. Some of these coins are still in the possession of Mr. Bartlett. They are much worn by circulation and it may therefore be conjectured that their deposition was posterior to the reigns of the Emperors whose effigies they bear."-J.Y. Akerman, in Arch., XXX (1844), 53"

name: PAS: Taplow 2833
comments: 2 VERY RUDE ROMAN URNS OF UNBAKED POTTERY FOUND DURING WORKS ON G.W.R NEAR ITS ABUTMENT ON TAPLOW. THEY CONTAINED 400-500 ROMAN SILVER COINS AMONGST WHICH WERE IMPERIAL COINS OF MID C1 AD TO LATE C2 (EMPERORS LISTED). PROBABLY BURIED IN REIGN OF AURELIUS, OR EARLY COMMODUS (B7-8,B12).

name: PAS: Treryn 2834
comments: Robertson 2000, 417 no. 1719:""There was found in hominum memoria, digging for the fox, a brasse (potte) ful of Roman money."J. Leland, Itinerary (1535-43), III, fol. 14, in a marginal note following a reference to a Vyvyan, lord of Tredine CastleThe findspot of the hoard was consequently assumed to be at "Tredine", a name otherwise unknown, and various attempts have been made to determine the exact locality. W. Borlase, Historical and Monumental Ant. ofCornwall (1769), 300, identified "Tredine" with Treryn and VCH Cornwall, 5 (1924), 41, suggested that this hoard was the same as that listed as near Padstow, before 1586 (Cornwall) [no. 1716]Undated"

name: PAS: Avebury 2835
comments: Robertson 2000, 415 no. 1698:""Coins near Beckhampton. When instructing a labourer in Avebury (October 3rd), as to searching for ancient relics for me, I happened to have a few 3rd Bronze Roman coins in my pocket, which I showed him, and asked if he had ever found any like them; he replied: 'When I were digging them big stones at Beckhampton (Beckhampton stone avenue] I dug up lots on 'em, but I thaught na one took no notice on 'em, so I let 'em bide).'"Rep. Marlborough College Nat. Hist. Soc, XXXVIII (1889), 110Undated. Probably 3rd or 4th century AD"

name: PAS: Isleham 2836
comments: Cambridgeshire HER 01592 (`Roman pewter hoard found on rotary quern immediately west of Isleham "Temple". Hoard excavated by Mr Smith in 1978 and sent to British Museum for conservation. Also 4 gold coins sent separately to BM and since sold.') Uncertain if gold or Roman coins.

name: PAS: Dyserth 2837
comments: Robertson 2000, 415 no. 1690:""In the latter part of 1868, some men engaged in making the railway from Prestatyn Station to the foot of Cwm Mountain came on about 20 silver and 1 gold coin, said to be Roman. The workmen disposed of them as soon as they could, but to whom is not known. Little also is known about the actual spot and circumstances of finding.The owner of the coins would probably furnish particulars as to their date, especially whether of Roman type. They are of the upper and lower empire."Scrutator, letter to the Editor, in Arch. Camb., 25 (1870), 145"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Millom 2838
comments: Robertson 2000, 417 no. 1724:""18 April, 1759. Sir Hedworth Williamson, Monksweremouth, told me at Millum Castle, Cumberland, (on River Duddon), which was a Roman castrum, they dug up two great urns full of silver Roman coins, which they sent up to London, and sold by pound weight."W. Stukeley, Letters and Diaries, ed. Surtees Soc., II (1883), 113Undated"

name: PAS: Sutton St. Edmund 2839
comments: Robertson 2000, 421 no. 1773:""'Monksdoles': Coin(s) found 'in an Urneunder some Large Squared Stones' (1741, SGS [i.e. Spalding Gentlemen's Soc.] Min. 3, f. 74d; letter from Maurice Johnson to Roger Gale, 1741, in Nichols, (Reliq. Galeanae, 345)."C.W. Phillips, ed., The Fenland in Roman Times (1970), 304Undated"

name: PAS: Yatton 2840
comments: Robertson 2000, 413 no. 1676:""I have never met with any of this kind of metal [i.e. debased white metal] brought from any great distance. I have one from Chedzoy Field, of Orbiana Augusta, and another from a large urn, holding nearly two gallons, found at the head of a skeleton, in a Roman cemetery at Yatton, at the foot of the encampment known as Cadbury-Hill, and now the garden of Rev. Richard Symes. The bodies were all deposited about eighteen inches below the surface, and the urn of black-ware was nearly full of second and third brass coins, of the lower empire. I one morning collected forty from the village shops, where they had for some weeks been passing as farthings."W. Stradling, in Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., I (1851) (1), 59VCH Somerset, I (1906), 370, through a misunderstanding of the above passage, assumed that the coin of Orbiana formed part of the hoard."Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Carlisle 2841
comments: Robertson 2000, 234 no. 953:"Re. "extensive excavations made in Carlisle for the erection of new markets in 1887: between 200 and 300 silver coins of Roman date, found there, were disposed of to a Liverpool dealer by one of the gaffers, who had been most active in handing over to the corporation anything that was too big for him to lift."-Chancellor Ferguson, in TCWAAS, XII (1892-3), 360Undated. Probably 1st - early 3rd century AD"

name: PAS: Barking 2842
comments: Unverified HER report (word of mouth) of a find of 200 coins, no denomination or metal given.

name: PAS: Bishopstoke 2843
comments: A hoard of Roman coins contained in a small jar is said to have been found in the Ballast field at Bishopstoke in 1878. Also found were complete pots and "a huge trench containing horses heads and grain". The HER record implies the hoard was found in this trench. Possibly associated with a Roman building.

name: PAS: Farnborough 2844
comments: HER record of two pots of Roman coins found by council workers during road or drainage work at Farnborough Manor Farm in 1926.

name: PAS: Haddon Hill 2845
comments: Robertson 2000, 423 no. 1802:""Near the western end of Haddon Hill, another conspicuous eminence, is a mountain called Hadborough, which in all probability was reared by the same people [i.e. the Romans], as several of their coins were dug up at the foot, when it was fenced round with a wall."-J. Collinson, Hist. and Ant. of Somerset (1791), III, 502Undated"

name: PAS: Roxby 2846
comments: Robertson 2000, 430 no. 1898:""Upon the top of the great ridg of the flying sand hills as you go from Santon to Burton market, in Santon parish, has been a great treasure of old copper coins hid; they have frequently been found there by whole handfulls, but are all so eaten away that nothing can be observed upon them."Diary of Abraham De la Pryme (1672-1704), ed. Surtees Soc., 54 (1890), 148"De la Pryme appears to have been mistaken in saying that these coins were found 'in Santon parish', because Santon belonged to the parish of Appleby and lay at some distance to the east of the 'top of the great ridg'. That this ridge denotes the highest point of the Risby Warren, which is in Roxby parish, can hardly be doubted, and this assumption is confirmed by the fact that persons travelling from Santon to 'Burton market' (Burton-on-Stather) would almost certainly pass across the Risby Warren on foot or horseback in his day."-H. Dudley, Early Days in North-West Lincolnshire (1949), 142Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Clent Heath 2847
comments: Robertson 2000, 425 no. 1835:""In or about the year 1790, a large jar [no. 1835], filled with Roman gold and silver coins was discovered by a labourer of the name of Benjamin Phillips as he was making a new pool on Clent Heath, a little below where the battle between the Romans and Britons was fought. In 1792 some silver coins [no. 1836] were found in a meadow at Old Mill. In another meadow lying east of this, a jar [no. 1837] of gold and another of silver were found by labourers."-J. Allies, Hist. and Ant. of Worcs., 2 ed. (1852), 135VCH Worcs., I (1901), 219, implied that Allies had used, as authority for the discovery of these hoards, W. Timings, Guide to the Clent Hills, 2 ed. (1826), 87, but although Allies mentioned Timings, it was not in reference to these hoards.Undated"

name: PAS: Carn Brea 2848
comments: Robertson 2000, 417 no. 1717: "Carnbrea. "A few years before [i.e. before 1749], one Mr. Stephens of the same town [i.e. Redruth] found about a quart of old Coins of the same nation, in the same place" [i.e. at the foot of Carnbrea Hill].W. Borlase, Historical and Monumental Ant. ofCornwall (1769), 300Undated"

name: PAS: Stanford 2849
comments: Robertson 2000, 421 no. 1783:""The Society of Antiquaries have a drawing of a Roman urn and coins, found 1753, in Sowthorpe pits, near Bernack and Stanford.R. Gough, British Topography (1780), II, 47Undated."

name: PAS: Offwell 2850
comments: Robertson 2000, 417 no. 1730:""Offwell - (Glanwell) Coins in metal box."R.N. Worth, Roman Devon (1891), 60Undated"

name: PAS: Abergavenny 2851
comments: Robertson 2000, 427 no. 1862:""It appears that, some years ago, several cistswere found in the same piece of ground [i.e. the nursery a few miles north of Abergavenny] by Mr. Saunders' workmen; but in these instances, it is believed, a large number of gold and silver coins were discovered in the vases contained in the cists. The workmen sold the coins, which were in perfect preservation; and, in order to secure the profit to themselves, left their master in a state of ignorance as to the circumstances that had occurred. Unfortunately, all trace of the coins has been lost."lJ. White, in JBAA, IV (1849), 313A reference by A. Hall, in Arch. Camb., 3 (1848), 172, showed that the date of discovery was before 1848, and recorded "a deposit of silver coins" only.G.C. Boon, in Monmouths. Antiquary, I (1) 1961), 5 n., regarded the mention of gold coins as a slip.Undated"

name: PAS: Clent 2852
comments: Robertson 2000, 452 no. 1837:""In or about the year 1790, a large jar [no. 1835], filled with Roman gold and silver coins was discovered by a labourer of the name of Benjamin Phillips as he was making a new pool on Clent Heath, a little below where the battle between the Romans and Britons was fought. In 1792 some silver coins [no. 1836] were found in a meadow at Old Mill. In another meadow lying east of this, a jar [no. 1837] of gold and another of silver were found by labourers."-J. Allies, Hist. and Ant. of Worcs., 2 ed. (1852), 135VCH Worcs., I (1901), 219, implied that Allies had used, as authority for the discovery of these hoards, W. Timings, Guide to the Clent Hills, 2 ed. (1826), 87, but although Allies mentioned Timings, it was not in reference to these hoards.Undated"

name: PAS: Netheravon 2853
comments: Robertson 2000, 425 no. 1831:""After a description of Roman remains uncovered by Col. Hawley and the Rev. G.H. Engleheart in 1907 in the grounds of Netheravon House, there follows the sentence: 'In the same grounds, a hoard of bronze coins, found many years ago, of which no record.'"-Letter, March 1958, from H. de S. Shortt, Salisbury and S. Wilts MuseumThe letter refers to an article by Canon E.H. Goddard, in Wilts. Arch. Mag., XXXVIII (1914), 294; cp. also Wilts Arch Mag., XLV (1930-2), 198Undated"

name: PAS: Birdforth 2854
comments: Robertson 2000, 431 no. 1905:""A few years since, a considerable quantity of small silver coins was found in widening Birdforth Beck. The treasure has been dispersed, and not a piece now remains in Birdforth. The place they were found being near the Roman Road, renders it not improbable that they might be Roman coins."-B. Jefferson, Hist. of Thirsk (1821), 98Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Cheltenham 2855
comments: Robertson 2000, 418 no. 1741:"July 28. As some labourers were digging a hole for the reception of a post, near the New Bath Turnpike, adjoining Cheltenham, they found an antique jar, containing many hundreds of Roman coins, mostly copper, bearing impressions of different Emperors and other devices."Gent. Mag., 1818, II, 174The Shrewsbury Chronicle, 21 Aug. 1818, gave the size of the hoard as "250-300 'Half a gallon' of Roman coins."E.J. Priestley, in CH VI (1981), 30, no. 135Undated"

name: PAS: Radstone 2856
comments: Robertosn 2000, 421 no. 1782:""Coins in urn; the urn is in Northampton Museum."F. Haverfield, in VCH Northants., I (1902), 220The urn has not been located in Northampton Museum.Undated"

name: PAS: Heapey 2857
comments: Robertson 2000, 419 no. 1757:""In January 1835, a large number of Roman coins were discovered, chiefly of brass, with some silver and many of them in excellent preservation."S. Lewis, Topog. Dict. of England (1842), s.v. HeapeyUndated"

name: PAS: Chiswick 2858
comments: Robertson 2000, 421 no. 1775:""In 1731 a Roman urn with coins at Turnham Green (Lysons)."M. Sharp. Ant. of Middlesex (1919), 89No reference to this hoard in any of Lysons' works has so far been traced.Undated"

name: PAS: Corwen 2859
comments: A coin hoard found "in an earthen urn" whilst removing a hedge in Corwen. No further details.

name: PAS: Barrow-On-Soar 2860
comments: Robertson 2000, 420 no. 1762:""Two recently discovered hoards, one at Barrow, the other at Kibworth, seem to have been removed from the county."Rep. Assoc. Archit. Soc., V (1859), 310Undated"

name: PAS: March 2861
comments: Robertson 2000,416 no. 1710:""Clipson's Farm.: when a large mound was levelled about 1940, a skeleton is said to have been found 'with a pot of money', but the find was destroyed. (Information from Mr. Walter Warby)."G. Fowler, in Proc. Cambs.Ant. Soc., XLIII (1949-50), 16; App. II, by E. J. Rudsdale and W. WarbyUndated"

name: PAS: Appleby 2862
comments: Robertson 2000, 420 no. 1767:""Appleby, where an earthen vase, surrounded by dark soil, and containing a considerable number of Roman silver coins, was discovered in a rabbit warren."E. Trollope, Sleaford and the Wapentakes of Flaxwell and Aswardhurn (1872), 59Undated"

name: PAS: Speen Stockcross 2863
comments: Robertson 2000, 416 no. 1705:""Amongst the most noteworthy of these relics [i.e. Roman coins, pottery, etc.] I may mentionanother vase, full of copper coins, at Stockcross."J. Adams, in JBAA, XVI (1860), 73Undated"

name: PAS: Bewcastle 2864
comments: Robertson 2000, 417 no. 1721:"Kirk Beck. "A hoard of coins was found in the beck close to the bridge, but is dispersed and has left no trace behind."R.G. Collingwood, in TCWAS, n.s., XXII (1922), 176Undated"

name: PAS: Grantham 2865
comments: Robertson 2000, 430 no. 1897:""7 Oct. 1726.Digging in my garden at Grantham, we found a pot full of old silver coin."-W. Stukeley, Letters and Diaries, ed. Surtees Soc., II (1883), 311Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Folkestone and Hythe 2866
comments: Robertson 2000, 430 no. 1893:""A cony drawing his yerth betwyxt Folkestan and Hyve did cast up antique mony."-J. Leland, Itinerary (1535-43), VIII, fol. 141Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Castle Ashby 2867
comments: Robertson 2000, 421 no. 1779:""Several Roman coins were dug up in forming this avenue in 1719." The avenue was that to Lord Northampton's house.J. Bridges, Hist. and Ant. of Northants., ed. Whalley (1791), I, 341Undated"

name: PAS: Dodington 2868
comments: Robertson 2000, 418 no. 1742:""A yerthen pott with Romayne coynes found in Dodington felde."J Leland, Itinerary, (1535-43), VIII, fol. 75; ed. Lucy Toulmin Smith, IV (1909), 131Undated"

name: PAS: Norton 2869
comments: Robertson 2000, 426 no. 1851:""1822. Top of face jug from Norton; Roman coins, much decayed, found with it (in it?). Hinderwell, MSS., 1825, i, 85. Copperthwaite MSS., drawing."-Mary Kitson Clark, Gazetteer of Roman Remains in E. Yorks. (1935) 114Undated"

name: PAS: Wanborough 2870
comments: Moorhead (2000, 59 no. 86) records a reference in correspondence to a find in the 1960s of a ceramic vessel with circular green markings on the interior from a  coin hoard. The coins were never seen. Presumably Roman.

name: PAS: Beaumont 2871
comments: Robertson 2000, 417 no. 1720:"Kirkandrews"Between 1819 and 1823, in cutting the canal from Carlisle to the Solway (now the Carlisle and Silloth Railway), a large hoard of Roman coins was found either in the parish of Beaumont of the adjoining one of Kirkandrews on Eden."R.S. Ferguson and C.F. Keary, in TCWAS, VIII (1887), 380Undated"

name: PAS: Richborough 2872
comments: Robertson 2000, 419 no. 1753:""In the north side of the castel [i.e. of Richborough Castle] ys a hedde yn the walle, now sore defaced with wether. They cawle yt Queen Bertha hedde. Nere to that place hard by the wal was a pot of Romayne mony found."J. Leland, Itinerary (1535-43), VII, fol. 138: ed. Lucy Toulmin Smith, IV (1909), 62Undated"

name: PAS: Helmingham 2873
comments: Pastscape record of a hoard of "gold coins in a lead container found circa 1820-30 in Helmingham park under oak tree". There is no further information about this record, which seems to have been created in the 1950s. However Bland and Loriot (2010, 244 no. 540) record a single find of an aureus of Vespasian from Helmingham recorded in Numismatic Chronicle 7, 1844-5, Proceedings 25th January 1844 p.7 that may be from this find.

name: PAS: Padstow, near; Lanteglos 2874
comments: Robertson 2000, 416 no. 1716:""Not long since, and in the remembrance of man, a brasse pot full of Roman Coine was found there, as I have often heard."W. Harrison, Description of Britaine, 2 ed. (1586), 65W. Borlase, Historical and Monumental Ant. ofCornwall (1769), 300, placed the find on the banks of the River Camel; Gough's Camden (1789), I, 20 at Wadebridge, near Camelford; and Davies Gilbert, Paroch. Hist. of Cornwall (1838), II, 403 at Camelford.VCH Cornwall, 5 (1924), 38, suggested that this is the same hoard as that listed under Treryn, before c. 1535 (Cornwall) [no. 1719].Undated"

name: PAS: Maiden Castle 2875
comments: Robertson 2000, 424 no. 1825:""Whellan's Cumberland and Westmorland (1860), gives, under Stainmore Chapelry (p. 735), a brief reference to the discovery of what looks to have been a coin-hoard:'About ten years ago some Roman coins of silver were found in the peat-moss, not far from Maiden Castle, and are now in the possession of Mr. Hill, of Appleby.'"-E. Birley, in TCWAS, n.s., 57 (1957), 187Undated"

name: PAS: Dorset 2876
comments: Robertson 2000, 418 no. 1735:"27 May 1830"Dr. Latham communicated to the Society the representation of a piece of silver, supposed to be a Coin; which was found in Dorsetshire, with a number of other Coins of the Roman Empire."Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., XXXVI (1830-5), 51Undated"

name: PAS: Worcester 2877
comments: Robertson 2000, 425 no. 1838:""By the side of the work [i.e. the Roman hearth within 100 yards of the walls of the city of Worcester], there was found out a pot of Roman coins, to the quantity of a peck: some of which was presented to Sir Dugdale and part thereof is now in the king's closet."-A. Yarranton, England's Improvement by Sea and Land (1698), II, 162Undated"

name: PAS: Bourne (Park) 2878
comments: Robertson 2000, 420 no. 1768:""About sixty years ago a tessellated pavement was found in the Park grounds, but destroyed a few days after:- There was also a large pot or urn found near it; it contained a sort of coin very uncommon, and what metal it was made of is not known, for on being exposed to the air it fell to powder. The stone that covered it was preserved. There appears to have been an inscription on it, but it was quite illegible."W. Marratt, Hist. of Lincs. (1772-1852), III (1816), 79Undated"

name: PAS: Broad Street 2879
comments: Robertson 2000, 430 no. 1899:"7 Sept. 1758"Two bricklayers' labourers in digging at the back of Mr. Pearson's house in Broad Street, discovered two vessels with ancient coins to a considerable value."-Annual Register, 1758, 108Uncertain if Roman"NB now "Old Broad St"

name: PAS: Grimsargh, Near Ribchester 2880
comments: Robertson 2000, 419 no. 1756:""Mr. E. Kirk states that he remembers the discovery of a hoard of Roman silver coins, circa 1845, on the Elston Hall Estate, near Ribchester, in one of the fields on the river side: but Col. W. Assheton-Cross, the owner of the site, appears to know nothing whatever about them."W.T. Watkins, Roman Lancashire (1886), 232Undated"

name: PAS: Longbridge Deverill 2881
comments: Robertson 2000, 424 no. 1829:"In 1854, there were exhibited at the temporary museum at Salisbury "by the Rev. A. Fane, Warminster:- seven Roman coins, found in an earthen vessel at Longbridge Deverill."-Wilts. Arch. Mag., II (1854), 34It is possible that this "earthen vessel" was the pot which is now in the Salisbury and S. Wilts. Museum, labelled "Brixton Deverill" [no. 1827].Undated"

name: PAS: Penrhyn Bay 2882
comments: A report of a hoard found in a garden at Penrhyn Bay In 1924. The hoard was found in a box. No coin details were available.

name: PAS: Exmoor 2883
comments: Robertson 2000, 422-423 no. 1800:"T. Reynolds, Iter Britannicum (1799), 439, writing of the Exmoor in Devon, said "several urns with Roman coins have been found in the barrows."H.M. Scarth, in Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., XXIV (1878), (2), 19, writing of the Exmoor in Somerset, said "Exmore, where the Exe rises, urns with Roman coins have been found, AD 1831."VCH Somerset, I (1911), 362, suggested that the writer in Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., XXIV (1879), (2), 19, was misquoting from Reynolds, Iter Britannicum (1799), 439, and wrongly attributing to Exmoor in Somerset finds made at Exmoor in Devon.Undated"

name: PAS: Birdlip 2884
comments: Robertson 2000, 418 no. 1740:"Royal George Hotelwhere a hoard of over 200 coins was found c. 1890."Britannia, XVIII (1987), 336; from R.F. and O.H.E. Butler, Birdlip and Brimpsfield: the story of two villages (1958)Undated"

name: PAS: Southwark Cathedral 2885
comments: 6 Roman coins, 3 of gold and 3 of bronze accidentally found in NE corner of [Southwark] Cathedral.

name: PAS: Frome 2886
comments: Robertson 2000, 423 no. 1801:""About twelve months previously [i.e. previously to the discovery of the Frome, 1865 hoard, no. 1126 - i.e. 'Mendip Hills hoard'] a hoard of about 230 Roman coins was found in a field close by."-(Sir) John Evans, in NC, 1866, 157Undated"

name: PAS: Nynehead 2887
comments: Robertson 2000, 423 no. 1803:""Some Roman coins found at Nynehead." Exhibited at local museum.-Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., XI (1863), (1), 52AJ, XXXVII (1880), Proc., 107, stated that there were found at Burrows Hill, East Buckland, Somerset, "a British urn in one locality, Roman copper coins in another." Exhibited by Mr. W.A. SanfordVCH Somerset, I (1911), 365, quoting as authorities the above two passages, recorded the discovery of a "hoard in urn, details not preserved." There is no evidence, however, that the coins found at Nynehead formed a hoard, or were found in an urn.Undated."

name: PAS: Gloucester 2888
comments: Robertson 2000, 418 no. 1744:""Fifty years ago it was the custom for schoolboys after a heavy rain to go to Wheeler's nursery at Kingsholm and pick up the coins that had been washed out of the ground by the rain. One lot of 700 has been found there."J. Bellows, in Trans. Bristol and Glos. Arch. Soc., XIII (1888), 50L.E.W.O. Fullbrook Leggatt, Roman Gloucester (1968), 63, located the find in "Mark Street", and P. Garrod and H. Hurst, in Ant. J., 55 (1975), 283, dated the discovery to 1859.Undated"

name: PAS: Bittesby 2889
comments: Robertson 2000, 420 no. 1763:""But the most memorable thing hereabouts is BENNONES or VENNONES, of the Romans, called in the Saxon times Cleycester. This station was situate, it is generally imagined, near Bittesby. The ground thereabouts is very irregular; and foundations of strong buildings have been frequently discovered; coins also in abundance have been dug and ploughed up, which very much strengthens the opinions of the Antiquaries, that this was a Roman station. Mr. Burton had a number of the coins found here: and Mr. Lee, of Leicester, also made a collection of ancient coins found here; he had also a fine Roman urn, discovered in ploughing near Bittesby, which I saw."J. Throsby, Leics. Views, II, (1790-2), 301 VCH Leics. I (1907), 211, giving as reference the above passage stated that "an urn and coins were turned up by the plough at an early date. Burton is said to have had some of the coins." This gives the impression that the urn and coins were found together, but Throsby's account offers no proof of this.Undated"

name: PAS: Sherston 2890
comments: Robertson 2000, 429 no. 1881:""At Sherston, near the Fosse Way, Roman Coins have been frequently found. Silver denarii of Antoninus, Faustina, Gordianus, and Fl.Julianus are deposited in Ashmole's Museum in Oxford."-J. Pointer, Britannia Romana (1724), 38"At Sherston, hath severall times been found Roman money in ploughing. I have one silver piece found there not long since (1653), of Constantine the Great."-J.E. Jackson, Wilts. The Topog. Coll. of J. Aubrey, F.R.S., 1659-70 (1862), 5, cp. 106If these coin finds included a hoard, it is not now possible to determine its date.Undatable"

name: PAS: Charlton Mackrell 2891
comments: Robertson 2000, 422 no. 1799:"Mr. J.G. Cox, of Ilchester, stated that a hoard of Roman gold coins was said to have been found at Charlton Mackrell in about 1948, but no further details can be recovered.Undated."

name: PAS: Whitwell 2892
comments: Marked on OS map. From HER: "According to the Ordnance Survey's Object Name Book for 1897 "There were two old jars full of old coins supposed to be Roman found here about 40 years ago". The information is said to have come from Mr Turner, Agent for the Duke of Portland."

name: PAS: nan 2893
comments: HER record of two urns filled with ashes "and many coins" discovered in Cheltenham High Street in 1816. It is not clear from the accounts if the coins were in the urns or nearby but the HER has recorded this as a hoard.

name: PAS: Wigan 2894
comments: `Some gold coins.' Shotter 1990, p. 178, 22(d) (`An elusive report [in the Powell Museum, Wigan] refers to the discovery of gold coins near a bus stop in Cherry Gardens.')

name: PAS: East Rudham 2895
comments: Robertson 2000, 421: " "It is said that a little pot containing a number of Roman coins was found in the ruins of Coxford Priory in the year 1719, but pot and coins alike have been lost."H.J.D. Astley, in JBAA, n.s., VII (1901), 104Undated"The site is St Mary's Priory, Oxford.

name: PAS: Stratton 2896
comments: Robertson 2000, 430 no. 1889: ""In this place several Brass Medals and some Silver Coins have been lately found, as I was assured by the present tenant of these lands, who found the former, and gave the four or five brass old Farthings (as he called them) to his children to play withall."-W. Borlase, Historical and Monumental Ant. ofCornwall (1769), 312Gough, Add. to Camden's Britannia (1806), I, 26, 194, supposed these coins to be Roman, but this is not absolutely certain.Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Wingfield 2897
comments: Robertson 2000, 423-424 no. 1814:""June 22, 1836. Miss Heyman told me that when her brother, Sir Henry Heyman, first went to reside as vicar at Fressingfield, she heard, that a short time previous, a considerable quantity of coins had been found at Wingfield; upon the premises of a poor man there; and that the discovery was made in consequence of some supposed supernatural appearances: the tale was this: the wife of this poor man was one day waiting for the return of her husband from work, when she was startled by the rustling of silk, and looking up observed a lady, who slowly walked towards their pig sty, and there suddenly disappeared: something like this she had before observed, but this time the poor woman was so struck by it, that when her husband returned home, she related the circumstance to him, and told him she was sure some treasure was hid there, and urged him so strongly to search for it, that he was at length persuaded to do so. Upon digging, he found numerous pieces of money; some of which Miss Heyman herself saw; they were all Roman, and small silver coins. Among them were also found some plates or ornaments of silver, which the poor woman said she had shewn to two gentlemen, who called to see them; upon examining them, they told her they were of very considerable value, but that they could not say what their precise value might be, till they were taken to a silversmith, to be weighed and valued; this they offered to have done for her, and she unwisely trusted them to their care, but never afterwards saw either the men or the silver.The fortunate discovery of this treasure made a considerable sum of money, by the sale of the coins, and purchasing the premises, built himself a new cottage, upon the site of the pigsty where they were found; and where he lived many years, and where, Miss Heyman believes, he still lives."Davy, Suffolk Coll. B.M. Mss., XV, 19092, fol. 379Undated"

name: PAS: Downham 2898
comments: Robertson 2000, 421 no. 1784A:""About twenty years since a jar or vase was dug up near Downham, six miles north-west of Ford, which contained a large quantity of silver coins... of the Roman Empire..History of the Berwickshire Naturalists' Club, Proceedings 2 (1841/9), 344Undated"

name: PAS: Wootton 2899
comments: Robertson 2000, 20 no. 102A:""Not many years ago, some gold coin was found in a field near Wootton Lodge, in that part of Staffordshire called the Moorlands, though no Roman road, camp town, or city lay near the place."Stebbing Shaw, Hist. of Staffs. (1798), I, 32It is possible that this is the same find as no. 102, Alton, 1725 (Staffs.)"Bland and Loriot:"Some gold coins of the Roman period are said to have been found there.' VCH Staffordshire, I, 1908, p. 190: `Ellastone.- Some gold coins of the Roman period are said to have been found near Wootton Lodge [Stebbing Shaw, Hist. Staffs. I, 32].' = Stebbing Shaw, The History and Antiquities of Staffordshire I, London, 1798, p. 32: `Not many years ago some gold coin was found in a field near Wootton Lodge, in that part of Staffordshire called the Moorlands, though no Roman road, camp. town or city lay near the place..."

name: PAS: St. Paul 2900
comments: Robertson 2000, 430 no. 1888:""In 1723, at Kerris, in the parish of St. Paul, a vault was discovered eight feet long, and six feet high, paved with stone; within which was a small urn of the finest red clay, full of earth, and some small brass coins."-S. Lysons, Reliquiae Britannico-Romanae, III (1814), ccxxivUncertain if Roman"Contra Robertson, the account by Borlase (1769, 307) mentions that the urn was Roman. It was described as small, of delicate shape and made of fine clay and was thought to have been a cremation urn but there does not appear to have been direct evidence for this. The coins were found "with" it not in it.

name: PAS: Darton 2901
comments: HER report of a seventeenth century find: "A Roman urn, full of coins, was unearthed at Darton towards the end of the 17th. Century" (Fletcher, J S, Picturesque History of Yorkshire Vol 1 1899 p.270)

name: PAS: Brixton Deverill 2902
comments: Robertson 2000,  424 no. 1827:"There was, before 1936, in the Salisbury and S. Wilts. Museum, a jar of hard pale grey clay 3 3/4 in. high, and 4 1/2 in. wide, with outcurving rim, which was labelled "Roman Vase dug up at Brixton Deverill full of Silver Coins." There is no record or trace of the coins. [See Longbridge Deverill, before 1854 (Wilts.) [no. 1829]]Pot drawn, 1938 (ASR)Undated"

name: PAS: Skerne 2903
comments: Robertson 2000, 426 no. 1853:""On May 12, 1897, a hoard consisting of 1 silver and 16 bronze Roman coins, with two pieces of bronze, probably portions of the handles of a box or leather bag, were found in deepening a drain on 'Copper Hall' farm, Skerne, 3 miles south-east of Driffield. The drain was originally cut about the year 1835; and from its appearance while deepening it in 1897, it is probable that the greater portion of it had been removed when the drain was first cut, leaving only a portion of the broken handle and the coins found in 1897.The late Lord Londesborough obtained the 17 coins last found."-J.R. Mortimer, Forty Years' Researches in British and Saxon Burial Mounds of E. Yorks. (1905), lxxxiii, 352Undated"

name: PAS: Penboyr 2904
comments: Robertson 2000, 427 no. 1860:""Mr. Beynon showed me a Coin (Silver) very bold impression, found in the parish of Penboyr, near the Tewy Side at a place called by the Welsh name of Red Breast."-J. Fenton, Tours in Wales (1804); in Arch. Camb., 72 (1917), Suppl., 2"A pot of Roman coins was found in the neighbourhood [i.e. of the church-yard] not many years ago."-S. Lewis, Topog. Dict. of Wales (1833), s.v. PenboyrUndated"

name: PAS: Croydon 2905
comments: Robertson 2000, 424 no. 1815:""Many Roman coins found in an urn near Croydon."-W. Stukeley, Itin. Cur., 2 ed. (1776), I, 119 n.Undated"

name: PAS: Bristol 2906
comments: Robertson 2000, 422 no. 1798:""At all the above stations [i.e. Hanham, Netherways, Westbury, Blaize Castle and Saymills], as well as in the pomerium of the Old City, at the Broad Weir, Clifton, etc., causeways, Roman remains, pigs of lead, glass vessels, and coins of nearly every emperor, down to the evacuation of Britain, have been found. Last year, a rude vase with above 1000 coins was accidentally discovered on the Somersetshire side of Bristol."J.F. Nicholls, in AJ, XXVII (1870), 65Undated"

name: PAS: Rowley Regis 2907
comments: Robertson 2000, 429 no. 1879:""In 1794, was also found at Rowley Regis, an earthen globe, containing about 1200 similar [i.e. Roman] coins in silver, which, when all together, formed a complete series of the Roman emperors; but they were unfortunately soon dispersed about the country, except about 300, which are in the possession of the Rev. Mr. Cartwright of Dudley."-Gent. Mag., 1796, II, 983Undatable"

name: PAS: Brancaster 2908
comments: Robertson 2000, 421: " "Eruuntur hic saepe Romana Numismata: ad me etiam nonnulla delata, cum duobus aliquando vasculis aeneis seu capedunculis."H. Spelman, Icenia (Posthumous Works) (1698), 148Undated"Vague reference to finds of Roman coins and two copper alloy vessels (paterae?) found in the area.

name: PAS: Uplyme 2909
comments: Robertson 2000, 417 no. 1732:""In a field called 'Holcombe bottom', in the parish of Uplyme, which is skirted by the road, a man, some years ago, employed in removing a large heap of stones, provincially termed 'a stone-burrow', discovered an earthen vessel containing a very large number of Roman coins, which he carried to Exeter for sale."J.B. Davidson, Roman and British Remains in the Vicinity of Axminster (1833), 56Undated"

name: PAS: Northampton to Peterborough railway 2910
comments: Robertson 2000, 412-413 no. 1669:"26 Feb. 1846"Edward Tyrell Artis, Esq., F.S.A., exhibited a small bronze casket described as having been found inclosed in an earthen vase, and containing various Roman coins, of early and late periods. It was brought to light in the course of excavations for the line of railway between Northampton and Peterborough; but the exact site had not been ascertained. It is now in the possession of the Earl Fitzwilliam."PSA, (1), I (1843-9), 120Late Empire?"Has been interpreted as a modern collection, reburied.

name: PAS: Mayfield 2911
comments: Robertson 2000, 423 no. 1808:""Some Roman money that has been sometimes found in Dale-close 'twixt Okeover and Mathfield and a Roman urn dugg about ten years agoe out of a bank in Church-towne field in Upper Mathfield,."-R. Plot, Nat. Hist. of Staffs. (1686), 404Brayley and Britton, Beauties of England and Wales, XIII (2), (1813) (2), 1006, recorded the find of coins thus: "Roman coins have been found in an urn at that [i.e. tumulus] in Dale Close."Undated"

name: PAS: Great Burstead 2912
comments: Robertson 2000, 418 no. 1737: ""About half a century since, about 1100 copper coins were discovered on the edge of a ditch by a labourer, on a farm called Tiled Hall, about 1[1/2] miles from Billericay; they were, with a single exception, all sold in London by the discoverer, who was afraid to go to bed lest he should oversleep himself and be detected ere he could dispose of them."Trans. Essex Arch. Soc., II (1868), 70Undated"

name: PAS: Littleport 2913
comments: HER entry on Heritage Gateway reads: "A number of metal finds discovered during a metal detector rally at Butcher's Hill Farm in autumn 2002. The coins are believed to come from a single organic container fastened by the pin. A few greyware sherds ware observed on the surface during the discovery. The site is recorded on old OS maps as being the location for a hoard" (HER CB15276).

name: PAS: Swinton 2914
comments: Robertson 2000, 427 no. 1856:"About 1870, a hoard of Roman coins of uncertain date was found at Swinton.Letters, 1936, from H. Copley, RotherhamUndated"

name: PAS: Lancaster 2915
comments: Robertson 2000, 419 no. 1758:""In 1849, an iron spear-head, now in Mr. Dalzell's possession, was found in Marsh Lane, in digging for the junction of the North-Western and Carlisle railways. A number of Roman coins were found at the same time, but were dispersed."W.T. Watkins, Roman Lancashire (1886), 185Undated"

name: PAS: Greenstead Green 2916
comments: HER report from a local resident of a discovery of a bowl "containing coins and other Roman sherds" in a garden in the neighbourhood. No further details were given.

name: PAS: Beaumaris 2917
comments: Robertson 2000, 427 no. 1858:""A large number of old Roman coins have been discovered in excavating for a new drive in course of construction at Baron-hill, the Anglesey seat of Sir R. Williams-Bulkeley, Bart."-F. Haverfield, in Antiquary, IV (1881), 28Undated"

name: PAS: Ellastone, Wootton Lodge 2918
comments: `Some gold coins of the Roman period are said to have been found there.' VCH Staffordshire, I, 1908, p. 190: `Ellastone.- Some gold coins of the Roman period are said to have been found near Wootton Lodge [Stebbing Shaw, Hist. Staffs. I, 32].' = Stebbing Shaw, The History and Antiquities of Staffordshire I, London, 1798, p. 32: `Not many years ago some gold coin was found in a field near Wootton Lodge, in that part of Staffordshire called the Moorlands, though no Roman road, camp. town or city lay near the place...'

name: PAS: Leicester (Castle Yard) 2919
comments: Robertson 2000, 420 no. 1765:"Leics. Museum Accession no. 85/1860"Six Roman copper coins in an urn in the Castle Yard was donated to Leicester Museum in 1860." Coins and pot not found.M.J. Winter, in Trans. Leics. Arch. and Hist. Soc., 53 (1977), 1-7Undated"

name: PAS: Croydon 2920
comments: HER record of "two bucketfuls" of Roman coins found around 1891 at a specfic findspot. It is possible that this the Carausian hoard recorded as being found in 1893 IARCH-D6D9B4 (at a different but imprecise findspot) but this is difficult to verify and so a record has been created for this hoard.

name: PAS: Frimley 2921
comments: Robertson 2000, 424 no. 1819:""At Frimley, near here, about sixteen years ago, an urn with roman coyns and intaglia's [sic] was found."-W. Stukeley, Itin. Cur. (1724), 198Undated"

name: PAS: Whitton 2922
comments: Robertson 2000, 429 no. 1880:"Castle Farm, Whitton"There a tessellated pavement, now in the Ipswich Museum, was found in 1870, and from time to time coins have turned up, some said to date from Vespasian's reign, others probably of the fourth century."-F. Haverfield, in Antiquary, XXXIII (1897), 104It is uncertain whether these coins constituted a hoard.Undatable"

name: PAS: Dowdeswell 2923
comments: Robertson 2000, 350 no. 1434A:""I know, from inspection, of four other examples of square mounds; two are in Gloucestershire; one of them called 'St. Paul's Epistle' (half mile W. of Andoversford) was found on excavation to be full of Roman coins."O.G.S. Crawford in Wilts. Arch. and Nat. Hist. Mag., XLII (1922-4), 59Letter, Jan. 1966, from L.V. Grinsell, suggesting that this may be the same as the Foxcote, Withington, 1863 (Glos.) find [1434]."This is supported by SMR info on Pastcape:" A square mound about 4 ft high and 36 ft long on each side. Witts mistook this mound for the round barrow to the SE[...], and it was perhaps in consequence of this that a note "Roman Coins found" was attached to St Paul's Epistle on the OS plan. (4)""

name: PAS: Kingston Upon Thames 2924
comments: Robertson 2000, 411 no. 1651:""Kingeston upon Tamise there yn ploughyng and digging have very often beene founde fundation of waulles of houses, and diverse coynes of brasse, sylver and gold, with Romaine inscriptions, and paintid yerthen pottes; and yn one in the Cardinal Wolsey's tyme was found much Romayne mony of sylver, and plates of sylver to coyne, and masses to bete into plates to coyne, and (chay)nes of sylver."J. Leland, Itinerary (1535-43), VIII, fol. 25; ed. Lucy Toulmin Smith, II (1909), 85The "plates of sylver to coyne, and masses to bete into plates to coyne" may have included ingots.Late Roman?"

name: PAS: Bourne 2925
comments: Robertson 2000, 428 no. 1873:"1 Jan. 1809"A person engaged in digging near the entrenchments which surround the castle at Bourn, lately discovered a small urn, containing upwards of sixty Roman coins. One of them is an aureus of Nero; the others are denarii and sestertii of Constantine, Augustus and Maximilian [sic]."-Annual Register, 1809, 307The account of the emperors represented in the hoard, and the denominations included is unlikely.Undatable"

name: PAS: Warminster 2926
comments: Robertson 2000, 429 no. 1882:""Near the N.W. angle of Battlesbury, AD 1773, in an old chalk quarry, 36 Roman coins were found in an urn, silver and copper of Antoninus Pius, Julia and Constantine, with some skeletons and bones of a horse."J.J. Daniell, Hist. of Warminster (1879), 5The description of the emperors included in this hoard is untrustworthy.Undatable"

name: PAS: Caernarvon 2927
comments: Robertson 2000, 431 no. 1908: ""Near it [i.e. the Roman fort at Caernarvon] was found not many years ago a brass pot [no. 1908] full of money under a tree. Another [no. 1909] the winter before I was there near the gallows on the bank of the marsh by the river side."Gough's Camden (1789), II, p. 556Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Hull 2928
comments: Robertson 2000, 431 no. 1906:""According to a newspaper report, a hoard of coins was found in a vase at Hull a little over a century ago."-Trans. East Riding Ant. Soc., XIV (1907), 60T. Sheppard, Hull City Museum, quoted in Mary Kitson Clark, Gazetteer of Roman Remains in E. Yorks. (1935), 93, threw suspicion on this find, which he thought may not have been Roman.Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Huddersfield 2929
comments: Robertson 2000, 426 no. 1846:"15 Nov. 1770"The last Summer, in digging for Gravel near Huddersfield, in the West Riding, several Urns were found with Coins in them."-Letter of Dr. Burton to Dr. Ducarel, in Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., XII (1770-3), 11Also in Arch., II (1773), 181Undated"

name: PAS: Wilford 2930
comments: Robertson 2000, 422 no. 1788:""Richard Cooper likewise told me of a pot of roman money found at Wilford near Nottingham."W. Stukeley, Itin. Cur, 1724, 101C. Deering, Nottinghamia Vetus et Nova (1751), Introd. 6, App. 286, cast doubts on the accuracy of Stukeley's statement.Gough's Camden (1789), II, 287, recorded the fact that "on the opposite side of the river at Wilford was dug up in the fields a pot full of copper coins."VCH Notts., II (1910), 35, suggested that Stukeley and Gough's Camden referred to one and the same find.Undated"

name: PAS: Y Felinheli 2931
comments: " A hoard of Roman coins said to have been found on the site of a cliff fort near Y Felinheli in about 1910" (Guest and Wells 1085). "

name: PAS: Roydon 2932
comments: A "discovery of Roman silver coins" reportedly made at Roydon, according to the diary of W. Wire in Colchester Museum (7th March 1855) (information from Pastscape).

name: PAS: Manchester 2933
comments: Robertson 2000, 420 no. 1760:""In 1777, a number of Roman coins were found on the banks of the Medlock."T. Baines, Lancs. and Chesh. Past and Present (1867), 268Undated"

name: PAS: Winterbourne 2934
comments: `Pot of gold coins': no date given, probably not Roman. S Glos SMR 1537-SG2305 "A pot of gold coins was found many years ago some 100 yards from where a gold ring, possibly 9th century, was later found." (J F Nichols, Archaeological Journal 31, 1874, pp. 87-9).

name: PAS: Clent 2935
comments: Robertson 2000, 425 no. 1836:""In or about the year 1790, a large jar [no. 1835], filled with Roman gold and silver coins was discovered by a labourer of the name of Benjamin Phillips as he was making a new pool on Clent Heath, a little below where the battle between the Romans and Britons was fought. In 1792 some silver coins [no. 1836] were found in a meadow at Old Mill. In another meadow lying east of this, a jar [no. 1837] of gold and another of silver were found by labourers."-J. Allies, Hist. and Ant. of Worcs., 2 ed. (1852), 135VCH Worcs., I (1901), 219, implied that Allies had used, as authority for the discovery of these hoards, W. Timings, Guide to the Clent Hills, 2 ed. (1826), 87, but although Allies mentioned Timings, it was not in reference to these hoards.Undated"

name: PAS: Roundway 2936
comments: Robertson 2000, 425 no. 1832:""On a hill called Rundway Hill, near Devizes, is a square camp with a single trench, supposed to be Roman. Many Roman coins of different emperors have been found in the neighbourhood of Devizes, together with pots and other earthen vessels supposed to be of Roman antiquity. In 1714, a large urn, full of Roman coins, was found buried under the ruins of an ancient building near the same place, and several brass statues of heathen deities were found crowded between flat stones and covered with Roman brick."-J. Goldsmith, The Present State of the British Empire (1768), 119 Wilts. Arch. Mag., XLV (1930-2), 176, referred to what was presumably the same hoard: "Rectangular earthwork enclosure on Roundway Hill.A small hoard of Roman coins is said to have been found in the bank of this enclosure but no details are known. Information from Mr. Richard Coward, formerly of Roundway."[See no. 1833]Undated."

name: PAS: Irchester 2937
comments: Robertson 421 no. 1780:""Fragments of a tessellated pavement and of Roman bricks, have been thrown up by the plough, and coins of Faustina, Adrianus, Gratianus, Antoninus, and Constantinus, have been found here.In an orchard belonging to Captain Ekins were lately found forty-five brass coins in an urn, with a ring and chain hanging to it."J. Bridges, Hist. and Ant. of Northants., ed. Whalley (1791), II, 181Undated"

name: PAS: Welton 2938
comments: Robertson 2000, 427 no. 1857:""We cannot satisfactorily account for the great number [i.e. of Roman coins] found singly dispersed over large tracts of country where they could not have been hid with a view to being afterwards dug up again, for when that has been the case they are found in numbers deposited in one place as was lately the case at New Village, near Welton."-T. Thompson, Researches into the Hist. of Welton and its Neigbourhood (1869), 145f.Undated"

name: PAS: Southwark (Park St.) 2939
comments: Robertson 2000, 430-431 no. 1900:""In 1786, the vessel No. 2, plate I, was discovered in digging a well for a steam engine on the premises of Messrs. Barclay and Perkins, in Park Street, near the spot where the Globe Theatre formerly stood; it contained several Roman coins, is composed of coarse red earth, and the exterior glazed with a brown glazing, the dimensions are six inches in height by four and a quarter in diameter."-W. Taylor, Annals of St. Mary Overy (1833), 9, pl. I, fig. 2 The description and figure of the vessel shows that it was a mediaeval, glazed jug with one handle. It seems very doubtful whether the coins found in it were Roman.Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Maltmas 2940
comments: Robertson 2000, 416 no. 1708: ""A hoard of coins and 'tons' of pottery said to have been found south of the house [i.e. Maltmas farm-house] about 1910. The pottery was used to make up the farm roads. (Information from Mr. Walter Warby)."G. Fowler, in Proc. Cambs. Ant. Soc., XLIII (1949-50), 15; App. II, by E.J. Rudsdale and W. WarbyUndated"

name: PAS: Myerscough 2941
comments: Robertson 2000, 420 no. 1761:""Not many years agoe, within the parke afforesaid in digging or cleansing of a ditch was found a Roman urne, in which was found great store of antient coynes, most of which I myself have seene, and were for some yeares after carefully preserved or bestowed on friends by that ingenious gentleman, Edward Towneley, esq., the proprietor, and owner, of the parke of ground where this urn was found."Kuerden Mss. Vol. vi, fol. 121, cap ii, in Herald's College; quoted by W.T. Watkin, Roman Lancashire (1886), 231, adding that the hoard has been completely lost sight of.Undated"

name: PAS: Uley 2942
comments: Structure VIII Phases 4 & 5a-c, within cella centrally placed pit F19 whose lower layers (18 & 208) contained cu alloy rings & 'groups of coins similar to those found in the main fill, context 17, above' (Woodward & Leach 1993: 34).

name: PAS: Bridlington (Prince Street) 2943
comments: Robertson 2000, 425 no. 1840:""There is a tradition in the town that a hoard of Roman coins was found in Prince Street, near the harbour; if so, it has disappeared."-Mary Kitson Clark, Gazetteer of Roman Remains in E. Yorks. (1935), 69Undated"

name: PAS: Llanymynech 2944
comments: Robertson 2000, 427 no. 1864:"[a] "Some years ago an urn was discovered by an old man while removing some of the 'raffle' or refuse stone, etc. from the quarry. It contained a large number of gold and silver coins, as well as bronze; many of which were identified as Roman. These were all disposed of to visitors for a trifle and doubtless the urn has found a resting place in the cabinet of some antiquarian visitor. [b] Another urn was also discovered but this one shared a curious fate. The person who found it had some misgivings as to whether he would be deemed the lawful owner, and consequently allowed his treasure to remain, it is supposed, where he discovered it, but as may be expected carried off many of the coins at intervals. Returning one day to again open the urn he found a large quantity of raffle had been carried to the place and completely buried it.[c] Another large find took place within the present century, and like the above, has been a 'family secret'. The parties forwarded the coins to the British Museum, and were amply repaid in current coin, which was apparently of more value to them. They are there to be seen in a cabinet, simply labelled 'Shropshire'."-J. Fawtrell, in Montgomerys. Coll., XI (1878), 205f.The coins from the last-mentioned find have not been located in the BM. It is uncertain whether the coins from the second and third finds were Roman. The first hoard, however, seems to have been Roman.(a) Undated(b) Uncertain if Roman(c) Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Caldey Island 2945
comments: Robertson 2000, 427-428 no. 1866:""A letter to Edward Lhuyd, dated 1693 (Ms. Ashmole, 1815, fol. 434), mentions the discovery on Caldey Island of an urn containing a glass vessel and many Roman coins."-RCHM Pembrokeshire (1925), 43, no. 98In a letter, Jan. 1953, Dr. J.N.L. Myres, when Bodley's Librarian, stated that the reference to Ms. Ashmole, 1815, must be wrong, as it has no fol. 434.Undated"

name: PAS: Benfleet 2946
comments: Robertson 2000, 418 no. 1736 (Benfleet): "Unlocated. It was reported in the 18th cent. that a man ditching in a field 'in the parish of Belfleet' found an urn containing 1,500 Roman coins (Bodl. Ms. Top. Essex b. 4f. 171)."VCH 3, Roman Essex (1963), 48Undated"

name: PAS: Alcester 2947
