comments: Robertson 2000, 424 no. 1823:"4 June 1812Mr. (J.) Brandish exhibited to the Society an additional quantity of Roman copper Coins, lately discovered in a gravel pit, adjacent to the town of Alcester, in Warwickshire."-Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., XXXIII (1808-11), 148Undated"

name: PAS: Eastington 2948
comments: Robertson 2000, 418 no. 1743:""I am informed that a labourer, while digging in his garden some years ago, turned up an urn full of Roman coins. They were, I am told, of the size of a halfpenny, but whether they were of early Emperors or the Follis of Diocletian I could not learn. This was not many hundred yards from the ancient camp known as Ranbury Rings."J.Y. Akerman, 21 Dec. 1865, in PSA (2), III (1864-7), 203f.Undated"

name: PAS: Warlingham 2949
comments: Robertson 2000,  424 no. 1821:"21 March 1895."Granville Leveson-Gower, Esq. M.A., V.P., Local Secretary for Surrey, exhibiteda bronze brooch, a ring, and eight defaced Roman coins found at Whiteleaf, Warlingham."-PSA (2), XV (1893-5), 357Undated"

name: PAS: Howden 2950
comments: Robertson 2000, 426 no. 1845:"15 Nov. 1770"Several Urns & Roman Coins were lately found about 3 miles E. by North of Howden."-Letter of Dr. Burton to Dr. Ducarel, in Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., XII (1770-3), 11Also in Arch., II (1773), 181Undated"

name: PAS: St Paul's Cray 2951
comments: Robertson 2000, 430 no. 1896:""A certain John Peret of St. Mary Cray found at St. Paul's Cray an earthenware jar called an erthencrokke with gold and silver in it, but how much they knew not; the gold and silver is in possession of Thomas Knooyle of St. Mary Cray who is responsible for it to the King"-Inquisitio Post Mortem on Thomas Squirry of West Wickham, died April, 14 Henry VI [i.e. 1435-1436]Quoted by B.H.St.J. O'Neil, in NC, 1935, 66f.Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Oxton 2952
comments: Robertson 2000, 421 no. 1787:""1765. A vessel filled with Roman coins was during the summer of this year dug up at a place called 'Robin Hood's Pot', on the road to Rufford. Many of these coins, some of a scarce class were purchased by John Newton, Esq., of Bulwell Hall."T. Bailey, Annals of Notts., III (1852-5), 1277VCH Notts., II (1910), 33, noted that "Robin Hood's Pot" was then called "Robin Hood's Hill."Undated"

name: PAS: Compton 2953
comments: Robertson 2000, 416 no. 1704:""As a labourer was ploughing on this spot [i.e. Perborough Castle] some years since, he discovered an earthen vessel full of ancient coins, which he secretly disposed of, but there can be little doubt that these coins were Roman."W. Hewett, Hist. and Ant. of Hundred of Compton (1844), 72Undated"

name: PAS: Kirkby Ravensworth 2954
comments: Robertson 2000, 426 no. 1848:""This [i.e. a tumulus near Castlesteads] is said to have contained a stone chest, or coffin, and by the side of it a cael pot, containing coins, but the discovery of the coins is disputed."(Footnote: "James Coates, an old resident of Kirkby Ravensworth says that 'his father was quarrying stones at the time when he broke into the place: and in the square coffin was a cael pot, but what was in it is unknown, though it was said at the time that his father had found money in it.' August 1848.")-H. MacLauchlan, in AJ, VI (1849), 343Undated"

name: PAS: Darfield 2955
comments: Robertson 2000, 425 no. 1841:""July 30, 1696. This day I was with one Mr. Cook, who says that as his brother was plowing on the fields of Darfield in Yorkshire about sixteen years ago, his plow bare a all [sic] the earth of a great pott like a butter pott which, he taking notice of, he found and discovered that it was top full of all Roman coins amongst which was several of gold, which he carry'd home, and, sending for a goldsmith he sold them to him for one pound, tho' they were worth above three times as much as he gave for them."-Diary of Abraham de la Pryme (1672-1704), ed. Surtees Soc., (1870), 108Undated silver (?) and gold coins."

name: PAS: York 2956
comments: Robertson 2000, 431 no. 1907:""New StreetA coin hoard of 'several hundred coins' found in a 'wooden box' is reported from the site, but no evidence has been found of its fate."-J. Radley, in Yorks. Arch. Register, 1967, Yorks. A.J., 42 (1967-7), 118Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Old London Bridge 2957
comments: Robertson 2000, 421 no. 1774:"28 Jan. 1853"Mr S.I. Tucker exhibited a Roman urn dug up at the time when Old London Bridge was pulled down. It is perfect, and has two handles. When discovered it contained various Roman coins."JBAA, VIII (1853), 54Undated"

name: PAS: Bathford 2958
comments: Robertson 2000, 422 no. 1796:"About the same time [i.e. about 1691] were discovered two Roman altars and an urn filled with coins of that people."J. Collinson, Hist. and Ant. of Somerset (1791), I, 111 VCH Somerset, I (1911), 300, was misled by a reference in Gough's Camden (1806), I, 118, to the discovery of a mosaic pavement and hypocaust at Bathford, into stating that the urn of coins was found in a Roman villa.Undated. "

name: PAS: Greatford 2959
comments: Robertson 2000, 420 no. 1769:""Numerous coins found c. 1824 in a gravel pit by Mr. W. Bland, farmer of Baston."O.S. Records: TF II SWUndated"

name: PAS: Roundway 2960
comments: Robertson 2000, 425 no. 1833:"In 1922, Miss Maria Coward presented to the Devizes Museum the "handle and upper part of a bronze jug; length of handle 3½ in., width of rim, 3¼ in. On the inside of the trefoil lip to which the handle was attached is the maker's name stamp - ASPIIR (for ASPER). Mr. Reginald Smith believes it to be of Italian make of late first or early second century date..The jug had no label but Miss Coward states that she always understood that it had been dug up on Roundway Hill with coins. A letter to Mr. Coward, from the late James Brown of Salisbury, dated 1878, contains a reference to the vessel with sketches for its proposed restoration, one sketch being indicated as 'the form most likely selected to contain coins (if any were found in it)'. It appears therefore that some previous mention of coins had been made in connection with the vessel."-Wilts. Arch. Mag., XLII (1924), 272, 601, fig. of bronze jugIt is possible that the bronze jug was the urn found with coins on Roundway Hill in 1714 [no. 1832].Piece of bronze jug now in Devizes MuseumExamined, 1960, 1978 (ASR)Undated"

name: PAS: Cottenham 2961
comments: 16 coins fused together seen in a collection of detector finds reported to HER.

name: PAS: Oldlands 2962
comments: Robertson 2000, 430 no. 1895:""I interviewed an interesting old man named Esau Lott, who was born in 1813, and in full possession of all his faculties. He informed me that about fifty years ago an urn containing coins was found in a field close to Little Buckland, formerly called 'Old Lands'."-G. Payne, in Arch. Cant., XXIV (1900), Proc., liiUncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Minskip 2963
comments: Robertson 2000, 426 no. 1850:""The only unrecorded hoard that I know of was found at Minskip near Aldborough about fifty years ago. It was found on land farmed by a man named Goland, and was contained in an earthenware vessel found while draining. The coins were all bronze and were taken away by the finder; the farmer reported the find to his landlord who was a clergyman, and he came over and recovered the urn and coins from the finder, taking the coins away and leaving the urn with Goland. I had this information from Goland many years ago, and the urn and another pot found at the same time were then lost. I have not been able to trace the coins."-Letter, Feb. 1936, from B.J.W. Kent, HarrogateUndated"

name: PAS: Kibworth 2964
comments: Robertson 2000, 420 no. 1764:""Two recently discovered hoards, one at Barrow, the other at Kibworth, seem to have been removed from the county."Rep. Assoc. Archit. Soc., V (1859), 310Undated"

name: PAS: Chalton 2965
comments: Robertson 2000. 418 no. 1747 :"Only about five years since, a crock was dug up full of Roman coins, principally copper, which were disposed of at Portsmouth, before any person of intelligence was aware of the discovery."C.J. Longcroft, Hundred of Bosmere (1856), 123Undated"

name: PAS: Gwinear 2966
comments: Robertson 2000, 416 no. 1714: ""A quantity of Roman copper and silver coins was found about 20 years since, in digging for manure on the estate of Trungle."S. Lewis, Topog. Dict. of England (1842), s.v. GwinearUndated"

name: PAS: Kettering 2967
comments: Robertson 2000, 429 no. 1877:"14 Dec. 1726"Mr. [E.] Sawyer produced a parcel of coins wch were found near Kettering in the field [sic] C. Caesar Germanicus Rv. Agrippina Drusilla Julia Trajan M. Aurel Faustina Gordian Antonia Augusta Claudius Constantinus Maximianus Middle Brass Carausius Allectus &C."-Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., I (1717-32), 195The range of emperors is unlikely for a hoard.Undatable"

name: PAS: Kiddington 2968
comments: Robertson 2000, 422 no. 1792:""'At the beginning of the seventies one of my brothers picked up more than eighty Roman silver coins, and part of a Roman broach [sic] and a bit of silver about 4 or 5 in. long. He found parts of an earthen vessel in which it may have been buried. It seems it had been turned up and broken by the plough-share: it was woodland just brought into cultivation: plowmen had not noticed it. My brother, walking over, had his attention drawn to it. This was on the Assarts Farm, adjoining Hill Wood.'Letter from George Busby, of Kiddington, to Percy Manning, 4. IV. 1899; Manning Mss. in Ashmolean Museum, OxfordThis reference is not to be identified with the mention, on the 6-in. O.S. map of Oxfordshire, of 'Roman Coins Found' at Out Wood, near Kiddington. It is not even certain that the O.S. reference denotes a hoard. Inquiries have brought no further details of this Kiddington silver hoard to light."VCH Oxfords., I (1939), 329Undated"

name: PAS: Brandon 2969
comments: Robertson 2000, 423 no. 1810: ""Other but less important finds [i.e. of Roman coins] have been made at Brandon."-G.E. Fox, in AJ, XLVI (1889), 338"BRANDON, Fenhouse Farm: Villa?:.There seems very good reason for supposing a villa here. Fox (map V) gives symbols for settlement, a coin hoard and a burial in this area."-C.W. Phillips, ed., The Fenland in Roman times (1970), 248Undated"

name: PAS: Street Or Winsham 2970
comments: Robertson 2000, 423 no. 1805:""In the year 1684, an urn containing many Roman coins was found betwixt this village [Strate] and Winsham."-J. Collinson, Hist. and Ant. of Somerset (1791), II, 479Undated"

name: PAS: Brightwell Baldwin 2971
comments: Robertson 2000, 422 no. 1789:""They write from Watlington that as a Farmer was plowing about three Weeks ago, in the Common field in the Parish of Brightwell, he found an urn containing near 1500 Roman Coins: About 1200 of them have been already examined among which were found Coins belonging to near twenty different Emperors and Empresses some of which had very curious Reverses."Jackson's Oxford Journal, 23 June 1759Undated"

name: PAS: Newark 2972
comments: Robertson 2000, 421 no. 1786:""He [i.e. Mr. Warburton of Newark] told me likewise a pot of roman money was found at Carlton-scrope [i.e. near the Fosse Roadside]." W. Stukeley, Itin. Cur. (1724), 99Undated"

name: PAS: Exmoor 2973
comments: Robertson 2000, 417 no. 1728:""Several urns with Roman coins have been found in the barrows" [i.e. at Exmoor]T. Reynolds, Iter Britannicum (1799), 439Undated"

name: PAS: Ilkley 2974
comments: Robertson 2000, 426 no. 1847:""About twenty other Roman coins were found on the site of the new bridge at Ilkley of about six different kinds."-A. Dodgson and others, in Thoresby Soc. Misc., XXII (1912), 52Undated"

name: PAS: Buxton 2975
comments: Robertson 2000, 417 no. 1726:""At Buxton a find of coins, about a dozen in number, have turned up, of what dates I have not heard."F. Haverfield in Antiquary, XXV (1892), 22Undated"

name: PAS: Shirley (and Croham) 2976
comments: Robertson 2000, 424 no. 1816/1817:""An old inhabitant (Dr. Westall) writing on the 16th of January, 1874, observes: 'I can remember a considerable number of Roman coins being found some thirty years since at Shirley, and others rather later, at Croham'."-J. Corbet Anderson, Croydon: Prehistoric and Roman (1874), 71VCH Surrey, IV (1912), 361, gave a very confused account of these finds.(Croydon: Shirley): Undated(Croydon: Croham): Undated"

name: PAS: Crowland 2977
comments: Robertson 2000, 428 no. 1874:""1 June, 1758. I bought a good many Roman coyns found in a pot at Aswic, near Crowland, some silver, Augustus, Tiberius, a brass Otho, two Carausius, others of all times of the Empire."W. Stukeley, Letters and Diaries, ed. Surtees Soc., II (1883), 310See (Whaplode), c. 1753 (Lincs.) [no. 1874A]The account of the composition of the hoard is unlikely.Undatable."Robertson 2000, 428 no. 1874: "A ref. in C.W. Phillips, ed., The Fenland in Roman times (1970), 300, to a hoard found at Aswic, has misled later writers to assign a hoard to Whaplode. The "Aswic" find was made at Crowland (c. 1758) [no.1874]."

name: PAS: Arlesey 2978
comments: HER reference to the findspot of a Roman coin hoard, without further details. The site was investigated in 1972 but may have been found earlier (the source appears to be OS Archaeology record cards).

name: PAS: Owslebury 2979
comments: Hoard of three siliquae. No further information.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2011 T049

name: PAS: Rowlands Castle 2980
comments: Possible report of a hoard "complete pot and coins" and footings of a Roman wall found to the north of Rowlands Castle before 1961.

name: PAS: Ewerby or Rauceby 2981
comments: Robertson 2000, 420 no. 1766:""An old man of Ancaster told me that by Ureby, or Roseby, a plough-man toke up a stone, and found another stone under it, wherein was a square hole having Romaine quoin in it."J. Leland, Itinerary (1535-43), I, fol. 31, ed. Lucy Toulmin Smith, I (1907), 28W. Harrison, Description of Britaine, 2 ed. (1586), II, 17, wrongly assumed "Ureby, or Roseby" to be the name of the ploughman who found the coins, and misled later writers into doing the same."Roseby" is presumably Rauceby, NE of AncasterC.W. Phillips ed., The Fenland in Roman Times (1970), 271, recorded this find under EWERBY ("Ureby"), which is farther to the NE of Ancaster.Undated"

name: PAS: Tickenham 2982
comments: Robertson 2000, 423 no. 1806:""Under it [i.e. Cadbury Camp] near Tickenham, Roman coins have been dug, many of which were in the possession of the late Sir Abraham Elton, Bart., of Clevedon."-W. Barrett, Hist. and Ant. of City of Bristol (1789), I, 19H.M. Scarth, in JBAA, XIII (1857), 113, recorded what appears to be the same find, as follows:- "In the rampart of this camp [i.e. Cadbury Camp] I understand a pot of coins was some time since discovered, which have unfortunately been dispersed."Undated"

name: PAS: Cirencester 2983
comments: Robertson 2000, 430 no. 1891:""By the town [i.e. of Cirencester] nostris temporibus was fownd a broken shank bone of a horse, the mouth closed with a pegge, the which taken owt a shepard founde yt fillid nummis argenteis."-J. Leland, Itinerary (1535-43) VI, fol. 65; ed. Lucy Toulmin Smith (1906), 101Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Canterbury 2984
comments: Robertson 2000, 412 no. 1666:"22 Feb. 1759"Mr. E. Jacob informs us, that some years since there was dug up in the Garden adjoining to the back part of the same House [i.e. the house in whose garden a Roman pavement was discovered] a considerable number of Roman Coins, chiefly of the lower Empire, and of Brass. The Gent. who found them was strongly of Opinion that more might have been discovered upon a further search."Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., VIII (1757-62), 130f."Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Norwich 2985
comments: 3 Roman gold coins and jewellery. 'Sweetbriar Road petrol station, while digging hole for storage tank. 3 Roman gold coins and jewellery. Information via A Gregory (Norfolk Archaeological Unit) but material not seen at Norwich Castle Museum.'

name: PAS: Leigh-On-Sea 2986
comments: Robertson 2000, 418: "At Leigh, by the fall of a cliff after rains, a quantity of Roman coins came to light, 176."Gough's Camden (1789), II, 52Undated"

name: PAS: Fenny Bentley 2987
comments: Robertson 2000, 417 no. 1727:""Mr. Degge, who resided at Fenny Bentley at the time Mr. Wolley wrote his Ms. history of the county (1712) had an urn and coins of the Roman period, which had been there discovered."T. Bateman, Vestiges of Ant. of Derbs. (1848), 158Undated"

name: PAS: Hockwold I 2988
comments: Robertson 2000, 431: " "There was a hoard of coins found at Hockwold in 1885 and a plan showing the position exists in the Museum of Archaeology at Cambridge, but the coins have disappeared and no one knows anything about their contents. This hoard may be Roman but is more likely to be a confusion with a hoard found in this parish of 500 silver pennies of Henry II and III."-Letters, 1938, 1952, from R.R. Clarke, Norwich Castle MuseumC.W. Phillips ed., The Fenland in Roman Times (1970), 240, recorded this find as a "Roman coin hoard", but without adding to the information given above.Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Nantwich (Marsh Lane) 2989
comments: Robertson 2000, 416 no. 1713"Mr. James Pick of Nantwich has twelve Roman copper coins, two of which are in excellent preservation. They were unearthed many years ago in Marsh Lane, Nantwich [no. 1713]. No other Roman remains, either iron or pottery, I believe, were found in these localities."J. Hall, in Palatine Notebook, I, (1881), 199; and in Hist. of the Town and Parish of Nantwich (1883), 8"

name: PAS: Ramsey 2990
comments:
Robertson 2000, 419 no. 1750A: ""anno 1721 many pecks of roman coyns were found there. Probably from the name we may conjecture it was a roman town."
-W. Stukeley, Itin. Cur. (1724), 77
"See before, p. 141 [i.e. for the March, 1730 (Cambs.) hoard, no. 321] These are the coins which Dr. Stukeley, Itin. Cur. I, p. 77, says were found at Ramsey, 1721.")
- Camden and Gough's Britannia II, (1789), 159 n.
Gough's suggestion is unfounded. The Ramsey hoard contained "many pecks" of coins, is said to have been found in 1721, and can have been found no later than 1724. The March hoard is securely dated to 1730, and contained "a Quart" of coins, c. 400 pieces.
Undated"

name: PAS: Wroxeter 2991
comments: Robertson 2000, 422 no. 1795:"Parkes, in his Mss. Add. 21180, fol. 78, figures two "Roman Urns, containing silver and copper coins, found at Wroxeter." VCH Shrops., I (1908), 256, noted that "this is probably a distinct hoard, or pair of hoards, being found earlier than that noted by Wright."Undated"

name: PAS: Milland 2992
comments: Robertson 2000, 424 no. 1822:""Hard by, at Milland [i.e. N.N.W. of Iping] an urn, containing a quantity of Roman coins, is said to have been dug up within the area of a fortified camp on the hill over Milland Place."-P.M. Johnston, in Sussex Arch. Coll., LII (1909), 194Undated"

name: PAS: Littleborough 2993
comments: Robertson 2000, 420 no. 1759:""James Schofield, Esq., of Stubley Hall, near Littleborough, informs me that when his father was excavating for the foundations of the new hall, he found an urn containing a number of Roman coins, 'also a cup'. This hoard was dispersed; some of the coins being given to the late Miss Newall, and it is not known what eventually became of them, or of the remainder."W.T. Watkins, Roman Lancashire (1886), 232Undated"

name: PAS: Fawler 2994
comments: Robertson 2000, 422 no. 1790:""About sixty years ago, the grubbing up of a tree in Ashe Close brought to light a quantity of Roman coins, mostly silver together with some broken pottery. Most of the coins were dispersed but the then Duke of Marlborough got a quantity."P. Manning, in Berks. Bucks. and Oxon. A.J., IV (1899), 17VCH Oxfords., I (1939), 329, stated that "Mr. L.G.B. Sacre, Land Agent to the present Duke, has very kindly sought for these coins at Blenheim, without success; and he reports that he has never heard of the existence of any collection of Roman coins at the palace."Undated"

name: PAS: Caernarvon 2995
comments: Robertson 2000, 431 no. 1909:""Near it [i.e. the Roman fort at Caernarvon] was found not many years ago a brass pot [no. 1908] full of money under a tree. Another [no. 1909] the winter before I was there near the gallows on the bank of the marsh by the river side."Gough's Camden (1789), II, p. 556Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Carn Brea 2996
comments: Robertson 2000, 417 no. 1718:"Carnbrea. "I believe that another hoard has been found in the last few years, but I have failed to get details."F. Haverfield, in VCH Cornwall, 5 (1924), 34Undated"

name: PAS: Mildenhall 2997
comments: Robertosn 2000, 425 no. 1830:"In Wilts. Arch. Register for 1978/9 (Wilts. Arch. Mag., 74-5 (1978-9), 206): "Mildenhall. Black Field. Collection of 853 coins ex Revd. C. Soames col. Devizes 97/1978."Letter, Oct. 1988, from Dr. P.H. Robinson, Devizes Museum, stating that there was "no evidence that a hoard was included among these."Undated"

name: PAS: Llangybi 2998
comments: Robertson 2000, 427 no. 1859:""Thirty-seven Roman coins were found on the farm of Tan-y-fforest, Llangybi, Cardiganshire, between 1830 and 1840 by the late Mr. Stephen Davies, the tenant. They were discovered in turf while stacking the yard."-Canon Ellis Davies, in Arch. Camb., 73 (1918), 362Undated"

name: PAS: Hughenden 2999
comments: Robertson 2000, 416 no. 1707:""In 1826, a labourer in trenching a piece of garden ground, which he had taken from the common near Hazlemere Turnpike Gate, turned up a small urn in which were four small silver Roman coins in good preservation and three copper coins much defaced."G. Lipscomb, Hist. of Bucks. (1847), 583Undated"

name: PAS: Uppingham 3000
comments: Robertson 2000, 431 no. 1904:""Near 200 pieces of antient silver coin being discovered at the house of Cornelius Nutt at Uppington [i.e. Uppingham], in Rutlandshire, a report was spread that the man's daughter had been informed of the place where they were hid in a dream. Be that as it may, some of the coins are said to be very valuable."-Gent. Mag., 1764, 301Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Fawler 3001
comments: Robertson 2000, 422 no. 1791:""About thirty years ago, during the digging of a drain to dry a piece of swampy land in Bury Close, the labourers found a Roman tessellated pavement beneath which was a hypocaust. At the same time a number of small silver coins and a quantity of broken pottery were found. The pavement was covered up again by order of the Duke of Marlborough and still remains untouched.The site is at the south end of Fawler village, between the southernmost cottages and the railway, close to the bank of the Ewenlode, and to the railway bridge which here crosses the river (Information from Thomas Eden, of Fawler, 1895)."P. Manning, in Berks. Bucks. and Oxon. A.J., IV (1898), 17Undated"

name: PAS: Edlington 3002
comments: Robertson 2000, 426 no. 1843:""It is scarcely deserving notice that hoards have been discovered at Alkley, Edlington, Clifton and elsewhere."-J. Hunter, South Yorks: Hist. of Doncaster, I (1828), Int. vUndated"

name: PAS: Fishguard 3003
comments: Robertson 2000, 428 no. 1867:""Twlay. 'Roman urn and coins' found in 1823. O.S. IX N.E. 10."-BBCS, IV (1929), 267Undated"

name: PAS: Puncknowle 3004
comments: Robertson 2000,  418 no. 1734:""About 1200 coins were turned up by the ploughshare in the year 1791 in an arable field known by the name of Walls. They had been deposited in an earthen vessel the form of which was not discernible, being almost entirely decayed by time."J. Hutchins, Hist. and Ant. of Dorset, 3 ed., II (1863), 769Undated"

name: PAS: Pantibigni 3005
comments: Robertson 2000, 428 no. 1868:""In the year 1828, according to the Ord. sheet [...] 'Roman coins' were found on the summit of Begney. No particulars of this hoard could be traced. One small silver coin of the find - too much worn for identification, but undoubtedly Roman - is carefully treasured up by a lady in the near locality, to whom it passed from her grandfather, who had been present at the discovery. Seen, 15th. June, 1920."-RCHM Pembrokeshire (1925), 169, no. 485Undated"

name: PAS: Bury Farm Manor 3006
comments: Robertson 2000, 418 no. 1748:""In digging the foundations [i.e. of Bury Farm Manor]a considerable number of Roman coins were discovered, most of them are still in the possession of Sir Charles."Brayley and Britton, Beauties of England and Wales, VI (1805), 202Undated."

name: PAS: Wellingborough 3007
comments: `Roman gold coins'. Recorded in Northants. Museum as 3 coins found in 1960

name: PAS: Eccleshill 3008
comments: Robertson 2000, 419 no. 1754:""A stone cross 2 ft. high, with some Roman coins under it, was found near Guide about 1865 on the direct line of the Roman road from Ribchester through Blackburn to Manchester."VCH Lancs. VI (1911), 278, from a lecture given by the Rev. R. N. Whitaker, vicar of Whalley in 1867Undated"

name: PAS: Derwen 3009
comments: Robertson 2000, 427 no. 1861:""The house and holding next to Ffynnon Sara is called Pwllan Perl. I well remember men in digging in a field close to this place coming upon a large number of coins of the size of sixpences. Owing to their rusted condition it was impossible to tell what letter or images they bore. The man who lived at Pwllan had the money, because this place and Ffynnon Sara were fresh old land."-Y Brython (1891), 326Translated by Canon Ellis Davies, Prehistoric and Roman Remains in Denbighs. (1929), 109Undated"

name: PAS: Hainton 3010
comments: Robertson 2000, 420 no. 1770:""At Haynton, the seat of George Robert Heneage, esq.; 12 miles from Lincoln, and eight from Louth, was found in digging foundations for a dog kennel a large posnet pot with three feet and a handle, full of various Roman silver coins, worth £80. Mr. Heneage gave the finder £10."Gough's Camden (1789), II, 275The pot does not sound like a Roman pot.Undated"

name: PAS: Astwick 3011
comments: HER reference to the findspot of a Roman coin hoard "in 1870-50", without further details. The source appears to be OS Archaeology record cards. Possibly radiates:  The HER record states "A single coin of Claudius II is recorded as being in Letchworth Museum, and may be from this hoard".

name: PAS: Trefeglwys 3012
comments: Robertson 2000, 431 no. 1910:""Some years ago an urn was found near the farm house of Ffinant in the parish of Trefeglws, containing a quantity of coin, and ashes of a dark colour. The person removing the urn broke it accidentally to fragments. One of the coins is now in the possession of Mr. Powell of Trewythen."-T.W. Hancock, in Arch. Camb., 3 (1848), 93Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Great Tew 3013
comments: Robertson 2000, 422 no. 1794:""There were also found several large ornamental red jars and coins of copper and brass, the copper much defaced but the brass in a good state of preservation (Account furnished by Mr. Nash to Brewer's Oxfordshire).At the distance of about 200 yards from this site, in forming a road on the north-east side in 1817, a pot of Roman coins was discovered (Information from Mr. Bolton, Esq., of Great Tew)."A. Beesley, Hist. of Banbury (1841), 41Undated"

name: PAS: Dorking 3014
comments: Robertson 2000,  424 no. 1818:""In 1911 a pot with Roman coins was found, but no note of the coins was made (Inf. Mr. H.E. Malden)."-VCH Surrey, IV (1912), 361Undated"

name: PAS: Deal 3015
comments: Robertson 2000, 430 no. 1892:""An urn containing silver coins thought to be Roman, was dug up in a field near Deal about 1765."-VCH Kent, III (1932), 152, without giving any authorityUncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Membury 3016
comments: Robertson 2000, 417 no. 1729:""In a lane leading from the village of Wambrook to Baalay down, in direct communication with the camp at Membury, and about two miles distant from it, there was discovered, some years ago, a very large quantity of Roman coins, to an amount so considerable that the place from that time has borne the name of 'Money-pit-lane'."J.B. Davidson, The British and Roman Remains in the Vicinity of Axminster (1833), 85Undated"

name: PAS: Millington 3017
comments: Robertson 2000, 426 no. 1849:"About half a mile north east of Millington, in the year 1845, the foundations of a circular building, and of two oblong buildings were found as well as Roman pavements, tiles, various other relics, and a hoard of Roman coins."-J.J. Sheahan and T. Whellan, Hist. and Topog. of Yorks. (1856), II, 562Undated"

name: PAS: Westleton 3018
comments: Robertson 2000, 423 no. 1813:"Jany. 18, 1848Lord Huntingfield gave me the following account of a discovery on his estate.In the year 1845, as some labourers were trenching some land for planting on the Scot Hall Farm, one of them struck his pickaxe into the side of an earthern pot, from whence fell about 18 or 20 pieces of coin. These were Roman, a few of them silver, the rest brass; they were greatly corroded, and the legends not easy to be made out, and none of them ascertained. The pot was of coarse earth, very thick; the sides near 1/2 an inch, and the bottom two or more; it was taken out whole, except where the pickaxe had broken a hole. There was also found near it, another smaller pot, wch. was broken in pieces, and contained nothing. The larger pot was about 8 or 10 inches high. The pot and the coins are now in Ld. H's possession.The soil in which these were found was of a very hard nature, and the stratum which immediately covered them, was about 3 inches thick, of a blackish colour, and so hard that the pickaxe could with difficulty break through it."Davy, Suffolk Coll. BM Mss. VII, 19083, fol. 132Undated"

name: PAS: Ramsgate 3019
comments: Robertson 2000, 419 no. 1752:""An urn containing 120 Roman coins, also Roman vases with a skeleton on the east side of the Margate Road by Hollowcombe Down, in the grounds of the S.E. College.Mr. W.H. Hills, 42 King St. Ramsgate, 1891."G. Payne, , Collectanea Cantiana (1895), 202Undated"

name: PAS: Evenley 3020
comments: Robertson 2000, 428-429 no. 1876:""In 1826, during the irrigation of a field in this lordship called Addington's Meadow, near the River Ouse in the direction of Brackley, were found several hundred Roman coins of Nero, Domitian, Alexander, Probus, Constantine and other emperors."-G. Baker, Hist. and Ant. of Northants., I (1822-30), 617The range of emperors is unlikely.Undatable"

name: PAS: Limpsfield 3021
comments: Robertson 2000,  424 no. 1820:""There exists also another earthwork, now in great part obliterated, which runs over a part of Limpsfield Common, called Cearn Bank, at no great distance from the woods there called the Chart. About forty years ago a workman in digging stones along the line of it came upon a quantity of Roman copper coins, but I have been unable to find out what became of them."(Footnote: "From information communicated to me by H. Cox. Esq., of Trevereux, Limpsfield. This gentleman has kindly presented me with three silver Roman coins, one of which, he believes that of Trajan, was found in his kitchen garden.")-G. Leveson-Gower, in Surrey Arch. Coll., IV (1869), 218Undated"

name: PAS: Llanwnog 3022
comments: Robertson 2000, 427 no. 1865:"Caersws. "I am credibly informed, that in the present century, a number of copper coins were found in a bottom below the town."-T. Pennant, Tour in Wales (1778), 425Undated"

name: PAS: Mildenhall 3023
comments: Robertson 2000, 423 no. 1812:""At Mildenhall (not the Mildenhall near to Marlborough) an old woman searching last spring for mushrooms found a 'canister' of Roman coins, weighing about five pounds."-F. Haverfield, in Antiquary, XXXIII (1897), 17Undated"

name: PAS: Swalcliffe 3024
comments: Robertson 2000, 431 no. 1902:""At the bottom of this hill [i.e. the hill on which Tadmarston Castle stands], on the west side, is a field, part of which is called Money Acre, from a pott of money found there near a hundred years since, and which, by the broken pieces of earthenware, and the richness of the soil, was certainly part of the old town."-Letter from Rev. F. Wise to Roger Gale, 13 Sept. 1732Quoted in Stukeley's Letters and Diaries, ed. Surtees Soc., III (1885), 156Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Aldington 3025
comments: Robertson 2000, 425 no. 1834:""Small Roman coins dug up in front of the manor house, coins etc. 'in a field on the left as you ascend the road from the bridge over the brook towards the railway' on the route from South Littleton to Bengeworth."-R.F. Tomes, in Berrow's Worcester Journal, 20 June 1891Undated"

name: PAS: Liddington 3026
comments: Robertson 2000, 431 no. 1903:"15 Jan. 1903"Some Lyddington men, working in a gravel pit at that village about 1862, found two small jars containing in all some 150 coins, mostly gold. These were claimed by the Crown, and the coroner collected as many as he could."-R. Haines, in PSA (2), XIX (1901-3), 201Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Maiden Castle 3027
comments: Account of a hoard of silver coins found in a peat bog near Maiden Castle around 1850.

name: PAS: Doncaster 3028
comments: Robertson 2000, 425-426 no. 1842:""It is scarcely deserving notice that hoards have been discovered at Alkley [i.e. in the parish of Doncaster], Edlington, Clifton and elsewhere."-J. Hunter, South Yorks: Hist. of Doncaster, I (1828), Int. vCp. Rotherham, c. 1828 (Yorks.) [no. 1701]Undated. Probably Auckley."

name: PAS: Great Chesterford 3029
comments: Robertson 2000, 418 no. 1738: ""Roman coins of the early as well as the later emperors have been found here; and, 1769, in digging down the walls to mend the road, a large parcel of very fine ones was found in a pot."Gough's Camden (1789), II, 62Undated"

name: PAS: South Petherton 3030
comments: Robertson 2000, 423 no. 1804:""In a field not far off [i.e. from Petherton bridge], two years ago, a pot full of Roman coyn to the quantity of six pecks was dug up."-W. Stukeley, Itin. Cur. (1724), 148Undated"

name: PAS: Great Barton 3031
comments: Robertson 2000, 423 no. 1809:""A fragment of a hoard on Red Castle Farm, Great Barton"-JRS, XLIV (1954), 97Undated"

name: PAS: Shirburn 3032
comments: Robertson 2000, 422 no. 1793:""a pot of Roman money was found at Sherburn in this neighbourhood last year."W. Stukeley, Itin. Cur. (1724), 41Undated"

name: PAS: Fleetwood 3033
comments: Robertson 2000, 419 no. 1755:""At Fleetwood, under the old Mount Pavilion, a hoard was found last January, in the sand. The coins were much corroded, and beyond the fact that the superscriptions were taken to be Roman, no details have reached me."F. Haverfield, in Antiquary, XXXVIII (1902), 176Undated"

name: PAS: Canterbury (Wincheap Green) 3034
comments: Robertson 2000, 419 no. 1751:"During the discovery of urns and burials at Wincheap Green, Canterbury: "among the objects found were a bronze utensil and a metal box of Roman coins."J. Brent, in JBAA, XXXIII (1877), 77 n.Undated"

name: PAS: Market Weighton 3035
comments: Pastscape / OS record of a tradition of a find of a "potful" of Roman coins in a field in which more recent finds have been made, including two coins of Claudius II.

name: PAS: March 3036
comments: Robertson 2000, 416 no. 1709:""A 'large pot' full of copper coins, found at March 'a few years since', i.e. before 1844 (Peckover MS)."G. Fowler, in Proc. Cambs. Ant. Soc., XLIII (1949-50), 16; App. II, by E.J. Rudsdale and W. WarbyUndated"HER 05915 suggests Hadrianic, if this is the same hoard?

name: PAS: Wing 3037
comments: HER record of a pot of Roman coins found whilst ploughing in the early years of the twentieth century. Reported as gold but it was later established that they were not. The finder reported seeing a 'circular platform' at the findspot.

name: PAS: Calne 3038
comments: Robertson 2000, 414 no. 1683:""At Calne incredibl [sic] numbers of roman coyn dug up."W. Stukeley, Itin. Cur. (1724), 137What was presumably the same find was referred to in W. Stukeley, Family Memoirs, I (ed. Surtees Soc., vol.73) (1880), 139:"At Chippenham, at Derry Hill [i.e. in the parish of Calne] Coyns found 1680." [no. 1828]Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., I (1718-32), 293, also referred to a find of coins, possibly the same find, at Calne:9 June 1732"Mr. West produced a fine Celt dug up lately with Several Roman Coins of the Lower Empire near Caln in Wiltshire.""Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Bristol (Temple Cloud) 3039
comments: Robertson 2000, 422 no. 1797:""On the very apex of this isolated eminenceRoman coins both of brass and silver have been discovered; of the latter a potful was dug up by a man repairing the hedge which bounded the camp to the west, which he took to Bristol and sold."J.D. Phelps, Hist. and Ant. of Somerset (1836), I, 150; quoting Skinner Ms. (c. 1818-24)Undated"

name: PAS: Manton 3040
comments: Robertson 2000, 420 no. 1772:""Roman coin hoard, details unknown, now lost."C.W. Phillips, in AJ, XCI (1934), 175Undated"

name: PAS: Ickworth 3041
comments: Robertson 2000, 423 no. 1811: ""It is said that in digging through the Devil's ditch on Newmarket heath near Ixning, they met with some antient pieces which Batteley was told were coins of Roman emperors."-Gough's Camden (1789), II, 81"A large pot of Roman coins found here is mentioned by Archdeacon Batteley."-VCH Suffolk, I (1911), 310, without giving a reference for the "large pot".Undated"

name: PAS: Y Felinheli 3042
comments: "Hoard of Roman Coins' found at 'Cae'r brenin, Gareg-goch' sometime before 1960" (Guest and Wells 1086). No further details given.

name: PAS: Clapton 3043
comments: Robertson 2000, 428 no. 1875:"(Low Leyton, Essex)9 Sept. 1783"As some men were emptying the lead mills, at Temple Mills, Hackney, which were repairing, they found an urn full of Roman coins, some of them in high preservation, with the impression of Julius Caesar and Constantine the Great, together with several medals; likewise a stone coffin, with the skeleton entire, measuring seven feet nine inches long; the inscription on the coffin is unintelligible; in removing the foundation a vault was discovered, in which were several urns, but quite imperfect: what is very remarkable, the vaults, for centuries past, are supposed to have been sixteen feet under water."-Annual Register, 1783, 216Gent. Mag., 1783, II, 899, referred to a newspaper account of the find, where the coins were said to range from Julius Caesar to Constantine the Great, but this may be a misquotation. Gent. Mag., loc. cit., also stated that inside the coffin, or in the mud outside it, were found an iron sword blade, an iron battleaxe, a padlock, a bronze helmet-crest, a bronze spur, and the rib-bone of some beast, "which probably fell in by accident." These objects were illustrated, and were all post-Roman. A little distance away, there were found two or three coins, one a large Roman brass, and another a Nuremberg counter.The account of this find is unsatisfactory.Undatable"

name: PAS: Willingham 3044
comments: Robertson 2000, 416 no. 1711: ""WILLINGHAM, Meadow Drove:It is said that coins in a pot were found here in 1902."C.W. Phillips ed., The Fenland in Roman Times (1970), 209, without giving any authorityUndated"

name: PAS: Reynard's Cave 3045
comments: Historic report of a hoard of Roman coins 'accidentally discovered' at the site (G H Wilson 1926, Some Caves and Crags of Peakland, p.11)

name: PAS: Holtye 3046
comments: Hoard of Roman coins (one silver and 10+ bronze) and associated pottery fragments. The coins were seized from the house of the finder by Kent police.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2008 T049Other PAS records associated with this hoard: KENT-FF2284

name: PAS: Rochdale 3047
comments: Robertson 2000, 9 no. 38;""A discovery made several years since at Castlemere, in the neighbourhood of Rochdale, and very near to the line of this Iter [i.e. from Manchester to Cambodunum] consisting of several coins of the middle brass and of the Higher Empire, one if I am not mistaken (for I am compelled to write from recollection) as early as Claudius."R.N. Whitaker, Hist. of Whalley, 4 ed. (1870), I, 45Including Claudius"

name: PAS: Winkfield 3049
comments: HER record of "a group of 2nd century sestertii which may have formed a hoard. Possibly associated with a bronze bowl spout". No further details available.

name: PAS: Bury St Edmunds Area 3050
comments: Robertson 2000, 75 no. 356:""60 denarii said by vendor to have come from Bury St. Edmunds area (Vendor could give no other information) c. mid 1st cent.-2nd cent [...]"-Notes in Ipswich MuseumCoins not seen, 1978 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Runton 3051
comments: HER record of a discovery in 1943 of a hoard of brass first century Roman coins from "Runton Cliff". No further information.

name: PAS: East Kirkby 3052
comments: 2 fused illegible denarii. NC 2011Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2009 T270Other PAS records associated with this hoard: NCL-D263D6

name: PAS: Bempton 3053
comments: Two burnt and fused silver denarii of Roman date. Both coins are distorted and have been rendered illegible. Diameter: 18.7mm; Thickness: 6.1mm; Weight: 8.9g.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2013 T907Other PAS records associated with this hoard: YORYM-387087

name: PAS: Capheaton 3054
comments: Robertson 2000, 421 no. 1784:""In the time of Sir John Swinburn, Bart. father of the late Sir John, some Roman sacra and coins were found by his labourers in making a cast for a hedge in a lane near his seat, called Silverlane from that discovery. They secreted all the coins and sold them. The sacra or sacrificing vessels were of silver. They sold most of these likewise, after breaking the bottoms out of some, and the handles and ornaments off others. They presented these following to Sir John, now in the possession of Sir Edward:"1. a sympalum, weighing 26 oz.2. the bottoms of 3 others3. the handles of 3 more, with beautiful figures in relief and gilt4. part of a handle5. a figure of Antaeus and Hercules wrestling6. a Neptune"The lane in which these antiquities were found is only about a mile from the Roman causeway."J.H. Wallis, Hist. of Northumberland (1769), II, 535The 9 silver frags. are now in the Dept. of Prehistoric and Romano-British Antiquities, BM. They are a plain patera, and the bottoms of three others; four patera-handles ornamented in high relief; and a medallion showing Hercules and Antaeus wrestling, and a Neptune. The silver is believed to be of the time of SeverusUndated?, or Severan?"

name: PAS: Manchester (Castlefield) 3055
comments: Robertson 2000, 234 no. 957:""Mr. J.J. Phelps recovered from a scrap-book once belonging to Mr. John Harland, F.S.A., a well-known antiquarian of fifty years ago, a cutting (now in the Free Reference Library) which contains a report furnished to the Manchester Guardian of a meeting of the 'Rosicrucian Society'.From information as to the Society gleaned from other sources Mr. Phelps has now identified the date of the newspaper cutting as Feb. 18, 1858. The set of coins exhibited and described is said in the report to have been selected from a much larger number found at various times in Castlefield, but 'some of them were found in a pot unearthed about 15 years ago', i.e. presumably between 1840 and 1850. Unfortunately nothing is said as to the character of the pot; an ancient hoard of genuine Republican coins, such as a number of these appear to have been would have been a novel and very instructive picture in the record of the Manchester area."Then came a list of 48 den. from Castlefield, not all of which, however, came from the pot:Den.Republic 20Tiberius 1Galba 2 Vitellius 1Vespasian 7Titus 3Domitian 3Nerva 1Trajan 3Sabina 1Antoninus Pius 1Faustina II 2Caracalla 1Julia Maesa 1Severus Alexander 148-R.S. Conway, J. MacInnes and G.C. Brooke, "The Roman Coins of Manchester", appendix to F.A. Bruton, ed., The Roman Fort at Manchester (1909), 126-8, types-R.W. Higginbottom, in G.D.B. Jones, Roman Manchester (1974), 137, observed doubtfully "the Rosicrucian Collectionmay have included a small hoard or hoards."As the only certain information about the coins in the pot is that they were denarii, the hoard can only be dated approximately."Undated. Probably 1st - early 3rd century AD"

name: PAS: Pleasley 3058
comments: Robertson 2000, 234 no. 954:""A poor labouring man, about 1770, found a large number of denarii, at a place in Pleasley, called Stuffine Wood, and sold them to a person in Mansfield for £5."-S. Pegge, in Arch., X (1792), 30Undated. Probably 1st - early 3rd century AD"

name: PAS: St. Just In Penwith 3059
comments: Robertson 2000, 46 no. 220:""As some workmen were removing a bank in a Field belonging to the adjacent Tenement of Boscadzhil, they found near a hundred Copper Coins which were all brought to him (i.e. Mr. Borlase of Pendeen) and the greatest part of them by him disposed of as a present to William Harris of Hayne in Devonshire, Esq; the few which he retained in his own keeping are now lost but ANTONINVS PIVS was very plainly to be read on some of them, as he well remembered. December 17, 1737."-W. Borlase, Historical and Monumental Ant. ofCornwall (1769), 300 n.Including "Antoninus Pius" (N.B. Could be a hoard containing rather coins of Caracalla or Elagabalus, as coins of Antoninus Pius tend to read "ANTONINVS AVG PIVS')"

name: PAS: Dalwood Down 3060
comments: Roberstson 2000, 46 no. 221:""A great quantity of Roman Coins were found in the year 1837."-J.B. Davidson, Ant. of Axminster (1861), 27"A great number of Roman coins has been dug up in a camp on Dalwood Down, the property of N. Olton of Widworthy House. The famous Icknield Streetruns along this down turning off on its way to Exeter.""On Dalwood Hill, about a mile from thence are the distinct remains of a Roman fortress. The workmen of C. Nolton in forming the hedges of plantations on this spot, in March 1837 found many coins of Antoninus etc. cf. Stirling History of Newton."-Henry Woolcombe Mss. Devon and Exeter Institution Library, 95; transcript supplied, 1978, by N. ShielIncluding "Antoninus""

name: PAS: Llantysilio 3061
comments: Robertson 2000, 46 no. 225:""There were Coyns of a base silver found by Pen Y Bryn in Maes Yr Ichen. Mr. Maesmor read Antoninus on one piece. A small piece and not thick."-E. Lluyd, Parochialia (1699); printed in Arch. Camb., 66 (1911), Suppl. I, 123Including "Antoninus""

name: PAS: Argam 3062
comments: obertson 2000, 425 no. 1839:""In 1869 some Roman coins, which had long lain hid, were brought to light in a very curious way. They were found in a mole-hill which the little miner had thrown up, and were in very good preservation."-T. Bulmer, Hist., Topog., and Directory of E. Yorks. (with Hull) (1892), 101Undated"

name: PAS: Aldersgate Street 3063
comments: Robertson 2000, 234 no. 958:""A vase of red ware, which when found contained denarii, is in Mr. Hilton Price's possession."-VCH London, I (1909), 86Undated. Probably 1st - early 3rd century AD"

name: PAS: Feltwell 3064
comments: Robertson 2000, 234: " "At Feltwell, near Brandon, three hundred Roman denarii, of the early middle period, were turned up by a man ploughing."-H. Prigg, in JBAA, XXXVI (1880), 104-G.E. Fox, in AJ, XLVI (1889), 338, gave the date of discovery as 1847.In Norwich Castle Museum, four den. of Trajan (3) and Hadrian (1), found at Feltwell in 1874, possibly came from this hoard.Undated. Probably 1st - early 3rd century AD"

name: PAS: Charlton 3065
comments: Robertson 2000, 235 no. 962:""As a proof that some [i.e. pottery vessels] were used to hoard money I saw one which was found at Charlton which contained upwards of 100 silver coins.There was one of these vessels found at Charlton a few years ago, containing about 120 [sic] silver coins."-J. Phillis, in Trans. Shepton Mallet Nat. Hist. Soc., 22 Nov. 1887-Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., XXXIV (1889) (1), 78, noted that Mr. Vonberg exhibited a "vase in which 200 Roman silver coins were found, 1880", at Charlton.VCH Somerset, I (1906), 318, said that the hoard consisted of "consular and imperial silver."Undated. Probably 1st - early 3rd century AD"

name: PAS: York 3066
comments: Robertson 2000, 235 no. 965:""Another find of about 200 denarii was made near the Foss Island about 1868, but the coins were unhappily dispersed. The number 200 would appear to have been a numerus receptus."-Handbook to York Museum (1891), 100 n.Undated. Probably 1st - early 3rd century AD"

name: PAS: Carisbrooke 3067
comments: An HER report of two hoards found by builders and during building work in Carisbrooke in 1969. The coins do not appear to have been studied and were not reported. A dealer described them as "silver washed denarii".

name: PAS: Sandown area 3068
comments: HER report of a hoard found in 1976 and sold in trade, reported by a dealer in 2002. "The hoard was examined by Malcolm Lyne who produced a report. 48 dupondii and sestertii were identified. They had been found in a truncated Rowlands Castle grey ware jar dating from the third century. [The dealer] believed that the sestertii and dupondii had been accompanied by an uncertain number of antonianii of Galienus, Victorinus, Claudius II, Tetricus I and II and Quintillus. These had been retained by the landowner".

name: PAS: Croydon (Pitlake) 3069
comments: Robertson 2000, 235 no. 963:""A hoard of coins of an early date was dug up at Pitlake about a mile from Wandle Road."-VCH Surrey, IV (1912), 361, without giving any authority-For later material possibly part of this hoard see no. 1047.Undated. Probably 1st - early 3rd century AD"

name: PAS: Gogmagog Hills 3070
comments: Robertson 2000, 234 no. 952: ""Jan. 27, 1731/2. Sir John Evelyn produced several Roman Medals of the Large Brass and a Silver Ring, found at Hogmagog [sic] Hills."-Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., I (1717-32), 279-Gogmagog Hills lie 4 miles SE of Cambridge, and are not readily to be assigned to a single parish.Undated. Probably 1st - early 3rd century AD"

name: PAS: Widdington 3071
comments: Robertson 2000, 234 no. 955: ""In the more immediate parishes of Debden, Wimbush and Widdington, pottery and coins have been discovered."-AJ, XI (1854), 214-"Widdington. Here I have been informed a large hoard of Roman silver denarii were discovered nearly thirty years ago."-R.C. Neville, in Trans. Essex Arch. Soc., I (1858), 197-"Widdington. Unlocated. A hoard of denarii is said to have been found in 1827, and other coins and pottery have been reported."-VCH Essex, III (1963), 200, with refs. to above two passagesUndated. Probably 1st - early 3rd century AD"

name: PAS: Minchinhampton 3072
comments: Robertson 2000, 234 no. 956:""At Amberley, near Minchinhampton, north of Nailsworth, in Gloucestershire, a hoard of imperial silver is stated to have contained an unusual proportion of Greek issues."-F. Haverfield, in Athenaeum, 1905, I, 250Undated. Roman coins: probably 1st - early 3rd century AD"

name: PAS: East London 3073
comments: Robertson 2000, 234 no. 959:"1 Jan. 1805"Some workmen, enlarging a pleasure-ground in the eastern suburbs of the metropolis, discovered an immense quantity of Roman coins, of different metals, the impressions in good preservation, and consisting of a great number of emperors, consuls, &c. supposed to have lain in the ground upwards of 1700 years."-Annual Register, 1805, 353Undated. Probably 1st - early 3rd century AD"

name: PAS: Birmingham (Jackson Road) 3074
comments: Discovered in a garden, no information obtained. According to the HER record "It is reported to have consisted of a small number of large Roman bronze coins. From this description it would appear that the hoard was made up of late 1st or 2nd century coins".

name: PAS: Lakenheath 3076
comments: Robertson 2000, 235 no. 970:""In 1948 Mr. Smith of Hiss Farm, close to Lakenheath Station, reported that the plough had turned up many sherds of pottery on a field just north of the railway line. He stated that twenty to thirty coins, close together as though from a hoard, and beads had been found in the same field in 1932. The coins had been sent to the British Museum for examination. Both coins and report are now missing, but the dates were said to be between AD 200 and 300."-Clare I. Fell, and (Lady) Grace Briscoe, in Proc. Cambs. Ant. Soc., XLIV (1951), 66Undated. Probably 3rd century AD"

name: PAS: Bluntisham Cum Earith 3077
comments: Robertson 2000, 235 no. 968: "From the Roman pottery kiln at Earith, "a coin hoard and other samples of pottery are also in the Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology, Cambridge."-H.J.M. Green, in Proc. Cambs. Ant. Soc., 58 (1954), 46-Cp. C.W. Phillips, ed., The Fenland in Roman Times (1970), 194:"EARITH, Fen Drove: 391759Small 3rdC coin hoard"Undated. 3rd century AD"

name: PAS: Selby 3078
comments: Robertson 2000, 235 no. 971:""A small hoard of third century Roman coins appears to have been found about seventy-five years ago at a place near Selby."-Letter, Nov. 1952, from Dr. D. Owen, Leeds City MuseumUndated. 3rd century AD"

name: PAS: Langton Matravers 3079
comments: Robertson 2000, 415 no. 1695 :""About the year 1842 on digging the foundations of the new dining room at Leeson House, then the property of J.B. Garland, Esqr., a small earthenware pot was found full of 3rd. brass Roman coins." Authorities, from local inhabitants, named.Ordnance Survey Object Name-book, quoted in letter from O.G.S. Crawford, 24 Jan 1934; photocopy supplied, Nov. 1988, by R.N.R. Peers, Dorset County Museum, DorchesterUndated. Probably 3rd or 4th century AD"

name: PAS: Bawtry Bridge 3080
comments: HER record of 8 radiates found "below stone bridge".

name: PAS: Sutton 3081
comments: A letter in the BM from the Potteries Museum and Gallery records a hoard of 68 bronze late third century coins in poor condition reported to the museum in 2000 but found in 1992 and so not Treasure. No further details other than findspot.

name: PAS: Harlton 3082
comments: Fused hoard, possibly the result of burning; leaving a distorted mass of what once had been four or more coins. Traces of a Roman style bust can be seen on the top layer - possibly a late Roman effigy but this remains subjective. Total weight is 9.21g so each coin must average 2.30g or less depending on quantity.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2013 T830Other PAS records associated with this hoard: CAM-33F2B5

name: PAS: Marford 3083
comments: Robertson 2000, 411 no. 1655:""About 25 years ago a hoard of 433 Roman coins was found in the garden of the Elms.This hoard was acquired by the late Mr. William Venn, who sold 105 of the coins to Mr. A. Seymour Jones of Wrexham, and these are now lent to the Wrexham Free Library Committee. All are of brass, and form a series ranging from the end of the Roman Republic to the close of the fourth century of our era. The remainder is said to have been disposed of to a Liverpool collector."RCHM Flintshire (1912), 57, no. 168BBCS, I (1921-3), 350, described this find as "?a modern collector's series."In 1947 the coins lent to the Wrexham Library were no longer there, and their present whereabouts are not known.Late 4th century AD"

name: PAS: High Wycombe 3084
comments: HER record of a hoard of 190 coins found with a ceramic pot base in High Wycombe under the roots of a tree. Described variously as having a date range AD 240-400 and "of approximately early fourth century date". Dr. Cathy King studied the hoard at the Ashmolean and concluded that it was "problematic" because "some of the mid fourth century coins present never turn up in British hoards" and it had similarities with material more common in early fifth century Egypt. The finder had some archaeological experience and was not using a metal detector.

name: PAS: Leeds 3086
comments: Robertson 2000, 410 no. 1639:""Mr. Thomas May, of Warrington, tells me that he obtained last year, in November, a hoard of 350 minims which had been discovered in demolishing an old house at Leeds. Some of these minims bear the Chi-Rho; the hoard therefore belongs, at earliest, to the fourth century."F. Haverfield, in Antiquary, XXXVI (1900), 106"Minims" ("Theodosian"?)"

name: PAS: Kings Lynn 3087
comments: HER record of five clipped siliquae "and some copper alloy coins" found at a rally in 1993 and noted as a possible hoard. This hoard does not seem to have been recorded elsewere from the limited information available.

name: PAS: Plymouth 3088
comments: Robertson 2000, 410 no. 1643:"N. Shiel has recorded a 4th century hoard from Plymouth.4th century AD"

name: PAS: Eriswell 3089
comments: HER record of a siliqua hoard found with four gold rings found "several years ago". Record dates to 1988. No further details.

name: PAS: Nantwich (Wall Lane) 3090
comments: Robertson 2000, 312 no. 1284:"NANTWICH (Wall Lane), c. 1849 (Chesh.)"The Roman coins alluded to are now in the possession of two gentlemen resident at Nantwich. Mr. Charles Laxton... has fifteen other coins found in a hard lump of earth in Wall-Lane tanyard, Nantwich, when the pits were being filled up, in or about the year 1849. All, or nearly all, are helmet headed, and are said to belong to various Roman emperors [no. 1284]...No other Roman remains, either iron or pottery, I believe, were found in these localities."J. Hall, in Palatine Notebook, I, (1881), 199; and in Hist. of the Town and Parish of Nantwich (1883), 8"

name: PAS: nan 3091
comments: Report on Pastscape of a fourth century coin hoard found at Holland-on-Sea, Great Clacton, Essex. No further information given.

name: PAS: Middleton In Teesdale 3092
comments: Robertson 2000, 410 no. 1645:""A hoard of coins was found in 1844 at High Force (near Middleton in Teesdale). Mr. J. McIntyre has ascertained that it consisted of twelve fourth-century brass pieces."JRS, XIX (1929), 1864th century AD"

name: PAS: Stainland 3093
comments: Robertson 2000, 426-427 no. 1855:""Some also of later Date [i.e. than those of Diocletian, Carausius and Allectus found at Hipperholme, no. 946] I was shown not long agoe found fallen from a Precipice of Stainland, but much defaced by time."-Dr. Richardson of Bierley, writing about 1714In T. Hearne's edition of J. Leland, Itinerary, 2 ed. (1745), I, 143This was probably the same find as that recorded by J. Watson, Hist. and Ant. of Parish of Halifax (1775), 54:"Near the foot of a large rock, at a place called Beestones, in the township of Stainland, about two miles from Slack, about 60 years ago, a considerable number of Roman coins was discovered: but the greater part of them falling into the hands of an exciseman, he carried them into the north, whence he never returned and it cannot even now be known what emperors they belongs to."Undated"

name: PAS: Hougham Without 3094
comments: Robertson 2000, 430 no. 1894:""Near 300 of the nummi argentei engraved by Camden, Batteley, and White were found together in a pot at Hougham near Dover, about the year 1780. The few that came into my possession are in the most perfect preservation and weigh from 17 ¾ grains to 20 each. Such coins have been found in England principally at Hougham, Reculver and in Thanet."-W. Boys, Hist. of Sandwich (1792), 870The only Roman silver coins of the weight mentioned above are very small siliquae, or half siliquae. The coins may possibly have been Anglo-Saxon.Uncertain if Roman"

name: PAS: Bitton 3095
comments: A reference in the "History of Bitton" 1881 Vol 5, p.267 by the Rev. H.T. Ellacombe to the finding of a fourth century coin hoard in the area of Bitton churchyard and vicarage. Thought to be the site of a minor Roman settlement.

name: PAS: Highgate 3096
comments: Robertson 2000, 411 no. 1650:""Rumours of a fourth-century copper hoard at Highgate a few years ago reached the Museum [i.e. the BM], but the coins themselves never came to hand."H. Mattingly, in NC, 1925, 398"Another find reported but with no trace remaining, is that from Shepherd's Cot (Hornsey Journal, 21 September 1928). No accurate location can be assigned to this find to justify its being placed on the distribution map. Research is being undertaken to attempt to establish more information but it seems possible that this was the hoard of coins 'rumours of which reached the British Museum in 1925'. The find was probably made on the demolition of the property known as Shepherd's Cot Farm, Shepherd's Hill Road." Caroline Neuburg, in Trans. London and Middlesex Arch. Soc., 23 (1972), 1684th century AD"

name: PAS: Lacock 3097
comments: Concreted group of about 15 small copper alloy coins or coin blanks, identified by Moorhead (2000, 57 no. 79) as a hoard. Found among a group of detector finds from an unknown site in Lacock parish.

name: PAS: Riddlesworth 3098
comments: Report on file at HER of a fused group of 4 or 5 radiates or nummi reported along with other objects. No further detail visible on X-ray.

name: PAS: Exeter 3099
comments: Fused lump of 10+ base metal coins. The hoard is a fused in a lump which has been squashed as if extruded through a narrow gap. Perhaps the result of concealment in a building which has subsequently burnt down. None of the uncertain number of coins can be identified but they are of the size of debased radiates or Constantinian nummi. Weight = 80.05g and max length = 75mm.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2012 T848Other PAS records associated with this hoard: DEV-4E4BE6

name: PAS: Blyford 3100
comments: Roman coin hoard: Nine 3rd-4th century coins fused together. The coins have been burnt, with some charcoal adhering to the corrosion products. The coins are visible in two stacks, one of the stacks has considerably more damage due to burning. Four coins are clearly visible in one stack, with one face exposed. No detail is visible on the exposed coin face - there is possibly a radiate crown, however this is uncertain due to the level of corrosion. The exposed coin has a diameter of 13.24mm. The amount of coins on the second stack is more difficult to assertain due to the fused and melted condition. This area appears to have four coins stacked on top of each other with corrosion products inbetween, a further coin joins the two stacks together. The remaining area of corrosion contains fragments of coins, however due to the burnt condition it is unclear whether these are part of the coins listed above, or are additional coins. It weighs 12.74 grams.Other PAS records associated with this hoard: ESS-962187

name: PAS: Duston 3101
comments: Robertson 2000, 351 no. 1440:""A vase and some coins (a 'second brass' of Claudius, a denarius of Severus, and about thirty-five of AD 259-380), were found hereabouts in 1854."VCH Northants., I (1902), 197, without giving any authoritySome, at least, of the 35 coins must have been ant., the others were probably small AE."

name: PAS: Southwark (Borough High Street) 3102
comments: Robertson 2000, 412 no. 1668:""In digging for the erection of a steam-engine at Messrs. Barclay and Perkin's Brewery [i.e. on the west side of Borough High Street] a human skeleton was discovered, and between the legs was found a vessel with several Roman coins, chiefly of the lower empire, in it."Gent. Mag., 1825, II, 633"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Old Ford 3103
comments: Robertson 2000, 336 no. 1373:""The tenant of one of the gardens, the property of Rev. John Stock, Rector of Finchingfield, Essex, told us he had dug up, within the last few years, at least five hundred Roman coins. Some specimens recently found Mr. F. Stock procured, and has requested me to present them to the Society. They are a denarius of Valentinian, and small brass of Tetricus, Carausius (?), Magnentius, and Constantine."C. Roach Smith, in Arch., XXXI (1846), 310The large no. of coins found suggest that they did come from a scattered hoard.The coins of Tetricus must have been ant., those of Carausius? probably so."

name: PAS: Devizes 3104
comments: Robertson 2000, 284 no. 1211:""Part of a Letter from Mr. Clark to Mr. Ludlow, Jan. 1700, concerning several Roman Antiquities found near the Devizes in Wiltshire.Sir,There has lately happened near us a very remarkable passage, which for the uncommonness of it deserves a more particular account than I shall pretend to give you. On Decemb. The 4th. 1699, a certain person digging in a ground of Sir John Eyles's near the Devizes in Wiltshire, about two foot under the surface took up a Pot of a pretty narrow mouth, about 18 Inches in its greatest circumference and 10 Inches deep, the Clay of a bluish colour, and of such strength and compactness, as it seem'd but little injur'd by Time, containing several hundred pieces of ancient Roman Coyn by different Emperors, with great variety of curious Figures and Devices on the Reverses. The most were of Copper, and but a very few of mixt metal." A description of 2 coins showed that they were of Salonina, and of Helena, rev. PAX PVBLICA.Phil. Trans. Royal Soc., XXII (1700-1), no. 263, 758f.The coin of Salonina was probably an antoninianus."

name: PAS: Chichester 3105
comments: Robertson 2000, 415 no. 1697 :""I hoped to have been able to lay a report before the Congress on a hoard of small Roman brass coins lately excavated in Chichester; but I failed in getting access to it."C. Roach Smith, in JBAA, XLIII (1887), 20Undated. Probably 3rd or 4th century AD"

name: PAS: Chrishall 3106
comments: Robertson 2000,411-412 no. 1657: ""I have examined thirty of these barrows, all in the neighbourhood, some close to, and others actually upon the earthwork [i.e the Dykes].The same rude sunburnt vases occur, except in one near Triplow, where a good Roman urn was found; the same interments also by cremation, one case again only excepted near Chrishall [sic] Grange, with innumerable third brass coins of the lowest empire, or their rude imitations."R.C. Nevile, in AJ, XI (1854), 211"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Langtoft 3107
comments: Robertson 2000, 415 no. 1696:""At a spot about half a mile from the Car-Dike and Langtoft, an urn was found, some fifty years ago, containing about 1000 small brass Roman coins; since which time others of silver and brass have been occasionally found, as well as in Uffington parish near here, including one of Vespasian."E. Trollope, Sleaford and the Wapentakes of Flaxwell and Aswardhurn (1872), 74 n.C.W. Phillips ed., The Fenland in Roman Times (1970), 253, gave the grid ref as [...]Undated. Probably 3rd or 4th century AD"

name: PAS: Bungay 3108
comments: Robertson 2000, 409-410: " "The hills on the Norfolk side of this common [i.e. Bungay common], form an amphitheatre, and are called the Bath-House Hills. On the summit of those on the east side, was ploughed up, in 1812, a pot of Roman coins called Minimi, several hundred in number, among which were those of Julius Caesar, Caligula and various other Emperors, most of them in fair preservation."S. Woodward, in Arch., XXIII (1831), 367G.J. Chester, in Norfolk Arch., IV (1855), 313; V (1859), 362, stated that the "small Roman Urn wasfilled with minute copper coins of the Lower Empire, which were distributed by way of "largess'".Proc. Suff. Inst. Arch., III (1864), 414, recorded that in 1861, at the Bungay meeting of the Institute there was exhibited "a tray of minimi selected from a thousand or more ploughed up in 1812 on the outside of the common.""Mr. Baker (of Bungay) has in his possession a selected series of 200 diminutive coins of the Lower Empire, taken from an urn found, as Mr. Chester has recorded, on the borders of Broome Heath close to Bungay, and filled with an immense number of these minute pieces which are very much smaller than the die with which they were struck, and could hardly have been intended for current coin."S.W. King in Norfolk Arch., VI (1864), 153S. Woodward, in Arch., XXIII (1831), must have been wrong in including Julius Caesar and Caligula among the emperors represented in this hoard of "minims".The "minims" may have been "Theodosian" small AE."

name: PAS: Pen-y-Gaer 3109
comments: Robertson 2000, 414 no. 1688:""Coins of the lower empire have been found here [i.e. at Pentre Gaer] at various times, some of which were in the possession of the late Archdeacon Payne."E. Poole, Ill. Hist. and Biography of Brecknocks. (1886), 230"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Letcombe Regis 3110
comments: Robertson 2000, 411 no. 1656:""About ten years ago there was a parcel of coins dug up in a common field about four miles off, at a place called Latcombe. They were first discovered by some scattered pieces in the field at harvest time. The owner of the land dug near the spot where these were found, and discovered three or four vessels one within the other, in the shape of the crown of a hat, with an edge to it of about 3 inches wide. It was full of holes like a cullenda, and I think it was brass, for I saw one of them. In this was a number of small coins, most of them silver, and a few gold, about the size of a half guinea, and as bright.The coins were those of the lower emperors."G. Goodward, writing on 21 Aug. 1759; quoted by J. Nichols, Bibl. Top. Brit., IV (1790), 29f.; cf. also 57"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Preston 3111
comments: Robertson 2000, 412 no. 1661:""in the year 1816, one of their body, [i.e. one of them men of Sutton and Preston] a carter of the name of Willshire, when ploughing in a field not half a mile distant from Rimbury, turned up an urn filled with Roman coins.They numbered several hundreds, and were hawked about at an average price of one shilling each. Willshire's wife also regularly attended Weymouth market, with the coins exposed for sale in a plate on a standing. The proceeds formed a nucleus (small as it might have been), which was embarked in smuggling transactions, and proving successful (his sons being bold fellows), the condition of the family was materially improved; indeed one of the sons, at the time of our excavations, was in the occupation of a farm of considerable extent in the adjoining village of Osmington.The coins, many of which are in my cabinet, were all of the Lower Empire."C. Warne, Celtic Tumuli of Dorset (1866), Pt. I, 60 n.)"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: South Tawton 3112
comments: Robertson 2000, 412 no. 1660:""A number of Roman coins of the lower empire."R.N. Worth, in Trans. Devons. Ass., 23 (1891), 81"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Llandybie 3113
comments: Robertson 2000, 415 no. 1689:"20 Jan. 1764"And about the year 1736, great Quantities (of coins) of the lower Empire were found in a Quarry in this County near Landebie, & Landevane Bath."Rev. W. Harris, in Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., IX (1762-5), 188; and in Arch., II (1773), 18"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Norley Wood 3114
comments: Robertson 2000, 412 no. 1663A:""Near 200 lb. weight of coins of the Lower Empire were found here [i.e. at Lymington] in two urns 1744. An urn full was dug up at Norley Wood, two miles and a half due east from Lymington."Camden and Gough's Britannia I, (1789), 132VCH Hants., I (1900), 345, suggested that these two finds, one from Lymington (1744) and one from Norley Wood, may really be one and the same. The findspots however were some miles apart."Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Glasfryn 3115
comments: Robertson 2000, 416 no. 1702:""Early last century a hoard of Roman third brasses was discovered by Jn. Jones, servant of Tyddyn Tarn, Cefn Brith, in an earthenware vessel while getting stones from a quarry in a field called Ffridd Hafod y Maidddistant nearly half a mile north-north-west of Hafod y Maidd farmstead.None of the coins can now be traced.They resembled 'ffyrlingod' i.e. farthings and would fill a hat. Mr. E.L. Hughes confirmed this account [i.e. of 1916-17], and added that he remembered several young men many years ago who had some of them attached to their watch chains."Canon Ellis Davies, Prehistoric and Roman Remains in Denbighs. (1929), 89Undated. Probably 3rd or 4th century AD"

name: PAS: Offchurch 3116
comments: Robertson 2000, 411 no. 1653:"An account of the discovery of an Anglo-Saxon cemetery at Offchurch, "situated between the road from Radford to Long Itchington and the Rugby and Leamington Railway, S.S.E. of the church, about 600 yards distant" in the Rep. of the Warwicks. Nat. Hist. and Arch. Soc., for 1876, gave a list of the small objects found, and concluded (40):"There were many coins, minimi, and Roman third brass, which ought to be inspected and catalogued. These, and several fragments of a black urn, are preserved at Offchurch Bury." J. T. BurgessVCH Warwicks., I (1904), 247, described the coins as "a number of 'third brass' of circa AD 264-400, and some minims, found probably in the neighbourhood", but did not, apparently, take the view that they were found in an Anglo-Saxon cemetery.In 1952, Miss Jocelyn Morris, Warwicks. (County) Museum, tried in vain to trace the coins at Offchurch Bury. It therefore remains doubtful whether the coins formed a hoard, and whether they were found in association with Anglo-Saxon remains. It is also uncertain whether the so-called minims were true minims.Late 4th century AD"

name: PAS: Bentley With Arksey 3117
comments: Robertson 2000, 236 no. 977:"Doncaster Museum had a note that during the building of a bungalow in Pipering Lane, Bentley, what appeared to have been a hoard of bronze coins (ant. or later) was found.Undated. 3rd century AD or later"

name: PAS: Bishopstrow 3118
comments: Robertson 2000, 415 no. 1699:""About three years since [i.e. since 1801], were discovered at Bishopstrow, half a mile from Pitmead, a vast number of small brass coins, nearly sufficient to fill a Winchester bushel; they were contained in three urns. Several hundred of these also are in the possession of Mr. Cunnington."J. Britton, Beauties of Wilts. (1801), II, 54Undated. Probably 3rd or 4th century AD"

name: PAS: Wisbech 3119
comments: Robertson 2000,416 no. 1712: ""WISBECH ST. MARY Calves' Field: 3 coins 'at Tholomas Drive' [sic] before 1914 (Wisb. M. Report, 1950-1, 7), perhaps hoard of later 3rdC."C.W. Phillips ed., The Fenland in Roman Times (1970), 298Undated"

name: PAS: Upton Grey 3120
comments: HER record of a hoard of "Roman minimi coins" found by workmen digging a chalk pit in the early part of the twentieth century. They are thought to have been in a bone box.

name: PAS: Duston 3121
comments: Robertson 2000, 410 no. 1638:""Three grave-like excavations in the ironstone, immediately beneath the surface-soil, were a short time ago discovered. These had a depth of some four feet in the rock, were arranged in a radiating position, and had a flooring covered with ashes, among which some burnt stones were found, and a nest of Romano-British Minimi. The perfect coins among them were secured by Lady Palmerston's agent, the fragments produced being left as my share."S. Sharpe, in NC, 1869, 169"Minimi" ("Theodosian"?)"

name: PAS: Maenporth 3122
comments: A hoard listed by Penhallurick found in a quarry at Penrose, Falmouth (he lists it under Budock, the former parish name). The report in the Royal Cornwall Gazette for 21st Dec 1822 notes the discovery "about two feet under the surface an earthen vessel containing 250 pieces of ancient Coin; the greater part of them were copper, of the size of a farthing".

name: PAS: Nutfield 3123
comments: Robertson 2000, 413-414 no. 1680:"4 Nov. 1756"Mr. Burrow informed the Society, That a considerable number of Roman Coins, chiefly of the lower Empire, amounting to between eight and nine hundred, were lately found in a Field in the Parish and Manor of Nutfield, near Bletchingly in Surry (sic) almost opposite to the Wind-mill there. They were discovered, he says, by a Plow, which in cutting through a Sandy Hillock in the Field, struck against the Earthern Vessel that contain'd them. Several of these coins he was pleased to exhibit, which were very fair."9 Dec. 1756"Mr. Webb acquainted the Society that a number of Roman Coins, to the amount of between two and three hundred chiefly of the lower Empire: lately found in a field near Ryegate in Surrey, and of which Mr. Burrow took notice in the Minutes of 4th. Novr. last, are now in the hands of Lord Roystone member of this Society who intends to take the first favourable opportunity of exhibiting to them such of the said coins as appear to be most rare and curious."Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., VII (1751-6), 282, 287.A ref. in Gough's Camden, 1789, I, 175, gave the date of discovery as 1755.VCH Surrey, IV (1912), 367, supposed, wrongly, that the second of the above passages referred to the discovery of a second hoard at Reigate."Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: between Orford and Aldeburgh 3124
comments: Robertson 2000, 418 no. 1743:"16 Feb. 1743"Mr. V.P. read a paragraph from a Letter sent him, giving some account of small Roman coins of the lower Empire found in great quantities on the Sea Shore between Aldborough and Orford in Suffolk."R. Gale, in Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., IV (1740-4), 190"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Bathealton 3125
comments: Robertson 2000, 413 no. 1674:""About a mile westward from the church, is an ancient encampment, nearly of a circular form; the area contains about 10 acres. The foss is nearly entire. Some Roman coins of the lower empire have been found within its circuit."J. Collinson, Hist. and Ant. of Somerset (1791), III, 23VCH Somerset, I (1906), 356, gave the date of discovery as about 1600 AD"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Somersham 3126
comments: Robertson 2000, 412 no. 1665: ""About the year 1731, in a piece of fen land belonging to William Thomson, esq; the plough turned up and broke a small urn containing several Roman coins, and Mr. Thomson and the rev. Mr. Whiston of Ramsey digging near the spot found another which contained about 60, mostly copper, and of the later emperors. This was near the road leading from Somersham to Chateris in the isle of Ely."-Camden and Gough's Britannia II, (1789), 159Later Empire"

name: PAS: Towcester 3127
comments: Robertson 2000, 413 no. 1670:"19 Jan. 1748"Mr. Nixonshewed the Society a parcell of small bras coins of the Lower Empire lately found near Towcester in Northamptonshire in digging of stone for repairing that part of Watling Street Road. Also there have been found several peices [sic] of urns bones &c which plainly shew there has been formerly some old Station or Town"26 Jan. 1748"Mr. Nixon shewed several fragments of Earthenware and some other old coins of the Romans found at Towcester."Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., V (1745-9), 208, 210"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Westhumble 3128
comments: Robertson 2000, 413 no. 1679:"31 Jan. 1788"In a farm near Westumble, between Dorking and Mickleham, a little to the North of N.W. of the course of this road [i.e. the Roman road] a number of brass coins of the lower empire were ploughed up by the farmer some years agoall so common as not to be worth exhibiting to the Society."Arch., IX (1789), 107"many brass coins of the lower empire have been ploughed up in a farm between Dorking and Mickelham, but they are so common as not be worth exhibiting."Mr. (W.) Bray, in Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., XXII (1787-8), 298f."Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Hagley 3129
comments: Robertson 2000, 414 no. 1685:""Several coins of the lower empire have been found in the adjoining fields, and particularly an earthen pot filled with them was taken out of a pool on the side of the hill not many years since."Treadway Nash, Coll. for Hist. of Worcs. (1781), I, 485"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Langton Matravers 3130
comments: A vase containing Roman coins of the third and fourth centuries A.D., including Constantine, Gallienus, Claudius, Gothicus, Posthumus and Carausius was ploughed up at Langton in 1817 ( Hutchins 1861, 560). The exact location of the find is unknown. It may be part of a hoard buried in time of crisis but never recovered.

name: PAS: Worksop 3131
comments: Robertson 2000, 413 no. 1673:""A similar find [i.e. to the Worksop, 1835 hoard, no. 1302] was also made at Shireoaks some years back of small brass coins of the Lower Empire."R. White, Hist. of Worksop (1875), 98"Lower" Empire"
