name: PAS: Llanvair Discoed 3132
comments: Find of a Roman urn containing ashes and "a few Roman coins of the lower empire".

name: PAS: Littleport 3133
comments: A collection of 4 Roman minimi found in Station Rd, Littleport, together with a tiny piece of bronze of uncertain use with a raised cross and 4 raised pellets on one face.

name: PAS: Kepier 3134
comments: Robertson 2000, 412 no. 1662:""I have authority to say that coins have been formerly ploughed up here [i.e. at Kepier, in St. Giles parish, Durham City], and lately some of the lower empire have also been discovered within its vicinage."J. Cade, in Arch., VII (1785), 78"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Northallerton 3135
comments: Robertson 2000, 414 no. 1686:""1788. In a field close to these hills, a large urn was dug up by one Lawrence Leadley, containing an innumerable quantity of Roman coins, chiefly of the latter emperors; a few were corroded, but the greatest part were in good preservation; the urn was of coarse blue clay and porous. So numerous were the coins, which amounted to several hundreds, that they soon got into circulation as farthings, and went by the name of 'Lawrie's farthings." C.J.D. Ingledew, Hist. of Northallerton (1858), 123B.H.St.J. O'Neil, in AJ, XC (1933), 305, implied that the hoard included coins of Antoninus Pius to Geta, and of Constantius II, quoting as authority F. Elgee, The Romans in Cleveland (1923), 7, 8, 14. The coins described by Elgee, however, were found in the railway excavations in 1838, along with various small objects and foundations of buildings, and have no connection with the hoard found in 1788.The coins, which circulated as "farthings", must have been AE.Later Empire"

name: PAS: Thurgarton 3136
comments: Robertson 2000, 413 no. 1671:""At Thurgarton priory more than would fill a peck basket were found a few years since, on removing a very ancient part of that fabrick." W. Dickinson, Ant. of Notts. I (1801), 97F. Haverfield, in VCH Notts., II (1910), 35, said that the coins were "chiefly of the later Empire".Later Empire"

name: PAS: Goodrich 3137
comments: Robertson 2000, 412 no. 1664:""Near to Goodrich, on Copped-Wood hill, about the year 1817, a large collection of coins of the lower empire was dug up."T. Wright, Wanderings of an Antiquary (1854), 14"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Ham Hill 3138
comments: Robertson 2000, 413 no. 1675:"At the Fifth Annual Meeting of the Somerset Archaeological and Natural History Society, held at Yeovil:"Mr. Watts, of the Mermaid Hotel, sent an ancient Roman Vase, dug up at Ham Hill some years ago; it was in a perfect state of preservation and when discovered was filled with copper coins, chiefly of the later Roman Emperors."Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., IV (1853), (1), 11This cannot be the same find as either Ham Hill (1802-14) [no. 583], since that hoard and its pot had already been deposited in the Library of Christ Church, Oxford, long before 1853, or Ham Hill (1816) [no. 651], since the pot which contained that hoard was broken on discovery. This must be yet a third hoard.Later Empire"

name: PAS: Lymington 3139
comments: Robertson 2000, 412 no. 1663:""Jan. 23, 1745.Mr. Collison communicated a Letter from Mr. Benj. Cook dated the 7th. Feb. 1744 at Newport, relating to a large parcell of Coins of the Lower Empire found near Limmington in the New Forest, said to be about 176 pound weight, contained in Two Urns."Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., V (1745-9), 49"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Caerwent 3140
comments: Robertson 2000, 415 no. 1691:"3 March 1763"A considerable quantity of small Copper Coin of the lower Empire has been dug up here."Rev. W. Harris, in Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., IX (1762-5), 62"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Marr Grange Holt 3141
comments: Records in HER of a hoard of 6 (possibly 4th century) Roman coins (HER 03396/01), a group of 8 third to fourth century coins (HER 03390/01) and a group of 13 Roman coins (HER 03395/01), with same NGR. Uncertain if a hoard or part of same hoard. Another record (HER 03387/01 and 03388/01) has a group of 15 fourth century coins in association with other objects.

name: PAS: Cefnydre 3142
comments: Robertson 2000, 415 no. 1692:"In 1859, in the temporary museum at Cardigan, there was exhibited to the Cambrian Archaeological Association, "a collection of Roman brass of Lower Empire, found near Cefnhendre, above Fishguard. - John Fenton, Esq."Arch. Camb., 14 (1859), 350"Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Haldon (Uncertain Parish) 3143
comments: Robertson 2000, 412 no. 1659:""In 1816, a labourer, digging for stone in the great barrow on the western side of Haldon, found several Roman coins of the later empire, which are in the possession of the Rev. John Templer."D. Lysons & S. Lysons, Magna Britannia, VI (1822), cccxiIt is possible, though not certain, that this find and the Haldon (Belvidere), before 1879 (Devon) find [no. 521] were one and the same.Later Empire"

name: PAS: Bishopstrow 3144
comments: Robertson 2000, 414 no. 1682:""About the year 1791, two earthen vessels were found by some labourers in making a ditch at the Berries, containing several thousand small brass coins of the Lower Empire. A lump of these coins, firmly rusted together, was given to Mr. Halliday."R. Harris and R. Colt Hoare, Hist. of Modern Wilts., III, Warminster Hundred (1830), 92J.H. Daniell, Hist. of Warminster (1879), 6, gave a more detailed account:"In 1792, Richard Archer and John Arnold while employed in levelling a high ridge and digging a ditch at the Buries, discovered several pieces of iron armour, much Roman ware, and two large urns, one of which contained several thousand Roman coins, a peck in measure, chiefly of the middle and small brass, of all ages of the Roman Empire from Tiberius, viz., Claudius, Vitellius, Domitian, Antoninus Pius, Commodus, Alexander Severus, Lucius Verus, Maximus, Gordian, Philip, Gallienus, Tetricus, Probus, Tacitus, Carausius, Allectus [sic], Carinus, Maxentius, Maximinus, Constantine, Constans, Magnentius, Victorinus, and two female heads, Salonina, wife of Gallienus, and a Julia. A lump of these coins, firmly rusted together, in good preservation, was in the possession of Mr. Halliday of Warminster but cannot now be found."The last sentence showed that Daniell was referring to the same hoard as Hoare, although the list of emperors he gave does not agree with Hoare's statement that the hoard was of "small brass coins of the Lower Empire." Daniell did not see the coins himself, and was probably mistaken about the composition of the hoard."Lower" Empire"

name: PAS: Wilford 3145
comments: Robertson 2000, 413 no. 1672:""It seems to have been anciently a Roman station, as many Roman coins were dug up here a few years ago, most of which were of the latter emperors."Britton and Brayley, Beauties of England and Wales XII (1), (1813), 182Later Empire"

name: PAS: Aston Clinton 3146
comments: HER record of "seven worn minims, presumably a hoard" found by a metal detectorist in Aston Clinton in 1993.

name: PAS: Chorley (Whittle) 3147
comments: Robertson 2000, 412 no. 1667:""A somewhat similar treasure [i.e. to the hoard of small brass coins, chiefly of the Lower Empire, from Heywood, 1856 (Lancs.), no. 769] was found in 1837, on removing the rock above the tunnel formed for the canal at Whittle, near Chorley."C. Hardwick, Hist. of Preston (1857), 49, 50, 613, where he stated the coins were "said to have amounted to nearly a thousand in number")"Lower" Empire?"

name: PAS: Tresco 3148
comments: Rumoured Roman coin hoard reported by Penhallurick but not verified.

name: PAS: Norton Fitzwarren 3171
comments: Robertson 2000, 355 no. 1457:"In 1938, Mr. A.P. Pallett presented the following 6 coins, 4 ant., and 2 small AE, from Norton Fitzwarren, to the Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM (BM Register of Coin Accessions, May, July 1938):Ant. AEVictorinus 1Tetricus I 2Carausius 1FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman 1Valentinian II 14 2(b.)(1 b.)(b.)(VICTORIA AVGGG, two Victories)Dr. H. Mattingly had a note that the above coins, along with another irregular imitation of the FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman type, were found as a hoard about 1880.Examined, 1948 (ASR)."NB See also Pastscape 189019. Possibly not a hoard?

name: PAS: Great Rollright 3172
comments: Robertson 2000, 338 no. 1384:"Roman "Coins (Tetricus to Valens) at Church End Farm."P. Manning and E.T. Leeds in Arch., LXXI (1921), 244Some at least of these coins were ant., the others were probably AE."

name: PAS: Willingham, Near 3173
comments: HER entry on Heritage Gateway (no.11781) reads: "From Journal of William Woodman metal detector: 'Things I handled as a dealer and didn't declare' - from near Willingham Cambs, 976 siliqua all unclipped, 65 miliarense, 3 solidii plus an aureus of Carausius with Pax on reverse. All in a greyware pot. Only 4 Emperors: Julian II, Valentinian I, Gratian and Valentinian II. Found in 1993. No further location information known therefore no grid reference given."

name: PAS: Filey 3174
comments: Robertson 2000, 356 no. 1460:""In my own parish of Filey, there has been a recent find of coin of Emperors as late as Valentinian II and Gratian."Rev. A.N. Cooper, in Trans. East Riding Ant. Soc., XVI (1909), 71This is probably the find referred to by Canon A.N. Cooper in JBAA, n.s., XXII (1916), 287:"A few years ago, on the same ground [i.e. the farm land of Mr. T. Smith, south of Filey Parish Church] a Roman urn and coins were found.""

name: PAS: Haddenham 3175
comments: Not a hoard but a collection of coins and artefacts found in a spring and stream bed. Not declared Treasure.

name: PAS: Crondall 3259
comments: 99 gold coins: 1 tremissis of Phocas; 16 Merovingian civic tremisses; 4 Frisian tremisses and 73 Anglo-Saxon thrymsas. See C H V Sutherland, Anglo-Saxon Gold Coinage in the light of the Crondall hoard, Oxford, 1948, p. 9, no. 1, where the coin is mis-identified as an imitation of a tremissis of Leo I. See also P Grierson, `A stray from the Crondall hoard', NC 1953, 148-9 and id., `The purpose of the Sutton Hoo coins', Antiquity 44 (1970), 14-18, where he corrects Sutherland's attribution of this coin (p. 15). MIBE 47.

name: PAS: Horndean 3260
comments: 4 solidi (Honorius, I, Anastasius, 1; Constans IV, 1; Constantine IV, 1). Found by Mr P Beasley with a metal detector in January-February 1997. Not Treasure Trove. Note: It is difficult to know how to interpret these coins. The first coin was found by Mr Beasley in January 1997and the remaining three examples in the same area, although not immediately adjacent to each other, the following month. They were reported to the coroner who decided that it was not necessary to hold an inquest on them. The earlier coins are not significantly more worn than the later ones, as one might expect if they were from the same deposit, but the discovery of four gold coins of this period in Britain in the same area is unprecedented and there must be a possibility that they are from a small hoard. Honorius, 408-23 (1)1. Obv.: D N HONORI-VS P F AVG, bust, pearl-diad., dr., cuir., seen from front, r. Rev.: VICTORI-A AVGGG, Emperor stg. r., in field: R V; in exergue: COMOB, Ravenna, AD 408-23, RIC X 1321, 4.50g, 1998-4-30-1Anastasius, c. 492-508 (1)2. Obv.: D N ANASTA-SIVS P P AVC, bust, helmeted, pearl-diad., facing with shield on l. shoulder and spear over r. shoulder. Rev.: VICTORI-A AVCCCI, Victory stg. l. holding long cross; in field r.: *; in exergue: CONOB, Constantinople, AD 492-508, MIBE 4a, 4.51g, 1998-4-30-2Constans II, c. 662-7 (1)3. Obv.: dN[.]N[.], busts of Constans II and Constantine IV facing. Rev.: VICTORIA AV??S, Two emperors stg. facing on either side of cross on steps, Constantinople, c. AD 662-7, MIBE 31, 4.37g, 1998-4-30-3Constantine IV, c. 674-81 (1)4. Obv.: D N CONT-A-N?S P P, bust, helmeted, pearl-diad., facing with shield on l. shoulder and spear over r. shoulder. Rev.: VICTO-A AV??S, Heraclius and Constantine stg. facing on either side of cross on steps, Constantinople, c. AD 674-81, MIBE 7, 4.26g, 1998-4-30-4. NC 1998, p. 298.

name: PAS: Kingston On Thames Area 3261
comments: At least ten tremisses of "Justin I" (Justinian I) and 3 Gallic imitations.

name: PAS: Scathwaite 3262
comments: `A hoard of gold and silver coins' from Scathwaite: no date given, probably medieval. This hoard is discussed by White (1996) who publishes the testiomony of the finders. He writes "it is reasonably clear that the coin hoard was contained in a lead pot, in or under an old wall. There were 52 gold coins and 98 or 99 silver" (White 1996, 118-9). One of the gold coins was said to have a cross on it, suggesting a post-Roman date.

name: PAS: Stony Stratford (White Swan) 3263
comments: When the old White Swan was being reconstructed at Stony Stratford, the workmen came across a jar full of gold coins - all Roman - and unquestionably of great value. Nothing was said at the time but one of the workmen subsequently became very prosperous. A year ago (1950?) the sole survivor of the party showed me the last gold coin he had kept. It was a beauty - as large as a florin, and as clear as when it was minted.' Sir Frank Markham, The Nineteen Hundreds, Hillier & Sons, Buckingham, 1951, p. 97. There must be doubt as to whether these coins were in fact Roman, since the one seen by Markam was the size of a florin, as this would make it 28 mm in diameter, much larger than either aurei or solidi and more consistent with a hoard of late medieval or early modern gold coins.

name: PAS: TARA 3265
comments:
"The only 'find' was a collection of fifteen Roman coins of small value, all belonging to the reign of Constantine the Great. They were discovered about eighteen inches below the surface of the ground, and immediately over the wide trench mentioned above.
 It is interesting to note that from the position in which they were discovered, it would seem that the trench had been filled up and the surface grass grown at the time when they were lost."
J. Healy, in Journal of Royal Soc. Ant. of Ireland, XXX (1900), 176
"It has now transpired that the hoard was put there a day or two before for them [i.e. the excavators] to find."
J.D. Bateson, in PRIA, 73 (1973), C 2, 59f., no. 73
"Reign of Constantine I".

name: PAS: FLOWER HILL 3269
comments:
"In the year 1827, Alexander McKinlay found in the townland of Ballyclough (in the part called Flower Hill, near Bushmills) three hundred Roman coins, all silver, but he concealed them for a long time, and at length parted with them by sending some to London, others to Dublin and selling to individuals as opportunity offered. At present I believe there are only two of them remaining."
J. Bell, in Ulster J. of Arch., 2 (1854), 187 n.
"1820. Near the Giant's Causeway, county of Antrim, were found about three hundred Roman silver coins: twelve of them were sold in London for 20; the remainder were of small value, being much decomposed, with the exception of a denarius of Matidia which came into my possession."
Letter from J. Carruthers, Belfast, to the Secretary of the Kilkenny Arch. Soc., quoted in Proc, Kilkenny Arch. Soc., 3 (1854/5), 61
J.D. Bateson, in Ulster J. of Arch., 34 (1971), 52f.; and in Proc. Royal Irish Acad., 73 (1973), C 2, 45, no. 5, discussed the above passages and others, and concluded that they refer to one and the same hoard, found probably in 1827.
Including Matidia

name: PAS: KILLANUMMERY 3270
comments:
"Lieutenant-Colonel [W.G.] Wood-Martin exhibited
seven Roman coins, said to have been found in the county Leitrim. These latter are the property of W. Lucas, M.D., who states that they were alleged to have been dug out of a rath close to the Church of Killenumery. The reputed discoverer of these coins is now dead; however, persons in the neighbourhood assert that they 'remembered Johnston finding a lot of old copper tied up in a boot (?) some years ago.' It is stated that upwards of one hundred specimens were then disinterred.
     W. Frazer, F.R.C.S.I., who examined the coins, pronounced the collection to consist of seven examples of small-sized, or third brass Roman coins, all different. They are coins of the Emperors:"
          Florian          1
          Probus          1
          Carinus          1
          Diocletian          1
          Maximian          1
          Constantine I, Aug.          2
          
                    7
?Journal of Hist. and Arch. Ass. of Ireland, VIII (1887-8), 103
?The coins from Florian to Carinus were of course ant., those of Diocletian and Maximian either ant. or folles, and those of Constantine I, small AE.
J.D. Bateson, in PRIA, 73 (1973), C 2, 62, no. 86, has questioned whether the coins constitute a hoard.

name: PAS: GIANT'S CAUSEWAY 3271
comments: Doubtful according  to Bateson 1973 p.50

name: PAS: GIANT'S CAUSEWAY 3272
comments:
"Subsequently the same person [i.e. James Quig, who found the previous hoard near the Giant's Causeway, no. 311] found large hoards at two different times [1871, 1872]: but never permitted any person to know how many. He took part of them to Dublin, and has since emigrated to Australia. None of these were buried at any great depth, as they were discovered while planting potatoes."
?J. Bell, in Ulster J. of Arch., II (1854), 187 n.
J.D. Bateson, in Ulster J. of Arch., 34 (1971) 52f.; and in PRIA, 73 (1973), C 2, 50, no. 21, regarded these two hoards as "Questionable".
Undated
UNDATABLE

name: PAS: BUTTEVANT 3273
comments:
"Several Roman Consular and Imperial coins were, a few years since, said to have been dug up at Buttevant, county Cork."
?J. Lindsay, View of the Coinage of Ireland (1839), 2
?J.D. Bateson, in PRIA, 73 (1973), C 2, 53f., no. 41, has classified this find as "Questionable".
Undated. Probably 1st - early 3rd century AD

name: PAS: Largo 3328
comments: On a rising ground to the north, called Norrie's Law, several antiquities in silver were discovered, together with a number of small silver Roman coins bearing the stamp of the earlier emperors. They are now in the possession of General Durham.?New Statistical Account of Scotland, IX (1846), 439 It is virtually certain that we have here a distorted account of the great hoard of silver ornaments found at Norrie's Law about 1819. They were unfortunately melted down almost at once. Subsequent search on the same spot brought to light a few remnants that had been unnoticed at first, and also two or three coins. The whole matter is discussed at length by Dr Joseph Anderson in his Scotland in Early Christian Times (Second Series, 34ff.), where the deposit is tentatively attributed to the seventh century at the earliest. Despite the positive assertion of N.S.A., there is no evidence for the discovery of any coins save those already mentioned.?(Sir) George Macdonald, in PSAS, 52 (1918), 238, 266. Macdonald noted that the coins seem to have been a second brass of Antonia Augusta, struck by Claudius, two silver coins of Constantius II and Valens and a Byzantine coin, but doubted whether the coins had any connection with the main deposit. Uncertain if a hoard

name: PAS: Leven 3329
comments:
Hector Boece, Scotorum Historiae (ed. 1575), fol. 86, verso, near end of liber v
As (Sir) George Macdonald noted, in PSAS, 52 (1918), 266, the account is too confused to be certain what were the dates of the coins.
Undatable
UNCERTAIN OF ROMAN

name: PAS: Nairn 3330
comments:
Est & in Moravia, marino littore, inter vetustissimae arcis ruinas, marmoreum vas, cui anseris duobus cum anguibus decertantis effigies mira arte insculpta, haud dissimili pecunia refertum, anno Christi millesimo quadringentesimo sexagesimo, a pastoribus inventum. Fuit idem lapis, uti a fide dignis accepimus, haud minus quam nummi diutius spectantibus admirationi argumentum, apud nostros majores Romanae pecuniae aliquando fuisse usum.?Hector Boece, Scotorum Historiae (ed. 1575) fol. 86, verso
Gibson's Camden (1695), col. 944 gave a more exact description of the site of the find: More inward, where Bean Castle now stands (look'd upon to be that Banatia mentioned by Ptolemy) there was found in the year 1460, a Marble Vessel very finely engraved, and full of Roman coins. Undated

name: PAS: Nairn 3331
comments:
Some years ago was dug up in a common near Nairn an urn containing a series of Roman silver coins of different emperors, a variety of duplicates, sets of which were presented to the faculty of advocates, and several other cabinets.
?R. Gough, British Topography (1780), II, 705
Undated

name: PAS: Possil Marsh 3332
comments:
Possil Marsh, with its strange wild life of all kinds, has long been a happy hunting ground of the Glasgow naturalists, and once saw the finding of a leather bag containing two hundred silver Roman coins.
G. Eyre Todd, Glasgow Tramway Car Guide (1911), 105
There seems to be no other record of this find, if it ever existed.
?Anne S. Robertson, in PSAS, 94 (1961), 151
Undated

name: PAS: Red Moss Of Crathes 3333
comments:
In their retreat [i.e. from Mons Graupius] the legionaries must have been in a very disorganised state, as, in the Red Moss of Crathes, on the estate of Sir Robert Burnett, are found scattered about silver coins of the empire, which, no doubt, were in possession of those Roman soldiers who had fallen down and died either from sheer fatigue or by the spears of the Picts. Some of these coins were presented to Blairs College by the late Sir James Burnett, the father of the present baronet, and are preserved at Blairs.
?Dr. A. Walker, in Trans. Aberdeen Phil. Soc. (1892), ii, 160 All that can safely be said is that the coins now at Blairs College are a miscellaneous collection, not a hoard; that some of them may have been found in Scotland, or even in the Red Moss; but that in the meantime there is no evidence authentic enough to warrant any conclusion. So far as can be judged at present, the hoard of AR from the Red Moss of Crathes is a myth.?(Sir) George Macdonald, in PSAS, 52 (1918), 269f. Uncertain if a hoard

name: PAS: Silverburn Or Normandykes 3334
comments:
At a place called the Silver Burn, near Aberdeen, a great Quantity of Roman Medalls was also found, many of which I saw in the Hands of some curious Gentlemen there.
?A. Gordon, Itinerarium Septentrionale (1726), 186
?This was probably the find recorded by G.M. Fraser in BNJ, III (1906), 329f.:
The largest find of Roman coins in this region was on the banks of the Dee, about ten miles west of the city of Aberdeen.
 It was in the immediate neighbourhood of this [i.e. of the camp at Normandykes] that many years ago a number of silver coins were found in a moss. Their precise denominations do not appear to have been ascertained beyond the fact that they were coins of the empire, and the supposition is that, for some reason or other, they had been buried in the neighbourhood of the camp when Agricola was on his return march from the North.
Undated. Probably 1st - early 3rd century AD

name: PAS: St. Ninians 3335
comments:
On 1 June 1946, there were presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, By the Exchequer, by order of the Lords of H.M. Treasury
Twelve Roman Coins, found at Sauchie, in the county of Stirling, brass.
Archaeologia Scotica, V (1890), App., 54
(Sir) George Macdonald, in PSAS, 52 (1918), 274, remarked that, Judging by analogy, we may conclude that these were a representative selection from a much larger hoard, and the chances are in favour of their being coins of the late empire.
The 12 coins presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland have not been located in the NMAS, Edinburgh.
Late Empire
UNDATED: PROBABLY 3RD OR 4TH CENTURY AD

name: PAS: nan 3336
comments: A quantity of Roman coins were found c. 1831 in a hillock near the reputed site of Durward's Castle (NO25SE 4) (NO 2635 5403). Warden, A J. (1880-5) Angus or Forfarshire: the land and people, descriptive and historical, 5v. Dundee. Page(s): Vol.4, 211

name: PAS: Laws 3338
comments: `A considerable number of gold coins;' no evidence that these were Roman.

name: PAS: Sanquhar 3339
comments: `A quantity of broad gold pieces:' probably not Roman. RCAHMS NS70NE (`The trench around the site of this castle is still visible. A quantity of broad gold pieces were found nearby some years before 1856. Several carved stones are built in a neighbouring dyke. Nothing, not even the name, is known of this cast

name: PAS: Corbridge 131
comments: A small mass of 8 folles found in 1912 deserves attention since this special currency, as elsewhere, is rare on this site. The latest coin not earlier than AD 309, but remainder can be all approximately dated AD 303-7. It should be observed that 1 of these 8 coins has come from Carthage, a mint not otherwise represented in Corbridge coins." H.H.E. Craster. 1915. AA (3) XII: 248.

name: PAS: Langtoft I 136
comments: 976 base-silver denarii (3), radiates (575) & large nummi (398) to Constantine I.  Detectorist find. Found a few yards away from Langtoft II. Findspot on county & parish boundary between Weaverthorpe  (N Yorks) & Cottam (E Yorks) & Langtoft (E Yorks) - reported to Yorkshire Museum. NGR from Treasure form. Pots appear to have been hit by plough & contents slightly scattered. Detectorists mentioned visible feature in field - could be Pastscape 64646 and 64631? Adjacent to High Street Roman road. Small excavation around find spot by Humber Field Archaeology (Evans 2000). Six worn Roman sherds found in the topsoil around hoard site.

name: PAS: Gloucester 219
comments: In 1958, during excavs at Bon Marche site, in masonry building with portico. The building poss an eating-house & it may well have had this status later on." ?building abandoned in the mid-4th century, but highest street-surfaces laid at a later date, perhaps after AD 375. Notable finds included part of a shale table-top, & small hoard of 20 folles of Constantine I & Licinius I found in layer of collapsed material above one of highest floors." A.G. Hunter. 1963. Trans. Bristol and Glos. Arch. Soc. 82: 27. J.P.C. Kent, ibid., 62, noted that in "layer of collapse over Floor 71, north of wall 3" there was "a small hoard of 20 coins of Constantine I and Licinius I, found closely corroded together, as if once been in a container. 20 folles in Glouc City Museum.

name: PAS: Caerwent (House XVI N, Basilica) 426
comments: In Room 3 of House XVI N, c. 6 inches above floor level 39 coins found, ant. & small AE. T. Ashby. 1906-7. Archaeologia 60: 129. House XVI N now interpreted as the Basilica.

name: PAS: Bradley Hill 446
comments: "During excavation of R-B settlement & cemetery, on Bradley Hill, Somerton, small hoard of 9 coins found in a pot buried with a sheep's skull in a pit cut through paved floor of Building I, Room 2. (Similar to a pit with a sheep?s skull in it below a floor at Catsgore, Leach 1982). The paved floor itself sealed a coin of c. 323-4. The container was a jar of a hard grey sandy fabric, with outcurving rim. E.M. Besly, in Britannia, XII (1981), 208, 210, types, mints; 240, fig. 21, 23, and 241 for pot. 9 coins in Somerset Museum, Taunton.

name: PAS: Clapton-In-Gordano 447
comments: "In autumn 1922 during ploughing, 28 Roman coins from AD 260-273 unearthed in field at Clapton-in-Gordano, near Clevedon. No further search made until July 1924, when Mr R.E. Godwin, to whose notice find had been brought, returned to locality. The same man who had ploughed up the coins, pointed out Spot where, to best of his recollection, they were discovered. ?at some little distance Godwin found 12 more coins on surface within a radius of several yards. Digging with a spade yielded occasional coins, & then earth full of coins, & finally bulk of the hoard at about a foot below the surface. 'These appear to have been in a wooden vessel, hooped with iron at the base... Also directly under the coins were two frags of wood, part of the bottom of the vessel. Coins appear to have been first wrapped in skin, as pieces of this had impressions of the coins. The whole stood on two flat pieces of sandstone. Broken pieces of a shallow black earthenware dish also found, put on the whole upside down to form the lid. Further digging within a few yards revealed a rough stone floor with broken pieces of pottery, coins, animal bones, two bronze brooches, and spindle whorls. Evidence of iron smelting everywhere, field under the shadow of Cadbury Camp." JRS, XIV (1924), 234, gave a slightly different account: "They had been put in a leather bag & that in a black urn devoid of a base but bound by an iron hoop and resting on a piece of wood supported by two stones. One of the two bronze fibulae was of a "4th-century type of oval shape with a conical centre." H. Symonds, in Proc. Somerset Arch. and Nat. Hist. Soc., 73 (1927), 127 noted: "At a later date, the hoard was arranged for exhibition in church room of Pill, a neighbouring village." 109 coins in Somerset County Museum, along with remains of leather bag and wooden container. Other 118 coins in Hull City Museum. Bulk of the hoard remained in hands of the finder." N.B. 3,250 coins sold to Nicholson Museum in Sydney in 1949.

name: PAS: Caister By Yarmouth 448
comments: During excav. of building near S gate, c. 1,000 ft. W of East Caister Church", & beyond, 11 small coin hoards discovered. The building interpreted as a seamen's hotel or lodging house. 7 small coin hoards found in it. More building debris, ditches, & pits contained bone and antler points, with R-B & Saxon pottery & 2 more late coin hoards, discovered in a trial trench cut northwards and uphill towards centre of the small town. C. Green. 1953. JRS 43: 122. There were also two pre-Constantinian hoards. The earlier of the two had 1 sest. & 15 ant. Darling, M.J. & Gurney, D.. 1993. Caister-on-Sea Excavations by Charles Green 1951-55. East Anglian Archaeology.

name: PAS: Sewing Shields 539
comments: Scattered hoard of cu alloy coins found inside Milecastle 35 on Hadrian's Wall during DoE excavs in 1978-80. M.F. Sekulla (unpublished) (pers. comm. from M. Savage.

name: PAS: Springhead 540
comments: "hoard discovered during excav. at R-B site of Vagniacis by Director S. Harker. It was buried within temple temenos in backfill of otherwise featureless pit, in area of open ground between a drainage ditch & path parallel to R 4. There was no indication of a container, & shape of coin mass suggested a cloth or leather bag. The hoard was wedged next to a very large flint, which could have aided recovery. It is also possible that hoard buried in relation to adjacent buildings, as Temples II and V (B4 and B7) are close & building rubble appears under nearby railway embankment. One coin from mint at Siscia is dated to 310/311 and closely corresponds with the likely date for deposition. P. W. Green. 1987. CHRB 7, BM Occas. Paper 59 (1987), 1-26. The hoard consisted of 2 ant., 647 Tetrarchic & Constantinian folles, 5 fractions, making a total of 654.

name: PAS: Catsgore 541
comments: E.M. Besly listed the 13 coins, in R. Leach, Excavations at Catsgore (1982) 101, 103.

name: PAS: Haddenham, Upper Delphs II 542
comments: 8 coins of AD 310-317, an unusual group Reece considers a small hoard, &/or from a purse.

name: PAS: Milton Keynes 1321
comments: 53 bronze nummi to AD 317

name: PAS: Prestwood B 1323
comments: 733 nummi and one radiate to 317 and pot. Yarrow (2009, p.237) writes: "Mr D. Valverde discovered this hoard on 18 July 1999 in a Buckinghamshire field while on a metal detecting club outing.On the same day in the same field a hoard of denarii was also found, the 'Prestwood A' hoard (CHRB XI, pp.163-168).2 Anumber of potsherds were associated with the find. The area has yielded no previous archaeological finds; the topographycan be described as a relatively isolated upland area a few kilometres from known settlements and roads of the Roman period. The hoard was declared treasure at an inquest at High Wycombe on 20 January 2000 and acquired by Buckinghamshire County Museum. There is a partial photographic record of this hoard at the British Museum."

name: PAS: Goodnestone I 1324
comments: 9 nummi and 1 half-nummus to AD 316. Selected from a group of 644 site finds as a possible hoard, scattered over an area of 50m2. TAR 2001, 193; NC 2002, 21.

name: PAS: Kelling 1325
comments: 1 radiate of Carausius and 20 nummi to 313. NC 2005, 43.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2004 T334HER record suggests that 12 coins from AD 307 to 310/313 were reported in 1993 and that the later batch should be considered addenda to these. No record of these earlier coins at the BM but the HER has a list (not consulted).

name: PAS: Bury St Edmunds Area 1326
comments: 13 nummi to 313. Addenda of 1 nummus of Maximian. NC 2005, 42. Addendum of 1 nummus 2014.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2004 T395; 2006 T068; 2014T391

name: PAS: Wold Newton 1327
comments: IARCH record for a hoard of 1856 nummi and 1 radiate found in a pottery container. Further ceramic sherds and a glass bead were reported with the find. The latter was found inside the pot. Sherds of a dish appears to have formed a lid to the pot but the objects are still being studied. Details of coins from unpublished catalogue by V. Drost.

name: PAS: Barking 1328
comments: 56 nummi to 313 - purse hoard? PATAR 2007, 500; NC 2008, 28.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2007 T142Other PAS records associated with this hoard: SF-2278D4

name: PAS: Paulerspury 1339
comments: Robertson 2000,  243 no. 1004:""About twenty years ago, several medals of Constantine, Maximin, and other Roman emperors were found in an urn, in digging the common field."-J. Bridges, Hist. and Ant. of Northants., ed. Whalley (1791), I, 314-These coins were probably all folles."Many Roman coins have also been found in ploughing in Paul's Perry fields, particularly a Constantine 'Soli Invicto Comiti'."-J. Morton, Nat. Hist. and Ant. of Northants. (1712), 531-If these two passages referred to the same find, it must have been discovered before 1712."

name: PAS: Chilton Polden 1342
comments: Robertson 2000, 262 no. 1096:""On August 7th, 1868, a small hoard of coins, chiefly Constantine I and II, was found in the peat diggings about two miles distant from the potteries."-A. Bulleid, 26 March 1914, in PSA, (2), XXVI (1913-14), 143-The coins were probably small AE."Placed in Shapwick parish by Minnitt 2007, 729 (recorded as being found "in the Turbary at Shapwick".

name: PAS: Burton On The Wolds 1343
comments: Robertson 2000,  243 no. 1001:""About two years ago [i.e. before 1804], a large quantity of Roman copper coins were found in a field belonging to Mr. John Shuttlewood of Walton, situate about one mile from Cotes Hall and about two miles from Walton; which are now in the possession of Mr. Adams, junior, bookseller at Loughborough; which must in general have been in high preservation when deposited in the earth, as they do not appear to have been much injured by currency; and even now, in their present state of decomposition, almost all of them are legible, and many of them are very fine; but they are in general common and obvious. One of them, however, of Severus Caesar, with the title of Augustus, appears seasonably in aid, to support the tottering credit of Goltzius, from whose time no mention has been made of it, except by Harduin, likewise under suspicion, to this day."Then came a list of 214 folles:FollesDiocletian 35Maximian 73Constantius I, Caes., Aug. 27Constantius I (deified) 5Severus II, Caes., Aug. 4Maximinus Daza, Caes. (?) 6Constantine I, Caes. (or Aug.?) 64214-J. Nichols, Hist. and Ant. of Co. of Leics.., III.2 (1804), 1136, rev. types"

name: PAS: Quedgeley 1348
comments: Robertson 2000, 410 no. 1647A:""Olympus Business Park: a fourth-century coin hoard associated with a (?) wooden box was recovered by metal detector".Britannia, XIX (1988), 4694th century AD"

name: PAS: Doncaster 1349
comments: "A Roman aes of Constantine 1 (AD 307-337)and a follio of Severus 2 (AD 306-7) were found in an electricity trench at the junction of Copley Road and Christchurch Road, with six others corroded to powder" YAJ 42 1969 252.

name: PAS: Brightwell 1372
comments: Robertson 2000, 222 no. 907:""I have the following Roman coins, found in the garden of Slade End Farm at Brightwell:- Tetricus, Quintillus, Constantius Chlorus, Allectus, all small brass."-P. Manning, in Berks. Bucks. and Oxon. A.J., IV (1898-9), 44"

name: PAS: Wroxton 1639
comments: Robertson 2000, 248 no. 1022:""In the spring of 1950 mechanical diggers belonging to the Oxford-shire Ironstone Co., Ltd., were removing topsoil to expose ironstone strata near Rignall House, Wroxton. After a Sunday of heavy rain Mr. J. Eadon, an employee of the company, discovered a hoard of Roman coins lying in a small pocket of earth. A scatter of Roman pottery and burnt ironstone for several hundred yards round the site of the hoard suggests that there might have been some sort of settlement there. No pottery, however, was found with the hoard, which may therefore have been buried in a piece of cloth.Altogether 136 coins were handed over to Mr. A. Mackay, a director of the Company, who kindly arranged, after consultation with Trinity College, Oxford (the owner of the land), that the hoard should be deposited for examination in the Ashmolean Museum. Since then Trinity College has allowed the hoard to remain on permanent loan in the Ashmolean."The 136 coins recovered were 3 ant. and 133 folles:Ant FollesTacitus 1Probus 2Diocletian 3Maximian 16Constantius I, Caes. 7Constantius I (deified) 2Galerius, Caes. 9Galerius, Aug. 2Severus II, Caes. 2Maximinus Daza, Caes. 1Maximinus Daza, Aug. 2Maxentius 2Constantine I, Caes. 5Constantine I, Aug. 66Licinius I 163 133"The date of burial is approximately established by the two Arelate coins of c. AD 315-16 and 316 respectively."-C.H.V. Sutherland, in NC, 1954, 62-7, types, mints-32 coins now in the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford98 coins in the Banbury Museum."

name: PAS: Walton 1640
comments: Robertson 2000, 246 no. 1013A:"The hoard was discovered by a group of four metal detector users [...] on a building site at Walton, within the area of Milton Keynes New Town, in late 1987. The coins were found scattered over an area of several square yards and there was no trace of any container; it is likely that the coins recorded here do not constitute the whole hoard. The Milton Keynes Archaeology Unit has discovered evidence of Roman occupation from two separate sites respectively within 300-400 yards and [within] half a mile of the hoard's find spot."

name: PAS: Whitburn 1752
comments: Robertson 2000, 247 no. 1017:""He [i.e. Dr. Smart at Brigg] says that, when he was a boy about sixteen years old, as he and some more of his companions were playing and casting handfulls of sand one at another, some of them grasped three or four old coins amongst the sand, and looking further, they found a peckful hid in the sand hill.They were all Roman emperors, and as fresh as if they were new coins, being all of brass or mixt mettal, and about the bigness of half crowns. The town's name, where they were found, is Whitburn."-From the Diary of Abraham de la Pryme (1672-1704) (ed. Surtees Soc., vol. 54) (1869), 112-This must be the hoard referred to in W. Hutchinson, Hist. of Durham (1787), II, 499 n.:"Several copper coins have been found at this place [i.e. Whitburn] of which the most were Constantine's, with the sun on the reverse and these words SOLI INVICTO COMITI. One of them was Maxentius with something like a triumphal arch on the reverse and these words CONSERVATORI VRBIS. There were also one or two of Licinius's and as many of Maximianus's.""

name: PAS: Cliviger (Dyer Wood) 1770
comments: Robertson 2000, 247 no. 1018:""About the Year 1764 in clearing away an Heap of Rubbish, a Countryman discovered near Barcroft in the Township of Cliviger, and about half a Mile from Mereclough, where the fine Collection of Consular Medals was turned up [no. 109], a Glass Vessel full of the small Brass of Constantine the Great and Licinius."-T.D. Whitaker, in Ralph Thoresby, Museum Thoresbyanum (= pt.2 of Ducatus Leodiensis), 2 ed. (1816), 1 n.-W. T. Watkin, Roman Lancashire (1883), 232, following a Ms. account in the Manchester Courier, 18 Aug. 1876, described this find as follows:"In June, 1761, a hoard of about 200 coins, chiefly of the time of Constantine the Great, and his sons, were found in a field called the 'Low House Wood', at the Dyer Wood, between Barcroft and Overtown, about two miles from Burnley, on the estate of Mr. Peter Ormerod, of Ormerod. This spot is close to the 'Long Causeway' and also to the site of the Mereclough discovery of 1695 [no. 109]. It is not said of what metal the coins were, but they appear to have been third brass. A description of only five has been preserved.":The coins were all folles:AEMaximinus Daza 1Constantine I, Aug. 3Licinius I 15The description of these coins shows that they were all folles.The 2 of Maximinus Daza and Licinius I had rev. GENIO POP ROM, mint Trier. The 3 of Constantine I, Aug. had revs. MARTI CONSERVATORI, SOLI INVICTO COMITI, mint Trier, and S P Q R OPTIMO PRINCIPI, mint Ostia. All 5 coins were of c. AD 310-13."

name: PAS: Monmouth 1771
comments: Robertson 2000, 249 no. 1025:"11 Dec. 1728"Mr. Smart Lethieullier brought 5 Roman Coins which were found 14 Sep., 1728. In the Town of Monmouth in an Earthen Vessel which contain'd near 2000 Coins of the Empr. Constantine Maximinus and Licinius, of the small brass, all perfectly preserv'd and with the following Inscrip:-1. Imp: Constantinus P F Aug Rv. Soli Invicto Comiti S FExerg. PLN2. Rv. Concord Milit3. Rv. Marti Conservatori4. Imp: Maximinus P F Aug Rv. Genio Pop Rom.-5. Imp: Licinius P F Aug Rv. Genio Pop Rom.-Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., I (1717-32), 228, types"

name: PAS: Llangwstenin 1772
comments: Robertson 2000, 244 no. 1006:""Two Constantinian coins from ? LlangystenninIn an envelope labelled '2 Const. coins E Wynne Eglwysbach' are two early fourth-century bronze coins with the following letter:'Caldy Cottage,Pontypant,Nr. Dolwyddelen9.5.22Sir,having two coins in good preservation with inscriptions IMP CONSTANTINVS PALIC [sic] on one + FL VAI. CONSTANTINVS NO BC [sic] on the other his Rev. Richards of Dolwyddelen asked me to write to you + to use his name stating you very likely would purchase them as they are so old & if so I could give you a call if convenient tomorrow or day after I shall be at Henfryn Trevor Street Llandudno tomorrow or day afterYours respectfullyE. Wynne' In Dr. Gardner's hand is pencilled: 'Given to me by E. W. in exchange for 2 v. fine L/Orme examples & my Pamphlet'; a further few words to one side of the signature read 'late Station master P.y.P. (Pont y pant)'. A note also in Dr. Gardner's hand on a slip of paper reads:'2 coins from E Wynne found by his father (living at Eglwys Bach) when stubbing up a tree nr (?) LlangwytCh (Llangystennin Church?); part of a quantity.'Here the corner of the paper has been torn off with any words which might have been there. It seems highly likely that they were part of a hoard which appears to be hitherto unrecorded. The coins which show only a slight degree of wear are:"FollesConstantine I, Caes. 1Constantine I, Aug. 1(MARTI PATRI CONSERVATORI S APTR(SOLI INVICTO COMITI T FPLN-Glenys Lloyd-Morgan, in BBCS, XXX (1982-3), 425, types, mints"

name: PAS: Portchester Castle 1773
comments: Robertson 2000, 243 no. 999:""I here send you the Head and Reverse of a Medal or Coin of the Emperor Maximin (as Plate).This ancient Coin or Medal was lately dug up, with many more, in a garden at Portchester."-A.W. in Gent. Mag., 1777, 313, and pl. showing that the rev. bore the GENIO POP ROM legend and type-There was, in the possession of Miss Olive Lloyd Baker, in Gloucestershire, a follis of Constantine I, Aug., (rev. SOLI INVICTO COMITI, with mintmark T/F, accompanied by the following note PLNaddressed to Archdeacon T. Sharp (1693-1758):"Dear Brother,The inclosed Medal was given me this day by the Rev. Mr. Jonathan Rashleigh of Wickham near Portsmouth as a Curiosity only on account of the fine preservation. An urn full of coins of which this was one was lately found at Porchester Castle by a man who was digging under an apple tree. He is well satisfied that the coin is genuine as he knows all the persons into whose hands they fell."This letter must refer to the same hoard as that mentioned by A.W. in Gent. Mag., 1777, 313. The hoard must therefore have been found before 1758.Letter, Dec. 1949, from H. de S. Shortt, Salisbury and S. Wilts. Museum"

name: PAS: Wells 1774
comments: Robertson 2000, 1003: " "I am told that many years ago a great number of Roman coins were found in the sand on the sea shore near Wells in Norfolk: enough it is said were discovered to fill a peck measure., One of them, belonging to Mr. Warren of Ixworth in Suffolk, reads DIVO CONSTANTIO PIO / MEMORIA FELIX[PTR], second brass. There were many coins of Maximianus. A Constantine in second brass reads MARTI PATRI PROPVGNATORI. A third brass Constantine reads SOLI INVICTO COMITI".-Letter from G. J. Chester, 11 April 1849-Quoted in Norfolk Arch., III (1852), 421"

name: PAS: Bryn Euryn 1775
comments: Robertson 2000, 254 no. 1069:""A hoard of Roman coins, contained in an earthenware vessel, was discovered about 1902 by Mr. William Owenand Mr. John Hugheswhile digging for gravel (shale) for the parapets of local roads on the rock, a few score yards to the S. of the ruins of Llys Euryn, which are ¼ m. S.S.E. a quarter of a mile south-south-east of the parish church. Owen's pick went into the vessel which was in a small hole about a foot deep made in the shale rock. The site has now some years been quarried away. The rock belongs to the Cayley Estate.Urn The vesselwas about 6 in. high and about 3 in. across the base. It had two handles near the top, and was glazed black to within 2 in. or so of the bottom. It broke in pieces, and no fragments were preserved so far as Owen knew.Coins These practically filled the jar. The bulk, so the writer was informed, got into the possession of the late Mr. Rowland Williams, of Hafryn, under whom Owen and Hughes worked. Owen himself also and others had a few. The writer's endeavours in 1925 to trace specimens signally failed. Dr. Willoughby Gardner, F.S.A. who was able, some years ago, to examine six of the coins, found them to be third brasses of Constantine the Great (310-15 A.D.)."-Canon Ellis Davies, Prehistoric and Roman Remains of Denbighs. (1929), 198Including Constantine I"

name: PAS: Kirkandrews 1776
comments: Robertson 2000, 243 no. 998:""Coins of Constantine and Diocletian found 1785, 750 yards N. of Cobble Hall."-W.G. Collingwood, in TCWAAS, n.s., XXIII (1923), 235-The coins were probably AE (folles?)"

name: PAS: Ash And Normandy 2043
comments: Robertson 2000, 246 no. 1012:""In the year 1904, at Manor Nurseries, Normandy, near Guildford, in a stream which runs through the garden, one of Mr. W. F. Field's children found a small urn, containing over one hundred Roman coins. The urn was broken but fragments have been preserved."The coins were all folles:FollesDiocletian 18Diocletian and Maximian 1Maximian 17Constantius I 14Galerius 14Severus II 3Maximinus Daza, Caes. 4Constantine I, Caes. 8Constantine I, Aug. 33 Licinius I 3115(1 Aug., 1 deified)(1 Aug.)(18 of AD 313-17)The pot was small and squat, 4½ in. high, and 5½ in. in diam., with a slightly everted lip, and girth groove on shoulder.-Mill Stephenson, in Surrey Arch. Coll., XXIX (1916), 49-58, types, fig. of pot-Pot and 115 coins in Guildford MuseumExamined, 1960 (ASR)"

name: PAS: near York 2044
comments: Robertson 2000, 248 no. 1023:""I have made it my business to enquire after Roman coins, medals and inscription which have been found about York or Aldbury. I have got above 100 copper coins which were digged up near York, of which there are 75 of Constantine, and 16 several designs on the reverse. There are 4 of Constantius, 3 of Maximianus, 1 of Magnentius, 5 of Maximinus, 1 of Maxentius, and 6 of Licinius; besides 2 which I cannot read. I have taken 16 of the fairest of Constantine, which contain all the several varietys on the reverse, and 1 a piece [sic] of the fairest of the rest, so that I have 24 fair coins, all several, which if you think convenient I can send you. I have a promise from Lawyer Hildyard (the only antiquary about York) to see what he has collected, which I shall do when I go next to York." -Letter from Noah Hodgson, Shipton, to Roger Gale, 21 April 1692-Quoted in W. Stukeley, Family Memoirs, III (ed. Surtees Soc., vol.80) (1885), 287, 289f., types, some mintsThe types given included 1 of Constantius I (deified), rev. MEMORIA FELIX, altar flanked by two eagles; 1 of Galeria Valeria; and 1 of Magnentius, rev. SALVS DD NN AVG ET CAES. It seems likely that the coin of Magnentius was an intruder."

name: PAS: Brough 2205
comments: Robertson 2000, 204 no. 836:"An aureus of Maximian, minted in AD 293, declared Treasure Trove.Inf., 1988, from A.M. Burnett"A single gold coin was discovered on 12 January 1986 in a field at Little Danethorpe Farm, Brough, in Nottinghamshire, just outside the Roman settlement of Crococolana. There was no trace of the container. The coin was declared Treasure Trove at an Inquest held on 18 September 1986, and has subsequently been acquired by the British Museum (accession no. 1986-12-25-1).The coin was minted in the name of Maximian at Rome. Although the reverse type is known, it does not seem to have been recorded with this mint mark, PR, rather than PROM.Obv. MAXIMI-ANVS P F AVG; laureate head, r.Rev. HERCVLI D-EdrumT, PR; Hercules killing the Lernaean hydra with a club.Weight: 5.06g. Axis 12. Pl. 39The coin does not appear in either RIC V or VI, but the reverse can be found with the mint mark PROM in the listing by K. Pink, 'Die Goldpragung des Diocletianus und seiner Mitregenten', Numismatische Zeitschrift 1931, p. 21. Following Pink's chronology, the coin would date to about AD 293.-A. M. Burnett, in CHRB VIII (1988), 216, type, mint, wt., axis, photo of coinThe coin is in the dept. of Coins and Medals, BM (Register of Coin Accessions, 1986-12-25-1)"

name: PAS: Yate 2206
comments: 732 radiates to AD 287.

name: PAS: St. Albans 2207
comments: Robertson 2000,203 no. 833: ""Among the curiosities collected by the late Ebenezer Mussel, esq., sold at Langford's in the spring of 1765, was a beautiful little vase, in the form of a cup, of whitish earth, full of coins of the lower emperors."-R. Gough, British Topography (1780), I, 423-The vase and coins appeared in the Catalogue of Ebenezer Mussell's Collection, sold at Langford and Son, on 5 and 6 June 1765 (photocopy provided by R. Bland, Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM, July 1987). Lot 19 was:"A small embossed earthen urn full of small Roman coins found at Verulam in 1749, and 6 Roman sepulchral lamps."A Ms. Appendix by Emanuel Mendes da Costa stated that the urn contained 345 coins, listed as follows:Ant. AEValerian I 1Gallienus 1Claudius II 1Aurelian 64Tacitus 12Florian 1Probus 185Carus 2Numerian 2Carinus 4Diocletian 49Maximian 21Magnentius 1Valens 1343 2It seems likely that the hoard was of antoniniani only, the 2 AE coins of Magnentius and Valens being probably intruders."

name: PAS: Tickenham 2208
comments: Robertson 2000, 205 no. 839:""About a mile and a half further westward, under the same ridge of hill, another discovery of Roman coins was made, Feb' 1, 1821. They were found in a ditch by the side of a coppice belonging to James Gordon, Esq. in the parish of Tickenham, near the land called Limebrock; it is about half a mile from Cadbury Camp; and many old foundations of buildings at different times have been discovered on this spot. I saw two parcels, one of 96 coins, the other of 72, chiefly brass, some few were washed with silver, all of small size, and of the lower empire. I examined the following:"Gallienus 2Salonina 1Victorinus 1Claudius II 1Quintillus 1Severina 1Tacitus 1Probus 2Carinus 1Diocletian 1Maximian 113(IOVI CONSERVATORI)(FELICITAS PVBLICA)-S. Seyer, Memoirs of Bristol (1821), I, 162, a few types-These 13 coins were probably all ant."

name: PAS: Llysfaen 2209
comments: Robertson 2000, 238 no. 985:""A farmer seeking lost sheep picked up what appeared to him an old button, which upon examination proved to be a penny of the Roman Empire. Upon making further search, a large number of such pieces were picked up, some bearing traces of inscriptions but many so corroded as to present no trace of any impression. The writer went to the spot and having turned up the sod with a spade found a coin nearly as large as an English penny piece. It was in a remarkably good state of preservation and bore a very excellent profile of the emperor Maximianus."-From Humphrey Rector's book-Quoted by Canon Ellis Davies, Prehistoric and Roman Remains of Denbighs. (1929), 375Canon Davies described the coin from Humphrey's impression as obv. MAXIMIANVS NOB CRTS [sic]rev. GENIO POPV ROMANI; exergue, REBBCS, I (1921-3), 349, gave the date of discovery as 1856, and described the find as "a considerable hoard of denarii or antoninianifound at Pentregwyddel: a great many were of Maximianus."Including "Maximian" (i.e. Galerius, Caes.)"

name: PAS: Sparkford 2210
comments: Robertson 2000, 232 no. 944:""The date and circumstances of discovery are unknown, but the hoard is said to have been found in 1973 in the Sparkford area. The 191 coins described below are thought to comprise around half of the hoard; they were examined by courtesy of a local dealer and have since been dispersed."The 191 coins were all ant.:Ant.Gallienus (sole reign) 57Salonina (sole reign) 4Claudius II 51Quintillus 4Tetricus I 6Tetricus II 4Aurelian 9Tacitus 4Probus 15Carinus, Aug. 1Diocletian 2Maximian 10uncertain radiates 24191(1 obv. brockage; 1 deified, b.?)(1 hybrid/Claudius II)(1 struck by Carausius)(1 of c. AD 294) (b.)-E.M. Besly, in CHRB II, BM Occas. Paper 31 (1981), 63-8, obv. and rev. legends, types, mints"

name: PAS: Cheddar 2212
comments: Robertson 2000, 209 no. 859:""Mr. Chaffers exhibited a parcel of Roman coins, recently found by a labourer while ploughing in a field at Cheddar, near Bristol: 'Some of the reverses', Mr. Chaffers observes, 'are rare, among which are those of Diocletian and Maximian with PAX AVGGG'.The following is a complete list of the coins exhibited."Then came a list of 99 ant. from Gallienus to Diocletian and Maximian.-JBAA, II (1847), 270f., types-In 1902, Somerset County Museum, Taunton acquired 74 ant. from this hoard. The two lists, of 99 and 74 ant., are:Ant. Ant.Gallienus (sole reign) 1Salonina (sole reign) 1Claudius II 2 2Aurelian 7 6Severina 1 1Tacitus 20 16Probus 36 27Carus 1Carinus 2Magnia Urbica 1Numerian 1Diocletian 17 14Maximian 12 599 74(3 with PAX AVGGG)(3 struck by Carausius with PAX AVGGG; S/P (2), S/PMLXXI C )(4 with PAX AVGGG)(2 struck by Carausius with PAX AVGGG; S/P: PROVID AVGGG; S/PMLXXI C )Examined, 1978 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Lincoln 2525
comments: Robertson 2000, 236 no. 978:""At this point it is worth looking more closely at the diagram of the Museums' coins. Two erratics must be considered: the first is an apparent hoard of folles, c. 294-307, which are obvious in the figures, and which a careful inspection might weed out."Jenny E. Mann and R. Reece, Roman Coins from Lincoln 1970-1979 (1983), 70"

name: PAS: South Shields 2526
comments: Robertson 2000, 238 no. 986:"Among "coins discovered within and near the Roman camp [sic] at South Shields (1874-1884) which have passed through the hands of R. Blair", P.J. Casey has isolated and identified two probable hoards [nos. 1103, 1342], and this one possible hoard:"(c) It is considered that the thirteen [sic] western mint, early tetrarchic coins purchased by Clapham constitutes the whole, or part of a further hoard [see nos. 1103, 1342]."These were:AEDiocletian 4Maximian 1Maximinus Daza, Aug. 1uncertain Tetrarchic 612(1 of AD 305-7)P.J. name: PAS: Mickleham 2527
comments: Record from Guildford Museum (noted on Pastscape) of a find of 9 nummi "of Diocletian, Maximian and Constatius I, dating overall AD 286-310" found as a group. A report on the coins is held by Guildford Museum (not consulted).

name: PAS: Bembridge 2529
comments: Three coins found together by a detectorist and recorded by M. Lyne. Details from HER.

name: PAS: Chipperfield 2530
comments: Robertson 2000, 239 no. 989: " "This small hoard of sixty-seven folles was found in three batches in April-May, 1972 close to a pathway in Scatterdell Woodlands, Chipperfield.The first batch of thirty coins was discovered on 28 April by Mr. C.G. Fakes using a metal-detector and a subsequent search by him on 1 May produced a further thirteen coins, and still later another five coins. A later search on 30 May by Mr. J.W. Condon, also using detecting equipment turned up a third lot of nineteen coins.Although no container was found and the coins were dispersed singly or in pairs, the consistency of patination and the coherence of the group, both as regards chronology and mints, strongly suggested that the coins had originally formed a hoard which had become scattered in the course of time..The coins cover the period from the first issues of the First Tetrarchy in AD 294 down to the issues of Constantine I as Caesar between AD 306 and 307."Then came a list of the coins:London Trier Lyons Ticinum Rome Carthage UncertainTOTALDiocletian 3 1 1 5Maximian 15 1 5 1 1 23Constantius I, Caes. 3 4 4 2 13Constantius I, Caes. (?) 1 1Constantius I, Aug. 1 1 2Galerius, Caes. 4 3 3 1 11Maximinus Daza, Caes. 1 1 2Constantine I, Caes. 9 1 10RULE33 14 13 1 2 1 3 67R.A.G. Carson, in NC, 1974, 182-4, mints, types"

name: PAS: Cliburn 2531
comments: Robertson 2000, 240 no. 992:""In 1984, a hoard of tetrarchic folles was recovered from the grounds of Shaw Hall, Cliburn (precise reference lodged with Carlisle Museum and Art Gallery). The 62 coins, which were mostly in good condition, were recovered with fragments of a black cooking-pot (see below). The range of the hoard is from AD 294 to a SOLI INVICTO COMITI issue of AD 310-313; this is a not uncommon hoarding-period..The bulk of the present coins are issues of the London, Trier, and Lyons mints, with a few issues from Rome, Ticinum, Aquileia, and Carthage. The nearest comparable hoard is that from Kirksteads, Carlisle [no. 998]."The 62 coins were listed according to mints and types. Rearranged according to emperors and mints they were:London Trier Lyons Ticinum Rome Aquileia CarthageTOTALDiocletian 3 11 1 15Maximian 11 1 2 1 1 16Constantius I, Caes. 3 5 1 1 1 11Constantius I, Aug. 1 1 2Constantius I (deified) 2 1 3Galerius, Caes. 3 3 1 1 8Maximinus Daza, Caes. 1 1Constantine I, Caes. 3 2 5Constantine I, Aug. 1 1RULE24 25 7 1 3 1 1 62(of AD 310-13)-D.C.A. Shotter, in TCWAAS, n.s., 86 (1986), 250-5, mints, types-"Fifteen sherds were recovered from a pot which was presumably the container. These allow the certain restoration in drawing of the profile and decoration of the vessel up to a height of 14.5 cm. This, in turn, permits the conjectural restoration of the whole vessel.The pot was made in a smooth pale grey fabric which today can be seen only in a few modern breaks and chips. Otherwise, all surfaces, including those of fractures, have been stained brownish by the soil conditions. This fact indicates that the pot was broken long ago, as is also suggested by the survival of no more than perhaps 20% of the vessel. The outer surface of the pot was smoothed by the potter with the exception of a horizontal zone commencing 6.0 cm. up from the base and 7.0 cm. wide. The zone was defined at its upper edge by a tooled line, and vertical lines were made with the same tool down the untreated zone. Form, fabric and decoration all agree in suggesting that the pot approximated to Gillam's Types 40 and 41 and the drawing restoration has been completed on that basis. The date range of those two types (AD 290-400) conforms to the deposition date of the hoard.The vessels illustrated by Gillam are Crambeck types, more likely to be found west of the Pennines after c. AD 350."-B.J.N. Edwards (ibid.), 251, pot drawn"

name: PAS: Weybridge 2532
comments: Robertson 2000, 238 no. 984:""On Whitsun Monday, May 20, 1907, the workmen engaged in making the Brooklands Motor-Track discovered, about two feet six inches below the surface, and broke with the pick, an earthenware jar containing a number of bronze coins. The exact number will probably never be known, for there was a scramble for the contents of the jar."There were at least 140 coins, of which 137, all folles, were:FollesDiocletian 44Maximian 30Constantius I, Caes. 31Galerius, Caes. 32137The date of discovery has been given variously as 20 May (as above), 21 May and 8 June.-(Sir) George Hill, in NC, 1908, 208-15-Also in Surrey Arch. Coll., XXII (1908), 184-91, both with types, mints, pl. of coinsVCH Surrey, IV (1912), 370, followed NC, loc. cit., but miscounted the numbers of coins attributable to each emperor, giving 45 to Diocletian, 28 to Maximian, 32 to Constantius I, and 32 to Galerius.In Weybridge Museum, 28 folles out of a total of 39 from this hoard, were presented soon after 1909. Some were believed by the former Honorary Curator, Mrs. D. Grenside, not to have been seen and described when the above list was made, but it is not now possible to say which should be regarded as additions.Examined, 1958 (ASR)74 folles in Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM (BM Register of Coin Accessions, July 1907, Oct. 1907, and Sept. 1917)Examined, 1948 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Downside 2535
comments: Robertson 2000, 245-246 no. 1011A:""The hoard was discovered on 14 August 1987 ... in a field to the north of Downside Abbey, Stratton on the Fosse. The site lies approximately 400 metres to the west of the Fosse Way in an area that has produced other Romano-British material. An aerial photograph held by Somerset County Planning Department which was taken in 1971 shows a rectangular enclosure of uncertain date immediately to the south east of the find spot"538 bronze nummi to AD 316.

name: PAS: Taynton 2536
comments: 50 nummi to 317; addenda: 98 base-silver nummi to AD 317 found together with a possibly Roman silver finger-ring; second addenda: 22 nummi to 317. Note there must be a strong possibility that the ring is not Roman, and not connected with the coin hoard. TAR 1997-98, 308; NC 2000, 35.Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2004 T168

name: PAS: East Holme 2537
comments: "The East Holme hoard of 151 post-reform nummi was found on 25 September 1988 by S J Dereham while using a metal detector in a field on the south-west side of the village. Some pottery fragments were also recovered. The pottery fragments and coins were taken to the Dorset County Museum and were subsequently sent to the Ashmolean Museum for classification and cataloguing. The coins were heavily encrusted with a greenish deposit which made them virtually impossible to identify initially. They were subjected to a minimal cleaning treatment which rendered all but two of them legible but left most of the encrustation on the coins.The pottery fragments were examined by Paul Both of the Oxfordshire Archaeological Unit who identified them as black burnished ware produced locally between the first and fourth centuries AD. Many pieces formed part of the same vessel of cooking pot form which, unfortunately, could not be more clearly dated in the absence of its rim. It seems quite likely that the hoard was originally deposited in this pot even though the breaks did not look recent...Composition of the hoard (Table 1)The coins consist of post-reform Tetrarchic folles minted between c. 295 and 310. Forty per cent were minted between 295 and 305, c. 22.4% between 305 and 307 and c. 36% between 307 and 310. The dominant mint is London with 37% of the total, but Trier produced 31% and Lyon c. 18% while the central mints produced c. 12% and the Eastern mints less than 1%. Two coins were illegible...The latest coins in the find occur after the weight reduction of the follis of 1/48th of the Roman pound (giving an average weight if c. 6.77g) which took place at the end of 307 and before the weight reduction to 1/72nd in 310. Thus it seems reasonable to suggest that the hoard was deposited during the course of 308 of 309.:FollesLondon Trier Lyons Ticinum Rome Aquileia Carthage Siscia 0Cyzicus 1uncertainDiocletian 5 9 1 1 1 1 1 01 1Maximian 14 9 5 4 3 1 1 0 11Constantius I Caes. 5 3 6 1 0 1Constantius I Aug. 1Constantius I deified 1 2 1Galerius Caes. 3 5 5 1 1Galerius, Aug. 5 1 0 11Severus II 4 2 3 1Maximinus Daza 5 1 1Constantine I Caes. 13 4 3Constantine I Aug. 4 5 1Uncertain 2* 1 156 47 27 7 5 1 3 2 01 12* 1 of AD307-10Cathy E King, in CHRB IX (1992), 217-25, types, mints, wts.

name: PAS: Upavon 2538
comments: Robertson 2000, 237 no. 981:""The Upavon hoard was found in June 1980 by Peter Stephens, on Upavon Hill in the parish of Upavon, which lies on the northern edge of Salisbury Plain, approximately eight miles north of the small Wiltshire town of Amesbury. The findspotlies just to the north of an extensive 'Celtic' field system, presumed to be of Iron Age or Romano-British date [...] (Wilts. Sites and Monuments Record no. SU 15 NW 610). Part of the field system is scheduled as an Ancient Monument (no. Wilts. 738). Apart from the hoard, the finder found in the same area forty other coins (an Ancient British gold stater, type Mack 62= British Mb, and thirty-nine Roman coins ranging in date from Julia Domna to Gratian [HER MWI13548]). These suggest that a habitation site was located in that area, presumably the Romano-British farmstead accompanying the field system. The finder also discovered two Roman bronze objects - a model of a Late Bronze Age socketted axe and the lid of a seal-box. The first of these could be considered a votive object and, indeed, an example was found at the Romano-Celtic temple at Cold Kitchen Hill in Brixton Deverill, Wilts. Other examples have, however, been found at Romano-British farmsteads at West Overton Site XII and at Pewsey (two examples). Finally, it may be noted that in the 18th century there was found in this area a solidus of Constans..The hoard of 111 reformed coins of Diocletian was held not to be Treasure Trove at a Coroner's Inquest held on 11 February 1982, and was subsequently given to the Devizes Museum by the landowner, the Ministry of Defence. The hoard contained 80 coins with no mint-mark, attributable to the Mint of London, 5 coins of Lyons, 24 of Trier and 2 of Ticinum."London Trier Lyons Ticinum TOTALDiocletian 21 6 2 1 30Maximian 23 4 2 29Constantius I, Caes. 17 10 1 1 29Galerius, Caes. 19 4 2380 24 5 2 111-A.M. Burnett and P.H. Robinson, in CHRB V, BM Occas, Paper 54 (1984), 89-99, types, mints, die axes, ills. Of all 111 coins"

name: PAS: Clevedon 2539
comments: Robertson 2000, 251 no. 1043:""When constructing a new tennis-court at Clevedon, Somerset, at the end of February, J. Hollier, the groundsman, turned up eight Roman coins and various fragments of black and grey pottery, about 20 inches beneath the surface, at a spot 110 feet above sea-level. The largest of the coins was a 'second brass' of Constantine the Great, bearing the London mint mark (rev. GENIO POP ROM); and the remainder, which were unfortunately in bad condition also belonged to the same period. The pottery was all Romano-British, of the 'Upchurch' type, one fragment of the grey being obviously a portion of a small round cullender."-F. Haverfield, in Antiquary, XXXIX (1903), 129"

name: PAS: Fyfield 2540
comments: Robertson 2000, 239 no. 988:""In March 1944 information reached the Ashmolean Museum that a mechanical excavator had brought to light a hoard of bronze coins on land in the parish of Fyfield, Berks., at a point situated about 1¼ miles south-west of the village.Later it was established that the hoard had been found on land owned by St. John Baptist College, to whom it was duly delivered, and by whom it was deposited in the Museum for examination and study..Nothing could be learned of the presence of a large jar, such as those in which many hoards have been stored: it is therefore probable that it was deposited in a chest or sack: in favour perhaps of the former was the fact that many of the coins when first sent into the Museum were struck together by oxide or mud in such a way as to suggest that they had been packed in rouleaux."The coins were 1 ant. and 2105 folles:Ant. FollesAurelian 1Diocletian 550Maximian 476Constantius I, Caes. 467Constantius I, Aug. 32Galerius, Caes. 461Galerius, Aug. 34Severus II, Caes. 23Severus II, Aug. 2Maximinus Daza, Caes. 41Constantine I, Caes. 191 2105(1 with QVIES AVGG)(1 with QVIES AVGG: 2 with GENIO POP ROM) -E.T. Leeds, A Hoard of Roman Follesfound at Fyfield, Berks. (1946), types, mints, figs. of coins-2106 coins in Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, many incorporated in the general coin collection"

name: PAS: Malmesbury 2541

name: PAS: Evenley 2542
comments: Robertson 2000, 239 no. 990:""On the 11th. November while Mr. Boughton was ploughing in one of his fields, south-east of the village of Evenley, near Brackley, the foot of one of the horses slipped into the earth and on examination of the spot, Mr. Boughton found an earthen vessel containing upwards of 3000 pieces of copper coin in excellent preservation, chiefly of the date of Vespasian. The vessel was placed upon the rock - but a little below the surface; it was surrounded with bones."-Gent. Mag., 1854, I, 55-R. Stuart Poole gave a list, with some types, of 3153 coins, apparently the whole hoard. They were not "of the date of Vespasian", but were ant. and folles:Ant. FollesValerian I 1Gallienus (joint and sole) 322Salonina reign) 19Victorinus 8Claudius II 293Quintillus 21Tetricus I 6Tetricus II 4Aurelian 14Tacitus 1Probus 8Diocletian 3 514Maximian 3 553Carausius 2Constantius I 506Galerius 486Severus II 71Maximinus Daza 80Constantine I, Caes. 233uncertain 5705 2448"The second brass were generally well preserved, but the third brass much worn"-R. Stuart Poole, in NC, 1855, 38-48, some types, mints-34 folles in Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM (BM Register of Coin Accessions, Feb. 1854)Examined, 1948 (ASR)"
