name: PAS: Spotland 2546
comments: Robertson 2000, 237 no. 983:""At Underwood, near this town (Spotland) about fourteen years ago (1804) was found a small iron box containing a rouleau of Roman brass coins, folles of the Lower Empire, in general extremely fair and fresh. Those which I have seen, besides a small brass of the emperor Tacitus, are of Constantius Caesar, Maximian, and Diocletian. The obverse of one apparently Diocletian is nearly effaced: the rev. a figure of Moneta with a balance and cornucopiae, circumscribed MONETA S A[V]GGG ET CAES The legend on the reverse of all the rest is the same GENIO POPVLI ROMANI"-R.N. Whitaker, Hist. of Whalley, 4 ed. (1870), II, 458"

name: PAS: Wiveliscombe 2547
comments: Robertson 2000, 242 no. 996:""Interea minime negandum est, Romanos hoc terrae tractu versatos, stationem in eo forsitan habuisse: quod ostendit Olla nummorum plena, non ita pridem ibi effossa: quorum aliquot ad me delatos, Diocletiani Aug; & Maximiani Nob. esse reperiri; proindeque Imperio in Britannia vergente Romano, fuisse conditos: qua nimirum aetate Romanis, hinc in alias Provincias evocatis, (procul dubio spe reditus) Thesauros sub Terram abdere, quod Historici tradunt, in more fuit."-W. Musgrave, Antiquitates Britanniae-Belgicae (1719), I, 8-"The number of coins contained therein was 1600 most of them the size of a halfpenny, and were all of copper: but there were not above half a dozen among them that were of different sorts."Then came a description of obverses of Diocletian, Maximian, Constantius I, Severus II, Maximinus Daza and Constantine I, Augustus. "On the reverse of all was the figure of Mars with this legend 'GENIO POPVLI ROMANI'."-J. Collinson, Hist. and Ant. of Somerset (1791), II, 488-This hoard was probably composed entirely of folles."

name: PAS: Mill Barrow 2548
comments: Robertson 2000, 241 no. 993:"In 1948 the Winchester City Museums bought, at the Corhampton House Sale, a "Roman coin-hoard with the pot which contained it, found at the Mill Barrow, at the north-west corner of Preshaw Park (near the Fox and Hounds Inn, Beauworth, Hampshire, about 1850-55)."At a later date 11 more coins were acquired, one of which was an ant. of Probus.The coins were 1 ant., and 290 folles:Ant. FollesProbus 1Diocletian 64Maximian 66Constantius I, Caes. 47Constantius I, Aug. 7Constantius I (deified) 6Galerius, Caes. 44Galerius, Aug. 16Severus II, Caes. 6Severus II, Aug. 1Maximinus Daza, Caes. 5Constantine I, Caes. 22Constantine I, Aug. 61 290(GENIO POP ROM)It seems possible that the ant. of Probus was an intruder.Cp. R.A.G. Carson, and J.P.C. Kent, in NC, 1956, 83-161, types, mints, die axes, of 285 of the 290 folles. 5 additional coins in the Winchester City Museums were folles of Constantius 1 (3 as Caes., 1 as Aug., 1 deified) (ASR)The pot was a small jar of hard grey clay, with grey slip, smoothed, 5? in. high, and 5? in. wide.Examined, and pot drawn, 1960 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Fakenham 2549
comments: Robertson 2000, 245: " "The Roman coins of which a description is herewith sent were found a few years since at Fakenham in Norfolk, by a labourer. They are all of small brass and generally of the commonest reverses". The mints were chiefly Trier, Arles, Aquileia and Lyons.AETacitus 4Diocletian 1Maximian 44Constantius I 16Galerius 21Maximinus Daza 93Maxentius 27Constantine I c.1152Licinius I 221c.1579(1 deified)(Caes. c. 22; Aug. c. 1130)-Gent. Mag., 1837, I, 86, some types-Some coins of Diocletian onwards must have been follesOver 800 coins of Constantine I had rev. SOLI INVICTO COMITI."

name: PAS: Bromley 2550
comments: Robertson 2000, 241 no. 994:""On 27th January, 1955, boys of Hayesford Raglan Secondary School at Bromley, while digging a long-jump pit in the sports field, dug up a pot containing Roman coins, and subsequent digging produced more coins which brought the total to 300..The find consisted exclusively of tin- or silver-washed bronze coins, the so-called folles.The coins range in time from about AD 295 to the reign of Constantine as Augustus, probably about AD 308. The mints represented are those of the Western Empire except for Antioch which is represented by only one coin. A feature of note is the good proportion of coins from a mint which did not sign its output, probably the mint of London, whose later signed coins are also well represented..The pot in which the Bromley coin-hoard was found is 6.9 inches high. The ware is moderately fine, fairly hard and brown to grey in colour. The vessel is roughly made, apparently by hand except for the rim which was probably finished on the wheel. There are smoothed zones above the base and below the rim; the intervening part of the surface is matt.There is a thick black deposit on the inside of the pot. Dr. A.E. Werner, of the British Museum Research Laboratory, reports that this 'appears to me to be carbonaceous matter, having no particular recognizable structure. It is the kind of deposit which one might expect to find inside a cooking-pot.' There seems to be no reason to think that the deposit may be the remains of a cloth or leather bag, in which the coins were contained within the pot.Two sherds from pots other than that containing the coins were associated with the find; one of these is of indeterminate coarse ware, the other is of coarse grey Roman fabric.The pot may be regarded as belonging to the class of late Romano-British cooking-vessels represented, for instance, at Verulamium and Richborough. An unusual feature of the Bromley pot is the convex or 'sagging' base."The coins were:FollesDiocletian 53Maximian 61Constantius I, Caes. 42Constantius I, Aug. 6Constantius I (deified) 3Galerius, Caes. 29Galerius, Aug. 19Severus II, Caes. 8Severus II, Aug. 4Maximinus Daza, Caes. 17Maxentius 1Constantine I, Caes. 31Constantine I, Aug. 26300-J.W. Brailsford, R.A.G. Carson, and J.P.C. Kent, in Arch. Cant., 70 (1956), 264f., mints, details of pot-Also R.A.G. Carson and J.P.C. Kent, in NC, 1956, 83-161, types, mints.Pot and 300 coins in Bromley Central Library"

name: PAS: Croydon (Wandle Road) 2551
comments: Robertson 2000, 251 no. 1047:"G.C. Boon, when at Reading Museum, reported in letters, 1951, that the Rev. W.S. Evans, The Rectory, Silchester, had in his possession 34 folles said to be "from a large hoard found in a pot during road work in Wandle Road, Croydon, shortly before the 1914-1918 war". The coins were dispersed among the finders, with only 34 coins surviving.FollesDiocletian 1Maximian 3Constantius I, Caes. 4Galerius, Caes. 3Galerius, Aug. 1Maximinus Daza, Aug. 2Constantine I, Aug. 2034(before AD 317)The mints were London, Trier, Lyons, with 1 coin from Tarraco (?). This may possibly have been the same as the hoard listed under Croydon (Pitlake), before 1912 [no. 963], even although that was said to have been of an early date."

name: PAS: near Leicester 2552
comments: Robertson 2000, 248 no. 1020:""SirThe latter end of August last, after a sudden and very heavy rain which washed away much earth from a gateway, a farmer drove a wagon through it, and the wheel running over a Roman urn broke it to pieces. The farmer, perceiving some money, picked up near 500 coins, most of them of the middle brasse. He did not disclose this till last Saturday; the day following I went and purchased them. I have turned over about one half, and find they are of Dioclesian. Maximian, Maximinus, Severus, Constantius, Constantius Magnus, some small ones of Licinius, one of Gallienus, and one of Constantinus with a head on each side." (Footnote: "The head upon the reverse is caput solis corona radiata.") "The metal appears to be common English copper, which makes me suspect them to be forgeries." (Footnote: "I had one of every sort afterward sent to me, and they were all genuine. - R.G.")-Letter from Joshua Platt, Leicester, to Roger Gale, 11 Oct. 1735, with footnotes by Gale-Quoted in W. Stukeley, Family Memoirs, II (ed. Surtees Soc., vol.76) (1883), 246R. Gale, 1 July 1736, in Ms. Min. Soc. Ant., II (1732-7), 200, implied that the date of discovery was about March 1736, gave the no. of coins found as above 600, added Maxentius to the list of emperors represented, and omitted Gallienus and Licinius.R. Smith-Carington, in JBAA, n.s., VII (1901), 3; and VCH Leics., I (1907), 204, gave the date of discovery, wrongly,as 1730."

name: PAS: Market Stainton 2553
comments: Robertson 2000, 236-237 no. 979:""In 1915 or 1916, near Market Stainton, and about 8 miles from Horncastle, a ploughman was breaking up a pasture, Hillside Field, alongside the Caistor Road, for the purpose of corn growing, when he struck and broke a pot containing a number of bronze coins. The coins were collected by the ploughman and his father, and retained in their possession until 1923. In that year, 294 coins were acquired by Grantham Museum and listed by Mr. Preston, along with 11 others in private hands.These 305 coins seem to have comprised the whole or almost the whole hoard."Mr. Preston's list of the 305 coins show that they were all folles, from Diocletian to Constantius I, Caes., and Galerius, Caes.By 1938, there remained only 186 coins from this hoard in the Grantham Public Library and Museum. "These 186 folles were all struck between AD 296 and 305 and are all in mint condition, any difficulty in deciphering being due to corrosion. There seems no doubt that the whole hoard of over 300 coins was made up of such folles, and must have been buried about 305 AD, before the coins had ever been in circulation."Then followed a list of the 186 folles.-Anne S. Robertson, in Grantham Museum Rep., XVII (1939), 14-16, types, mints, photos, of 4 coins-"H.R. Mossop has drawn attention to a further series which were found there by Mr. Eric Ranby whilst deep-ploughing in 1938/9. The later find consisted of about 400 coins of which 259 survive. They are mainly in fine condition; in a number of cases corrosion has produced small rouleaux of coins, which when separated, show signs of their original plating. No die identities have been noted..The 1939 find was ploughed up in the 'Third West Field near the Caistor Road.'No part of the jar found with the first hoard remains: in the case of the second, the base of a coarse jar was discovered, the fabric typical of much pottery found on the Eastern Wolds of Lincolnshire..The coins of both finds all belong to the first tetrarchy and have the Genio Populi Romani reverse: accordingly the extreme range of date lies between AD 296 and 305.The earlier ploughing would have been no more than 6 in. deep, whereas deep-ploughing penetrates the soil to a depth of 12-14 in., and, in view of the rarity of such finds, the similarity of the reported find-spots and the fact that only the base of the container was found on the second occasion, it is reasonable to suppose that Mr. Ranby's discovery represents the lower half of the Market Stainton hoard published by Miss Robertson..The absence of the Fortuna, Moneta and Providentia reverse types suggests that the hoard closed in or about AD 300 - a view which the mint-marks confirm."The followed a list of 259 folles.-J.C. Mossop, in NC, 1958, 59-71, types, mints, die axes, pl. VII of 10 coins-The lists of 305, 186 and 259 folles are as follows, with the lists of 186 and 259 totalled together:Folles TOTALDiocletian 63 42 61 103Maximian 86 62 75 137Constantius I, Caes. 80 55 61 116Galerius, Caes. 64 27 60 87uncertain 12 2 2305 186 259 445Of the pot four large fragments survive, making up the base and lower part of the vessel, with 12 small fragments of the body. The clay is very hard grey with a darker slip inside and outside, and a brownish surface over the grey outside. There is a faint lattice pattern on the side. The inside is stained green from the coins. The base is 2¾ in. wide, and has a footstand with a raised knob inside.Pot drawn, 1958 (ASR)40 coins in Lincoln City and County MuseumExamined, 1978 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Budock 2554
comments: Robertson 2000, 242-243 no. 997:"In June? 1865, "The coins, mostly second and third brass, and more than 900 in number, were found in ploughing near the shore, rather more than a mile to the south of Falmouth, at a spot about 400 yards west of Pennance Point, and near a small farm called 'Bone's Cottage'. Mr. Fox describes the field, which is the property of his grandson, as a steep piece of land that has probably not been often ploughed. It was brought under cultivation this year, and a few coins were turned up; on further search about 950 pieces were found at a depth of about 12 to 18 inches, coated with clay that adhered closely, and only a portion had been cleaned when Mr. Fox made known the find to Mr. Rogers. It was stated that a black substance like decayed skin or leather was noticed near the coins; the laborer [sic] by whom they were brought to light observed also that they seemed to have been placed in rows, arranged side by side, four rows in breadth, sloping upwards on the hill-side; they had possibly been deposited in a leather case or wooden box, the crumbling remains of which were lost amongst the surrounding earth."-J.J. Rogers and R.W. Fox, in AJ, XXII (1865), 333-F.W. Madden, in NC, 1865, 318f., gave a list of 391 coins (types, mints). T. Hodgkin, in Royal Cornwall Polytechnic Soc. Rep., 35 (1867), 71, gave the date of discovery as Feb. 1865, the name of the farm as Pennance Farm, and the no. of coins found as about 1000. They were stated to have "rested on a rude floor of stone, 2 feet below the surface. Mr. Fox bought 631 which were catalogued by Dr. T. Hodgkin."The two lists, of 631 coins and of 391 coins, were:TOTALGallienus 5 5 10Postumus 1 1Laelianus 1 1Victorinus 1 2 3Claudius II 4 4Tetricus I 1 1Aurelian 2 1 3Tacitus 4 2 6Probus 9 4 13Diocletian 152 80 232Maximian 129 93 222Constantius I, Caes. and Aug. 110 75 185Galerius, Caes. and Aug. 132 80 212Severus II 16 10 26Maximinus Daza 20 10 30Constantine I, Caes. and Aug. 39 29 68uncertain 5 5631 391 1022Of the coins from Diocletian onwards in the group of 631, one third were said to be folles. Those from Gallienus to Probus must have been ant.All the folles had rev. GENIO POPVLI ROMANI. "A very large proportion of folles [were] without mintmark, the earliest of which, struck by Diocletian and Maximian the elder, are precisely similar in style to the coinage of Carausius and Allectus." -F.W. Madden, in NC, 1865, 318f.-"At Pennance Farm, Budock, Cornwall, a labourer lately unearthed two Roman coins of Constantinus and Maximianus in splendid condition." [strays from the hoard?]-F. Haverfield, in Antiquary, XXXVIII (1902), 324-In County Museum, Truro, 4 ant. (of Gallienus (sole reign), Postumus, Tacitus and Probus), and 10 folles (of Diocletian 2; Maximian (deified); Constantius I; Constantius I (deified); Galerius; Severus II; Maximinus Daza; and Constantine I, Caes. and Aug.), all from this hoard.Examined, 1958, 1978 (ASR)In Plymouth City Museum and Art Gallery, 1 ant. of VictorinusInf., 1978, from N. Shiel"

name: PAS: North Bierley 2555
comments: Robertson 2000, 252 no. 1049:""That Iron was made in this Neighbourhood in the time of the Romans a late discovery has sufficiently convinced me. Upon removing a heap of Cinders to repair the High-Ways withal, a good Quantity of Copper Roman Coyns were discovered, some of which I have now in my possession. These were of Constantine, Constantius, Diocletian, and of the Usurper Carausius. This Country abounds with such heaps of Cinders, though we have not so much as any Tradition that ever Iron was made there."-Dr. Richardson, of Bierley, in T. Hearne's edition of J. Leland, Itinerary (1714), I, 144-The coins of Carausius were probably ant."

name: PAS: Oldham (Hollinwood) 2556
comments: Robertson 2000, 243 no. 1000:"In August 1887, workmen excavating for cellars for a new mill for Messrs. Hoyle and Jackson, midway between Chamber Road and Manchester Road, close to Heron Street, in the Werneth district of Oldham, discovered about 200 Roman bronze coins embedded in clay about 18 inches from the surface. Most of the coins were much corroded. Near the spot was found what had apparently been the handle and lock of a box. The handle was of brass and about 3 inches long. The supposed lock was much corroded but was seen to have a movable bar attached. Remnants of a wooden box were found at the same spot, but when touched, crumbled away. The coins were dispersed, but 24 were deposited in Oldham Municipal Museum.Inf., 1937-8, from W. H. Berry, Oldham Art Gallery and Museum, based on local newspaper reportsThe 24 coins in Oldham Art Gallery and Museum, were all AE folles of Constantine I, Aug., of AD 306-8, minted at London, Lyons and Trier, in excellent condition:London Lyons TrierCOMITI AVGG NN 2CONCORD MILIT 2MARTI CONSERVATORI 1 1PRINCIPI IVVENTVTIS 4SOLI INVICTO COMITI 5 5 414 5 5Examined, 1938 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Fincham 2557
comments: Robertson 2000, 243: " "80 Roman coins with a head of (?) Sol Invictus were found."-Britannia, XVIII (1987), 330, from CBA Group VI Bulletin, no. 31 (1986)-Letter, 8 Nov. 1988, from Miss Barbara Green, Norwich Castle Museum, stating that the Fincham 1986 find was not a hoard, but a scatter of Roman coins."

name: PAS: Winterbourne Earls 2558
comments: Robertson 2000, 240 no. 991:""In 1865 a labouring man ploughed up some coins in an urn between Winterbourne Earls and Old Sarum. Further search brought to light two more urns and coins also some indication of a Roman villa. The police heard of the discovery and claimed the coins as 'treasure trove', and ultimately the great bulk of the coins, but it is believed not the entire find, came into the possession of I.H. Campbell Wyndham Esq., the Lord of the Manor. They consisted of the following coins, all in good condition and had apparently never been in circulation. 2nd Br."Then came a list of 30 folles, from Diocletian to Constantine.-Dr. Blackmore's Ms. Notebook, in Salisbury and S. Wilts. Museum-The urn, the 30 folles described by Dr. Blackmore, and 2 more folles from the hoard, were presented to the Salisbury and S. Wilts. Museum, some time before 1892. The urn cannot now be identified in the Museum. A list of the 32 folles and Dr. Blackmore's list of 30 folles are:Blackmore ASRFolles FollesDiocletian 7 7Maximian 12 8Constantius I, Caes. 7 7 Constantius I, Aug. 1Galerius, Caes. 5Severus II, Aug. 1 1Maximinus Daza, Caes. 1 1Constantine I, Caes. 2 230 32(of AD 306)(of AD 306)From the description of the 30 coins given by Dr. Blackmore, it is obvious that 4 of those attributed by him to Maximian should really be assigned to Galerius.-Anne S. Robertson, in NC, 1949, 245-8, types, mints-The Salisbury and S. Wilts. Museum has since acquired 3 more folles from this hoard; Constantius I, Caes. (2); Galerius, Caes. (1)."

name: PAS: near Oxford 2559
comments: Robertson 2000, 237-238 no. 983A:""The four Tetrarchic folles described here were left at the [Birmingham] Museum for identification at the beginning of 1951. They were added to the Museum's collections as accession numbers A.867'51 to 870'51. During the 1950s the coins became "detached" from these numbers and were recatalogued in 1961. The 1961 numbers have been retained in the list given below.One of the letters sent by the Museum to the depositor includes the sentence "I understand that they were found in a field near Oxford and form part of a hoard." This statement is amplified in the accessions register where the coins are described as "Part of a hoard found during the building of an aerodrome in Oxford". In the light of this information and bearing in mind that the coins arrived at the Museum in 1951 it seems very likely that they were part of a larger hoard found during the construction of a wartime airfield, of which there were a number that could be described as "near Oxford". It has not been possible to identify such a hoard and it is likely that the find was dispersed without a record being made..follesLondon Lyons Ticinum TOTALDiocletian 1 1Maximian 1 1Constantius II, Caes. 1 1 11 2 1 4D. Symons, in BNJ 60 (1990), 133, types, mints, sizes, wts., die axies"

name: PAS: Carlisle 2560
comments: Limited details about some coins from near Carlisle thought to be a hoard (BM file). No information on circumstances of discovery. The total number is not known - it may have just been the five, but a 'considerable number' were reported from adjacent fields, of which the coins seen at the BM were a sample.

name: PAS: Selsey: Greenlease Farm 2561
comments: Robertson 2000, 252 no. 1048:"A Roman gold ring, with bezel engraved with clasped hands, was found on the east beach, Selsey. It was given a date in the latter part of the 4th century."The date is further supported by the fact that at the same spot several bronze coins of Diocletian (ob. 313) and of Constantine the Great (ob. 337) have come to light."-E. Heron-Allen, in Sussex Arch. Coll., LVIII (1916), 196, engraving of gold ring"

name: PAS: Crich 2562
comments: Robertson 2000, 247 no. 1015:""9th of March, 1778. Abraham Harrison and another labourer as yey were removing a heap of stones in Culland Park, in the Parish of Crich, found a large flat stone among them, lying upon two others, which stood on an edge, under which was a mug pot, narrower at top than in ye middle, being in fact an antient urn, in which was a large quantity of copper coin, viz., about 700, some as big again as others & more. The pot or urn was so rotten yt it broke in pieces, but yey took ye money and sold it for what yey could get in ye neighbourhood. The inscriptions on those I have seen are as follows."Diocletian 1Maximian 2Constantine I, Caes. 2Constantine I, Aug. 11Licinius I 117The rev. legends were all either GENIO POPVLI ROMANI, MARTI PATRI PROPVG, SOLI INVICTO COMITI or S P Q R OPTIMO PRINCIPI. There was also a coin of Constantius I (deified).-Notebook of J. Reynolds (1748-78)-Quoted in Derbs. AJ., VIII (1886), 228-30; and Ms. BM Add. 6705, fol. 104; and 6708, fol. 18T. Bateman, Vestiges of Ant. of Derbs. (1848), 158, said that the urn "was filled with third brass coins of Gallienus, Salonina, Diocletian, Constantine etc. (Mr. J. Reynold's Collections).""

name: PAS: Little Malvern 2563
comments: Robertson 2000, 238 no. 987:""A few weeks since a discovery of Roman coins was made in Little Malvern parish, on the western side of the road leading to Ledbury, and opposite to the premises called Little Malvern Grove, within half a mile of the foot of the Herefordshire-Beacon Hill. A party of visitors were rambling over the hills, and one of them struck his iron-pointed mountain-staff into the turf, just upon the margin of a stone quarry, at the spot described, causing the turf and stones, with an urn containing about 300 Roman brass coins, to fall amongst the rubbish beneath, from which they were picked out by various persons, and are now in the possession of Col. Colston, Henry Trant, Esq., and in numerous other hands. All those which I have seen are of Diocletian, Maximian, or Constantius, and they are in very perfect condition."-J. Allies, in AJ, IV (1847), 356f.-Also in Hist. and Ant. Of Worcs., 2 ed. (1852), 160W.S.W. Vaux, in NC, 1849, 19, gave a slightly different account of the circumstances of discovery, and said that of about 200 coins examined, "no coins have been found except of the five emperors, Diocletianus, Maximianus Herculeus, Constantius Chlorus, Galerius Maximianus, and Maximinus Daza. They fall therefore within the period AD 286-311. They are all of the size called second brass, and in excellent preservation; and the larger part of them are so sharp and well defined, that they could hardly ever have been in circulation."Then came a list of the rev. types included, but not of the total no. of coins attributable to each emperor.In 1848, Mr. Cox Mayne presented to the Dept. of Coins and Medals, BM, the following folles from this hoard (BM Register of Coin Accessions, April 1848):FollesDiocletian 4Maximian 6Constantius I, Caes. 3Galerius, Caes. 114Examined the 10 folles of Diocletian and Maximian, 1948 (ASR)"

name: PAS: Colwyn Bay 2564
comments: Robertson 2000, 254 no. 1068:""These coins were found wrapped in a sheet of lead in an old stone drain in the garden of Rhos Abbey when the site was being cleared for the erection of a hotel (Rhos Abbey Hotel) [Railway Arms Hotel] in 1898."-Byegones (Oswestry), 28 Dec. 1898, 551-Canon Ellis Davies, Prehistoric and Roman Remains of Denbighs. (1929) 198, saw 6 coins from this find. They were all folles of Constantine I, with the following reverses:GENIO POP ROM (1), MARTI CONSERVATORI (1), and SOLI INVICTO COMITI (4).5 coins preserved in St. Asaph Cathedral, 1 with rev. SOLI INVICTO COMITI having apparently been lost.Examined, 1958 (ASR)Including Constantine I"

name: PAS: Fort Augustus 3296
comments:
A letter from an officer at Perth, dated May 2, says, 'Last week I was out with a command to Fort Augustus, where some part of the fortifications are repairing. Whilst there, some labourers, in digging a trench, found an earthen urn, of a blue colour, with about 300 pieces of coin, of mixed metal, some a little larger than our halfpence, and the others the size of farthings. They appear to me to be all of the Emperor Dioclesian.
?Scots Magazine, 1767, 326
?The coins seem to have included both ant. and folles.

name: PAS: Aird 3291
comments:
?Letter, May 1949, from Dr. J. Allan, former Keeper of Coins and Medals, BM. Including Constantine I.
A Roman Coin Hoard was found whilst making a drain in a military camp near Stranraer during the 1939-45 war. The only coin recovered was a bronze of Constantine I (Reverse SARMATIA DEVICTA mintmark PTR) being but one of a soldier's share of the find of about 50 coins. It is in the possession of W Redfern, Stockton-on-Tees, a private collector. A S Robertson 1952

name: PAS: Melrose 3292
comments:
A list of Roman coins found at Newstead, previous to the year 1854, included the following antoniniani and small AE:
                    Ant.          AE
          Victorinus          No.?          
          Diocletian          1          
          Carausius          1          
          Galerius                    1
          Constantine I, Aug.                    4
(or AE)
(or more, 2 with VOT XX, AD 320)
and no Roman coins of a later date, as far as I have been able to learn, have been found in the neighbourhood.
?Dr. J.A. Smith, in PSAS, I (1851-4), 36, types
?In 1863, an antoninianus of Tetricus I was handed over to the Queen's Remembrancer along with a hoard of Scottish coins, mainly billon placks.
We have no proof that the Roman coin was found with the others, although its appearance would support that supposition. It is just possible, however, that this coin had been at some time discovered by itself, and that when the Procurator-fiscal was in course of reclaiming the Newstead coins, the holder of the Roman coin had then come forward with it, in the hope of sharing in the promised reward.
?G. Sim, in PSAS, 5 (1862-4), 107
?(Sir) George Macdonald, in PSAS, 52 (1918), 272, suggested that the Roman coins may have come from a hoard.

name: PAS: Craigmillar Castle 3293
comments:
In October 1952, Mr. AD Lacaille
Glasgow, submitted 15 coins belonging to Mr. Douglas Annan
Edinburgh. Mr. Annan had got them from an unnamed donor, whose son said he had found them in a 'gourd' at a depth of 10 ins. in the vicinity of Craigmillar Castle.
There were 11 Roman bronze coins:                   AE
          Constantine I          5
          Constantine II, Caes.          1
          Constantinopolis          1
          Helena (before AD 337)          1
          Constantius II, Aug.          3
          
                    11
(Lyons 2; Arles 1; Rome 1; Antioch 1)
(Cyzicus)
(Siscia)
(Arles)
(Thessalonica; Antioch; and uncertain mint)
The latest coin of Constantius II, Aug. was of AD 347-8
There were also a Greek imperial coin of Gordian III, minted at Edessa in Mesopotamia, and two Alexandrian coins of Probus, and a small copper coin or token of Charles IX of France (1560-74).
The 11 Roman coins, and possibly the 3 Greek and Alexandrian coins may have come from a hoard, but even this is doubtful.
Anne S. Robertson, in PSAS, 94 (1961), 151f., types, mints

name: PAS: Covesea 135
comments: Sculptor's Cave, Covesea, near the base of impressive cliffs where the Moray Firth meets the sea. The cave interior 13.5m x 20m in area and up to 5.5m high, is reached via twin passages 11m+ long, from a large entrance. The site is inaccessible at high tide. In 1929-30, during excav., the cave produced a range of objects of LBA date including bronze armrings, ring money, a swan?s neck pin, pottery & worked bone, along with numerous human remains, predominantly of children (Benton 1931; Shepherd 2007). Skull & mandible frags. in entrance passages suggests the display of heads at the cave entrance, & at least one juvenile frontal bone was probably deliberately defleshed (Armit et al. 2011). A concern with the human head appeared again during the Roman Iron Age, when a number of individuals were decapitated in the cave, possibly in the context of ritual activities. Armit, Schulting, Knusel and Shepherd, I, R, C.J.and I.A.G. 2011. Death, decapitation and display? The Bronze and Iron Age human remains from the Sculptor's Cave, Covesea, North-east Scotland. Proc Prehist Society 77. A later occupation layer contained a rich assemblage of Roman Iron Age material (rings, pins, beads, bracelets & toilet instruments) ranging from the 2nd to the 4th centuries AD, including R-B potsherds (samian & coarse ware of 2nd C.), along with c.  230 Roman bronze coins, 9 being official issues, & remainder irregular. 9 coins dated nearly to middle of 4th C., AD 337-354. 8 show no signs of wear, but 3 were pierced. Of the barbarian coins, their condition was deplorable. Sylvia Benton. 1931. PSAS 65: 209-16. One small bronze object of uncertain use bore an inscription, read either as TRES (Benton 1931: 193) or SPILV (Wright 1966. JRS 56: 221). Also rock art on cave walls, poss. Pictish/early med in origin.

name: PAS: Corsock 3294
comments:
In January 1953, Mr. J.G. Scott, Glasgow Museum, submitted a fairly worn Urbs Roma coin, minted at Cyzicus, and a worn bronze coin of Constantius II, minted at Constantinople. He had been informed by Miss Weir
Glasgow, and her brother, that a pot containing 20 or more Roman coins had been found in about 1918 on the farm of Halcroft. The farmer, Mr Muirhead, sent the coins to London. A few were retained in London, and the rest were returned to Mr Muirhead. The two now examined are all that remains of those that were returned. Anne S. Robertson, in PSAS, 94 (1961), 151, types
The coin of Constantius II, Aug. had rev. FEL TEMP REPARATIO, Emperor, two captives, of AD 346-50 (LRBC 2010)

name: PAS: Balgreggan 3295
comments:
On 29th October 1913 an interesting discovery of Roman coins was made at Balgreggan Quarry, in the parish of Stoneykirk. Three labourers in the employment of the Wigtownshire County Council were engaged in stripping the turf and soil from the top of the rock, when their attention was attracted by one or two small objects of an unusual character lying amidst the loose earth. On being picked up and washed, these objects proved to be coins, which had been concealed in a small earthenware jug. As the result of a careful search, many more were recovered; 119 in all, along with some fragments of the jug, were voluntarily handed over to the Crown authorities. 
The fragments of pottery showed that the jug had been made of whitish material, covered with a black or dark-brown slip. When complete, it had apparently been about 3½ inches high. No part of the bottom remains.
Then came a list of the 119 coins recovered, along with 6 others in private hands. They were all AE.
(Sir) George Macdonald, in PSAS, 48 (1914), 395, fig. of pot
Frags. of pot and 119 coins are in the NMAS, Edinburgh.
The pot is a small bulbous vessel, 3½ in. high and 3¼ in. wide, with a constriction low down on the body.
The list of 125 coins given in PSAS, 48 (1914), 395, and a list of the 119 coins, made recently in the NMAS, Edinburgh, are:
                    AE          AE          AE
          Constantine I          2          2          
          Fausta          1          1          
          Constantinopolis                    1          
          Constantius II, Aug.          31          18          
          Constans, Aug.          24          22          1
          Constantius II, or                              
          Constans, Aug.                    15          
          Magnentius          61          55          1
          Decentius          2          1          
          uncertain          4          4          
          
                    125          119          2
(1 deified)
(1 b., 2 slightly b.)
To the list of 119 should be added 1 AE of Constans, Aug. (in Glasgow Museum), and 1 AE of Magnentius (in Wigtown District Museum, Stranraer)
Anne S. Robertson, in PSAS, 103 (1971), 130, types
Examined 119 coins in the NMAS, Edinburgh, 1948, 1978 (ASR); updated list to be published

name: PAS: Dreghorn 3300
comments:
The Dreghorn Hoard, July, 1897
Among the collections of the Grosvenor Museum (Chester) is a box containing a small tube of decorated bronze sheet (acc. no. 99.R. 1976) , a bronze fibula, Collingwood type M with the pin missing (acc. no. 100.R. 1976) and a group of some 36 coins in a fair to poor condition, 13 ant. and 23 small AE:
          Ant.          AE
          Victorinus          4          
          Tetricus I          2          
          Tetricus I or II          1          
          Victorinus or Tetricus (I?)          4

name: PAS: Nettleton (A) 152
comments: Robertson 2000, 322-323 no. 1338:"(A) and (B)At Nettleton, during the excavation of the West Lodge (Building XVIII): "From the coins found in Building XVIII two groups of coins have been listed separately as they seem to belong to hoards or deposits.Both groups belong to the middle and end of the fourth century, but although the first was found as a group and noted as such, the second group only became apparent during the identification of the coins, when it was noticed that a large number of coins from a single deposit were remarkably similar in date, degree of wear, patina, and occasional corrosion. The first group may well be complete, but the second group is almost certainly too small since no coin was included unless it had all the necessary characteristics. One point that makes the second hoard almost certain is the lack of wear on these coins of Valentinian I and his co-rulers. In a site which went on to the end of the fourth century such good condition is most surprising, and can only be accounted for by the coins having been lost together or hoarded."Group A consisted of 1 ant. and 53 AE:AEAnt. Amiens Trier Lyons AquileiaUncertain TOTALVictorinus 1 1Constantine I 2 2 Constantine II, Caes. 4 1 5Constantius II, Caes. 1 1Constantinopolis 6 1 7Urbs Roma 5 5Theodora (after AD 337) 3 3Constantius II, Aug. 3 1 4Constans, Aug. 4 1 1 6Magnentius 1 1House of Constantine IGLORIA EXERCITVS,2 stand. 71 stand. 4VICTORIAE DDAVGGQ NN 3FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman 2 3 191 3 42 4 1 3 54(3 b.)(1 b.)(1 b.)(b.)(5 b.)(2 b.)(b.)(b.)(b.)"Group A [no. 1338] ends with a copy of a coin of Magnentius (died 353) and copies of the House of Constantine of c. 353-5." There was also a regular AE coin of Constantius II, Aug. with the FEL TEMP REPARATIO, falling horseman rev. type, minted at Lyons.Group B [no. 1427] consisted of 131 AE:Trier Lyons Arles Rome Aquileia SisciaUncertain TOTALValentinian I 2 13 18 6 4 1 44Valens 1 14 26 6 1 8 56Gratian 11 18 2 31RULE3 38 62 2 12 5 9 131The nos. of coins of Valentinian I and Valens were totalled as 42 and 58 respectively. However, the LRBC refs. given were of 44 AE coins of Valentinian I and 56 of Valens."Group B probably ends with coins of 378-83, though it is just possible that these are intrusive. This will affect the date of the deposit very little, however, for the group could have been formed and buried any time up to c. 388 when the issues of the House of Theodosius came into Britain in large numbers."R. Reece, in W.J. Wedlake, Research Rep. Soc. Ant., XL (The Excavation of the Shrine of Apollo at Nettleton, Wiltshire, 1956-1971) (1982), 115-17, types, mints"

name: PAS: NEWGRANGE 3264
comments:
R.A.G. Carson, in PRIA, 77 (1977), C 2, 35-42, types, mints, described 25 Roman coins, from Domitian to Arcadius, found to 1977 in the burial mound at Newgrange. Clair O'Kelly, ibid., 43-6 discussed their circumstances of discovery, and their location with reference to the burial mound. Both she and Dr. Carson considered that the various coins might have represented votive deposits, but not a hoard or hoards.
Cp. J.D. Bateson, in PRIA, 73 (1973), C 2, 46f., no. 10                                                                              Bateson 1973, 46 also lists earlier finds of gold coins from Newgrange in 1700 and other coins and ornaments

name: PAS: Crichton 3301
comments:
On 14 Nov. 1785, there were presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland
by Mr. George Cairncross.
Twelve Ancient Roman Bronze Coins of the Emperors Domitian, Antoninus, Gratian, Magnentius, Constantine, Gallienus, Licinius, Tetricus, Posthumus, Victorinus and Claudius, found in a Roman encampment on the estate of Crichton-dean, in the parish of Crichton. Archaeologia Scotica, III (1831), App. II, 50
F. Haverfield, in Antonine Wall Report (1899), 164, and (Sir) George Macdonald, in PSAS, 52 (1918), 272, pointed out that the above coins, with the exception of those of Domitian and Antoninus, probably came from a hoard. Those of Gallienus, Postumus, Victorinus, Claudius (II) and Tetricus must have been antoniniani.
The 12 coins presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland have not been located in the NMAS, Edinburgh.

name: PAS: Traprain 181
comments: 4 coins discovered with silver hoard; one each of Valens and Valentinian II, and 2 of Honorius. The Valentinian coin may have been of Arcadius rather than of Valentinian II. During excav. of hillfort on Traprain Law, "The latest floor, some 10-12 inches beneath turf, was exposed over a square of 50 feet. ?foundations planned & removed, & those on the floor level at depth of 10 in beneath had likewise been examined. Foreman, loosening surface with pick so that soil could be passed through a riddle, brought up on the end of it a silver bowl. A more careful inspection revealed a pit, 2 ft in diameter &18 in to 2 ft in depth. Top of hoard only1-2 in. below 2nd floor level, so near to surface that deposit obviously belonged to later date. The pit was dug until large stones of an earlier phase were encountered which prevented farther progress, & on stones lowest objects of the treasure were resting. No sign of any sack, chest, or containing vessel, & manner in which objects lay suggested that treasure had been dumped into hole & covered with soil rather than systematically placed. No stone or structural remains, covered spot?. but a curving line of stones, holding this spot within its radius, poss indicated wall of a house/structure, in shelter of which treasure was buried. There were numerous silver flagons, dishes, bowls & other vessels, spoons, a strainer, buckles & strap fittings etc, but many folded up, hammered flat or fragmented ? turned into hacksilber. The total amounted to more than 160 pieces, & weighed over 53 lb (24 kg).  Fortunately, when the treasure was unearthed, 2 coins were found, and in washing of the soil which came from the pieces, 2 more discovered. A.O. Curle. 1923. The Treasure of Traprain.  In 1964, K.S. Painter observed a graffito on reverse of bowl of a spoon ? ?CAVIMMIXOVIVS?, with a symbol above the first M. Name is unmatched, but there are Celtic names which end in -ovius (-a, -um)". JRS 1966 56, 221, n. 24.  Cf. M. Sekulla, in PSAS, 112 (1982), 285"94 There were Chi-Rho symbols & other Christian elements on several pieces. The silver vessels restored to shape & placed in NMAS, Edinburgh together with  4 sil. A massive silver chain of Early Christian period found near quarry between 600-700ft contours in Jan 1938, dated 6th-8th C.

name: PAS: nan 3303
comments: The seventh-century hoard of silver objects (including plaques, mounts, handpins and Hacksilber) from Norrie?s Law, Fife, is said to have contained ?numerous coins?. W F Skene recorded two of them as silver coins of Constantius II and Valens. The coins are now lost, but Skene?s drawing has recently been rediscovered, and the three coins illustrated can be identified as siliquae: (a) C onstantius II VOT XXX MVLT XXXX of c 357?361; lightly clipped. Mint uncertain. (b) V alens VRBS ROMA , 364?75; lightly clipped. Mint uncertain. (c) Probably a VI RTVS ROMANO RVM siliqua of Milan for Arcadius or Honorius, c 397?402 (cf RIC X, 1227?8); heavily clipped. Bland. Moorhead and Walton 2013.

name: PAS: Coleraine 3268
comments:
"In the month of April, 1854, the following appeared in the Coleraine Chronicle, and was copied into several other newspapers:-
'EXTRAORDINARY DISCOVERY OF COINS. - A very extraordinary discovery was made by a labouring man the other day, while cleaning out a ditch. He found an urn containing 1937 coins, together with 341 ounces of silver, in pieces of various sizes. The coins are Roman, in the most perfect state of preservation, of the most antique description; and what is very singular, no two coins appear to bear the same superscription. The silver is composed of a large number of ingots, and ornamental pieces supposed to have been used on armour for horses. There are also several battle-axes, marked with Roman characters. The whole is now in the possession of Mr. James Gilmour, watchmaker, Coleraine, where they may be seen by anyone curious in the science of numismatics.'
 
Mr Gilmour
soon afterwards placed the entire collection of coins in the hands of my friend, James Carruthers, Esq., the well-known numismatist, who has undertaken to prepare a detailed catalogue of them; the other articles he intrusted to me for a similar purpose. Mr. Gilmour has also explained to me more fully and more correctly than was possible in a hastily written newspaper paragraph, the circumstances connected with their discovery.
The discovery was made in the neighbourhood of Coleraine, viz., in the townland of Ballinrees, parish of Macosquin, and county of Londonderry; about three and a half miles west of Coleraine, and upon the estate of Lady Emily Richardson. It was made, as was stated in the newspapers, by a labouring man, but not 'while cleaning out a ditch'. Had it been so, the inference might have been raised, that the hoard had been deposited in a ditch, and, consequently, since the formation of the existing land-divisions; but from a sketch-map of the field, since furnished to me, it is manifest that the deposit had no reference to any of the present boundaries. Neither was it found in 'an urn'; there was no trace of any vessel or covering; although from the closeness with which the whole lay packed together, it is highly probable that the collection, when deposited in the earth, had been contained in some case, bag, or box, which has utterly decayed, so that no trace of it remains. It was found at such a depth below the surface that it must have been carefully buried in the place where it was discovered; not simply dropped on the surface, and afterwards accidentally interred by the spade or the plough. The soil is 'moory', but seems not to have been covered with water at any time since the deposit of the treasure. The coins in the collection amount to 1506, not 1937, as stated in the paragraph; they are all Roman, and of silver, but small; few being larger than a sixpence, and many considerably less: far from being "all in the most perfect state of preservation,' many are clipped, defaced, and otherwise injured;- they certainly are not 'of the most antique description', as there is not a single consular coin in the heap; all are of the lower Empire; and there are many duplicates.
 
The silver articles found along with the coins, and placed in my hands, weigh altogether, as ascertained by my friend Mr. Gray, of Castle-place, Belfast, not 341 ounces as stated, but 200 ounces 15 pennyweights, Troy; to which, however, must be added two or three ounces, for the weight of one half of one of the ingots retained by Mr. Gilmour for the purpose of having it assayed. The fracture of this ingot shows the silver to be very fine. The pieces in the 'find' are, briefly, eleven large and four small ingots, or rudely cast short silver bars, unhammered; seven ingots, or lumps of silver, of various shapes and sizes (chiefly small), hammered, and most of them broken; uninscribed: two ingots, or rather fragments of ingots, hammered, and bearing inscriptions; three fragments of what Mr. Carruthers conjectures to have been a large but very thin silver cup, or other similar vessel, rudely ornamented; five fragments of the knobbed rims of broad silver dishes, or perhaps of one such dish, if we suppose the edge to have been divided into compartments ornamented in different patterns, though in the same style; and twenty-five other fragments of manufactured plate, most of them so bruised, broken, and contorted, that it would be difficult to assign to them any definite use. There is no article in the 'find' which could suggest to any but the most inexperienced eye the idea either of 'horse armour', or a 'battle-axe'."
Then came descriptions of six of the silver pieces, as follows
"1. A fragment of an ornamented silver cover for the lid of a box, or for some such purpose.
2. An elegant strap or narrow plate of silver.
3. A piece of very solid plate.
4. One of the two hammered and inscribed fragments of ingots.
This fragment bears the inscription EXOFPATRICII.
The other inscribed ingot, which is nearly of the same shape, but larger, has only the last part of its inscription, shewing the letters CVRMISSI.
5. A small fragment of a very solid piece of plate, apparently the lid of a flagon.
6. A very elegant silver ornament, which also was one gilt
"
J.S. Porter, in Ulster J. of Arch., II (1854), 182-7; and in NC, 1856, 101-15
J. Carruthers gave two different lists of 1483 and 1405 or 1406 coins from the hoard in NC, 1856, 111-15, and in Ulster J. of Arch., II (1854), 188"92
W. Frazer, in Journ. Hist. Ass. of Ireland, VIII (1888), 105, stated that the hoard contained 2000 coins and 200 ounces, 15 dwt. of silver, and gave a list of 1983 coins.
(1854. "In 1854 a hundred and ninety-five Roman coins were found near Coleraine, not far from the place of the discovery of the great hoard of coins found in the same year, as described above. These were of the emperors Gratian, Honorius and Valens.")
?T. Wright, in Arch. Camb., (3), 12 (1866), 303
This seems to be the only record of this additional find. If the coins were silver, they were probably strays from the large Coleraine hoard.
The three lists, of 1405 or 1406 coins, of 1483 coins, and of 1983 coins, are:
                    Sil.          Sil.          Sil.
          Constantius II          22          22          22
          Julian II          68          75          68           Jovian          2          2          2
          Valentinian I          34          34          34
          Valens          71          71          48
          Gratian          85          85          68
          Valentinian II          17          17          27
          Theodosius          41          41          41
          Magnus Maximus          52          52          52
          Flavius Victor          8          8          33
          Eugenius          37          37          37
          Arcadius          142          142          132
          Honorius          141          141          112
          Constantine III          1          5          2
          clipped, or partly                              
          clipped          684          751          1305
          
                    1405 or          1483          1983
                    1406                    
(miliarense)
(or 1406)
A discussion of the hoard by H. Mattingly, J.W.E. Pearce and T.D. Kendrick, and illustrations of some of the silver articles appeared in Antiquity, XI (1937), 39-45, pls. I-VI; cp. K.S. Painter in JBAA (3), XXVIII (1965), 1, 6, 7, 12f., 15; and in Ant. J., 52 (1972), 84-92, with photos. of silver ingots
In 1855/6, J. Gilmour sold the silver articles and 88 of the siliquae to the BM. The silver and 30 coins are in Dept. of Prehistoric and Romano-British Antiquities, and 58 of the coins in Dept. of Coins and Medals (BM Register of Antiquities and Coins, Aug. 1855, and Dec. 1856). Among the 58 coins there is one of Constantine III.
More recent studies of the Coleraine silver ingots (8, 2 stamped), other silver articles, and 31 sil., were by J.P.C. Kent and K.S. Painter, Wealth of the Roman World (1977), 125-7, nos. 200-30, photo. of silver bowl. For the silver coins, cp. Cathy E. King, in BNJ, 51 (1981), 6, 8, 11, 14, 16, 18f., giving nos. as 1506 sil., 1 half sil., 341 oz. of silver, c. 50% of coins clipped; also A.M. Burnett, in Britannia, XV (1984), 165f.
J.D. Bateson, in PRIA, 73 (1973), C 2, 42f., listed, with types, 21 sil. from Coleraine in Ulster Museum; cp. ibid., 63f.
M.W.C. Hassall, and R.S.O. Tomlin, in Britannia, XVII (1986), 453, have noted that "K.S. Painter has recently re-iterated support for the interpretation of Mattingly and Pearce that the second line of the stamp [on one of the silver ingots] should be expanded to cur(ator) missi (onum)".
